Title:
Compounding British Interests in Zanzibar: Accounting for Continuities between Sultanate
                                 and Protectorate
Abstract:
In the first decades of colonial rule, British imperial administrators abolished slavery
 in Zanzibar, but their attempts to persuade Arab landowners to embrace wage labor
 in the place of slave labor fell on deaf ears. The once-powerful Arab clove planters
 had lost much of their political influence over the course of the 19th century, and
 many were heavily in debt to Indian moneylenders. The development of this situation
 is vital to understanding how colonial policies were implemented and how Zanzibaris
 navigated the changes which occurred in the early colonial period. This thesis analyzes
 the current state of scholarship on Zanzibar's early colonial history, and argues
 that there has been a tendency for studies to rely too heavily on casting 1890 as
 a turning point, which has the effect of downplaying continuities between pre-colonial
 and early colonial processes of economic, political, and social change. I advocate
 for a rethinking of temporal boundaries in future research on this subject, and I
 examine two processes, the slave trade and the British exploitation of Indian merchants,
 which demonstrate the theoretical benefits that can be derived from crossing the imagined
 border between the pre-colonial and colonial eras.

Title: The 'Red Line' Of Journalism: Shifting Visions Of The Media In The UAE
Abstract:
This project focuses on the gap between the vision of journalism in the UAE and the
 position of the press in practice. The first two chapters piece together a history
 of journalism in the country alongside a theoretical discussion of the role and responsibilities
 of the press in society. This is followed by an examination of the UAE's canon of
 media law and a news analysis of national newspapers. Despite a push to foster journalism
 in the country, the legal framework has not yet caught up with the purported vision
 of the press. This dichotomy of informal promises on the one hand and the formal legal
 canon on the other is one of the biggest challenges the press currently faces in the
 UAE. This creates uncertainty in the newsroom, ultimately leading to an inclination
 towards self-censorship when reporting sensitive issues because of a fear of crossing
 the 'red line' of journalism.

Title:
War of Words: How UAE Think Tanks Use War On Terrorism Discourse To Produce Knowledge
                                 And Promote Policy
Abstract:
This project uses discourse analysis of the terrorism literature of four UAE think
 tanks--Al Mesbar Center for Studies and Research, the Emirates Center for Strategic
 Studies and Research, TRENDS Research & Advisory, and Hedayah--to examine how think
 tanks in the UAE use the discourse of the war on terrorism in their policy research.
 It found that UAE think tanks mimic and adapt various forms and stages of the American
 discourse on the war on terrorism.

Title:
"The Lighter Our Task, The Heavier Our Burden" An Ethnography Of Political Dissidence
                                 Among Punks And Anarchists In Indonesia
Abstract:
Punk and anarchism, as lived practices that espouse anti-authoritarianism and prefigurative
 politics as their guiding principles, share a close affinity. Yet, the political value
 of punk has tended to be overlooked in favor of the punk "identity." This paper considers
 the overlapping politics of anarchists and punks in Yogyakarta, Indonesia, through
 ethnographic description of the everyday practice of political dissidence. I approach
 punk from an anarchist point of view, analysing it as an expression of prefigurative
 politics. Drawing upon fieldwork with members of a newly formed anarchist website,
 anarkis.org, and a punk squat in the north of the city, I show how political dissidents
 in Indonesia are fostering connections to global punk and anarchist movements through
 their everyday lives. I contend that punks play an important role in the embodiment
 of anarchism as a political way of being, while revealing the contours and complexities
 of radical political movements in Indonesia.

Title: Constructing an Enemy: Representations of the Middle East and Islam in U
Abstract:
My project investigates the dominant portrayals of Arabs and Muslims in history textbooks
 in the United States. Specifically, my study concludes that world history textbooks
 perpetuate the notion of a "rise and fall" of the Middle East and the Islamic faith
 and present Arabs and Muslims as antithetical to American values. My research further
 seeks to determine why these representations came about. In other words, what political,
 economic, and social forces have influenced the negative portrayals we see in American
 textbooks? I have found that these representations are in part due to a rise of conservative
 voices in educational curricular development since the 1980s that has created an education
 system that narrowly defines the American nation by its white, Christian roots and
 seeks to preserve the notion of American exceptionalism.

Title:
"A New Paradigm" for Syrian Refugees?: Development, Displacement Management and (Dis-)Empowerment
                                 in Jordan
Abstract:
This paper examines the extent to which development planning can provide solutions
 to protracted displacement crises by looking at the case of the "Jordan Compact,"
 a multi-stakeholder policy agreement that promised to turn the Syrian "refugee crisis"
 in Jordan into a "development opportunity." Drawing on fieldwork conducted in Jordan
 over the summer of 2018, I argue that the Jordan Compact failed to reach target outcomes
 due to a number of structural implementation challenges, including policy decontextualization
 and a competitive development architecture. In terms of the empowerment of Syrian
 refugees, however, the failure of the Jordan Compact was not so much a question of
 flawed implementation as it was of the "anti-politics" of development-based refugee
 policy. Syrians in Jordan do not just suffer from "underdevelopment," but also from
 a weak protection regime that circumvents the question of durable solutions and facilitates
 exploitation, discrimination, and abuse. In this way, a critique of the Jordan Compact
 should first and foremost highlight the political failure of the compact to strengthen
 refugee protection and offer a durable, long-term solution to the refugee crisis.

Title: Perceptions and Practices of Emirati visitors at Louvre Abu Dhabi
Abstract:
This research studies Louvre Abu Dhabi and the "Roads of Arabia" exhibition, its role
 in nation-building and UAE branding, and its reception by the local population. Firstly,
 I examine the museum's reconciliation of local and universal heritage, the UAE nation-building
 and branding. Secondly, I study Emiratis' reception of such big Western-style museum
 projects. I argue that Louvre Abu Dhabi brand becomes regionalized and appropriated
 for the UAE nation-branding and regional diplomacy. At the same time, I demonstrate
 that Emiratis, despite appreciation of the universal narrative, view the museum primarily
 as a branding project and a tourist-oriented establishment, disapproving of its emphasis
 on the Western culture and insufficient reach out to the local population. Hence,
 Emiratis desire bigger representation of the local heritage at Louvre, seeing it as
 worthy of being part of the universal narrative. In addition, I argue that Louvre
 Abu Dhabi, apart from mitigating the nation-building and branding contradictions,
 gives a way for a young educated upper- and middle-class Emiratis to practice and
 express their elitist cultural identity in contradistinction to the older, less educated,
 and religiously conservative Emiratis.

Title: LGBT+-Activism in Tunisia: Brokering Progressive Politics Independently
Abstract:
Based on two fieldwork trips and extensive interviewing, this capstone looks broadly
 at how LGBT+-activist organizations function in the political context that is contemporary
 Tunisia. The capstone consists of four main chapters, each contributing separately
 to the existing literature on the topic, but also coming together as a whole. The
 first chapter is a historical account of LGBT+-activism in Tunisia, identifying important
 periods and ruptures. The second chapter is a contemporary mapping of the Tunisian
 LGBT+-activist community, focused on organizations' differences, interplay and conflicts.
 The third chapter argues that Tunisian LGBT+-activists are doing a good job at navigating
 complex political structures to their benefit and also details the concrete work being
 carried out. The final chapter argues that if Tunisian LGBT+-activists continue to
 self-evaluate and improve their ability to assert influence, they have a unique chance
 to become brokers of broad political alliances over progressive social policies. This
 is in part due to the fact that LGBT+-rights are not a politically polarizing issue
 and in part because the organizations are not tainted by affiliations with the Ben
 Ali dictatorship.

Title:
Never كافي: Understanding Emirati Youth Subculture development in Abu Dhabi Specialty
                                 Cafes
Abstract:
With the increased number of specialty cafes in Abu Dhabi, Emirati youth have appropriated
 cafes as a space of sociability. Through field interviews and ethnographic research,
 this paper investigates how the influx of specialty cafes has developed the practice
 of sociability between young Emiratis, and how these spaces of sociability affect
 their modes of identification. I argue that Abu Dhabi youth transform specialty cafes
 into a young people's place that is socially acceptable, while encouraging them to
 expand their social circle beyond their family. By doing so, they not only create
 a subculture inside this social space but also reconstruct social norms to fit the
 category of the youth. I discuss the themes of anonymity, privacy, gender hierarchy
 and the performance of identity. Just like the title indicates, there is "never enough"
 layers and information on how cafes can be understood in Abu Dhabi.

Title: Aesthetic Assertion: Taste-Making at the Sharjah Biennial
Abstract:
Art has long served as a platform for cultural exploration, representation, and exchange,
 particularly in the space of international art fairs and biennials (Althuser 2008;
 Kirshenblatt-Gimblatt 2007). From souqs and Kalba Nature Reserve to canopied saris
 and dancing chess pieces, the Sharjah Biennial, the first art biennial in the Arabian
 Peninsula, takes visitors on a physical trip through Sharjah and an ideological journey
 through global contemporary artistic forms and themes. How does the Sharjah Biennial's
 juxtaposition of local traditions and internationally relevant concerns shape local
 aesthetic tastes? How do spatial and aesthetic discourses affect these tastes? This
 capstone paper investigates the effect of these discourses, grounded in local historical
 narratives, on the creation of aesthetic preferences. With this research, I challenge
 the hegemonic rhetoric on modernization and identity retro-formation in Gulf art scenes
 by arguing that the Sharjah Biennial draws on local histories to shape its future.
 I fill a gap in contemporary art and biennial literature by offering the first academic
 paper on the Sharjah Biennial and by shedding light on the roles of art events in
 the shaping of local aesthetics, contributing to a wider understanding of contemporary
 Gulf cultures.

Title:
Kafala and Binding are Synonyms: A Consequence of Capitalist Class Formation in Ethnic
                                 Regimes in the United Arab Emirates and Israel
Abstract:
This capstone questions the lack of nuance present in the critiques aimed at the kafala
 system I observed as a student in Abu Dhabi, which was highlighted during my time
 in Israel, which has a remarkably similar binding system. Unsatisfied by reports that
 dismissed the kafala as a product of unique Gulf historical or cultural factors, I
 conducted a comparative historical study of Israel and the United Arab Emirates to
 determine what forces led to the creation of these privatized visa sponsorship systems.
 I conclude that universal forces behind capitalist class formation in these ethnic
 regimes led to the creation of their contemporary labor migration regimes; this is
 further reinforced by their different scales of labor migration population, which
 speaks to the longevity of their respective labor migration regime. This capstone
 compiles labor migration histories of Israel and the United Arab Emirates, and establishes
 one of the few robust comparisons of these two countries.

Title:
Ideologies of Persuasion: an Examination of the Political Rhetoric of Gamal Abdel
                                 Nasser in Egyptian and International Media, 1958-1965
Abstract:
The goal of this capstone is to use a case study of Nasser's Egypt to examine how
 governments use the media for political persuasion. Using speeches broadcast over
 Radio Cairo and interviews given to foreign media outlets by President Nasser himself,
 the study examines the language, subject matter, and rhetorical strategies employed
 to persuade the audience to support him and his government. Additionally, the study
 provides an analysis of historical context, popular discourse, and intended audience
 to provide a better understanding of the strategic persuasive choices made by the
 government, as well as an analysis of the nature and the role of ideology in Nasser's
 appeals. Finally this dissertation uses this evidence to provide a characterization
 of Nasser himself as a politician, orator, and key figure in the development of political
 mass media in the Middle East.

Title:
One for One and All for Themselves: The Role of Individual Emirates' Considerations
                                 in the Formulation of Emirati Foreign Policy
Abstract:
Analysts and scholars have frequently framed Emirati foreign policy formation as a
 highly centralized story, where political interests and sub-national considerations
 play little or no significant role. This narrative has traditionally depicted Emirati
 foreign policy formation as being the sole creation of the capital and wealthiest
 emirate, unimpeded by the considerations of the other six emirates. This capstone
 seeks to problematize this narrative as overly simplistic and incomplete. Through
 investigation into the history and current dynamics surrounding UAE foreign policy
 formation, this capstone highlights the numerous considerations that affect Emirati
 foreign policy. It does this by examining three cases: Emirati policy towards Islamism,
 towards Iran, and Emirati foreign economic policy. Under Sheikh Zayed al-Nahyan, each
 emirate had limited freedom to formulate foreign policy concerning other states. Since
 Sheikh Zayed's passing, his son and the de-facto leader of the UAE, Sheikh Mohamed
 bin Zayed al-Nahyan, has worked to centralize the federal government under himself.
 Understanding Emirati foreign policy as more than just driven by Abu Dhabi is important
 for any policymaker or academic whose work relates to the UAE.

Title:
Bridging the Gap between Expectation and Reality: Urban Planning and the Public Bus
                                 System in Abu Dhabi
Abstract:
This paper analyzes Abu Dhabi government's initial goals of establishing the public
 bus system, the efficiency of the currently implemented bus system, and real users'
 experiences and social meanings of public transport in Abu Dhabi. While Abu Dhabi
 Department of Transport (DoT) constructed the urban transportation system to facilitate
 economic activities and comply to the idealized version of modernity, the public buses
 are evaluated to be inefficient and reinforce social stratification, further creating
 social isolation and sense of unbelonging. Moreover, the government's implementation
 of the transport system seems inefficient and people find strategic ways to navigate
 the city that challenge or even subvert the intentions of the DoT. Therefore, this
 paper argues that state-led urban planning and goals often differ from the actual
 implementation and utilization by residents, a gap commonly found in processes and
 outcomes of urban planning and transport infrastructure on a global level.

Title: Bina'a Al Bee'ah Al Mahalee'yah Al Fen'nee'yah (The Building of the Local Art Community)
Abstract:
My capstone project seeks to address the issue of introducing the museum experience
 to a generation of children and parents who are relatively new to the museum culture.
 Abu Dhabi's biggest legacy in the realm of the arts may be the introduction of innovative
 museums like the Louvre Abu Dhabi (2015), the Norman Foster designed Zayed National
 Museum (2016), and the Guggenheim Abu Dhabi (2017). However, prior to their public
 openings a need exists to expose the general community to "museum culture." To address
 that process, I have completed working on an arts education initiative that focused
 on building a museum going society. I have worked in collaboration with the Abu Dhabi
 Tourism and Cultural Authority and Abu Dhabi Education Council on this project and
 I have developed and conducted workshops with private and international schools in
 the emirate for 150 students. The works produced during these workshops were exhibited
 from May 4th, 2014 until May 25th, 2014 at the Manarat Al Saadiyat.

Title:
The Not-So-New Kid: The Changing Relationship to National Representation in the National
                                 Pavilion of the United Arab Emirates at the Venice Biennale, 2009-2013
Abstract:
This paper explores the brief history of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) at the Venice
 Biennale. It addresses the recent and rapid development of the UAE's cultural infrastructure
 and the history and significance of the Venice Biennale art fair. Due to its continued
 use of national pavilions, the Venice Biennale acts as a space in which art is presented
 within a narrative of national identity and representation. However, in recent years
 many countries have shown pavilions that question or reject the nation-based format.
 In its time at the Venice Biennale the UAE Pavilion has demonstrated a shift away
 from overt and largely promotional national representation, in turn towards a critical
 engagement with the country's history and development, and finally towards an examination
 of nationhood itself. The alignment of this transformation with prevalent Biennale
 trends may imply, particularly within the context of the Venice Biennale, a greater
 appreciation for and emphasis on art on the part of the UAE.

Title: D-WR
Abstract:
D-WR encompasses the globe. Sourced from an international community, the project depicts
 events that punctuate four years of global travels. The events reveal themselves through
 visual translation into several thousand "reactions", that is, images, movements,
 and the like painted, drawn, or etched into the canvas in their appropriate geographical
 positions. Pictures taken over the duration of the paintings' creation record each
 instance, frame by frame, into a condensed animation. Both the canvas and the animation,
 shown side by side, serve to answer questions about both the formation and experience
 of cultural memory, by revealing in the absolute terms of geography the indeterminate
 movement of human recollection. They serve, in particular, for the community whose
 movements and inputs inspired and informed the work, to reveal a collection of memories,
 and those memories' power to shape worldviews when shared.

Title: Special Identity
Abstract:
Special Identity is a project to develop and implement a corporate identity for the
 Ability Center, a local school for students with special needs. By working with the
 students, faculty, and caregivers, I created a narrative, visual identity, and set
 of materials that reflects the Ability Center's particular strengths and offerings
 as a place of enabling community. The brand gives the Ability Center the agency to
 define their own identity and engage supporters, future students, and the community
 of Abu Dhabi. Please visit www.adabilitycenter.org to learn more about the Ability
 Center.

Title: Reencuentros
Abstract:
Reencuentros is a webpage that displays the lives of three Salvadorian visual artists
 that worked during the Civil War and created an active art scene in El Salvador.

Title: Collision
Abstract:
I was driven to create the sculptural series Collision due to the psychological shift
 I experienced once I began driving. Suddenly I was forced to see and react to every
 stimulus. I became overwhelmed by what was out of my control and what surrounded me.
 In order to regain control, I created objects that attempted to negotiate this fear.
 Collision is a series of aluminum sculptures created through a cathartic performance
 that attempts to reconcile my fear of experiencing road traffic trauma. Collision
 negotiates the opposing forces and the promise of survival beyond trauma.

Title: Topography of a Parallel Universe
Abstract:
This project is an investigation of in-between areas as places of temporary habitation
 to distinguish the idea of "being-in" from the concept of "insideness". I have chosen
 the state of madness as a ground for exploring a mental oscillation between counterparts
 within a mirrored space, created by alienating the consciousness from the self, thereby
 individualizing the reflection from the reflected. I attempt to trace and illustrate
 the topography of this mental state from history surrounding the ship of fools, existential
 theories, Literature, and my personal experience through the creation and curation
 of an exhibition.

Title:
A Feast for the Eyes: Pictorial Conspicuous Consumption in the Cornucopia of Food,
                                 Flora, and Fauna of 17th-century Dutch Still Life
Abstract:
During the 17th century, the artistic genre of Dutch still life can be divided into
 two distinct trends. The first half of the 17th century is characterized by a monochromatic
 trend, using restrained colors and subject matter due to an economic slump and Calvinist
 ideology. During second half of the 17th century, due to trade and Dutch colonialism,
 rare goods and luxurious commodities pour into the Netherlands, and become objects
 of admiration and subjects of the pronkstillleven genre (show-off still life). With
 this surplus of wealth, a consumerist attitude is born instilling an urge to conspicuously
 display one's wealth. I analyze the contrast between the two trends and discuss how
 and why this change took place. Through the analysis of four works of still life,
 comparisons and contrasts will be drawn that mark these opposing artistic trends.

Title: ДОМА | DOMA
Abstract:
Home. This words means many things to people around the world. A bed at a parent's
 house, a particular street, or neighbourhood, or even a smell can be associated with
 home. The project Home Feeling investigates what happens with the meaning of home
 in cosmopolitan settings. The writing describes the stages of the project starting
 from the origins and inspirations to the process, challenges that were faced during
 different stages.It is explained how through painting, sculpture and installation, the artist expressed
 the feeling of home, which, in a globalised world, turned into a mixture of connectivity
 to places, people and memories.The paper is concluded by the explanation of how the project turned out to be about
 identification, home, and feelings. It is discussed how the difficulties and challenges
 helped to develop the project, and which conclusions were made from a year-long process
 of its realisation.

Title: Vaselisa the Lovely: Russian Fairytales Revisited
Abstract:
This paper goes through a chronological documentation of my capstone project, Psychogeographica.
 This is a yearlong research project that delves into my personal experience of Abu
 Dhabi, and particularly how this experience involved me feeling alienated by the space
 of the city, but not knowing exactly why this reaction had occurred. I recognize that
 this was because I felt no semblance of time passing – there was no evidence of decomposition
 or aging within the buildings, streets, sense of place and consequently within myself
 as I existed within the city. As such, the paper follows the process that led to my
 collecting found objects and sourced objects in order to create artworks that attempt
 to reveal the existence of time in Abu Dhabi. The reader is implicated in the mental
 processes that I faced whilst involved in this yearlong endeavor. There is also an
 assumption that the reader has encountered the work either in person or through images
 (which will accompany the archive).

Title: Psychogeographica
Abstract:
This paper goes through a chronological documentation of my capstone project, Psychogeographica.
 This is a yearlong research project that delves into my personal experience of Abu
 Dhabi, and particularly how this experience involved me feeling alienated by the space
 of the city, but not knowing exactly why this reaction had occurred. I recognize that
 this was because I felt no semblance of time passing – there was no evidence of decomposition
 or aging within the buildings, streets, sense of place and consequently within myself
 as I existed within the city. As such, the paper follows the process that led to my
 collecting found objects and sourced objects in order to create artworks that attempt
 to reveal the existence of time in Abu Dhabi. The reader is implicated in the mental
 processes that I faced whilst involved in this yearlong endeavor. There is also an
 assumption that the reader has encountered the work either in person or through images
 (which will accompany the archive).

Title: PROBE: an investigation of contemporary institutional critique
Abstract:
"Institutional critique" is a term used to describe art that is reflective about its
 positions in institutions and systems within the art world. Institutional critique
 typically takes the practices that allow art to be exhibited, circulated, exchanged,
 and sold as the subject of the artwork. This kind of artwork encourages the viewer
 to reflect on the idea of "the institution" by addressing it both directly and indirectly.
 
 This exhibition explores three contemporary examples of artists engaging in institutional
 critique and considers their artwork in relationship to one another, in an historical
 framework. The exhibition investigates the methods used by artists to identify and
 address different institutions. This exhibition is a curatorial Capstone project.
 As a student project, it lies outside the typical framework of "the art institution."
 Still, the university can be understood as a cultural institution. Thus this project
 is, ultimately, an experiment in curating institutional critique from within an institution.

Title: Ramadan Recipes: Ten Ideas For Iftar Meals
Abstract:
A 68-page full color book featuring illustrations and photographs, Ramadan Recipes
 proposes ten iftar recipes to break the fast for each day of Ramadan. Every recipe
 in the book was passed on to the author through interviews with Muslim families living
 in the UAE. Using Ramadan as a unifying element, the book weaves together stories
 for each dish, including not only its history but also memories associated with the
 meal as shared by the Muslim families. Ramadan Recipes celebrates the cultural diversity
 of Abu Dhabi and explores the heart of the Islamic faith. Most importantly, the book
 seeks to teach readers about the value of food and community, and encourages them
 to cook and gather around the dining table with their friends and families. Through
 recipes and stories, Ramadan Recipes presents food as a giver of life, a gem of family
 tradition, and a place of gathering.

Title: Rethinking the East/West Binary: Transcultural Porcelain, 16th-21st Century
Abstract:
How does the binary of East and West affect the history, analysis and display of transcultural
 works of art? More particularly, how does the binary affect the analysis of porcelain,
 a medium that emerged from trade exchange and has been widely appropriated to suit
 various cultural tastes? Through three case studies of transcultural dialogues embedded
 in porcelain, I reveal the shortcomings of polarizing eastern and western influences
 and provide alternative theoretical frameworks for studying cross-cultural exchange.
 The first exchange, a Jingdezhen bottle gilded in London in 1585, will be defined
 through its framing abilities. The second, a Sèvres chinoiserie basin from c.1790,
 will be understood through its mimetic faculty. The third, a Jingdezhen vase commissioned
 by Lebanese artist Raed Yassin in 2012, will be analyzed through its simulation processes.
 I argue that the East/West binary is the product of, rather than the process of, transcultural
 exchanges in global art practices.

Title: points of potential
Abstract:
points of potential is an installation work exploring the state of simultaneously
 knowing and being unable to know in the context of denied spaces. Reinforcing how
 queer spaces subvert hegemony, the installation captures the processes of unbeing
 and unbecoming. Reflecting on current spaces and their elsewheres, a denied space
 is being looked through textual and sound installation(s). By exploring territories
 of occupation, points of potential is asking us to reconsider our own occupations
 and find the potential to open up new spaces.

Title: Wings of Resistance
Abstract:
Wings of Resistance is an Escape the Room-inspired installation piece. It consists
 of two parallel escape rooms, meant to be experienced by two teams of 3-4 people each.
 The teams are led blindfolded to the rooms, where they must find clues and solve puzzles
 in order to find their reward and successfully complete the game. Although each team
 is in their own room and may believe they are the only ones taking part on the experience,
 eventually they unlock a video feed that connects them to the parallel room and the
 second team. Wings of Resistance is not only a test of wit, bit also of trust and
 cooperation. Some puzzles in the rooms require the exchange of information between
 teams, leading to the final reward. Before the final puzzle, the teams are presented
 with Prisoner's Dilemma-like scenario: finish the game alone at the cost of the other
 team, or trust them and cooperate. However, this is also a test, as betrayal leads
 to instant disqualification - the only way to succeed is through cooperation. Successful
 teams are awarded a pin for them to remember the experience.

Title: Modern Ghosts
Abstract:
The Exhibition "Modern Ghosts" seeks to explore the absence islamophobia creates,
 an absence that only helps strengthen islamophobic beliefs. Being absent refers to
 the way many Muslims tend to shrink back into themselves out of fear. We shrink into
 ourselves after being bombarded with misconceptions. It is an exhausted gesture, a
 protective stance against the backlash and prejudice that our beliefs and ways of
 life
 continuously face. We hide or become silent. We hide out of fear. We hide out of being
 tired. We hide so as not to stand out. We hide to melt into the midst of society.

Title: Between
Abstract:
Between is an exhibition of mixed media works exploring the themes of memory and location,
 as well as the playfulness and joy of working with color, form and materiality. Consisting
 of both narrative and abstract work, a dialogue is created between past and present.
 From drawing upon childhood memories in Tennessee to experimenting with systems of
 color, the artist uses textures, gestures, and fragments translating them across different
 materials. It is an exploration of identity of one's self and as an artist, while
 seeking to understand the 'betweenness' amidst it all. Creating connections, playing
 with language and drawing upon the process.

Title: Wiswas
Abstract:
Wiswas (وسواس) is an Arabic term that roughly translates to reoccurring thoughts,
 notions, or instinctive drives, that consume a person's subconscious. Wiswas is a
 force that evokes fear, suspicion, and unnecessary anxiety. In this installation,
 I create an environment that both reflects and conjures emotional responses with relation
 to Wiswas. Looming figurative forms inhabit the gallery and abstract expressions explode
 across canvases representing my obsessive paranoias.

Title: Nafseeya
Abstract:
My capstone questions, confronts and explores the stigma of mental illness in the
 Middle East and the local region.

Title: Unrealized to Levitate
Abstract:
I hope to build a poetics of floating from the objects that surround a centerpiece,
 one that is incomplete and unrealized. If there is anything I could sway the audience
 with words, the works convey a feeling embedded in failure, a source of nostalgia
 and desolation. But audience is one who sees, and few hear the whispers of disquiet.
 Can someone be blind and alone? A feast of silent gathering, a subliminal space of
 unrealized dreams, and an agora with figures suspended between the sky and earth—these
 are a few modes of expression to what constitute the whole. A multimedia installation,
 the composites yearn for meaning in what is a rubbish heap.

Title: Manthiram, A Graphic Novel
Abstract:
Manthiram is a series of interconnected vignettes of the Mannar pearl fisheries off
 the coast of Sri Lanka. This graphic novel explores humanity's enchantment with the
 sea and its contents, and the charms and rituals with which we attempt to commune
 with it.

Title: BRAVADO
Abstract:
The art exhibition Bravado studies a series of the ancient Greek statues and recreates
 them through large-scale charcoal drawings. The pieces deconstruct the ideal of male
 beauty depicted by the original statues--they emulate the graceful figures while also
 degrading and complicating their forms using abstraction techniques and artistic interventions.

Title: Sobremesas
Abstract:
In Spanish, "sobremesa" refers to the lingering time during which people remain together
 at the table after a meal has ended. My exhibit contains ephemeral moments spent with
 people in the UAE, embodied in paintings and screen prints. It aims to give these
 temporary moments a chance to linger in permanent visual representations. A main source
 of stylistic and conceptual inspiration is Impressionist painting, which in part aimed
 to capture impressions of transient moments of light and color.

Title: Idle Contortions
Abstract:
Idle Contortions is a self-portrait exhibition portraying an almost comedic take on
 how the physical body manifests thoughts and emotions. By re-creating versions of
 myself in deceptively calm contortionist positions, I am reflecting on a wide-range
 of internal conflicts. I create self-portraits that speak to my personal thoughts,
 and thus I believe I am speaking to the struggles of many other people across the
 world, who are just as conflicted and reserved as me.

Title: The Portrayal of Vincent Van Gogh's Artwork Through Cinema
Abstract:
Van Gogh lives, just like Elvis. He lives both in popular culture and high art. The
 number of films and television series featuring Vincent van Gogh (1853¬–1890) as a
 character has long since exceeded one hundred. This thesis questions the difference
 of seeing reproductions of his paintings on screen rather than the originals in museums
 or reproductions in books or online. The narrative and accessibility of film medium
 allows a wider audience to see his paintings in places where his paintings have not
 been previously exhibited. While translating painted images to the filmic medium cannot
 reproduce the experience of seeing the originals, van Gogh continues to entice filmmakers
 from different generations to render different stories about van Gogh and his art
 on screen. By examining the first major Hollywood film on the artist, Lust for Life
 (1956), and later Vincent and Theo (1990), and the first fully painted animated film
 Loving Vincent (2017), I argue how over time technological differences allowed filmmakers
 to shed new light on the van Gogh myth and his artwork by using film as a means for
 reaching different audiences.

Title: Shik-gu: The People Who Eat Together
Abstract:
Shik-gu: The People Who Eat Together is a socially engaged art project and a platform
 for people of NYU Abu Dhabi to connect and provide company for one another through
 sharing a meal online. In two months, eight different students broadcasted their
 dinner live as @eating_at_nyuad on Instagram.With menus ranging from ramen to KFC
 to half a gigantic watermelon, these students talked about long distance, insecurities,
 well-being, and body image in the company of their friends and family who followed
 the account and joined the livestream. This artwork responds to our community's
 concerns and offers a platform for conversations, at once intimate and public, that
 otherwise might remain unexpressed.It explores the vulnerability of putting ourselves
 online in a meaningful way, of mitigating the loneliness that is amplified by eating
 on one's own. It connects us to others also participating in the livestream and brings
 us together as a temporary "family."

Title: The Cultural Foundation in Abu Dhabi, 1981-2008
Abstract:
If you were to ask any person who grew up in Abu Dhabi in the 1980s or 1990s, how
 they spent their free time, they most probably will mention their trips to the Cultural
 Foundation (CF). While there were other cultural centers in the United Arab Emirates
 (UAE), none compared to the CF. Located in the heart of the city, it attracted people
 from all over Abu Dhabi and other Emirates because of its reputation as a nexus for
 writers and artists. The CF played a significant role in the development of Abu Dhabi's
 art and culture ecosystem. Most importantly, it had sustained engagement with its
 surrounding community and activated a space for all to be a part of. To this day,
 many have described the CF as their second home where they attended lectures, workshops,
 poetry nights, and movie screenings.This paper examines the CF's first active period
 1981-2008 and its relationship with the Abu Dhabi's community. The three main questions
 addressed in this paper are: Why was the CF so popular amongst the community? How
 was that achieved and what can be learned from that experience?

Title: Between the three of us: A Visual Arts Virtual Capstone Exhibition
Abstract: Between the three of us chronicles my narrative within my family, culture, and stereotypes.

Title: Go Back to Sleep
Abstract:
Go Back to Sleep is a bedtime story, for an overwhelmed young adult. In a series of
 colorful digital illustrations, the project follows me through the course of the night,
 weaving between thoughts inside my head over the past few months. The picture book
 explores the relationship between the personal and the collective – self, family,
 friends, university, country, generation – as an intersection of girl and world through
 little (and big), disconnected musings.

Title: The City of Athem
Abstract:
The City of Athem is a combination of photography, graphic design, writing and some
 line-based sketches, all depicting an imaginary city. It stands outside of time and
 reality. The chapters do not follow any specific linearity. Some talk about alternate
 pasts, others talk about hopeful futures, while others still bear a heavier reference
 to the two neighboring cities that inspired this work. Names, architecture and urban
 planning all play a large role, if sometimes subtle. The names are taken from Arabic
 and intentionally butchered in their transliteration to play off an ambiguity that
 often arises during that process. Aside from that I will not provide further hints
 about the meaning of any of the names, that's a mystery for you to figure out.

Title: Desi
Abstract:
Desi is a photo series on the South Asian community in Abu Dhabi. Making up the largest
 demographic of the country, South Asians are significant to the culture and social
 landscape of the city and the country. This project explores their impact on Abu Dhabi
 as well as their everyday realities by observing and capturing the lives lived and
 the spaces occupied.

Title:
The Past is Present: The Collection and Exhibition of Modern and Contemporary Egyptian
                                 Art at the British Museum
Abstract:
The world's interest in modern and contemporary art from WANA (West Asia and North
 Africa) regions is increasing: the art market is growing, and many major museums—including
 the British Museum and the Met, as well as the Victoria and Albert Museum and Tate
 Modern—have recently hired curators who specialize in modern and contemporary works
 from the WANA regions. My capstone project analyzes the changing perception and reception
 of modern and contemporary art from the WANA region over the last thirty years, with
 a focus on the collecting and display of these works in the British Museum. My research
 investigates the British Museum's collection strategies and exhibition patterns for
 modern and contemporary art from the WANA regions, with a special emphasis on works
 created in Egypt. This paper will trace this recent history and provide a broader
 historical context for this shift in the curation, collection and exhibition of modern
 and contemporary Egyptian art at the British Museum.

Title: Sada
Abstract:
For my senior project at NYU I designed and manufactured a high-fidelity speaker with
 the goal of demonstrating that craftsmanship & heritage in the UAE can be utilized
 to create modern luxury products that are able to elegantly embody and integrate the
 stories and traditions of the past. To achieve this objective, I drew inspiration
 from the traditional craft of Dhow (ship) building in the UAE and Gulf region.

Title: Tambapanni
Abstract:
For my undergraduate thesis, I am creating a card deck that sources from Sri Lankan
 visual imagery as a way of reclaiming colonial erasure. Though there are many facets
 of colonialism, I am focusing on how day to day objects define our post-colonial existence.
 For example, Sri Lankans often wear jeans and T-shirts, even though our sarongs and
 kurtas are more appropriate for tropical weather. We design our billboards and store
 signs in English, despite Sinhala and Tamil being more common languages. It is this
 ubiquitous occurrence, the things that we do not think twice about, that define our
 colonial legacy. Card decks and card games are other aspects of this ubiquity. The
 standard card deck references French royalty, textiles, and patterns, and though we
 play card games frequently in our culture, we are using a seemingly irrelevant set
 of cards. When we look at them, they do not reference our own rich, complex, and diverse
 history. I aim to change that.

Title: Astral
Abstract:
'astral' conveys the relationship between artist flow and the spiritual and creative
 process. Artist flow is not ignoring the realities of the world, but rather, the ability
 to use one's being and experiences to enter a meditative space. Subsequently, work
 is born from an unexplored place within the self. 'astral' consists of a series of
 prints, paintings, ceramics and other three-dimensional work that embody the discovery
 of new universes within one's artistic and spiritual self. Personally, creating art
 is a spiritual experience which is influenced by an interest in witchcraft. The series
 of work also explores what it means to navigate the world in the female body, and
 both the pleasure and pain it endures — self-inflicted or otherwise. The creative
 process leads to psychedelic effects in the works, which can only be described as
 a result of artist flow. 'astral' is, as such, inspired by the intrinsic, ethereal
 connection each of us has to the universe; art is simply a means to understand it.

Author(s): Al Hosani, Al Reem Ahmed Hussain Ali
Title: Of Fragments
Abstract:
'Of Fragments' is a series of mixed media works that explore the themes of fragility
 and complexity. These artworks probe how we give meaning to embodied experiences and
 explore the mental and physical power our bodies hold.

Title: Along the Way
Abstract:
The paintings and drawings created relates to the idea or emotion one expresses and
 feels when something unexpected happens: this unsought, unintended, and unexpected
 discovery that is fortunate. Through my artworks, I would welcome accidents. I am
 driven to create by the feelings attached to these serendipitous moments. How would
 one feel when they just won a lottery, meeting a childhood friend, or finding treasure?
 Our paths are aligned in a certain way. Whatever happens, was meant to happen. It
 is destined to occur.

Title: The Lens
Abstract:
What happens when a private space is placed into a public space? The notion of a Private
 space varies once its context differs. It can become a place of peace and serenity
 and can become a place of stress. The emotions that are being produced within that
 room are a result of multiple factors, one being the light the room is using, another
 is the color of the room. This project aims to explore the factor of lighting and
 color to display illustration in a private space, in an aim of provoking a peaceful
 feeling in the participant.

Title: This Website Dies
Abstract:
As the usage of the Internet becomes more invasive in every day life, people are increasingly
 building more Internet personas for themselves, building more lives, leading double,
 triple lives on various social networks. The accumulation of all that personal information,
 behavior, emotions, data, and visual imagery flocks and fills up spaces in servers
 everywhere. Yet since these data embodies people and rely on people to inhabit, maintain,
 and add to them, it was fascinating for me to explore the scenario when immense amounts
 of data is left uncared-for, will they continue to exist or disappear? will they live
 in some other form? will they ever get erased from data servers at all? And there
 is also the other side of the equation too: the scenario when people intentionally
 cut themselves off from this information architectures/personas/ that they have spent
 time and effort building. In short, my capstone project focuses on the mortality and
 immortality of digital data, in relation to human life.

Title:
Time is Out of Joint at La Galleria Nazionale: From the Historical to the Ahistorical
                                 Display
Abstract:
After renovation works, La Galleria Nazionale in Rome marked its reopening in 2016
 by rearranging the permanent collection in the exhibition Time is Out of Joint. Under
 the guidance of the new director, Cristiana Collu, the new display shuffles the artworks
 from different time periods drawn from the museum collection of art from the 19th
 to 21st century. The rehang questions previous displays based on linear art history
 and proposes an experiential encounter with the collection. Since the early 2000s,
 similar innovative curatorial strategies have been adopted by museums in Europe and
 elsewhere to address the role of institutions in society with consideration to visitor
 engagement. By using Time is Out of Joint as a case study, this paper aims to review
 the original vision of the "national museum" in Italy through the examination of the
 institutional history in relation to the new display of the permanent collection at
 the Galleria Nazionale. The analysis of the curatorial approach of Time is Out of
 Joint contributes to the wider discussion about the relationship between museums,
 displays, and history. At the same time, the paper will explore how the rehang engages
 with a new idea of the contemporary art museum.

Title: Spaces in Hyphen: Of Present-Absence and Absent-Presence
Abstract:
The Capstone research and project, entitled Spaces in Hyphen: Of Present-Absence and
 Absent-Presence, is a series of photographs that documents spaces around the NYU Abu
 Dhabi campus. With hints of human labor and activities featured in the compositions,
 the photographs communicate a human presence, without having people appearing in the
 frame. In particular, the man-made environment of Saadiyat Island is explored, highlighting
 the thresholds or ambiguities that delineate the natural versus artificial elements
 of a space. The documentation of these juxtapositions often appears ironic and incongruous
 to suggest the complexities of such heavy-handed interventions.

Title: Pixel (User Interface and User Experience Design)
Abstract:
Pixel (Pick + Sell) is an interactive high-fidelity mobile application prototype designed
 for female-identifying students on campus who wish to buy and sell secondhand products
 more conveniently and effectively online. Pixel transfers the popularity of consumer-to-consumer
 (C2C) commercial activities observed on "Female RoR" to a mobile platform. In the
 best aim to design a user-centered app, surveys, interviews, competitive analysis,
 heuristic evaluations, affinity mapping, and literature reviews were carried out to
 understand the users. The design process included creating personas, user journey
 maps, and task flows to specify user needs and requirements.

Title: Monstress
Abstract:
My capstone examines the case of the female monster through a series of paintings.
 The monstress is often depicted as transgressing from the narrow bounds of an idealized
 femininity, displaying a power that is threatening. They are commonly antagonists
 of the stories in which they feature and thus, serve as a warning, policing women
 who stray outside acceptable limits of female power, sexuality, or control. Despite
 this, there is a complexity in the space that the female monster occupies that is
 compelling. As monsters, women can have complicated emotions and rich internal lives.
 By centering a narrative on the female monster, I want to create space for deviations
 and nuance in models of femininity.

Title: To He - A Reflection on Vietnamese Identity, Culture, and Tradition
Abstract:
"To He" is a story about a brother and sister during wartime in Northern Vietnam (1954-75).
 The brother creates a new tò he, a traditional Vietnamese toy made from glutinous
 rice every day for his little sister, while their father is going to war. A core subject
 of the film is the author's reflection on the complex notion of identity and belonging,
 war loss, and globalization's reality.

Title:
The Currency of Chanoyu (茶の湯): Theorizing the Performative Aspects of the Japanese
                                 Tea Ceremony
Abstract:
Chanoyu (茶の湯) is the highly aesthetic and ritualized practice of preparing powdered
 green tea, or matcha, in the Japanese tradition. This paper examines the aesthetic,
 philosophical, political and socio-economic aspects of the tea tradition from its
 origins to contemporary expressions. Under the influence of Shintō beliefs, Zen Buddhism,
 Daoist philosophy and Japanese aesthetics, the drinking of tea developed into "The
 Way of Tea" replete with disciplined rituals, a code of ethics, an aura of spirituality,
 requisite implements and sophisticated aesthetics. The tradition of chanoyu was fluid
 over time, shifting from the exclusive circles of the nobility, clergy and warrior
 elite to the interested populus. The merchants through tea trade were conduits for
 the dissemination of tea culture. This commercial component accounts for the spread
 of the tea cult from Japan across the world. This analysis explores how the Japanese
 tea ceremony or chanoyu tradition remained distinctive and coherent while flexible
 and responsive to change throughout its dynamic evolution. For this reason, I argue,
 "The Way of Tea" is a significant source of inspiration and creativity for contemporary
 artists and designers globally.

Title: Adam
Abstract: Major: Film and New MediaAbstract: Adam, a displaced man and a family lost in the midst of the Syrian conflict.

Title: Two Strangers Meet in a Bar
Abstract:
Major: Film and New MediaAbstract: An interactive short film that lets the audience guide the story of a chance
 encounter between a man and a woman, whose lives are mysteriously connected.

Title: Narrative of the Most Extraordinary and Distressing Excavation of Professor Ahab
Abstract:
Major: Film and New Media. Abstract: A lazy and unmotivated colonist on an off-world
 settlement is sent back to the desolate wasteland that is Earth on a daring and mysterious
 mission: to re-establish contact with a famed researcher who went missing there some
 time ago in search for a mythical whale skull.

Title: No More
Abstract:
Major: Film and New Media, EconomicsAbstract: The UAE has a very recent history. In such a short time it has incredibly
 developed and progressed. But often development and progress imply sacrifices. In
 case of the UAE it seems that it has sacrificed its history and identity. This short
 documentary seeks an answer to why the history of the UAE is being forgotten by its
 own people and why the Emirati identity is being diluted.

Title: This Place
Abstract:
Major: Film and New Media, TheaterAbstract: Paper documenting the creation of 'This Place' - a thirty minute performance
 exploring the LGBT experience in the UAE through the mix of documentary film and narrative
 theatre.

Title: Lost in Escapade
Abstract:
Major: Film and New Media, Economics. Abstract: "Lost in Escapade" is a short psychological
 drama with elements of magical realism about a Georgian couple, Sandro and Tina, who
 get lost in the desert of the Emirates and discover changes happening in their relationship.

Title: Aisha; Starstuff
Abstract:
Major: Film and New Media, Literature. Abstract: How to find purpose in life when
 death could come at any moment? How to reconcile the urge for solitude with the need
 for human connection? How to change? My capstone project is an exploration of these
 questions in two mediums: a short film titled "Aisha" and a short story cycle titled
 "Starstuff." In "Aisha," a man named Saeed is deeply affected by a brief encounter
 with a dying woman named Aisha. In "Starstuff," a soul is reincarnated nine times,
 experiences nine different aspects of humanity, and makes a final choice - life or
 death. She chooses life.

Title: Rescue
Abstract:
Major: Film and New MediaAbstract: Rescue is a short narrative film set immediately after a three-man spacecraft
 crash-lands on a desert planet. The film centers on Alex, a stranded astronaut who
 struggles to resolve the panicked events of the crash, and find meaning in his new
 situation. In order to prevent total isolation and loss of self, Alex must overcome
 his yearning for an unattainable past and his moral absolutes. The film's stark aesthetic
 construction emphasises Alex's psychological state and underscores his fear of loneliness
 and his grappling with past trauma. Forgiveness lies at the core of this film: Alex
 must learn to forgive his crewmates' actions before he can let go of the past.

Title: Closed Space
Abstract:
Major: Film and New MediaAbstract: Closed Space is a short film about a guide whose job is to lead human souls
 to the other side. When he meets yet another soul, we experience his internal struggles
 from doing this unique job.The film is an allegorical piece that portrays the state of disorientation generated
 by the dramatic political change after the USSR's breakdown and its impact on the
 individual psyche. It reflects the claustrophobic experience of entrapment between
 the old and new state: being nostalgic about the past while longing for a better future.

Title: Amnesia Subtitulada
Abstract:
Major: Film and New Media, TheatreAbstract: Amnesia Subtitulada, along with its accompanying exhibition Memoria Obstinada,
 mark the end of a three year cycle of work on the interaction of familial memory and
 familial bodies in the context of post-dictatorship Chile, developed in collaboration
 with Silvia Olego, Roberto Kozak, and Nathalie Kozak. This text works through the
 conception of the work, as well as its conceptual extrapolations in relation to light,
 family, and postmemory.

Title: Typing
Abstract:
Major: Film and New Media, Social Research and Public Policy. Abstract: Typing…SYRIA
 is a socio-artistic performance piece where any subscriber can witness a conversation
 between two Syrian characters unfold on WhatsApp for 30 days. Drawing from the vocabulary
 of a collage of news articles on Syrian refugees, the advertisement of this project
 echoes the international community attitudes towards refugees. In experimenting with
 appeals of exclusivity, intimacy, and hints of tragedy, Typing…SYRIA addresses questions
 of voyeurism, the ethics of witnessing, and the role of the international media's
 "gaze" towards the Syrian experience in light of the civil conflict. The performance
 also invokes prolonged exposure as well as social engagement, as subscribers document
 their emotional experience throughout the month by contributing screenshots of impactful
 moments of the conversation, alongside a short written commentary. At the end of
 the month, subscribers will be left with not only their own archive of the Syrian
 voices, but will also have access to the archive of other participants' experiences,
 comments, and reflections.

Title: Fair Trade
Abstract:
Major: Film and New MediaAbstract: 'Fair Trade' is a short narrative film that I produced and directed as part
 of my Capstone Project. The Capstone paper describes the process of making this film.

Title: Chipin
Abstract:
Major: Film and New Media. Abstract: chipin is a student-lead startup that uses crowd-sourcing
 as a mechanism to organize group orders to bring food variety from Abu Dhabi city,
 to the remote Saadiyat island campus.

Title: The Separation Defense Paper
Abstract:
The Separation is a short narrative film that complicates incorrect perceptions and representations
 – of gender, clothing, family, and ways of life – of Arabs and the Arab World in Western
 media by depicting their impacts and consequences. It is a story about a young Arab
 boy on his first day in a Western school, and his experience of being treated negatively
 by his new classmates. The narrative is an exploration of identity – particularly,
 children's – and how it is shaped by attitudes and mentalities about race, religion,
 and culture influenced largely by Western media. The Separation aims to raise, rather
 than answer, these questions: What are the assumptions about Arabs and the Arab World
 that are so familiar to children that they might not register as prejudice? When these
 assumptions influence and impact children and their behavior, what does this say about
 society? And, how can we then reverse these damaging effects?

Title: Unlearner Defense Paper
Abstract:
Inspired by true events, namely the 1972 exodus of Asian Ugandans ordered by Idi Amin,
 Unlearner attempts to comprehend the extent to which forced migration can damage families
 and individuals. The film identifies past and present conflicts of coexistence between
 ethnic Ugandans and Asian Ugandans. Although during the reign of Idi Amin, there was
 a major political exploitation of Indophobia, Unlearner unfolds socio-economic pressures
 that manifest contemporarily within the Ugandan society. Unlearner explores a young
 Ugandan man's existence when he is removed from this specific context. Arthur Makoli,
 moves to work in the UAE as a security guard. Arthur's journey allows him to meet
 his newly discovered half-sister who fled Uganda with her Indian mother during the
 exile. Despite trying to build an emotional attachment with Huda, he feels threatened
 by her and he truly believes that she would reject him as a brother. Throughout his
 time in Abu Dhabi, Arthur personifies a clash between the two groups.

Title: Sacrifice and Survival in Remnants of the Hive
Abstract:
After the apocalypse, 15 year-old Mina is faced with the role of caregiver as her
 grandfather's memory begins to deteriorate. By considering parallels between the behaviors
 of honeybees and humans, this short narrative film explores the distinction between
 love and obligation and the implications of sacrifice. It stars award-winning American
 artist, John Torreano, alongside British-Algerian actress, Farah Taleb, and was shot
 on location in Al Ain and Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.

Title: A Collector's BIG TIME
Abstract:
A Collector's BIG TIME is a short documentary film about Dr. Ahmed Al Khoori's attempt
 to preserve his sense of personal and collective identity by collecting numerous material
 artifacts of the Emirati provenance in his house-museum.

Title: Finding Nasseebi
Abstract:
A soul-searching, non-religious filmmaker sets out to make a documentary about the
 United Arab Emirates' Islamic hotline center, where scholars answer questions and
 guide people towards the right path according to the Quran. As a friendship blossoms
 with one of the scholars, the filmmaker's relationship with a Muslim boyfriend makes
 her question her beliefs and the integrity of her film. This self-reflexive documentary
 follows one woman's journey to understand Islam and to love, regardless of differences
 in faith.

Title: Dreaming Fish
Abstract:
A bride with a magical fish tattoo keeps the wedding guests waiting at the reception
 when she goes fishing with her father to a concealed lake. Alíz has to face the most
 painful memory in her life when her father vanishes. This short magical realist drama
 explores cyclical grief and how pain can recur at events when most unexpected.

Title: Longing for Ukraine: Oleksandr Dovzhenko's World War II documentary cinema
Abstract:
This Capstone investigates why Oleksandr Dovzhenko's love for his people was considered
 nationalism by the Soviet regime. Looking at The Battle for Our Soviet Ukraine (1943)
 and Victory on the Right Bank Ukraine (1944), I examine limitations to articulating
 Ukrainian national identity under Soviet rule and documentary film's ability to convey
 contested political histories. I ask whether it is possible to understand Dovzhenko
 as a Soviet director or also as a Ukrainian one, and to what extent this question
 remains political in the contemporary context of Russian imperialism. Due to censorship,
 Dovzhenko's expression of Ukrainian identity in these documentaries emphasizes Ukraine
 as distinct from other nations within the USSR, particularly Russia, in indirect ways
 that differ from strategies used by Ukrainian nationalist movements. My research builds
 on emerging scholarship on Ukrainian cinema that seeks to understand artistic practices
 suppressed by the Soviet regime and omitted by generations of scholars.

Title:
Restrained by Freedom: Perestroika Cinema as an Overlooked Transition from Soviet
                                 to Russian Filmmaking
Abstract:
This paper analyzes how political changes and artistic freedom during the Perestroika
 ("restructuring") period of 1985–1991 reflect a crucial transitional moment between
 Soviet and Russian cinema often dismissed as unimportant, especially the genre of
 chernukha, due to its low production values and sensational stories. The freedom from
 censorship that came with Perestroika often resulted in permissiveness in content
 that became destructive of State ideology and film industry, rather than constructive.
 At the same time, relaxed censorship allowed films that were never widely released,
 such as Andrei Tarkovsky's The Mirror / Зеркало (1974), to be screened in cinemas
 for the first time. By analyzing the style, main plot conflicts and character types
 in Perestroika films, I elucidate an overlooked moment of transition from Soviet to
 Russian society and cinema that was popular with audiences but considered a failure
 by critics.

Title: Inquieto
Abstract:
"Inquieto" is a directive to a musician to perform a certain passage in a restless,
 uneasy, or agitated manner. "Inquieto" also captures the spirit of this short narrative
 film that focuses on highly charged mother-daughter relationships. Nathalie, a chain-smoking
 woman, struggles to cope with her teenage daughter, who reluctantly prepares for a
 piano recital. When grandma pays them a visit, Nathalie finds herself sinking deeper
 into despair, all the while trying to keep the music flowing and a smile on her face.

Title: The Phantoms of Projection // Afterlife: an audiovisual performance
Abstract:
A joint Capstone in Film & New Media and Theater, this project combines research and
 audiovisual performance to investigate ways that light and projected images have been
 tied with representations of life after death. Popular during the 18-19th centuries,
 magic lantern phantasmagoria shows were spine chilling theatrical experiences that
 utilized the pre-cinematic technology of the magic lantern, an early slide projector,
 to create the illusion that there were ghosts in the room. The technologies and performances
 anticipate video jockeying, a form of live performance that emerged in 1980s club
 culture, that uses video to heighten club atmosphere. Based on this research, Afterlife
 utilizes video jockeying to reimagine a phantasmagoria show and investigate the concept
 of afterlife as a state of intermediacy. Remixing and improvisation become central
 to exploring notions of time and light as disembodiment by using the techniques of
 VJing to play, alter and remix projected visual content in real-time.

Title: Falasttini 'Kohh'
Abstract:
As bombs drop on Gaza thousands of miles away from Abu Dhabi, a Jordanian Palestinian
 doctor's amputated leg throbs in phantom pain, while she treats a belligerent Palestinian
 patient. In this thriller drama, the examination shifts from the patient's wounds
 to the doctor's Palestinian identity after she offers to help the patient's family
 in Gaza.

Title: When Grown Wild and Far
Abstract:
Lonely and awkward Antonio struggles to connect with both his family and neighbors.
 Antonio makes an attempt to reconnect with his reluctant grandson Pedro, throughout
 an afternoon together. Based on the boy's taste when he was much younger, Antonio
 tries to show Pedro home videos, play with firecrackers, and soccer in order to engage
 his grandson. However, Pedro and Antonio soon realize that the preconception that
 they had of each other is not all true.

Title: Afaf
Abstract:
The government implements a law to test women at universities to ensure their hymen
 and – thereby their purity – is still intact. Having only one day until her virginity
 test, Afaf must do the impossible to pass the exam that threatens to wreck her academic
 career. At home, a conflict is brewing, as the dynamic between Afaf and her father
 is on the edge of disintegration if she is found out. Her only hope is to crash an
 underground women's class that promises her a shot at passing the virginity test.

Title: The Hafiz
Abstract:
To honor his late father, Sultan tries to memorize the entire Quran. However, his
 passion for music constantly distracts him. Now he struggles between honoring his
 late father and playing music.

Title: Free Shipping
Abstract:
Put on the Virtual Reality goggles and get ready to experience the identity of a delivery
 truck loader. You are standing in front of a conveyor belt and the only thing you
 can rely on while the packages keep coming and coming is your judgement. Or is it
 your biases? If you got through the challenge of keeping your job, you can compete
 to earn a high score. Pressed by time, your boss, and political correctness you will
 need to face decades of biases that are ingrained in your subconscious from misrepresentation
 in the media, your country and your upbringing. In the end you will not only figure
 out which parcel is shipped to which country but you will also interact with your
 unconscious biases. Hopefully in the meantime you will also figure out whether to
 ship rice to China, India, the Middle East, Mexico, UAE or Africa.

Title: Practical Dreams
Abstract:
"Practical Dreams" is an experimental documentary mosaic which showcases and at the
 same time calls for a reevaluation of one's own life choices. Through contemplative
 voice over, long landscape shots of Dubai, and the unyielding stares of its residents,
 the piece allows its viewers into the world of UAE-based architect Antony, while at
 the same time giving space for an individual, introspective journey for the duration
 of the film.

Title: The GIG : Good Indian Girls
Abstract:
Radhika has been promoted to Vice President of her company, Phantom Brands. She returns
 home to celebrate with her fiance, Jai, only to discover that he has lost his job
 and worse, his mother has flown in from Delhi, to chivvy the young couple to her city
 where Jai can run the family business. Will Radhika stand up for herself ? Will she
 sacrifice her ambition for her relationship? Will Jai ever learn of Radhika's sacrifice?
 Will Mummyji ever make her own cup of tea? These questions will be answered by the
 short film The G.I.G by Riva Razdan.

Title: Every Day, Except Sunday
Abstract:
Every Day, Except Sunday (2019), is a short live action film about a 10-year-old boy
 discovering his faith. The film shows how religion is something that is shaped by
 each individual in a personal manner, according to their own beliefs and values. I
 want to show that following a religion word by word will not make you a better person
 if you do not feel good with yourself. I want to demonstrate that it is possible to
 discover that there can be a personal way to follow a religion, without being constrained
 and scared by the rules imposed by religious "authorities", or any other sort of rule.
 A day before his first confession, Enzo fears the worst after stealing a motorcycle
 emblem. He writes a list of his sins, but he must overcome one more challenge: the
 owner of the motorcycle is the priest he will confess to. Will Enzo face his fears
 and confess his sins?

Title: Vicky, I and Herself
Abstract:
Vicky, I and Herself narrates the drifting subjectivities of Southeast Asian female
 migrants in Abu Dhabi, blurring the line between reality and fantasy. Synopsis:
 Vicky, a 25-year-old Chinese migrant worker, works as a mural painter at Warner Bro
 World's construction site in Abu Dhabi. Soon, she will be leaving for China. At this
 heightened moment, Vicky, her friends and the filmmaker converge at a transient space;
 imagining, dreaming, and hoping to be remembered by the city. While recounting the
 everyday experiences of Vicky and her friends, the narrator attempts to grasp her
 obscure relationships with them.

Title: Zahra
Abstract:
This narrative film is derived from real stories of interviewed women who have been
 victims of arranged marriages in their childhood. It is dedicated to all the young
 girls who are subjected to the backward practices that define our lives. In conservative,
 sexist, and patriarchal societies in the Middle East, many girls are betrothed after
 menstruation when they are considered 'ready' to fulfill their purpose in life. The
 narrative follows a mother's strife by both perpetuating and fighting the patriarchal
 society in which she is trapped. As a result, this film aims to show hardships women
 face in a patriarchal society without villainizing anyone, by demonstrating the struggle
 the mother goes through when deciding to either succumb to or break out of said society.

Title: How We Leave
Abstract:
The feeling of getting older is familiar to everyone, but still each of us lives through
 it in our own unique way - depending on the experiences we have had and what we have
 done with them. Identity is fleeting and nothing throughout our lives stays the same.
 That might be the only consistent thing in it. How We Leave is a short narrative film
 that shows a day in two girls' lives, in which they have to learn how to grow up.
 The story examines the way children deal with trauma and perceive adults, what it
 does to their friendship. Fear follows them no matter how far away from everyone they
 go, because the biggest monsters truly are hidden within ourselves. Growing up doesn't
 mean that fear goes away, it means that the person learns how to keep moving forward
 while being afraid. And it looks like it is much easier to do so if there is a friend
 on your side.

My piece titled "|" is an artistic endeavor exploring the concept of existence through
 a memoiristic abstraction of reality and realities. Through a series of films in an
 online format, my piece explores themes of sexuality, love, family, religion, and
 death as the film follows an unnamed woman who killed herself at a young age. Her
 older self, however, continues to experience various realities of what her life could
 have been. The viewer is put into control as to how they experience this narrative
 as they interact with an online exhibition. This exhibition, through showcasing vignettes
 of the main character's life, explores a universal yet individualistic existential
 questioning of the purpose of one's life. The space in which the character exists
 in the four rooms emulates the concept of a void, showcasing what could have been,
 while forcing the audience member to come to terms with their own reality of how their
 interaction with the narrative actually is.

Title: Show Me AD
Abstract:
Show Me AD is a short video guide hosted by senior NYUAD student, Emma. She enlists
 the help of a few of her friends to show her around Abu Dhabi. The catch: they have
 a student budget! The resulting videos will be posted on the NYUAD official youtube
 channel, targeted towards the incoming NYUAD students. It was inspired by Emma's own
 experience moving to Abu Dhabi, and feeling overwhelmed by the city and the different
 logistics and possibilities that revolved around finding things to do. This series
 is designed to help the students who may also arrive feeling out of depth, to give
 them a head start regarding places to go, things to see, and how to get there.

Title: Sister
Abstract:
Sister is an episodic fictional narrative that recognizes the effects of UAE's working
 spaces on an African migrant's every day experience. It looks at the dynamic between
 two African women working at a boutique hotel in Abu Dhabi, and how the space subtly
 affects their psychological experience. The research process for the film was set
 off by an article published by Khaleej Times in 2019 detailing the court case of a
 young Kenyan female who was raped by an Emirati student and allegedly taken to the
 scene by a male Cameroonian friend. The film's narrative is shaped by interviews conducted
 with African female migrants in Abu Dhabi along with a written interview with Prof.
 Yaw Nyarko of NYUAD, whose work focuses on the economic effects of UAE's labor system(s).
 Other applied sources include testimonials drawn from online articles, book chapters
 and YouTube videos. Most of these contents reflected the invisibility or otherwise,
 the victimhood of the African female perspective in migrant narratives seen in both
 the media and the spaces they occupy within the Gulf.

Title: Breakout Rooms
Abstract:
This defense paper examines how the short film Breakout Rooms is a project that revolves
 around abruptions created in the online and offline spaces that we occupy, especially
 in light of a pandemic that has forced the entire world to grapple with the implications
 of a newfound, 'virtual' reality that is both real and a counterfeit. It operates
 on two levels that speak to each other to create the overarching narrative of the
 film— the first level is the 'online' context of Zoom, where the characters interact
 on rectangular screens and attempt to build a fleeting relationship. The second level
 is the 'offline' context of the UAE, a country where migrants make up the majority
 of the population and are often temporary inhabitants in the region. This paper addresses
 the various narrative and cinematic strategies used to highlight that both a Zoom
 breakout room and the migrant experience in the Gulf are temporary.

Title: A City Gone to Sleep
Abstract:
A City Gone to Sleep is a documentary detailing the impact of Covid-19 on the restaurant
 industry in New York City. At its core, the film is a commentary on the crucial role
 of restaurants in the social, historical, and economic architecture of the city. The
 restaurant industry employs over 300,000 New Yorkers in over 24,000 locations, many
 of which have been around for decades. It is a primary employer of immigrants, many
 of whom have also set up their own establishments. Whether you have been to New York
 or not, many of us have an image of what New York is supposed to be. Restaurants give
 character to the streets of New York and serve as reminders of the city's rich diversity.
 The pandemic has forced us to reflect on what the loss of these spaces will mean for
 New York City for years to come.

Title: Gair (outsider)
Abstract:
Eager to fit in with his high school friends in Abu Dhabi, Armaan distances himself
 from his parents and his Indian identity. Ali, a taxi driver, yearns for his family
 in Pakistan as he struggles to make ends meet and provide for his daughter's education.
 One day, when Armaan plans to go partying with his friends, their divergent lives
 serendipitously intersect, unravelling questions of identity, position and privilege
 in Abu Dhabi. Through Armaan and Ali, who represent two sides of the South Asian migrant
 experience in the UAE, the film explores the themes of identity, belonging, and masculinity.
 I spent three months writing the script, two months on pre-production, and three days
 on production in fall 2020. In spring 2021, I worked extensively on post-production,
 tightening the film and working on sound design. What started as an 18-page script
 eventually became a 10-minute film.

Title: POSERS
Abstract:
POSER takes place in Abu Dhabi, an environment where its expatriate population outrageously
 outnumbers its national population. It's a city where many young people develop a
 third culture kid identity – those who grow up for a majority of their youth in countries
 outside those of their nationality. Specifically, the film is set in a skatepark,
 where many teenagers living in Abu Dhabi come to meet and socialize. However, often
 the reality of being a third culture kid is the fluctuating nature of friendship,
 as expats continue to leave for various reasons. This begs the question: how does
 this uncertainty of their next years affect their behavior and personality? What does
 it mean to develop strong relationships with the temporary people around you? How
 do TCK's react to goodbyes? How did the Covid-19 pandemic further affect these temporary
 people? POSER attempts to capture the bittersweetness of goodbyes by following two
 young TCK's, who have unspoken feelings for each other, as they spend one last morning
 together. Through the use of a rapidly developing yet relaxed skate culture in Abu
 Dhabi, POSER explores the meaning of home and youth.

Title: Bubbles of Happiness
Abstract:
Bubbles of Happiness tells a story of a bond between two unlikely people that share
 a mutual appreciation for karak. Coming from different socioeconomic backgrounds,
 the film explores social expectations, cultural traditions, and belonging that ultimately
