 determines the fate of the friendship.

Title: Umalis Si Maama (Migrant Mother)
Abstract:
Umalis Si Maama (Migrant Mother) is a semi-ethnographic documentary which follows
 three domestic workers on their day-off in Abu Dhabi. Documented over four months,
 the film attempts to capture the dualities of love and separation, community and longing,
 leisure and labour, which permeate the lives of migrant mothers. Grounded in a practice
 of self-reflexivity and ethical inquiry, this film intends to raise questions about
 gaze, positionality and power. Who gets to tell whose story? What does nuanced and
 ethical representation look like? How do we begin to disrupt the ethnographic gaze?
 By combining observational footage and informal interviews with Whatsapp photo archives
 and amateur video-making, this project aims to expand and experiment with the documentary
 form, and open space for agency and self-expression.

Title: The Nine Circles
Abstract:
In the enticing thought experiment of "The Floating Man" (On the Soul: The Floating
 Man, 1037), philosopher Ibn Sina wondered what a mind would experience if it was suddenly
 born disconnected from all physicality and devoid of all senses. The goal of The Nine
 Circles is to explore this concept through an audiovisual approach. For most of history
 people have believed that a spiritual or mental part of us remains after physical
 death. Thus, the most direct way for us to explore the "floating" mind is to imagine
 what the post-death experience could be. My film opens with the death of the protagonist,
 and what follows is an exploration of that mind, unlinked from physical reality. First
 the mind feels lost in the dark, but then it slowly learns how to imagine and navigate
 in a new world of its own. This experience ultimately becomes akin to our own 'living'
 reality. I hope the journey of this floating mind can open new ways of imagining this
 inevitable destiny of ours which we refer to as 'death.'

Title: Next to Normal
Abstract:
Three short scripts which are interconnected: The superstitious and reckless attempts
 of a desperate mother to meet her dead son again are doomed to fail. After realizing
 the impossibility of receiving unconditional love, a teenage boy decides to use his
 suicide as a protest to his parents. A young immigrant tries to build his identity,
 swaying between a family of oppressed elders and a homosexual lover he just met.

Title:
"More Often Now He Suggests or Advises": The Changed Relationship Between Britain's
                                 Representatives and the Sheikhs of the Arabian Gulf, 1947-1971
Abstract:
Major: HistoryAbstract: Britain exerted power over the Persian Gulf between 1820 and 1971 through
 personal relationships between British representatives and the local Gulf rulers.
 From 1947, the tone of those relationships changed substantially, from authoritarian
 to more collaborative. Recent scholarship suggests that this change was due to a diversification
 of the educational backgrounds of the British representatives: prior to 1947, all
 of them had attended public schools, which imbued them with highly imperialistic attitudes.
 However, after 1947, their education was more diverse, and no longer propagated such
 an imperial ideology; thus, the British representatives were no longer as authoritarian.This thesis offers a more nuanced version of this argument, by taking into account
 the prevailing attitudes towards Empire in Britain, as well as pressures on Britain's
 position in the Gulf from powers in the region. Ultimately, I argue, educational background
 merely contributed to the change in the relationship; more significant were regional
 pressures that forced the British representatives to effect policy that necessitated
 greater collaboration with the local rulers, and thus a change in the nature of the
 relationship.

Title: Violence and Exchange: Middlemen of the Sixteenth- and Seventeenth Century Mediterranean
Abstract:
Major: HistoryAbstract: Historians of the pre-modern Mediterranean have challenged the argument
 that the sixteenth- and seventeenth-century Mediterranean ceased to exist as a frontier
 of fruitful cross-religious contact between Christian Europeans and Muslim North Africans.
 This thesis supports that position by showing that amidst violence, specific types
 of middlemen, including corsairs, captives, slaves, and diplomats, continued to live
 in connection with both Christian Europe and Muslim North Africa. I argue for an understanding
 of religious violence that accepts its tragic and harmful consequences while acknowledging
 it as an avenue through which cross-cultural and religious knowledge was facilitated.
 Within this framework, I explore the physical violence of piracy and captivity as
 well as the concept of structural violence in connection with the career of the Jewish
 merchant and diplomat Samuel Pallache. Finally, I turn to consider an anti-Christian
 polemical work that has received limited scholarly attention: Ahmad ibn Qasim al-Hajari's
 Kitab nasir al din 'ala 'l-qawm al-kafirin (The Supporter of Religion Against the
 Infidel). The violent language in Kitab nasir al-din was the only way in which al-Hajari
 could convey stories of his respect and admiration for Christians to his Muslim North
 African audience.

Title:
The Doctor as Biographer: The Politics of Intimacy in Historical Biographies of Winston
                                 Churchill and Mao Zedong
Abstract:
Major: HistoryMajor: This thesis compares the politics of intimacy in two biographies written by
 doctors: Churchill: The Struggle for Survival 1940-1965 (1966) by Charles Wilson (known
 by his honourary title of Lord Moran), and The Private Life of Chairman Mao (1994)
 by Li Zhisui. Both Moran and Li spent over twenty years serving as the personal physicians
 of Winston Churchill and Mao Zedong respectively, forming extremely close relationships
 in the process.All biography written by personal associates raises the question of how such relationships
 affect not only the content of the work, but also its reception. However, research
 regarding this question is surprisingly thin, and in turn the question remains largely
 unanswered. This thesis, by comparing biographical traditions in both England and
 China, and by examining biographies of Winston Churchill and Mao Zedong, offers specific
 answers to this question. I argue that a comparative analysis, mindful of the distinctive
 features of Chinese and English biographical traditions, reveals that the politics
 of intimacy in historical biography is greatly shaped not only by historical context,
 but also by present day values.

Title:
Internalising Identities: Internment Camps in Australia in World War II as a Tool
                                 of Nation Building
Abstract:
Major: HistoryAbstract: The internment of foreign nationals in Australia during World War II is
 one example of exclusionary practices used in Australian history to define in and
 out groups in Australian society. This example often disappears from dominant narratives
 of Australian military and social history, or internees' experiences are written about
 in isolated categories of nationalities. This study examines internees' own stories
 from the Tatura and Loveday internment camps in conjunction with official histories
 and different trends in writing Australian history. In addition, this study looks
 at ways internees were forced to confront their own identities through internment
 and how on exit from the camps, internees were pressured to adopt attitudes in line
 with Anglo-Australia and internalised their internment experience. Finally, this study
 shows that recent trends in Australian history have focused on finding space for non-white
 others and that internment camps need to be incorporated in these histories to understand
 the forces that have constructed white Australian identities and subsequent politics.

Title: Dying Among the Geraniums: Madness in the Congo Free State
Abstract:
At the turn of the 20th century, violent conditions in the Congo Free State colony
 of Belgian King Leopold II sparked international outcry. Reformist literature surrounding
 the London-based Congo Reform Association (CRA) criticized the King and his colony
 by inverting imperial discourse, identifying Leopold's State with excess, savagery,
 and madness. Through this mode of critique, CRA writers perpetuated an imperialist
 ideology based on a masculine ideal of the colonizer. In reworking these accusations
 of madness, modern literary and historical adaptations of the history of the State
 and the CRA repeat an ultimately unproductive discourse of violence, rooted in ideals
 of imperial masculinity. This paper examines the gendered nature of this discourse,
 and attempts to move away from hegemonic representations of violence through historical-literary
 analysis of three distinct moments. The paper tracks the trope of madness through
 the interweaving stories of the CRA, the trial and execution of British consul Roger
 Casement, and Jean Boenga's account of a colonial officer's suicide, and reads these
 moments for alternative representations of violence.

Title: Crossing Mountains: Tea Trade and State Building in the Sino-Tibetan Borderlands
Abstract:
For over a thousand years, Tibetans relied on China for the supply of a dietary necessity
 – tea. As both a revenue-making and a state-building tool for the Chinese state, tea
 trade continued to connect Tibet and China across formidable mountains even as state
 power failed to do so during the Republican period (1912-1949). This capstone examines
 the relationship between tea trade and state building in the Sino-Tibetan borderlands
 as China struggled to create a modern nation from the ruins of an empire. Drawing
 on both archival and published sources, the author uncovers the divergent paths taken
 by two Chinese provinces – Sichuan and Yunnan – as they continued to supply tea to
 Tibet amidst ongoing border conflicts after the Qing Empire collapsed in 1911. Imperial
 legacies of taxation, complex frontier politics, and the successful integration of
 the Sino-Southeast Asian trade networks into the Sino-Tibetan tea trade all contributed
 to this divergence.

Title: Contesting Aboriginality in mid-20th Century Sydney
Abstract:
This capstone charts the development of the concept of Aboriginality in Sydney, Australia
 during the 1950s and 1960s. As the federal government and the states adopted policies
 designed to assimilate the Aboriginal population, official publications promoting
 this administrative strategy, as well as internal classification schemes used by the
 state of New South Wales, produced contradictory understandings of Aboriginality.
 Grass-roots activists associated with the Aboriginal-Australian Fellowship sought
 to create a distinct Aboriginal identity that could be integrated within a multi-ethnic
 Australian nation. Their compromise position would be challenged as Aboriginal people
 began to demand land rights, challenging the sovereignty of the Australian state.
 Debates over the place of Aboriginality in Australian society were played out at the
 local level as Aboriginal activists sought to claim a space within the city of Sydney,
 against opposition from other residents and government agencies. Exploring Aboriginality
 in an urban context in this period reveals how local governments, community organisations
 and Aboriginal leaders laid claim to their own understandings of Aboriginality. In
 shaping this contested concept as these varied historical agents responded both to
 local social and economic conditions and to broader international movements for racial
 justice.

Title:
"A Hero Appears!": The Many Manifestations Of Musa Ibn Abi Ghassan In Orientalist
                                 Literature and Muslim Televangelist Programming
Abstract:
This study traces the development of the story of Musa Ibn Abi Ghassan's, from early
 19th century Washington Irving's romantic Conquest of Grenada to its "discovery" by
 mid 20th-century Arab academic historians. It examines how Muslim Televangelist programmes
 make parallels between Abi Ghassan's stories and the 21st-century Muslim predicament,
 focusing on the necessity of educating the Muslim youth in Abi Ghassan's story as
 an essential precursor to a religious and cultural renaissance. The programmes extract
 often contrasting lessons from Abi Ghassan's story, as a representation of loyalty
 to the state, a "genuine" Islamist movement leader, and/or as a lost example of cultivating
 a proper work ethic in Muslim and Arab youth.

Title: The Birthplace of the UAE: The Legacy of the First Permanent Hospital in Abu Dhabi
Abstract:
My capstone project explores the emergence and foundational period of the Oasis Hospital
 Al Ain, the first permanent hospital in Abu Dhabi. The project examines the political,
 social and cultural underpinnings that brought a Protestant missionary hospital to
 Al Ain. In doing so, it traces the history of Christian medical missionaries in the
 Trucial States/UAE, namely the Protestant Evangelicals of the Reformed Church in America
 (RCA) and is therefore part of the wider history of Christian missionaries in the
 Gulf. Utilizing missionary letters and oral history interviews, this project considers
 how the Al Ain Oasis Hospital has become a crucial part of UAE's history. Furthermore,
 this capstone also provides historical context for the current environment of religious
 tolerance and freedom that has been perpetuated by the UAE government today.

Title:
A Wok Through The Redefinition of Qingzhen (Halal) Dietary Practices Among Chinese-Muslims
                                 In Republican China
Abstract:
Sometime in 1935, Yang Lisheng, a teacher in a Muslim Primary School in the town of
 Neixiang, located in China's Henan province, fielded the following question from one
 of his students: "Why don't you Muslims eat pork?" Yang's answer: "Pigs are filthy
 animals, and since we are very particular about hygiene and the nature of health,
 we don't eat it." In his 1936 treatise, "Why Muslims Do Not Eat Pork", Yang attempts
 to formulate a more comprehensive answer to that question; one that includes notions
 of hygiene and health. This provides us with a window into the questions and challenges
 teachers working in Islamic schools in China faced during the first half of the twentieth
 century, and to how they addressed those challenges by reframing their teachings to
 include social issues of the time.

Title: A Center by Its Own: Multifaceted Life of a Native Mu Elite in Lijiang, 1499-1553
Abstract:
This capstone examines the perspectives of Mu Gong (1499-1553), a native elite in
 Lijiang, on his and his family's relationship with the neighboring powers, including
 the Ming Chinese state. Mu Gong was a patriarch of the Mu family, whose succeeding
 generations had held positions of authority in Lijiang since at least 1253. Lijiang,
 a historical border region that intersects China and Tibet, has remained a marginal
 space in conventional area studies and a geographical periphery with an ambiguous
 political status. Analyzing the written works from Mu Gong, this capstone argues that
 Mu Gong identified and facilitated different forms of relationship between himself
 and the neighboring powers in cultural, political, and military aspects; during this
 process, the Ming Chinese state played an important yet only partial role. For example,
 he was a committed follower of Chinese literary culture, an independent politician
 who valued his family's historical legacy in Chinese statecraft, and a powerful military
 leader who kept an intricate balance with neighboring forces, including China and
 Tibet, while expanding his own territory for economic gain.

Title:
Epistemologies on the Margins of the Malayan Insurgency (1942-1989): Analyses of Selfhood,
                                 Gender, and the Jungle in Autobiographies and Memoirs
Abstract:
This capstone investigates gendered and spatialised epistemologies of the Malayan
 insurgency. Studying autobiographical texts by characters who are often left out in
 the historiography of the war, I analyse how these writers present selfhood, gender
 expression, and their relationship to the jungle.

Title: Institutionalized Personalization: Carter's Ambassadors-at-Large for Middle East Peace
Abstract:
This project examines the special diplomatic office of Ambassador-at-Large as a window
 into the organization and institutional tensions of the US foreign relations ecosystem.
 As a case study, it analyzes the three Ambassadors-at-Large employed by President
 Carter (1977-1981) during the Israeli-Egyptian peace process. Situating this case
 within the broader history of the position, the shifting responsibilities of the Ambassador-at-Large
 exemplify long-standing tensions over Presidentialization, Personalization, and Professionalization
 in US foreign relations. Highlighting the contradictions of an institutionalized mechanism
 designed to circumvent its own institutions, the project presses for a reexamination
 of special diplomats as reflective of the structures that produce and employ them.

Title:
Memory of Monarchs: The Shaping of 15th - 17th Century Christian Ethiopia through
                                 Dynastic Memory
Abstract:
This thesis examines the role of historical memory in the Christian Ethiopian Solomonic
 monarchy from roughly 1434 CE to 1632 CE. Using evidence from the Ethiopian Royal
 Chronicles, hagiographic literature, and European sources, this project claims that
 the actions, policies, and religiopolitical attitudes of the 17th century Christian
 Ethiopian king Susǝnyos were shaped by the dynastic memory of his 15th century ancestor
 Zä'ra Ya'ǝqob. This project explores the internal religious and political history
 of 15th to 17th century Christian Ethiopia from the height of the Ethiopian medieval
 period until the end of the Jesuit Period while touching upon the wider intersecting
 global histories which affected the Christian Kingdom and that Ethiopia affected in
 turn. By studying Christian Ethiopia through the lens of memory, this capstone reexamines
 the role of history making in general, and medieval Christian Ethiopia in particular,
 reflecting upon the impact of royal education on political and religious policies
 implemented by the emperors of medieval Christian Ethiopia.

Title: Tracing Black Power: Revolution and Memory in Trinidad and Tobago
Abstract:
In February of 1970, the Black Power Movement took over the streets of Trinidad and
 Tobago, taking inspiration from contemporaneous movements in the wider Caribbean,
 North America, the United Kingdom and beyond. This capstone argues that the Movement
 in Trinidad and Tobago was a transnational exercise in shared blackness which manifested
 in varied ways that were specific to the Trinbagonian experience. This capstone does
 not frame global Black Power as emanating from a North American core, but as a Movement
 in which underling connections created an environment of collective radical black
 action in the late 60s and 70s. It uses memory as a lens into the 1970s, and also
 as a connector to the complicated contemporary Trinbagonian experience with blackness,
 specifically in the Movement's 50th anniversary. Based upon the oral testimony of
 individuals who lived through the Movement, the project illuminates various transnational
 themes such as black consciousness, black ideology and black cultural practices. Parallel
 to these connections, it looks at the localised manifestations of Black Power in organisations,
 cultural artforms and in spirituality to demonstrate that Trinbagonian Black Power
 arose out of the particular historical experience of Black persons in the Caribbean.

Title:
Opposing the EU: Historical Legacies of Eurocriticism and Euroscepticism in France,
                                 1950-1992
Abstract:
The project chronicles the evolution of Eurocritical and Eurosceptic sentiment in
 France between 1950 and 1992 to determine whether Eurosceptic ideas in the country
 today appeared in public and political discourse prior to the Maastricht Treaty referendum
 in 1992. Scholarly consensus denotes the referendum as the first time in French history
 when Euroscepticism affected French political outcomes. Contrarily, this study demonstrates
 that French foreign and national policy has consistently displayed Eurocritical attitudes
 since 1950. Such sentiment has significantly affected political outcomes on a national
 and EU level, culminating in the rise of Eurosceptic political parties and policies
 long before 1992. The study synthesizes numerous newspaper articles, speeches, interviews
 and public opinion polls to reveal several frequently cited concerns regarding national
 sovereignty, the gradual loss of French influence over European affairs and complex
 relations with Germany and the United States. The project demonstrates that France's
 foreign policy interests have consistently been at odds with the European integration
 process. Exploring this tension reveals a historical legacy of French hesitation towards
 the EU; one firmly ingrained in political and public discourse and one playing a key
 role in French and European political outcomes.

Subdivision:
Interactive Media (2020 - )


Scope and Contents

Earlier projects related to interactive media may be found in either Art and Art History
                                 (visual arts) or Film and New Media sub-series.
Title: Homo Ludens // Learning to Play
Abstract:
Homo Ludens // Learning to Play is an Interactive Media project which consists of
 a guidebook and a single game that is about using games for learning through play
 which is meant for both classroom and non-classroom oriented environments. What Learning
 to Play does is it introduces you to how you can design your own games based on a
 set of rules which can then be used as a learning tool.

Subdivision:
Interactive Media (2020 - )


Scope and Contents

Earlier projects related to interactive media may be found in either Art and Art History
                                 (visual arts) or Film and New Media sub-series.
Title: Simulacra
Abstract:
How can we find comfort in a society dominated by spectacle? How can meaningful interactions
 help to create this comfort? These are the two overarching questions my Capstone project
 addresses. Informed by key ideas from Situationist International and Sherry Turkle,
 my Capstone seeks to react to these theorists' concepts by considering them in relation
 to our current situation with social media. Overall, composed of two experiences:
 a social media daring game and an interactive installation, my Capstone invites people
 to reconsider their relationship with social media and their use of it as well. As
 subjects to the attention economy that drives and monetizes social media, it is imperative
 for social media users to be aware of its implications and to have some critical understanding
 of the dynamics at play. In light of this, the two components of my Capstone project
 strive to facilitate this understanding.

Subdivision:
Interactive Media (2020 - )


Scope and Contents

Earlier projects related to interactive media may be found in either Art and Art History
                                 (visual arts) or Film and New Media sub-series.
Title: mirari
Abstract:
During the period of Fall 2019 to Spring 2020, I began my process of brainstorming,
 prototyping, playtesting and finalizing my Capstone Project, mirari. The essay outlines
 my entire process till completion, and discusses how I came to decide on the design
 aspects, to the struggles I faced along the way. I began with the themes of reality,
 perception, light, landscape and infinity. Throughout the building process, I went
 through several experimentation stages and prototypes, welcoming new methods and ideas
 which all connected to the elements I had chosen. Integrating the historical and theoretical
 themes that helped me polish and contextualise my project. With a recent study I did
 on James Turrell's artwork, whom I acknowledge is a large inspiration to my project,
 I found that the backbone of my project falls in parallel with his theories. As well
 as, specifically, minimalism and the Light and Space movement.

Subdivision:
Interactive Media (2020 - )


Scope and Contents

Earlier projects related to interactive media may be found in either Art and Art History
                                 (visual arts) or Film and New Media sub-series.
Title: Liked
Abstract:
"Liked" is a Chrome extension that manipulates the output of liking a photo on Instagram,
 therefore addressing contemporary anxieties around the increased online presence and
 use of social media as well as the phenomenon of circulationism.

Subdivision:
Interactive Media (2020 - )


Scope and Contents

Earlier projects related to interactive media may be found in either Art and Art History
                                 (visual arts) or Film and New Media sub-series.
Title: A Hero's Passage: Chapter 1
Abstract:
The first chapter of a 2D, single-player adventure/puzzle pc game about the afterlife,
 faith, and moving on. Play as a dead hero who helps a god carry their task of ferrying
 spirits to the other side.

Subdivision:
Interactive Media (2020 - )


Scope and Contents

Earlier projects related to interactive media may be found in either Art and Art History
                                 (visual arts) or Film and New Media sub-series.
Title: Soucouyant Stories
Abstract:
Every culture has its own story which becomes embedded into our daily lives. We grow
 up hearing and reading the mythology which shaped our society for years. Soucouyant
 Stories is a three-part production which showcases some of the folklore characters
 found in Trinidad and Tobago with the aim of exploring the research question: How
 do we Preserve Oral Tradition. By comparing oral, written, and immersive platforms,
 this project strives to better understand which elements of the three forms of media
 were most impactful.

Subdivision:
Interactive Media (2020 - )


Scope and Contents

Earlier projects related to interactive media may be found in either Art and Art History
                                 (visual arts) or Film and New Media sub-series.
Title: Venus Ex Machina
Abstract:
Venus Ex Machina is an exploration into the future of body modification. Humans will
 be able to expand their capabilities through the use of easy-to-buy, non-humanoid
 prosthetics. Fashion, self-expression, bodily autonomy, and resolve; these ideas are
 present in a world where body modifications have been normalized, and are a painless
 procedure. Where do YOU draw the line on altering your body?

Subdivision:
Interactive Media (2020 - )


Scope and Contents

Earlier projects related to interactive media may be found in either Art and Art History
                                 (visual arts) or Film and New Media sub-series.
Title: Kinka's Recipes
Abstract:
My capstone is a cookbook accompanied with an augmented reality mobile app that attempts
 to document my grandmother's stories and teach users how to cook her Taiwanese and
 Hakka dishes.

Subdivision:
Interactive Media (2020 - )


Scope and Contents

Earlier projects related to interactive media may be found in either Art and Art History
                                 (visual arts) or Film and New Media sub-series.
Title: Surreal Plastics: Humanizing the Disposable
Abstract:
Surreal Plastics is a series of infinitely looping 3D animation pieces united by one
 concept and goal of tackling society's perception of plastic as a material that is
 often deprecated for its waste potential. Through this project and the underlying
 research, the artist examines the relationship between our consumption habits and
 waste by shifting the perspective from the magnitude of plastic pollution towards
 our intimate relationships with disposables.

Subdivision:
Interactive Media (2020 - )


Scope and Contents

Earlier projects related to interactive media may be found in either Art and Art History
                                 (visual arts) or Film and New Media sub-series.
Title: Mischievous Algorithm
Abstract:
Built using p5.js and javascript, Mischievous Algorithm is a networked program that
 gives instructions to two or more users working real-time to create a collaborative
 drawing. However, there is a twist. A third 'hidden' player is the Mischievous Algorithm,
 which introduces uncertainty by bringing in new elements or changes into the users'
 work. Accessed through a link hosted on a service called Ngrok, users are presented
 with an interface similar to Windows Paint, but built using p5.js. The program has
 three areas: a set of instructions, a canvas for drawing and a minimal tool set derived
 from common drawing apps, which includes a color picker, the ability to change brush
 size and an eraser. While users are interacting with each other through the canvas,
 on the backend there is the Mischievous Algorithm that changes the users' work in
 ways that only a computer could do.The project reverses the expected behavioral roles
 of human vs. machine through an interface where the user follows direct instructions
 to create a piece of digital art, while the interfering code creatively and unexpectedly
 modifies it.

Subdivision:
Interactive Media (2020 - )


Scope and Contents

Earlier projects related to interactive media may be found in either Art and Art History
                                 (visual arts) or Film and New Media sub-series.
Title: Bodily Particles
Abstract:
Bodily Particles (NYUAD Air) is a sci-art installation that provides a looking-glass
 into the deadly world of microscopic particulate matter in the air. Situated within
 the sub-urban setting of the NYUAD campus, it challenges our perceived sense of comfort
 and cleanliness: just because we don't see smoke-churning factories or polluting vehicles
 near us, it does not mean the air we breathe is safe. The installation addresses this
 neglected issue by offering two intertwined components on NYUAD campus. The first
 component is a socially distanced outdoor installation that makes invisible air pollution
 hypervisible, allowing us to see ourselves in relationship with the microscopic particles
 we breathe in. The second component is a network of air quality monitoring stations
 across campus (Campus Center, Dining Hall, and outside of Arts Center), providing
 real time air quality data and health suggestions.

Subdivision:
Interactive Media (2020 - )


Scope and Contents

Earlier projects related to interactive media may be found in either Art and Art History
                                 (visual arts) or Film and New Media sub-series.
Title: BlockIt!
Abstract:
BlockIt! is a mobile game that prompts users to create a 3D model of a given noun
 using simple shapes while whoever they are playing with must guess what they are creating.
 Once a user creates this 3D model, a marker is dropped at the user's current longitude
 and latitude position onto an in-game map. Other users of the application can travel
 to this location, tap on the marker, view the model that the user created and guess
 what this object is. The capstone sits between being a case study in effective interaction
 design for mobile experiences and a project that explores user agency and their ability
 to create with the tools and affordances provided to them through the application.
 The application uses augmented reality as a tool for designing, exploring the potential
 for the technology to be used effectively for 3D design.

Title: Considering Constitutional Gaps in the UK
Abstract:
I plan to investigate how the absence of a formalized or written constitution in the
 United Kingdom (UK) is compensated for within the legal system, other laws and treaties.
 Because a large portion of these laws come from the EU or international conventions
 that have been brought into local legislation, primarily the Human Rights Act of 1998,
 I want to study the implications Brexit may have on an uncodified and EU derived conception
 of Human Rights. Aside from theoretically analyzing this through the law and bills
 and acts, I aim to survey UK residents or citizens- i.e. those who the laws and possible
 change in the provision of human rights in the UK impact. In my survey, I will try
 to understand whether the subjects know about how their rights are provided in the
 UK, whether they feel a gap due to the uncodified nature of the constitution and whether
 they know the impact Brexit may have.

Title: The Ethical Ramifications of Artificial Intelligence in the Legal Profession
Abstract:
Artificial intelligence is disrupting most traditional industries, and the legal sphere
 is no exception. Artificial intelligence offers the potential to greatly increase
 access to the law, particularly for low-income clients, but raises many serious ethical
 questions. These questions include, first, the extent to which artificial intelligence
 can offer competent legal representation, and second, whether additional regulation
 is required to protect individuals from incompetent representation or breaches of
 confidentiality. Artificial Intelligence will alter the relationship between lawyer
 and client, and require from lawyers a keen understanding of developments in this
 nascent field. These ethical concerns give rise to issues of regulation and legal
 education. This paper analyses the current state of Artificial Intelligence in general,
 as well as its current and potential future impact on the legal profession.

Title:
By Capitalism: An Environmentalist Approach to Implementing a Sustainable Capitalist
                                 Economy in the United Arab Emirates
Abstract:
The growing economies are risking the environment. Climate change and global warming
 are major threats that the world is facing today. While countries are neglecting taking
 action to protect the environment, countries such as Finland, Sweden, Norway and Switzerland
 have enacted a policy to decrease CO2 emissions and have successfully done so. While
 capitalism is the driving force for environmental destruction, it can be part of the
 solution by introducing sustainable capitalist methods.

Title: Nepotism in the Arab World
Abstract:
The capstone project thesis is: nepotism and money laundering have corrupted Kuwait's
 judicial and democratic system by preventing the law from operating the way it should.
 It weakened the enforcement of the law and thus, justice was not served properly due
 to intervention from powerful authorities. The thesis explores the meaning of nepotism;
 its history and origins with a contrast between Confucianism and Islam. It discusses
 nepotism in other countries and considers current responses to nepotism in various
 countries. Nepotism in Kuwait is the focus of the thesis. The following factors of
 Kuwait are considered: legal system, National Assembly, politics and the Al Sabah
 family, the meaning of money laundering, Kuwait's law on money laundering, Malaysian
 Fund Case, Social Media Influencers case, and Bangladesh MP Shahid Islam case. The
 thesis concludes with an analysis of the three cases and possible remedies.

Title:
Examining Islamic Triple Talaq in India through the Perspectives of Gender and Human
                                 Rights
Abstract:
This research project focuses on the issue of Triple Talaq – also known as Talaq-e-biddat
 or Muslim instantaneous divorce – in India and the analysis of reforms related to
 the issue from the perspective of gender and human rights. This paper will be structured
 in two parts. The first examines the issue of Triple Talaq in India from a legal perspective,
 bringing forward landmark cases in the matter and relevant statutes. The second examines
 the issue and particularly, the reforms undertaken (including the landmark case Shayara
 Bano v. Union of India and Others and the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage)
 Act of 2019) from the lens of gender and human rights. The focus will be on gender
 equality, as a human right and framework of analysis. To do so, the research will
 engage cross-disciplinary interpretations and reconciliate the aforementioned perspectives
 with broader socio-legal analysis, including methodologies within feminist jurisprudence,
 to critically evaluate the amendments on Triple Talaq in India.

Title: The functioning of institutions in an independent Catalonia
Abstract:
This paper presents the hypothetical independence of Catalonia from the rest of Spain.
 The different sections create a journey through the history of internal and external
 conflicts in the region to understand the historical memory, an explanation of the
 functioning of national and local institutions as well as the formation of the so-called
 Historical Communities. The document explores what Catalonia would be like if it decided
 to become independent and what conditions the institutions and citizens of a new Catalan
 state would have to face.

Title:
Anxious Omnivores: Animal Ambivalence and Meat Ambiguity in Animals, Life of Pi, and
                                 The Year of the Flood
Abstract:
Major: LiteratureAbstract: This thesis examines the cultural politics and ethics of meat and meat-eating
 in three contemporary Canadian novels: Don LePan's Animals, 2009; Yann Martel's Life
 of Pi, 2001; and Margaret Atwood's The Year of the Flood, 2009. I argue that each
 novel contains a specific anxiety over whether—and under what conditions—eating meat
 is ethically justifiable, and that in each case this anxiety stems from questions
 about how humans draw distinctions between their own species and nonhuman animals.
 Each novel also demonstrates an awareness that these boundaries, both between humans
 and nonhumans and between different species of animals, are often arbitrary and subject
 to change. Fundamental human ambivalences in how to relate to different species of
 animals lead to the physical ambiguity of meat; acknowledging these ambivalences results
 in a "cannibal anxiety", or anxiety over whether eating nonhuman flesh is any different
 than eating human flesh. I will examine how these novels reveal or suggest ways of
 dealing with these ambiguities and their resultant anxieties, and how they challenge
 the reader to rethink both their meat-eating practices and their wider relationships
 to nonhuman animals in general.

Title: World Literature in Spanish: Realismo Mágico from Vela to García Màrquez
Abstract:
Major: LiteratureAbstract: This thesis explores the forgotten history of both world literature in Spanish
 and the circulation of magic realism through Madrid to Latin America. By telling these
 often untold stories, the thesis reevaluates current theories of world literature,
 as well as provides a new reading of magic realism as a genre and canonical magic
 realist texts such as One Hundred Years of Solitude.

Title:
Feminism, West African Fiction, and the Problem of Genre in Buchi Emecheta's "The
                                 Rape of Shavi"
Abstract:
Major: LiteratureAbstract: From Chinua Achebe to Buchi Emecheta, African writers have tended to write
 in a realist style. In creating realist narratives of resistance to colonialism and
 neocolonialism, these writers have implicitly cooperated with western literary critics
 who insist on reading literary works by African-born writers as anthropological accounts
 of life in "Africa." Nigerian-born author Buchi Emecheta's critical reputation was
 built around her early realist fiction, which critics continue to read as anthropological
 accounts of a universally African female experience. This paper reads Emecheta outside
 this critical paradigm by focusing on her only work of speculative fiction, The Rape
 of Shavi. Ultimately, reading Emecheta's work in relation to The Rape of Shavi suggests
 new modes of reading the canon of African women's fiction.

Title:
On leaving a little smarter: Navigating space and a "minor" identity in transvergent
                                 post-beur cinema
Abstract:
Major: Literature and Creative WritingAbstract: Cinéma beur has traditionally been treated as a sociological cinema documenting
 the 'real' French-Maghrebi experience. The young protagonists of Jacques Audiard's
 Un Prophète (2009) and Mohamed Hamidi's Né Quelque Part (2013) navigate between Frenchness,
 Arabness, and Muslimness in ways that render their complex identities institutionally
 irreconcilable. Throughout the films' narratives, they encounter changing conceptions
 of their overlapping identities in the context of their movements through spaces via
 temporal and metaphorical journeys within (and without) the French Republic.Borrowing Will Higbee's notion of 'post-beur' cinema, I argue that these films resist
 being read through the realist, sociological, and postcolonial lenses that differentiate,
 if not the films themselves, then the analyses that they invite, from the "beur" generation.
 They mark a departure towards a transvergent cinema that deconstructs notions of center
 and margins, incorporating Deleuze's rhizome towards a reading of how the features
 and inconsistencies of a racialized French society serve as catalysts towards these
 characters "becoming" minoritarian.

Title: Unsettling Nomadism: Becoming-Minor in Galsan Tschinag's Die Rückkehr
Abstract:
Major: Literature, HistoryAbstract: The study of non-ethnic German authors, of increasing importance to German
 literature, has traditionally focused only on those within Germany. The enigmatic
 work of Galsan Tschinag, however, a Tuvan Mongolian shaman and author of thirty books
 in German, provokes a radical re-imagination of the contours of German literary and
 linguistic history. His fictionalized autobiography Die Rückkehr: Roman meines Lebens
 [The Return: Novel of my Life], the most aesthetically self-conscious of his texts,
 invokes Mongol, Soviet, Tuvan, and European literary forms to weave together Central
 Asian and European histories. I read Die Rückkehr in conversation with Deleuze and
 Guattari's Toward a Minor Literature, whose emphasis on language as a deterritorialized,
 dynamic space of imagination, rather than an entity circumscribed by national boundaries,
 allows me to analyze Tschinag's work within the broader contexts of German and Mongolian
 literatures, and of minor literatures in general. The text's formal experimentation
 and staging of autobiographical truth through fiction allow the author to comment
 on both post-socialist Mongolia and contemporary Germany. By revealing the various
 traditions that converge in his work, I argue for a more integrated understanding
 of Eurasian history via German as a global language.

Title: 'The Time-Devouring Nightingale': Toward A Borgesian Conception of World Literature
Abstract:
Major: LiteratureAbstract: Many of Jorge Luis Borges's works reject linear understandings of time,
 allowing him to rewrite history and tradition. Borges uses translation to reshape
 his literary heritage, as well as his own national history. This practice is exemplified
 by his 1925 translation of the last page of James Joyce's Ulysses in the publication
 Proa, which recreates Ulysses in Buenos Aires and, when published, challenged conceptions
 of what Argentine literature should look like. His Antología de la literatura fantástica
 ('Anthology of Fantastic Literature'), which includes other translated portions of
 Ulysses, upsets traditional understandings of the canon, periods of literary history,
 and traditional practices of translation. My project explores Borges's unconventional
 understanding of chronology to consider how his literary texts unsettle orthodox understandings
 of world literature, as well as of Argentine history and literary tradition. An alternative
 conception of world literature based on a non-linear sense of time elucidates Borges's
 own works, as well as Joyce's Ulysses, and suggests how current dominant models of
 world literature could be reimagined.

Title:
Disorderly Time in Jhumpa Lahiri and Amitac Ghosh: Narrative Studies as a Strategy
                                 for Reading Migration Novels
Abstract:
This project relies on the field of narrative studies to demonstrate how migration
 novels by Lahiri and Ghosh espouse conceptions of migration temporalities that stray
 from the irreversible, often times oppressive, model of linear time. Employing concepts
 of narrative temporality, I argue that these texts attribute more agency to the fictional
 migrant and promote an optimistic sense of migration in which the homeland can be
 recovered from a shifting, malleable experience of time. This project thus highlights
 narrative form as a productive site where new conceptions of time and migration in
 literature can thrive and converge.

Title: Ra7ala
Abstract:
Ra7ala is a semi-autobiographical novella, that follows Leila, a young Egyptian woman
 who has recently re-discovered her Palestinian roots, as she goes to Palestine in
 search of her great-grandmother's house. This journey brings Leila face-to-face with
 her family's history and with questions about identity, loss, and diaspora. Leila's
 story also illustrates the nature of privilege, in that Leila is able to go on this
 journey with the thought that she will be able to return, and that she is able to
 determine for herself how she wants to be defined.

Title:
Angels of History: Feminist Politics of Autobiography and Historiography in Maja Haderlap's
                                 Angel of Oblivion and Assia Djebar's Fantasia: An Algerian Cavalcade
Abstract:
Using Maja Haderlap's 2011 Angel of Oblivion and Assia Djebar's 1985 Fantasia: An
 Algerian Cavalcade, this paper articulates a theoretical paradigm that rethinks subjectivity
 and temporality in order to affirm autobiographical narratives of grief as sites of
 historical revisionism. Reading the novels as autobiographies reveals the transformation
 of forms that dissolve the individual subject and give voice to the collective heritage
 of silenced women. The project draws on Walter Benjamin's notion of messianic time
 to call attention to the ways in which the novels interrupt patriarchal and imperialist
 productions of history. Bringing together these feminist and postcolonial autobiographies
 from disparate contexts elaborates an ethics and aesthetics of individual and collective
 mourning practices that force us to reexamine how we think about "history."

Title: بيت لبيت House to House
Abstract:
House to House is a collection of ethnographic, photographic, and text-image based
 poetry in which I present undocumented oral narratives of the diverse peoples of the
 Dubai Creek, including communities of Al Bastakiya, Al Shindagha, and Deira, mostly
 through details of the everyday, or what George Perec termed the "infraordinary."
 This work explores the blurred boundaries between memory and history, and how memory,
 in its fragmentation, reproduction, retelling, (and un-telling), eventually becomes
 its own kind of history.

Title: Wesam's Sister
Abstract:
The novella centers around questions of faith, self-discovery, and the difficulties
 confronting a Muslim family as it tries to preserve their Muslim identity in a Western
 city. This story is told from the perspective of Zahra Alim, an Iraqi-British eighteen-year-old
 returning to Edinburgh to clean out the dorm room of her sister, Dua, who has disappeared
 from college without a trace. Zahra stumbles upon a stack of letters Dua had written
 just before her disappearance and discovers that Dua lived a whole other life unbeknownst
 to her family. As she reads through the letters, Zahra faces the dilemma of whether
 or not to tell her parents about her sister's secret life. • My novella begins with
 "She looks at herself" – That is essentially what this whole project is about: self-discovery,
 reflection, but not only so, my novella is about looking back and understanding, empathizing
 and recognizing the struggles and actions of one's family – more specifically, a Muslim
 family in a Western society.

Title: Tayeb Salih's Season of Migration to the North Across Its Intertexts
Abstract:
This capstone studies the intertextual relationships within Tayeb Salih's Season of
 Migration to the North. As a postcolonial narrative, the novel straddles Eastern and
 Western literary traditions and uses these literary references to strategically resist
 any one reading. Intertextuality becomes a game under the hand of the novel: it is
 cognizant of the global literary landscape that it must participate in, with these
 various literary references becoming a performative exercise in striking the balance
 between disparate influences and cultures that a postcolonial novel comes out of.
 Gérard Genette's classification of transtextuality has been useful in understanding
 how different modes of intertextuality can work within the same space. Aamir Mufti's
 conception of World Literature highlights the cultural dynamics that underlie such
 references. Thinking with both highlights the need to re-evaluate how intertextuality
 fits within these new literary contexts. Season of Migration to the North seems to
 be anticipating space for a kind of postcolonial intertextuality, which owes a debt
 to theories of intertextuality while highlighting how such a technique becomes a strategic
 tool for a novel to insert itself into a universal library.

Title:
The Difficulties of Resistance: The Female Body as object in The Lament of the Dhobi
                                 Woman, The End of Innocence, and Fasting, Feasting
Abstract:
The paper explores the difficulty of resisting the patriarchy in three South Asian
 novels, The Lament of Dhobi Woman, The End of Innocence and Fasting, Feasting. The
 young female characters in the novels use their bodies as tools for resisting the
 patriarchy.

Title:
Writing as a Case of Performative Translation: A Reading of Valeria Luiselli's Fiction
                                 and Non-Fiction
Abstract:
This Capstone Project is an analysis of the fiction and non-fiction works of Mexican
 contemporary writer, Valeria Luiselli. This analysis seeks to conceptualize "performative
 translation" as a new term that refers broadly to the ways in which translation is
 built into the form and content of a text in its "original" iteration. The project
 operates on an understanding of translation as a creative practice. Finally, in proposing
 this new concept, the project emphasizes the relevance of Luiselli's work in introducing
 academic and non-academic works that encourage a rethinking of translation's capaciousness
 as an analytical concept and creative strategy for writing.

Title: Dear Nani Amma
Abstract:
Dear Nani Amma is a novella that explores the issues of diasporic death, the concept
 of home and the silences and absences that unfold in the life of a Pakistani family
 after a family member passes away. It centers around Safiya, a twelve-year-old girl,
 as she tries to grapple with the new family dynamics. She must take on a caretaker
 position, while at the same time dealing with her own anxieties being bullied at school.

Title: Erasure as Resistance: HOMO Sapienne in/as Contemporary Greenlandic Literature
Abstract:
I propose that through a radical contextualization of HOMO Sapienne—which considers
 the literary historical trajectory into which the novel inserts itself, the rhetorical
 disparagement of contemporary Greenlanders by their historical colonizers, and the
 market-facing considerations Korneliussen and her publisher might make to slate the
 novel for wider circulation among those former colonizers—we discover a unique rhetorical
 strategy in HOMO Sapienne that other postcolonial may emulate to maximize their readership
 without mollifying the potential anger of or discontent in their texts: Rather than
 verbalize any anger she may feel with Greenland's pre-post-colonial wounding by its
 former colonizers, Korneliussen writes Denmark out of existence, provincializing the
 former colonizing country and using erasure and non-representation not just to sublimate
 HOMO Sapienne's anger, but to amplify poignancy and impact.

Title: June
Abstract:
Life is lived at the fingertips. Through touch, through material, tactility. From
 building looms for my great-grandmother to quilting baby blankets and typing on a
 laptop, from weaving merino wool to rubbing the thin pages of the Bible between my
 fingers and holding my mother's hand as she holds the blanket I wove for her. The
 entirety of my life is nothing more than the story of my fingertips, what they have
 held, what they have transformed, and what they have yet to touch. Poetry is made
 by touch, either your fingers on a keyboard or holding a pen, and is experienced through
 touch on a page. The language of poetry is material and tactile, makes something from
 nothing, enacting change on the world around it; and thus, language is performative.
 My poetry reflects the things I have touched and the things that have touched me.
 June enacts the theoretical framework of anti-memoir in order to tell the story of
 a life through the tactile qualities of poetry and weaving.

Title: Fish Curry and Other Stories
Abstract:
Fish Curry and Other Stories is a project of documentation, of femininity and domesticity,
 of migration, and of the postcolonial variety. It is a collection of short stories
 inspired from the stories, legends, and collective memory of my Tamil-Brahmin family
 who moved from Palakkad and Kanyakumari to Mumbai, Maharashtra – essentially moving
 from a land on the border of two states to a borderless, cosmopolitan city. In this
 collection, I am particularly interested in the stake that a family like mine has
 on the city of Mumbai. I also explore the female experience of migration, as well
 as issues of caste and religion.

Title: A Storied Inheritance
Abstract:
A Storied Inheritance is a humorous piece of creative non-fiction that explores the
 complexities of locating "home." The piece puts my personal experiences as a South
 Asian-Canadian woman in conversation with the migration experiences of the women in
 my family. I examine this tradition of movement and carrying "real" and "unreal" memory
 through various forms such as memoir, dialogue and journalistic inquiry. This essay
 is an attempt at creating a humorous – sometimes absurd – narrative about diaspora,
 as opposed to one that is about nostalgia and loss.

Title: jazz/poetry: in a moment
Abstract:
How do we attempt to define jazz? Or poetry? And what materializes at the intersection
 of the two languages? My capstone comprises an artistic/research exploration about
 the 'genre' of jazz poetry, followed by my own creative work, titled in a moment.

Title: Caminante en Nueva York
Abstract:
Caminante en Nueva York is a work of non-fiction about walking in New York. Walking
 is portrayed as a way for traveling through time and space, for meeting new people
 and for navigating reality while staying offline. Whenever the eye meets something
 new, it fixates on it to understand it through multiple lenses. It's the author's
 memoir of her time spent in New York, and a collection of walking propositions for
 thinking and using the city and the body.

Title: Noah
Abstract:
This capstone is a speculative fiction work and is a hybrid between a screenplay and
 prose. It follows the story of a young African American man named Noah who grows up
 in Reality 6, where slavery never happened. He discovers Reality 12 (our reality),
 where slavery was a part of history, and the more he learns about the inadequacies
 of his world, the more he becomes frustrated about his own Black identity. Encouraged
 by his mentor Harriet, he decides to leave Reality 6 and venture to Reality 12. However,
 he gets trapped there. What was initially supposed to be a quick visit turns into
 a journey of Noah discovering what a black identity looks like to him and uncovering
 more about himself than he thought possible.

Title:
Preserving Hong Kong's Postcoloniality: An Analysis of Leung Ping Kwan and Louise
                                 Ho's Poetry
Abstract:
For ages, Hong Kong was known as a "cultural desert" that merely took on the culture
 of its British colonizer. It was only when Hong Kong identity faced the "double trauma
 of the signing of the Sino-British Joint Declaration of 1984 followed by the Tiananmen
 Massacre of 1989" did people realize that "the Hong Kong way of life with its mixture
 of colonialist and democratic trappings was in imminent danger of disappearing" (Abbas
 6-7). The 1997 Handover, which, marked the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule, then,
 became a deadline against which the city's writers utilized different strategies to
 preserve Hong Kong's postcolonial identity, to resist the imminent threat of identity
 decolonization and potentially, recolonization. This thesis specifically will investigate
 the specific strategies used by Leung Ping Kwan and Louise Ho in their poetry to preserve
 Hong Kong's postcolonial identity, looking towards yet another deadline in 2047- when
 the "One Country, Two Systems" arrangement that currently governs Hong Kong is set
 to expire.

Title: Grotesque Melancholies
Abstract:
'Grotesque Melancholies' is a long poem that sets out to explore the balance between
 Eva's own creative voice and her passion for the work of T.S. Eliot. We follow the
 speaker as she navigates her way around London and the city's history in conversation
 with Eliot, and witness a 21st century Waste Land build up around her.

Title: Self Help: Grief Rituals
Abstract:
The capstone is a creative self-help guide on how to grieve. I explore, through multiple
 forms of poetry, the messiness of grief. There is no prescription for how to grieve.
 This project offers a different trajectory to grieving. It aims to circulate emotions
 and ideas and allows the reader to really think about those who have left us, in their
 day to day life. It does not offer a solution but offers company to those who read
 it.

Title: Strings
Abstract:
Strings is a novella-length character study of a fictional figure, Hamza. It comes
 as no surprise that Hamza could not stay. He was born a 'stringless' child, without
 an umbilical cord, that was a sign. When he sets off to New York in pursuit of his
 long-lost youth, he never looks back. His estranged son endangers Hamza's new life
 plan when he gets into legal trouble and needs his father's help. A tale about fatherhood
 and escapism, it is a story about a man that tries to untangle himself from the life
 he's been prescribed.

Title: The Blunt Edge of Modern Sports Manga: Ironic Medium of Female Realities
Abstract:
Modern sports manga rarely features female characters as main protagonists; they are
 almost always on the sidelines. When they take on a more active role in the narrative,
 it is to be in the service of others. This capstone project sought to understand the
 nature of sports manga's "soft power" in contemporary culture through exploring the
 connection between the conservatism of sports manga's gender politics and its popularity.
 This conservatism is the lingering legacy of Japan's encounters with Western attitudes
 and ideals, especially in terms of athleticism and womanhood, which have been adapted
 into Japanese cultural norms. Examples included deference to hierarchy and images
 of masculine strength. The prevalence of such norms, as evidenced by its representation
 on the pages of modern sports manga like Furudate Haruichi's Haikyū!!, this project's
 case study text, hinders modern manga from realizing its full potential to be progressive.

Title:
The Trouble with Utopias and Humans: Posthumanism in Politics and Folklore in Arkady
                                 and Boris Strugatsky's Monday Starts on Saturday and Tale of the Troika
Abstract:
"Like all science," says Roman Oira-Oira, "our work deals with human happiness." Oira-Oira,
 one of the most respected employees of the National Institute for the Technology of
 Witchcraft and Thaumaturgy (NITWiT), announces this claim in the first chapter of
 Arkady and Boris Strugatsky's utopian novel Monday Starts on Saturday (1965). Within
 the text, his statement is not hyperbolic: the fictional Institute is centered around
 improving the human condition and contains a Department of Linear Human Happiness,
 a Department of the Meaning of Life, and a Department of Eternal Youth. This project
 examines different ideas of utopia – political, scientific, and literary – within
 a cycle of hope and disillusionment as the narration shifts from the realistic to
 the fantastical in both Monday Starts on Saturday and its sequel Tale of the Troika
 (1968). I look at how different conceptions of human nature intertwine and conflict
 with utopian visions within the Soviet communist ideology, expressed through representations
 of folkloric characters and magic systems. By zooming in on the mechanics behind the
 fantastical, this project crafts an analytical approach to deconstructing utopia and
 understanding human nature.

Title: The Liminality of Visual Novels
Abstract:
Visual novels are a form of video game that occupy an odd space within the label of
 "video games," but there is something odd about them: although they are considered
 video games, most of the gaming experience consists of reading and experiencing a
 narrative. Gameplay usually consists of choice-making moments where the narrative
 flow stops for the player to make a decision, and the choice will alter how the story
 plays out. Since VNs have this gameplay factor in them, they have never been theorised
 as part of Literature. But since their gameplay is limited and most of their focus
 is on story, they are not theorised as part of Game Studies either. Through three
 analyses, I find a way to read visual novels using elements from both literary analysis
 and game analysis but enabling for a better reading of visual novels as forms of art.

Title: Hawak
Abstract:
"Hawak" is a novella about an aswang, a local monster from Filipino urban legend that
 feeds on unborn children, that awakens in modern-day Baguio city. It is a story about
 female communities and bridging gaps between women of different social backgrounds
 through the body of the monster. It seeks to retake ownership over the figure of the
 aswang that has long been transformed after years of colonization in order to address
 modern issues that women face today. "Hawak" also serves as a response to Filipino
 Literary History that hopes to expand the role of women and their characterization,
 transitioning from the domestic and expanding outwards into the world.

Title: The Sample Book
Abstract:
The Sample Book' is a manuscript of prose, lists and collections of my memories of
 growing up in Dubai. It is an attempt at recording the ordinary in order not to forget
 or be forgotten.

Title: What Remains: الطلل
Abstract:
This capstone examines how Hurricane Katrina (and natural disasters in general) impacted
 cultural transmission in the Lebanese diaspora in Mississippi.

Title: Na'ila's Eyes
Abstract:
If you have ever lived in Al Ain then you know it's not really a place. Al Ain is
 an event in your life and once it's over you look back on it with the same incredulous
 wonder that you might consider a vivid dream. My capstone is a novel that explores
 Al Ain and the unseen djinn city that exists on the other side of it: Na'ila. Harper
 is a young woman from Canada who escapes her small-town life by agreeing to study
 for a semester at a university in Al Ain. Aisha is a young djinn who has just received
 her visa to enter Na'ila where she'll be working as a maid for one of the most powerful
 djinn families: the Raaeds. Their stories intertwine when Aisha begins to visit Al
 Ain and Harper falls in love with Majed-- one of the Raaed brothers. When Harper finds
 out she's pregnant the Raaeds decide the baby belongs to them. Aisha might be the
 only one who can keep Harper and the baby safe.

Title:
"In accord with more universal vibrations": Totality, Race, and Gender in Teju Cole's
                                 Open City
Abstract:
My capstone offers a reading of the 2011 novel Open City by Teju Cole through the
 lens of aesthetic theory and the concept of novelistic totality. The problem animating
 my paper is the rape of Moji Kasali, a Nigerian acquaintance of the novel's narrator,
 Julius. Moji accuses Julius of having raped her when he was fourteen and she fifteen.
 My capstone is shaped by Moji's accusation. In my paper, I consider Moji's rape to
 be the founding rupture of the novel: Open City arises, in other words, in response
 to this disastrous event in Moji's and Julius's lives. Troubled by the rape — which
 he has forgotten — and by its reminder through Moji's accusation, Julius, I suggest,
 writes Open City as an attempt to recreate the innocent, pre-lapsarian wholeness that
 was lost when he raped Moji. Along the way his attempt at totality is disturbed by
 race, gender, history, all three embodied foremost by Moji.

Title: The End of the World and Other Experiments
Abstract: This collection of short stories explores form, style and voice in storytelling.

Title: Cranes
Abstract:
Cranes is a collection of poetry and creative non-fiction bridging cosmopolitanism
 and women of color (WOC). Spanning four sections – taking off, flight, orbit, and
 land – the book follows the voice of a flâneuse, navigating different "cosmopolitan"
 cities like Abu Dhabi, New York, and Paris. But all cities have histories, which have
 created different unjust systems that affect the WOC's mobility and conception of
 self today. How can her body then exist with difference, and still keep and construct
 her own autonomous identity, intact? I argue for love, the creative space, and community
 as solutions, spaces where the WOC can rebuild a self on her own terms.

Title: Amani
Abstract:
Amani is a young adult novella about three girls who share the same soul. Amani is
 a middle-class 17-year-old who stumbles upon a BuzzFeed quiz that asks whether she's
 curious about her fate. Curious, Amani starts a free trial that embarks her on a journey
 of seeing and constructing her alternate lives: Naima and Amina. As the trial counts
 down, Amani decides and observes a snapshot of an event that happens every year in
 each of the girls' lives. The trial is counting down, and Amani has to decide her
 favorite fate. Which will she decide? And what will it be based on? This novella digs
 deep into how privilege and choice come in various shapes and forms and highlights
 the reality of how humans react to the environments they find themselves in.

Title:
Between and Across the ʿAjāʾib, Riḥla, and Kommentaranthologie Traditions: Toward
                                 an Encyclopedic Reading of Yūsuf al-Shirbīnī's Hazz al-quḥūf (fl
Abstract:
In this thesis I propose to read Yūsuf al-Shirbīnī's Hazz al-quḥūf (fl. 1686)
 in light of the encyclopedic ethos that permeated the postclassical period (13th–18th
 centuries) in Arabic literary history. In the introduction, I show that scholars have
 considered it either a historical text or a literary one—but never both (or neither).
 I situate Hazz in the ʿajāʾib and riḥla traditions to explore questions of fact,
 fiction, ethnography, and, ultimately, encyclopedism. I read al-Shirbīnī contra
 Evliya Çelebi's Seyahâtnâme. This reading reveals a textual epistemology that is
 not concerned with fact per se, but with truth-value. Next, I turn to the questions
 of structure and genre; I explore the structure of Hazz. I draw on Gilles Deleuze
 and Félix Guattari's notion of the rhizome to theorize the structure of the Kommentaranthologie.
 I also engage Jacques Derrida's discussion of the "supplement" and his "law of genre"
 to theorize how Hazz exceeds the genre it situates itself in. I then speculate about
 the possible social purpose of the text's structure. Finally, I reflect on this thesis's
 contribution to undoing the problematic inḥiṭāṭ narrative, and explore alternative
 pathways to problematize this paradigm by situating the text within (a) Mediterranean
 literary history.

Title: An English Translation of Christmas in Mecca by Ahmad Khairi Al-Omari
Abstract:
My Capstone is a translation of some parts of the Arabic novel Christmas fi Mecca,
 or Christmas in Mecca. A diasporic Iraqi family, torn by war, reunites in Mecca over
 Christmas break. Western and Arab traditions, habits, and values collide in the individual
 family members, and the regrets of the past linger along with the uncertainties of
 the present. This novel explores family ties, the history of Baghdad, and the relationships
 between different religious sects, as told by five character perspectives.

Title: Television Dreams & Other Poems
Abstract:
A collection of poetry using cross-genre writing, documentary poetry, and verbatim
 writing to explore rage and haunting in the context of diasporic queer Palestinian
 experience.

Title: Painful Laughter: An Analysis of Comedy in the Discourse of #MeToo
Abstract:
This capstone project is a comparative analysis of two recent and extremely popular
 standup comedy specials, The Bird Revelation by Dave Chappelle and Nanette by Hannah
 Gadsby. My analysis uncovers how these comedians engage with the #MeToo movement using
 standup comedy and highlights the comic strategies they use to make their argument
 onstage and off. A hallmark of these specials is the willingness of the comedian to
 make the audience feel uncomfortable, which results in quite unique comedy specials
 that make several formal innovations. Ultimately, what the comedians argue in their
 specials has consequences for how we consider standup comedy and its potential for
 social reform in the #MeToo era.

Title: Afterwards: Five Tales Written in the After
Abstract:
This short story collection is a personal project that reflects on and records specific
 moments that I have experienced during my time at NYUAD, but in fictionalized form.
 It is a diary that records striking or overwhelming memories that have pushed me to
 reevaluate what to hold on to in life. By writing these tales, I aimed to move away
 from the memories that each character manifests, and towards an afterwards; the fact
 that there exists such an afterwards—that I got to step away from the past and materialize
 snippets of valuable thoughts and feelings on paper—is what matters. The project consists
 of a lyric poem and five short stories that are different in setting, narrative style
 and form, and point of view. While each story centers on the keyword of "after-life,"
 it also stretches for something bigger than the boundaries of an afterlife. Each character
 encounters some experience with death, but more so, find themselves alone and isolated
 from the rest of the world. Join these vulnerable characters on a journey of loneliness
 and fragility, as they navigate and grapple their way through life and contemplate
 what is to be left afterwards.

Title: Poothan and Thira
Abstract:
This submission from my novella is inspired by the mythology of the small village
 of Thozupadam in the state of Kerala, India. At the centre of the lore and legends
 lies the Poothan and Thira, an artistic ritual performance that has been around for
 over 200 years. This novella aims to reflect the village's growing concerns about
 religious and cultural heritage disappearing, by following the life of a boy named
 Kutty and his family who have inherited the ritual. When prompted by a choice between
 preserving tradition and promising opportunities outside the village, Kutty's beliefs
 in the village gods, demons, and magic stagger as he grows. The ghouls of the village
 send one of their own, Poothan, on a task to regain Kutty's faith. The supernatural
 entities must ensure that the boy fulfils his fate of inheriting the ritual himself
 so that the cycle of tradition is undisrupted, and so that their survival is not threatened,
 even if revival requires unorthodox means.

Title: Thoo!
Abstract:
In an alternate timeline, the city of Abu Dhabi is made out of buildings controlled
 by the PES, a mechanical system that expels residents from their apartments when it
 is their time to leave. The fictional novel follows Anaswara, a Malayali expat woman
 born and brought up in this city. Anaswara is now a 25-year old researcher who digs
 deeper into her childhood home and writes about her life in the PES. However, her
 past comes crashing into the present when an old friend, Nourah, contacts her to help
 with an investigation that connects together a series of deaths from 2008, to the
 PES system crash in 2015—the same one that forced Anaswara and her family out of Abu
 Dhabi. This capstone is a novel-in-progress and what you read is about 1/3rd of the
 complete novel.

Title:
Writings of Oceania: Examining Postcolonial Identity in Satendra Nandan's "The Wounded
                                 Sea"
Abstract:
Oceanian studies, particularly under Epeli Hau'ofa, has traditionally looked at identity
 through the ocean and land— land as the root of Oceanian history and culture, ocean
 as an extension of those roots. Additionally, the field has been characterized by
 its rejection of misconceived Oceanian "smallness," which has belittled the region
 socio-politically and geographically. But if scholars such as Epeli Hau'ofa refer
 to Oceanian lands as the root of Oceanian identity, then what of those who, under
 colonialism, were forcibly brought to labor on that very land? This paper seeks to
 expand upon such frameworks of Oceanian postcolonial studies in regard to identity
 and "smallness," and aims to examine them through an analysis of Satendra Nandan's
 "The Wounded Sea". Firstly, this paper argues that "The Wounded Sea" explores Oceanian
 identity on the national and regional level; and, that the novel not only interrogates
 the pillars of Oceanian identity— land and ocean— but also renders them active agents
 in reasserting Indo-Fijian belonging. Secondly, this paper argues that the "The Wounded
 Sea" is an Oceanian novel that pushes back against conceived Oceanian "smallness,"
 by engaging in wider discourses of literature and genre, and ultimately situating
 itself in a larger postcolonial literary tradition.

Title: Star Wars and the Eco-Politics of Survival
Abstract:
From the scrappy Millennium Falcon to barren, backwater planets, the Star Wars universe
 revolves around junk, trash, and waste. Through the perspective of material ecocriticism,
 however, representations of so-called "dead" matter in Star Wars reveal how nonhuman
 elements of the environment are never truly inanimate. These representations prompt
 us to recognize the surprising "force of things," an experience which Jane Bennett
 summarizes as "thing-power," or "the curious ability of inanimate things to animate,
 to act, to produce effects dramatic and subtle" (Vibrant Matter 6). This capstone
 expands the boundaries of material ecocriticism, which has demonstrated relatively
 little interest in the thing-power of media, while bringing material ecocriticism
 to popular cinema. I analyze stereotypically inanimate matter or "lesser" life-forms
 (such as the Tusken Raiders, the Death Star, and carbonite) to argue that Star Wars
 casts the nonhuman as agentic across its sprawling storyworlds. Along the way, I track
 how eco-philosophy evolves throughout almost fifty years of Star Wars history. Analyzing
 Star Wars as a global transmedia phenomenon illuminates how our media environments
 and natural environments are enmeshed, embedded, and continuously interact. Ultimately,
 Star Wars advocates for an eco-politics of survival by expanding the definition of
 the "Anthropos" in the Anthropocene.

Title:
Recreating Performance Styles of Fats Waller, Erroll Garner, and Art Tatum Through
                                 Computer Programming
Abstract:
Major: Music, EconomicsAbstract: I created a computer program using Max, a visual programming language, to
 generate jazz piano solos that imitate the performance styles of Fats Waller, Erroll
 Garner, and Art Tatum. I explored the limitations of computer programming by first
 transcribing their performance recordings, analyzing patterns in their performance
 styles, and recreating jazz melodies according to these identified patterns that were
 encoded into the program.

Title: AUHDIO
Abstract:
Major: Music. Online Project. Abstract: A monthly live music showcase and platform
 that features live music in unconventional and underutilized venues with the goal
 of vitalizing the music scene of Abu Dhabi.

Title: Ámame como Amas: A Music Capstone
Abstract:
Ámame como Amas is a four-song EP that intersects with three different languages and several musical
 styles. It features covers of well known songs that rotate through the languages of
 English, Arabic, and Spanish, and the genres of electropop, Cuban and modern pop salsa,
 and traditional Arabic music. This EP brings together three groups of musicians thoroughly
 familiar with these styles of music so that their specialties might combine without
 facing the boundaries usually in place between their respective genres. The choice
 of English, Arabic, and Spanish reflects my personal experience of studying these
 languages and some of the musical and vocal traditions that have developed alongside
 them.

Title:
Music, Voice, and Agency: Response Mechanisms of Politically Marginalized Groups and
                                 the Case of the Rastafari Minority in Ethiopia
Abstract:
This research project uses Minorities at Risk (MAR) data and an original ethnographic
 dataset to examine how politically marginalized groups respond to exclusion. Drawing
 on Albert Hirschman's theory of exit, voice, and loyalty, my analysis reveals global
 patterns in minority responses, while my case study of the Rastafari provides insight
 into the complex politics of inclusion and exclusion in Ethiopia from the 1950s to
 the present. Both these datasets demonstrate that groups who are excluded establish
 political agency through different modes of voice, which, in Rastafari communities,
 takes the form of Ethiopian reggae music. Although my research indicates that groups
 with political representation are more likely to express dissent through pressure
 group tactics, it suggests also that music can serve as an important platform for
 envisioning and negotiating political and cultural inclusion in the absence of formal
 representation.

Title: Unheard Of: Creating Cinematic Soundscapes
Abstract:
Unheard Of: Creating Cinematic Soundscapes comprised of developing all audio components
 for the following four film capstones: Alma (Jime Reyes), Acheevment (Gergő Varga),
 Mahaa (Yunbo Wu), and Thirty (Yi Yi Yeap). These audio components included my assumption
 of all the following roles:• Production Sound Mixer, Boom Operator, Sound Editor • Producer, Sound Designer, Music Supervisor• Composer, Performer, Recording Engineer• Foley Supervisor, Foley Artist, Foley Mixer• ADR Supervisor, ADR Mixer• Mixing EngineerThe motivation of the capstone project came from my desire to explore further my previous
 experiences in designing music and sound for films and theater performances, specifically
 the notion and conscious use of silence (or lack thereof) in creating an effective
