 sonic ambience. The question of using silence with emotional impact is in response
 to film director Henri Colpi's quote, "Above all, no gaps or holes, cry filmmakers
 with alarm. And if hole there be, plug it up with music," and offers a counterexample
 of using non-musical elements – in line with musical elements – to elicit similar
 emotional response.

Title:
Symbolic Oscillations: Using Feedback to Augment Parameter Relationships in Digital
                                 Music Systems
Abstract:
This paper suggests that the implementation of tactile feedback works towards restoring
 embodied cognitive relationships in digital music systems. I ask whether we may use
 tactile feedback in another manner, for example, to augment symbolic relationships
 by physicalizing the relations between sound variables and synthesis processes in
 digital music systems. This departs from the discussion of how digital instruments
 engage users in hermeneutic processes of cognition, in contrast to processes of embodied
 cognition, more typical of the relationship established with acoustic instruments.
 Finally, I propose the design and construction of an interactive digital synthesizer
 system to explore and test the ideas discussed in this paper.

Title: Blending Technology, Virtual Instruments, and Live Performers in Music Scoring
Abstract:
The paper describes the framework that is introduced by me, which aims at blending
 virtual instruments, live performers, robotic instruments, and controllers together
 in a concert environment in a form of an orchestral piece of music that is approximately
 40 minutes long. Somewhat similar framework, known as hybrid score, is largely used
 in film music production. The largest difference of the approach described in the
 paper is that it utilizes multichannel audio as the main feature of the virtual instruments'
 sound reproduction, creating the feeling of listening to a live full orchestra.

Title: Sonido Bogotano
Abstract:
This ethnography follows closely the lives and works of young upper-middle class men
 who are a part of what is understood to be the emerging "alternative music" scene
 of Bogota, Colombia. Based on four months of fieldwork, this ethnography tells the
 story of what it is like to be a struggling musician in a large city with ever-growing
 cultural offers. In my work, I theorize scene building in the context of popular music,
 and explore the relationship between art, place, and the imagination. Ultimately,
 I propose that the city of Bogota is the main character in a popular music scene that
 is otherwise characterized by its musical heterogeneity.

Title: Romanian Folk Music and Dubstep: Recontextualizing Folk Styles in Contemporary Forms
Abstract:
Fusions of music styles are happening all over the world, to the extent that it oftentimes
 becomes questionable to which genre a certain piece pertains. Intermixtures between
 contemporary styles and folk music are important because of their ability to revive
 old genres that are not as present in the lives of today's generations anymore. This
 paper explores ways to create such fusions between Romanian folk music and the Electronic
 Dance Music genre "Dubstep" through three versions of the Romanian folk song "Ca pe
 luncă" created in the Digital Audio Workstation Logic Pro. The first version is simply
 a recreation of "Ca pe luncă" with digital and recorded instruments. The second version
 was created with the intention of keeping a larger amount of the Romanian piece intact,
 preserving its meter and tempo. The last version was made to preserve the meter and
 tempo of the Dubstep genre, thus keeping more of its main characteristics.

Title:
Analyzing the transformative effects of Music Production on the Expressive Value of
                                 a Composition
Abstract:
Through this capstone I aim to examine how music production can act as a medium to
 de-contextualize and re- contextualize a piece of music and affect its expressive
 value by influencing its composition, lyrics, arrangement and sonic characteristics.
 I will do so by producing the same song 5 different ways and reflecting upon the expressive
 transformation that occurs.

Title: Narrated Liquid Contaminants
Abstract:
Narrated Liquid Contaminants is a 15-speaker sound installation divided into 4 zones,
 each following a theme of contamination; from E-waste to human-caused pollution, naturally
 caused contamination, and viral contaminants. Each zone has dedicated contaminated
 bottles with touch sensors at the bottom which once triggered, initiate visual projection
 and soundscapes. The audience then interacts with photoresistors on the bottles by
 casting a shadow over the projection, altering the soundscapes of curated field recordings.
 This project embodies a form of situated listening that addresses topics of contaminated
 waterbodies and the effect they play on the environment. Water is used as a medium
 to conceptually portray flows of contamination, replicating those existing in the
 natural environment, and sound as a channel of narration, accompanied by video. The
 mediums connect with each other once interacted with via physical touch or shadow
 movement, letting the installation act as a means of situating the audience in an
 altering soundscape by participating in the narrative rather than being passive observers;
 a reflection on our co-existent relationship and active contribution to our surrounding
 environments.

Title: Past, Present, Palimpsest: Hungarian Folk Music's Performance Evolution
Abstract:
This Capstone Project occupies the domain of practice research, in that its key questions
 are posed through an engagement and intermingling of my own practice, others' practice/s,
 and the supporting musicological and philosophical literature. My key area of problematicity
 is concerned with notions of authenticity in Hungarian folk music, and especially
 folk music involving vocal performance. It considers folk music as an evolving tradition
 that is not restricted by a modern-day understanding of geographical borders; time
 period; or performance practice. Such a conception challenges the notion of folk music
 as a 'fixed', 'pure', and 'authentic' form of music, and consequently a static performance
 practice; a perception that is still surprisingly commonly held by some scholars,
 performers, and audiences in parts of Hungarian society today. My Capstone work aims
 to draw from the past by previewing the future, placing folk songs in a perpetual
 present that is constantly adapting, influencing, and being influenced.

Title:
Towards a sustainable career as a post-millennial singer/songwriter: A Step-by-Step
                                 Guide to Independence in the Music Business
Abstract:
Success in the music industry is not the same as it was a few generations ago. Building
 a career as an independent artist is changing with shifting expectations from all
 the stakeholders in the music business. Additionally, the emergence of multimedia,
 streaming platforms, and blockchain technologies, create more complex environments
 for emerging artists to navigate. In this study, I present a roadmap that will facilitate
 the process of releasing music for post-millennial independent singers/songwriters
 with consideration for all new variables in the market. In developing this roadmap,
 I analyze recent developments in the most important domains that an independent singer/songwriter
 needs to know about. These domains include (i) legal frameworks in the music business,
 (ii) marketing and distribution strategies, and (iii) monetization in the music business.
 I also analyze my experience in composing, producing, and releasing two songs in the
 form of contributions to this work to demonstrate where important domains overlay
 in practice. My goal, through this step-by-step guide, is to support emerging artists
 starting from zero to promote their music independently and who want to develop a
 sustainable career in Pop music.

Title: Thoughtcrimes: Investigating the Creative Process Through a Self-Study
Abstract:
This capstone project is a practice-based research that explores the creative process
 through the composing of a music piece for string quartet. It examines the nature
 of creative thoughts, the questions that ground an artistic vision, and the practical
 challenges faced in such an undertaking. In both the music and the critical reflection
 of this project there is constant struggle between what I believe music should be,
 and the desire to push outside of that limiting preconception.

Title: Departure: a staged song cycle
Abstract:
Departure is a staged song cycle that consists of seven original songs. These songs
 are sung by a semi-autobiographical character, Jenna, who is portrayed at three different
 ages (12, 24, and 36) of her life by three actors. The 30-minute cycle explores the
 emotional complexities associated with departure of many kinds, while reminiscing
 about the innocence of youth and contemplating the uncertainty of the future. The
 project aims to address the following questions: How can song cycles depict a narrative
 and explore psychological states, and how can they be enhanced by staging? How could
 I write a song cycle with a consistent theme of departure while portraying vignettes
 of a character's growth over time? How can a theatrical impulse shape the process
 of songwriting? Moreover, how can I create semi-autobiographical female roles that
 are different from superficial archetypes?

Title:
Problematizing 19th Century Western Conceptions of the East in Contemporary Vocal
                                 Repertoire
Abstract:
My project centers on an exploration of the East and its conception in the West, as
 found in vocal repertoire of the 19th century, and consists of a research paper and
 a formal recital presenting vocal works from both traditions. This project aims to
 provide answers to the primary question, 'can practice research help us understand
 manifestations of the East in 19th century Western vocal repertoire?' I approach this
 question by understanding and using key concepts and methods of practice research,
 by researching concepts of Orientalism and wider Orientalist themes, by recounting
 my personal artistic journey exploring my Sri Lankan vocal heritage, and by studying
 Western repertoire from the same period and by problematizing vocal technique in the
 performance of works from both traditions in a formal recital. Western repertoire
 was selected from French Operas and German Lieder. Eastern repertoire was exclusively
 taken from the oral tradition of Sri Lanka which includes folk song, religious music
 and literary quatrains of courier poems, all of which would have been performed during
 the 19th century in Sri Lanka (Ceylon).

Title:
Traversion of Memories, Time, and Place through Songwriting in the Form of a Song
                                 Cycle entitled Postcards: An Artistic Research
Abstract:
The recollection of memories within realms of places and through periods of time has
 been a thematical link that several artists explored in their artworks via different
 artistic media. Songwriting, as a form of storytelling, can serve as one of these
 tools to allow personal recollections to take shape and be conceptually presented
 in a narrative-like structure. At the same time, the way we listen to and experience
 music, such as songs, is affected by the construction of performative space and its
 ability to create a certain environment in which the audience positions itself. Historically,
 culturally, and socially, spaces allow listeners to interact with music in a distinct
 manner, from liturgical music presented in cathedrals through musical theatre performances
 placed within imagined sceneries to sound installations displayed in public spaces.
 Drawing on conceptions of the power of songwriting as well as constructed space and
 its effect on audience interaction, this paper investigates the traversion of memories,
 time, and place through the exploration of songwriting in the form of an autobiographical
 song cycle entitled Postcards.

Title: Live Room
Abstract:
Live Room is an audiovisual installation presenting 25 minutes of recorded original
 music exploring fragmented notions of presence and identity in the digital age, particularly
 in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. Structurally, the installation explores the
 naturalization of surrealism in both musical performance and in broader conceptions
 of engagement with electronic media. Spatiality is the primary area of experimentation
 in this project. The project engages with these topics at musical, visual, and methodological
 levels, as the concepts within the artistic material are reflected, or perhaps refracted,
 by their modes of transmission and reception in the installation. Acoustic space,
 innately embedded in time, is condensed, manipulated, and framed in new temporal environments
 through the layered operations of performance, recording, signal processing, and dispersion
 in the room. Audio-reactive distortion of the filmed performance interplays with mirrors
 and curtains in the room, and visual space becomes digitally distorted and physically
 fragmented. Dictated by the dynamics in the music, as well as the structures and surfaces
 in the space, the ocular experience is fluid and nonlinear, and the presence of the
 audience becomes the only constant in the installation.

Title: Vibing Solo: Investigating How Emotional Labor Manifests in Individual Music Practices
Abstract:
In this capstone project, I comparatively study the nuances of producing music remotely
 "in the box" and in the recording studio. I explore whether there is a relationship
 between music-making and in-person interaction and investigate whether working in
 a strictly remote format - mimicking the virtual nature of the pandemic - influences
 the vibe of the music-making process in any way. For the purpose of my research, I
 use scholars Allan Watson's and Jenna Ward's discussions on emotional labor (Watson
 and Ward 2013) as well as Teresa Brennan's work on affect theory (Brennan 2015), as
 a foundational theoretical framework from which I define and base my discussions on
 vibe, emotion, and affect in the process of music-making. My research specifically
 attempts to create a framework for understanding how emotional labor manifests itself
 in solo music-making practices with non-sentient entities.

Title: Dark Matter as an Instance of Duhem's Problem: A Bayesian Analysis
Abstract:
Major: PhilosophyAbstract: This paper applies the structure of Bayesian confirmation theory to new
 questions in theoretical physics, in particular to those surrounding the observations
 that have led to the hypothesis of dark matter. I argue that observations used as
 evidence for dark matter are relevant examples of Duhem's problem in confirmation
 theory. Using Bayesian analysis, I calculate the conditional probabilities of several
 different ways of accounting for the unexpected observations, and attempt to discern
 which are justified as explanations. I conclude that relatively unpopular alternatives
 to dark matter theories, like modified Newtonian mechanics (MOND), deserve greater
 scrutiny in light of these calculations.

Title: A New Trivialization Objection to the Statistical Solution to the Generality Problem
Abstract:
Major: PhilosophyAbstract: This thesis examines James R. Beebe's statistical solution to the generality
 problem for process reliabilism. Beebe's solution employs concepts from cognitive
 science along with a mechanism of statistical relevance to pick out a unique process
 type. I argue that Beebe's view cannot rule out process types defined by periods
 of time, and because of this, the view falls victim to a trivialization. Beebe's
 view yields the result that true beliefs are maximally justified and false beliefs
 are maximally unjustified. I explore several strategies to avoid the temporal types
 trivialization and ultimately find them to be unsatisfactory.

Title: Conundrums in Compatibilism: Manipulation and Identity
Abstract:
Major: Philosophy, Political ScienceAbstract: In this paper, I endeavour to lay out some of the virtues and flaws of the
 prominent historical compatibilist account proposed by John Fischer and Mark Ravizza
 in Responsibility and Control: A Theory of Moral Responsibility. Specifically I aim
 to demonstrate that making the notion of identity salient enables Fischer and Ravizza
 to more adequately deal with certain local and global manipulation cases that are
 commonly thought to be problematic cases for compatibilists. However, this approach
 is open to historical and non-historical compatibilists alike and thus considerations
 of identity may ultimately lend support to non-historical compatibilist views by decreasing
 the force of counterexamples facing these accounts.

Title: Against Concept Empiricism
Abstract:
Major: PhilosophyAbstract: My capstone is an argument against concept empiricism as presented by the
 philosopher Jesse Prinz. Concept empiricism is a claim that all concepts are perceptually
 based. I explore what it means to be perceptually based and then offer two main arguments
 against concept empiricism.In my first argument I explore how the modular nature of face processing hints at
 the existence of an innate and complex 'face' concept. I argue how and the innate
 nature of this complex 'face' concept poses a threat to concept empiricism. The second line of argument is the more common strand of arguing against concept empiricism.
 I argue that there might be non-innate complex concepts that we learn about later
 on in our lives that can't possibly be perceptually based. I demonstrate this argument
 using the example of Minkowski Space-Time.

Title: Towards a Better Theory of Admissibility in Supervaluationism
Abstract:
Major: PhilosophyAbstract: Supervaluationism posits that a vague statement is true if it is true on
 all admissible precisifications of its vague terms. However, many prominent philosophers
 have often punted on giving a concrete theory of what 'admissible' means, often leaving
 it a primitive term and at best associating it with 'appropriate' or 'correct'. I
 suggest two alternative theories for defining 'admissible', which overcome some of
 the problems that primitive concepts of it encounter, such as higher-order vagueness
 and inaccessibility of meaning facts. I finally compare these alternative theories,
 a polling view and a core traits view of 'admissible', with the primitive conceptions
 to show that it is worth exploring more concrete theories of admissibility in order
 to improve supervaluationism.

Title: Examining Appiah's Identity and Cosmopolitanism
Abstract:
In his book Ethics of Identity, Appiah explores the messy territory of the relation
 among identity, individuality, and ethics. His exploration begins with his view of
 the nature of the self and leads to his view about the obligations that individuals
 have toward others, which he calls Rooted Cosmopolitanism. Appiah's work draws upon
 liberal and communitarian ideas which have been in tension since the inception of
 the liberal-communitarian debate in the 1980s. In each case, Appiah deliberately places
 himself in the middle ground between liberal and communitarian ideas. In this paper
 I aim to systematise both Appiah's view of the self and his Rooted Cosmopolitanism,
 and examine the relation between the two views. I will then locate each view on the
 spectrum of ideas between those of the hardline liberal and the hardline communitarian
 to determine whether or not his view is coherent and truly original.

Title: Reasoning About Promises
Abstract:
In his recent book, Shaping the Normative Landscape, David Owens presents a view on
 the value and function of obligation. This account includes a theory of promissory
 obligation that is very different from established thought on the subject. In my capstone,
 I hope to provide a critical summary of Owens' view. I will examine the extent to
 which promises require us to change our thinking about what to do and provide an interpretation
 of Owens' explanation of how this happens. Finally, I evaluate cases in which we are
 exempt from fulfilling our promises and provide an alternative to Owens' mechanism
 for dealing with these cases based on his analysis of how promising should change
 our practical reasoning.

Title: Is Neutrality Possible? State Neutrality and the Liberal-Communitarian Debate
Abstract:
We are surrounded by views of all kinds, especially when it comes to the good life
 and what it constitutes. This poses a problem for states who want to cater to everyone's
 views. For liberal states that try to respect individual liberty, a plurality of views
 means it is harder for states to act while keeping their commitment to catering to
 all the views in their society. Liberals nonetheless claim to have the answer to this
 problem - state neutrality. However, the idea of state neutrality has come under intense
 scrutiny by thinkers known as communitarians, sparking off the liberal-communitarian
 debate. I will examine the arguments by communitarians in this debate and use them
 to assess models of justifying state coercion put forward by various liberals.

Title: Time Travel and Leibniz's Law
Abstract:
Leibniz's Law can be summed up in the following: if a is identical with b, every quality
 of a will be a quality of b. Time travel, which is possible according to our best
 physics, entails that the same thing can be in two places at the same time. If we
 go back to Leibniz's Law, it tells us that the same thing cannot be in two places
 at the same time because that entails having different qualities (namely, being in
 different locations). Leibniz's Law and time travel seem to be incompatible. More
 broadly, time travel represents a complex case of the problem of change while Leibniz's
 Law constitutes the foundation of material identity. In my capstone project, I examine
 different philosophical views that attempt to resolve the broader tension between
 the problem of change and material identity in Leibniz's Law. I evaluate these views
 based on whether they are able to explain the specific case of time travel and offer
 a potential refinement.

Title:
Unlocking Strawson: An Analysis of an Interpretation of Locke's Theory of Personal
                                 Identity
Abstract:
John Locke's theory of personal identity was revolutionary in many ways at the time
 it was published. For the first time in the Western philosophical tradition it was
 argued that the connections that make a person the same person across time are essentially
 psychological. However, there have been many interpretations of Locke's theory. One
 of the most recent is Galen Strawson's. Strawson argues that Locke's theory of personal
 identity works as a theory of moral accountability. My capstone is a close reading
 of Galen Strawson's take on Locke, questioning whether it makes sense to think of
 Locke's account of personal identity primarily in terms of moral responsibility.

Title: Twins, Tigers, and Refrigerators: On Prescientific Kind Terms
Abstract:
This capstone argues the ways in which natural kind terms in the philosophy of language
 designate to their respective kinds. There has been a longstanding conception that
 natural kind terms are rigid designators and that theoretical identities involving
 natural kind terms are necessary a posteriori statements. I argue that prescientific
 natural kind terms were not rigid designators and that they were stipulated to be
 rigid after certain scientific discoveries were made, rendering the theoretical identities
 involving those terms necessary by stipulation only and not a posteriori.

Title: Depersonalization & Buddhist No-Self
Abstract:
Bringing together elements from philosophy of mind, psychology, neuroScience, and
 Buddhist tradition, my capstone uses depersonalization to address questions of selfhood
 and normativity behind "losing" our experience of being a self. Depersonalization,
 a phenomenon which entails feeling estranged from how we normally experience ourselves,
 is typically understood as a mental disorder; as harmful, disruptive, and negative.
 However, a central motivation in Buddhist philosophy is to demonstrate the illusory
 nature of the self, and to rid ourselves of its grip through certain practices. Consequently,
 my project analyzes the differences between depersonalization and the Buddhist practices,
 backing each up with neuroscientific data when possible, to explain how each bears
 on our experience of ourselves as selves. Additionally, I weigh both accounts against
 philosophical criteria of what constitutes a mental disorder, drawing conclusions
 which separate depersonalization and Buddhist practices both in terms of the underlying
 processes, and the normativity behind each experience.

Title: Mind Your Language: A Philosophical Investigation into Objectivity in Journalism
Abstract:
Despite the notion that objectivity is used to combat bias, this paper argues that
 appealing to objectivity is far more difficult.

Title: Debunking Evaluative Realism
Abstract:
I examine several versions of the debunking arguments of evaluative realism. Locke
 and Korman has demonstrated that the appearance of safety and sensitivity does not
 guarantee epistemic integrity. I believe that the explanatory concession defeats only
 indirectly: the explanatory concession defeats the a priori entitlement to make evaluative
 assumptions, and the modal concession, which follows from the inability to make evaluative
 assumptions, defeats our evaluative beliefs.

Title: Ethics of Zakat: Comparison of Islamic Ethical Approaches on the Example of Zakat
Abstract:
Zakat, meaning almsgiving, is a form of charity compulsory for all Muslims. Considering
 that the Qur'an provides a minimal amount of information on the specifics of paying
 and receiving zakat, Muslims had to rely on theological and ethical interpretations.
 Inevitably authors had disagreed not only on the specifics of the zakat tradition
 but also on the reasons and frameworks backing the Islamic pillar. Thus, this paper
 presents three frameworks of zakat in detail: Al-Ghazali's Mysteries of Almsgiving,
 Al-Qaradawi's Fiqh al-Zakah, and Maliki's Al-Muwatta. To prove the significant disparity
 between these frameworks, each of them is compared to a different western normative
 ethical perspective: virtue ethics, consequentialism, and deontology(respectively).
 Furthermore, these frameworks are situated into their Islamic historical background,
 to portray the history of each specific ethical tradition within its context. Conclusively,
 I present the varying ethical justifications of the different frameworks Muslims need,
 for the application of the specific methodology of paying zakat. Overall, this paper
 contends that each of the authors had a significant personal influence on the interpretations.

Title: What We Talk About When We Talk About Structure
Abstract:
In this paper I examine what the notion of "structure" should amount to in the context
 of the mind-body debate. I consider two interpretations considered the most promising,
 put forth respectively by Pereboom(2015) and Chalmers(2010), and conclude that both
 fail.

Title: Proportional Choice for Normative Uncertainty
Abstract:
Normative theories tell us what we ought to do or believe. But if you're not sure
 which normative theory is correct, how should you act or believe? Philosophers have
 proposed various higher order normative theories. I argue that the theories all suffer
 serious problems. In turn, I propose and defend Proportional Choice--following the
 recommendations of the theories you believe in proportion to how much you believe
 them--as the correct higher order theory for normative uncertainty.

Title:
Causal (In)dependence in Counterfactual Analysis: Deterministic and Indeterministic
                                 Worlds
Abstract:
A need for invoking causal independence when evaluating counterfactuals under David
 Lewis's standard possible-worlds semantics has been argued for by many. This paper
 aims to present a comprehensive account of the philosophical discussions on the role
 of causal dependence in counterfactual analysis, argue for the significance of causal
 considerations in both deterministic and indeterministic worlds and shed light on
 some problems with incorporating these causal considerations in the semantics. I present
 counterexamples to Lewis's standard semantics and discuss how these counterexamples
 suggest a need for invoking causal independence. I reject the premise—that Morgenbesser
 counterfactuals are true—based on which Schaffer and Edgington claim that Morgenbesser
 cases pose a problem for the standard semantics in the first place. I argue that when
 the indeterministic nature of Morgenbesser cases is accounted for, the counterfactuals
 comes out to be false. However, I contend that considerations of causal dependence
 are nevertheless significant in counterfactual analysis for both deterministic and
 indeterministic scenarios. In the end, I argue that the degree to which one event
 causally depends on another factors into whether the counterfactual in question is
 evaluated as true or false. Therefore, notions of causal relevance in the current
 causal independence approach need to be fine-grained.

Title: Weighing Property Rights: The Cabin and The Mosque
Abstract:
This capstone weighs the moral and prudential weight of property rights with other
 rights, when conflicts of rights arise. Conflicts of rights occur when a situation
 only allows one right to be preserved at the expense of another. This capstone discusses
 specifically, situations where the right to life might seem to trump the moral and
 prudential force of property rights. Through a series of arguments, I will end with
 Ruth Barcan Marcus' discussion on moral dilemmas, where I demonstrate that property
 rights have the ability to generate genuine moral dilemmas.

Title:
Does My Ethics Professor Know Anything?: Resisting Skepticism about Moral Knowledge
                                 from Moral Disagreement
Abstract:
My capstone examines premise 1 of Sarah McGrath's epistemological argument against
 moral knowledge in "Moral Disagreement and Moral Expertise." I incorporate the Higher-Order
 Evidence framework so that moral disagreement counts as a piece of higher-order evidence
 threatening our moral knowledge. I examine different strategies to defeat this higher-order
 evidence. I argue that whether numbers have epistemic significance in moral disagreement
 is crucial to defeating the higher-order evidence of moral disagreement. I hypothesize
 that numbers do not have epistemic significance in the moral context.

Title: Educational Justice Adequacy, Equality, and Leveling Down
Abstract:
My capstone explores the philosophical area of distributive education justice which
 looks to find the best way of distributing resources destined to education. Looking
 at theories of equality and adequacy we find that arriving at an answer of how best
 to distribute resources is no easy task. On the one hand, the equality view tells
 us that the distribution should be done in a fair and comparative way. On the other
 hand, the adequacy view tells us that resources should be distributed to ensure every
 individual reaches a certain threshold. Specifically, I delve deeper into the controversial
 but seemingly plausible idea that prohibiting parents from privately investing in
 their own children's education is morally justified. This is the problem of leveling
 down, and the focus of my capstone.

Title: Indoctrination
Abstract:
In discussions of contemporary education, the term "indoctrination" often appears
 as an accusation or criticism, describing education that poses detrimental threats
 to students' learning and personal development. This negative connotation of the word
 influences our perception of it: when we use the word "indoctrination," it is almost
 certain that we are not describing any admirable goal of education, but a kind of
 "bad" education. This project investigates various philosophical accounts that describe
 worrying cases of indoctrination. This thesis concludes that a successful philosophical
 theory of indoctrination has two components. The first step consists of either the
 intentions-based view or the outcome-based view which evaluates the relationship between
 the indoctrinator and the indoctrinated individual. The second step, the system-based
 view, lifts some, if not all, of the moral responsibility of indoctrination off the
 teacher's shoulders. I argue that the decision between the intentions-based view and
 the outcome-based view does not rest upon the details of the two theories, but a broader
 decision one has to make regarding whether indoctrination is a kind of morally wrong
 action type or state of affairs.

Title: Directing Dinamene: Creating Impactful & Accessible Theater
Abstract:
Major: Theater, BiologyAbstract:Directed the play, "Dinamene, or the Light Indestructible," which follows
 the mental and emotional destruction of poet Luís de Camões in the aftermath of a
 shipwreck in which he let his lover die to save his unfinished manuscript. Haunted
 by guilt, he writes a poem in which to immortalize his lost love, only to create a
 tormenting spirit by mistake: Dinamene. A hyper-perfect version of the drowned lover,
 Dinamene confronts Luís with the reality of his own black heart, unraveling his world
 as she manipulates time, space, and memory to destroy him.

Title: Dinamene and Tin Nan Men' Dictée
Abstract:
Major: TheaterAbstract: I will play Dinamene in "Dinamene: Or the Light Indestructible" in collaboration
 with Emily Eagen, Alyazia Al Shaibani, and Claudia Carrasco who are respectively the
 playwright, the designer, and the director.

Title: Capstone Essay
Abstract:
Major: Theater and HistoryAbstract: Essay discussing the process of working on a collaborative art piece and
 the discovery of what dramaturgy means to me.

Title: CGC: a devised piece
Abstract:
Major: Theater, Psychology Abstract: A devised theater capstone exploring prescribed gender roles in the modern
 world and their effect on young girls' development.

Title: Mnemosyne: An Immersive, Interactive Experience
Abstract:
Major: TheaterAbstract: Mnemosyne is an immersive, interactive performance exploring the idea of
 the hero. It tries to position the audience as an active participant in the creation
 of a story. It sprung out of my love and dissatisfaction with the two most important
 art forms of my life: theater and video games. I believed the combination of mediums
 would create an exciting, new hybrid genre that cancelled out the limitations of both,
 while empowering their respective disadvantages. This was the only way I thought I
 could tell an effective and engaging story about the hero, and his journey, inspired
 by the dramaturgical structure of Joseph Campbell's monomyth, as well as the visual
 styles of film noir, cyberpunk and psychological thrillers.

Title: The Farewell Experiment
Abstract: Major: TheaterAbstract: Farcical romp — sometimes musical — through human aversions to saying goodbye.

Title: [_______] Missing
Abstract:
Major: Theater. Abstract: What does it mean to miss someone? What happens between
 noticing their absence and feeling it?

Title: FEMME
Abstract:
Major: TheaterAbstract: This paper is aimed at unpacking the developmental process of FEMME, a devised
 performance piece about the collisions of masculinity and femininity, in relation
 to the proposition that a loom can stand analogous to a cross. The dramaturgical and
 dilated structure of the piece is that of a queered crucifixion, and the central question
 is: will masculinity be transformed, cemented, or removed from the space when it comes
 into conflict with the femme? This paper traces the personal origins of the piece
 emerging from my grandfather's death, rediscovery of a Lutheran faith, and questions
 around the ethics of trans masculinity; the theoretical background of a horizontal
 process and my challenges with putting that theory into practice in terms of collaboration
 and design; and reflection on how this work fits into my growth as an art maker.

Title: Yénze
Abstract:
Major: TheaterAbstract: "The "Yenźe Project" is a choreopoem that juxtaposes my childhood poetry
 against my current poetry. It grapples with four reoccurring ideas in my life:•The ever changing and growing image of who God is to me•The strength of my mother as a representation of God•The view of my mother as a majestic tree that has always given me shade•The friends that have rotated throughout my life who have shown me the dark and light
 sides of humanity.I journey back to my little-self using my poetry. I search for what I would say to
 her. I believe the possibility of returning to one's little-self has repercussions.
 I'm interested in those repercussions. I hope that my little-self shall meet me half
 way.This paper narrates how "Yenźe" originated, the inspirations behind it and a glimpse
 of what it has evolved into. It highlights the challenges of juxtaposing one's younger-self
 against ones' current self.

Title: Reclamation or How To Really Do It
Abstract: Major: Theater

Title: Nubia; a performance about my grandmother
Abstract:
Abstract: This project dissects my return to the womb; it is the culmination of my
 research project in Cali, Colombia. I travelled to my mother's homeland in search
 of everything that hurt me in being attached to it. I looked for the pain in my mother
 tongue, in family memories, and in the grave of my grandmother. But instead of pain,
 I found peace. Nubia; a performance about my grandmother weaves together the original
 pain that still haunts me with the peace I discovered in my recent return to Colombia.
 This yoking together informs the environment, performance, and dramaturgical structure
 of the piece. In this way, my grandmother becomes the house, her death is manifested
 as a field of coffee beans, a memory of blood exists as earth, my birth lives in a
 sowing machine, time is a game of Parcheesi, and my mother's imagined death is my
 performance.

Title: Bil3arabi
Abstract:
سجّل أنا عربي. 'Write down, I am an Arab.' What does it mean to be an Arab today?
 We no longer fit into the traditional framework of our parents' generation, yet we
 are not entirely westernized. Bil3arabi is a performance piece that aims to create
 a space that exists between these tensions. Looking at the influences of technology,
 family, nationalism and culture, Bil3arabi journeys through the causes and effects
 of merging East and West and investigates how language is the core of creating an
 identity. Drawing inspiration from different modes of performance such as Arabic hip-hop,
 spoken word poetry and stand-up comedy; the performance invites the audience to question
 the role language has in forming identity.

Title: Galatea Becoming / Devour
Abstract:
This process paper explicates the relationship between the practice and theoretical
 components of my capstone: Devour, a game/performance piece that experiments with
 the game form's potential to address constructions of American race; and Galatea Becoming,
 a thesis paper that explores different technologies of creation through the lens of
 the Pygmalion-Galatea myth. Devour is a dinner table game in which players attempt
 to successfully role play stereotypes of their own races while also engaging in conversations
 about various news and cultural topics. Galatea Becoming examines how the Pygmalion-Galatea
 myth is performed through different forms that allow the Galatea figure to express
 subjectivity and exercise agency in different ways.

Title:
can we talk? A Staging of Loneliness and the Difficulties of Communicating in the
                                 Digital Age
Abstract:
can we talk? paints a portrait of one man's self-imposed isolation in the face of
 interpersonal difficulties. Through the use of projection and found footage, the work
 raises questions about the omnipresence of media in the modern world, and its possibly
 deleterious effects on human interaction. As a silent monologue, the piece garners
 influences from dance theater and one-man shows, and investigates the relationship
 between socialization and mental health. It explores ideas of dreams, of memories,
 of space, and of bodies, and attempts to dive into some of the actor's personal anxieties.

Title: Julia, A Lesbian!
Abstract:
"Julia, A Lesbian!" is a one woman collaboratively written sitcom performed by Nathalie
 Kozak and directed by Allanah Avalon. During the performance, the audience bears witness
 to the complex nature of female-to-female relationships, as well as the challenges
 in the pursuit of romantic stability.

Title: Drowning in Cairo
Abstract:
Drowning in Cairo follows the lives of three Egyptian gay men from different walks
 of life, whose fate forces them together time and again over a 20 year period. The
 play is set between 1997 and 2017 as Moody, Khalid and Taha aged from 13 to 33 and
 the political system and queer life transform around them. In eleven episodic scenes,
 Drowning in Cairo chronicles the contemporary history of the queer community's relationship
 to the law and public space in Egypt.

Title:
Re-encounters: Exploring Diasporic Homecoming and Geographies of Identity through
                                 Performance in Ghana
Abstract:
This paper examines the 2017 iteration of the Pan-African Historical Theatre Project
 (PANAFEST), a bi-annual theater festival that takes place in Accra and Cape Coast,
 Ghana. Initiated by the legendary playwright and cultural visionary, Efua T. Sutherland,
 who understood the link between theater and national development in post-independent
 Ghana, PANAFEST explores both the traumatic legacies of the transatlantic slave trade
 and contemporary socio-political issues that impact people across the continent and
 the diaspora. Recognizing that the Festival is complex and layered, I specifically
 explore how dance, speeches, and rituals engage with the idea of diasporic homecoming
 and demonstrate the importance of using the arts to construct and cultivate a sense
 of unity and interconnectedness among African and African diasporic peoples.

Title: A Woman's Prize
Abstract:
There's an old story we have all forgotten. Shakespeare's infamous woman-tamer Petruccio
 has just remarried the sweet, demure Maria after he murdered his first wife, Kate.
 Maria reveals quickly that she is not all he deems her to be, and through understanding
 her own nature, sets out to claim her legacy against his oppression. A Joint-Capstone,
 directed by Sebastian Grube and written by Arianna Stucki, A Woman's Prize is a 30-minute
 play that utilizes song, Old Irish, and immersive storytelling. This play asks us
 all to consider an alternative narrative in which women reclaim and reshape their
 mythologies, remembering the female names and stories lost to history.

Title: Patch 1
Abstract:
Melancholia can be described as an unresolvable state of longing, for something lost
 that can never be recovered or replaced. Studies into some diasporic groups refer
 to a melancholia that arises from being caught between the longing for their old home
 and estrangement from their new home. Patch 1.0 was a series of rehearsal experiments
 aiming to question the systems of belonging that are embedded in our cultures, with
 the goal of producing a show. This goal was not reached however, and what was instead
 produced was an archive of theatrical investigations into how interactivity and performance
 can be used to articulate these ideas.

Title: Performing Nature
Abstract:
Performing Nature is a durational site specific performance wherein an architectural
 structure is the actor. The structure emulates characteristics of nature, through
 organic decay, imperfection, asymmetry, and vastness, in order to replicate nature's
 ability to inspire sublimity.

Title: where did you get this power?
Abstract: an episodic play about love in the Anthropocene

Title: Post Scroll Double-Tap Repeat: Performance and Performativity of Instagram
Abstract:
Every spare minute of every day, my friends and I reach for our phone, tap on Instagram,
 upload photos, and scroll for hours. Why do I get excited when "likes" flash on my
 screen after I post a photo? Why do I post photos at all? And why do I follow three
 Victoria's Secret models!?

Author(s): Al Jallaf, Mira Anis Abdulla Mohd
Abstract:
131 is an extended performance piece that "begins" there and "ends" here but exists
 everywhere at all times. Over the past year in C3 131, collections of two audience
 members at a time experienced intimately constructed simulations. In the performance
 of 131, one audience member at a time will enter the space of the simulations reinstalled
 in C3 036. In this space lives the history of C3 131; the people that spoke in the
 room, that ate in the room, that drank in the room, that created in the room, and
 that connected in the room. The experiences that manifested through these engineered
 simulations will be embodied through a 10-minute audio based performance piece that
 allows the audience member to uncover the inner workings of the NYUAD paradigm.

Title: Tango Palace
Abstract:
Tango Palace, an abridged adaptation of the play by Cuban-American playwright Maria
 Irene Fornes, is an intimate exploration of two people and their relationship to one
 another within a strange and limited world. Leopold, an earnest youth, wakes to find
 himself locked in a room with Isidore, an androgynous clown, who rules with a sword
 and magically printed index cards. In my direction of Tango Palace, the characters
 attempt to assert their relative power and manipulate each other. Through this, I
 explore the ways in which we reveal and disguise vulnerability through enacted violence,
 as a process of combating loneliness and building human connection.

Title: Intimate Interiors
Abstract:
My project seeks to explore the relationship between social intimacy and the analog.
 It does so through a series of one-on-one portrait-drawing sessions with approximately
 80 students from the NYUAD community, during which participants are invited to take
 on the role of observer and observed. These sessions produce physical artifacts in
 the form of drawings which will be taken in conjunction with written reflections on
 the conversations had during the interaction to produce a study of the components
 that generate meaning within social interactions. The documentation of these sessions
 will be accompanied by a book of compiled research and images on the topics of social
 interaction, intimacy, and their artistic resonances. The book and sessions will form
 the basis of a gallery exhibition presenting the work and its findings.

Title: On Our Borders
Abstract:
Composed from interviews with students in New York and Abu Dhabi, On Our Borders is
 a verbatim performance with original music about Third Culture Kids and the questions
 their between-cultures experiences pose. In a world still catching up with the profound
 shift in quotidian experience globalization has brought, are we defining identities
 and communities in ways that further the global circulation of ideas? Is it possible
 to create a world where everyone can be part of a greater whole? What does it mean
 to be a global citizen, not fully belonging to any one nation? And is it viable to
 reconcile our desire for cross-border communities with rising nationalist governments,
 parties, and policies?

Title: Sült
Abstract:
Sült is a 30-minute one-man show that attempts to state the truth about my Hungarian
 identity through the embodiment of different characters. I am performing a series
 of short stories that tackle questions regarding socio-political responsibility, personal
 and inherited memories. The fictive and semi-fictive monologues are triggered through
 the ritual of frying chicken, a significant activity that reminds me of my mother.
 As I serve a fresh plate of meat, I confront the traumatic history of my country by
 providing testimonies that can help me have a conversation about my own identity while
 contemplating answers to the question of what it means to be patriotic.

Title:
From Stonewall to Mar Mikhaël: A Case Study of Beirut Pride and the Implications of
                                 Pride in the Arab World
Abstract:
Over the past 50 years, Pride has grown from a localized celebration of queerness
 to a global gay phenomenon. Founded in 2017, Beirut Pride has been heralded as the
 first "Pride" in the Arab World. However, this raises the question what does "Pride"
 mean for Beirut and how does Beirut perform a "Pride"? In this paper, I argue that
 Beirut Pride has a dual effect of creating advocacy and safe spaces for Beiruti citizens
 while also reshaping Western narratives of the Middle East and Pride as a whole. By
 looking at Pride as a performance of queer visibility and community building both
 locally and in a larger global discourse, Beirut Pride calls into question the ways
 in which visibility is manifested while creating a physical space for the local community.

Title: memory is a partial victory over death
Abstract:
memory is a partial victory over death is a site-specific dance performance in the
 A5 Atrium that occurs over the course of sunset. Drawing upon the relationship between
 memory and materiality, the work invites the audience to witness two performers attempting
 to pursue, find, and ultimately reimagine each other's images on the window reflections
 that fade through time. The piece was inspired by how my grandmother, who has frequent
 memory loss, talks about her childhood memories. While I have an urge to materialize
 memories as a response to my fear of forgetting, the conversation with her allowed
 me to consider how memories can be remembered and worked on through immateriality.
 Facing the inevitable conditions of material disintegration, the two performers pay
 close attention to the urgency of the present as well as the repeated actions in order
 to archive memories.

Title: Civil
Abstract:
Civil was a Theater capstone that took the shape of a publicly performed attempt at
 erasing handwritten phrases of violence inscribed on chairs. The phrases were collected
 from different situations on campus and were imposed on four chairs through repetitive
 handwriting. The piece took place on the East Plaza Lawn for a duration of three hours,
 over the course of which participatory audience members aided me in the process of
 concealing, yet, re-marking, the phrases through the use of white ink corrective pens.

Title:
Theater architecture as an expressive language: A case study of the Théâtre du Soleil
                                 in La Cartoucherie de Vincennes
Abstract:
The Cartoucherie, home of the renowned theatre company Théâtre du Soleil since 1970,
 is located in the Bois de Vincennes, on the outskirts of central Paris. This paper
 argues that the layout and designation of the Cartoucherie as a physical space intersects
 with and underlays the work of the Théâtre du Soleil to raise consciousness on social
 issues such as migration - asking how human beings should live together in a culturally
 diverse and global society. The static view of architecture as the permanent presence
 of structures is complicated by the utilization of space for theatrical purposes.
 Events that take place within theatrical spaces allow the structure, the architecture,
 to become a laboratory for modelling society and experimenting with creative forms
 of reality, especially so when these spaces double as contact zones for multicultural
 communities, who are themselves products of movements through space as is the case
 with the Cartoucherie.

Title: nature(
Abstract:
The interactive installation "nature(.c)ode" is a piece that invites the audience
 on a sensory journey to explore the possibility of organic coexistence between nature
 and technology. Structured around two large wooden structures, the installation offers
 the audience an opportunity to test how their responses to technology change when
 usual, synthetic surfaces of interaction are replaced by natural textures and organic
 materials. Designed as a ten-minute experience, the installation guides the audience
 in the space through its light design. As the lights continually shift, moving from
 the front to the back, shining on different sides of the two central structures at
 different times, the audience is invited to move through the space in a similar manner.
 The two cuboid-shaped central pieces, which serve as the interfaces of interaction,
 reflect a similar linear progression. By touching different wooden and plant attachments
 on these structures, the audience plays different tones, creating music together.
 While the front side of the first structure is covered in more technological tones,
 these gradually soften towards the back, where they are even accompanied by a light-interaction
 when the interaction occurs through plants.

Title: Spectra
Abstract:
'Spectra' is a comic book- play adapted from Stan Lee and Jack Kirby's Amazing Fantasy
 #15, the origin story of Marvel Comics' character, The Amazing Spider-Man. Conceived
 as a 'comicbook-play,' 'Spectra' was developed through a series of rehearsal laboratories
 and writing workshops. 'Spectra' explores playwrighting as a collaborative process
 and engages the visual form of comic books as a mode of playwrighting. In doing so,
 'Spectra' experiments with ways of developing script, where text functions as an icon
 for language and image, as in the form of comic books.'Spectra' explores the effects
 of internal and external violence upon the fractured psyche of a superhero seeking
 to reconcile the trauma of the past with their desire to wield power in the name of
 a greater good. By engaging with studies on feminism, tricksterism, transformative
 justice and queer theory, 'Spectra' seeks to question patriarchal notions of masculinity
 in order to redefine what it means to be a superhero. 'Spectra' seeks to reframe
 the vision of the superhero as the sole author of violence in the name of an absolute
 moral authority and propose a model for the superhero as existing within and accountable
 to a community of care.

Title: SAFAR | सफ़र
Abstract:
SAFAR| सफ़र is a site-specific walk that investigates female sacrifice and performance
 of femininity across three generations of women in my family: paati→ amma and chiti→
 me. By understanding my body as a site that has inherited language, memories and music,
 I seek to re(connect) with my amma, chiti and paati through this work. SAFAR is my
 journey through spiritual time and physical space that employs the practices of oral
 history, documentary theater and embodied writing to create a discontinuous historical
 narrative highlighting these three women and their sacrifices . Nine participants
 are invited to meditate, recuperate and celebrate in the space as they descend together.
 The walk is location-driven and ends in front of a 120 by 57 centimeter storage unit
 that became sacred to me during my four years here. The only objects left behind during
 this SAFAR are the sacrificial objects brought by participants into the space.

Title:
Safety, Impact, Communication, Expressivity, and Agency: Finding New Ways to Understand
                                 Participation in Live Performance
Abstract:
Every audience member in every event of live performance always participates in some
 way in creating the full theatrical event. Considering the many experiments that have
 taken place in the art world over the past century, it seems that there is not yet
 a clear vocabulary for speaking clearly about audience participation. By drawing from
 both theoretical research and having carried out several practical art experiments,
 this paper proposes a new model for understanding participation based on five distinct
 aspects: Safety, Impact, Communication, Expressivity, and Agency. This capstone project
 also brings together lessons from the field of Game Design by exploring the ideas
 of Fun, Flow, Meaningful Play, Verbs, Objects and Systems. This capstone also consisted
 of a 2 hour long Game-Theater piece titled "Paperclips and Power". This piece is a
 post-apocalyptic nation-builder simulator where up to 30 audience members must find
 a way to survive in a world where the main resource is paperclips. The piece functions
 through several mechanics that create a system that allows for emergent stories to
 take place, allowing the audience to express their political views through the actions
 that they take during the piece.

Title: Book of the Dead
Abstract:
This theater practice capstone aimed to create a devised performance from the stories
 of two industrial disasters: the 1931 Hawks Nest Tunnel Tragedy and the 1984 Bhopal
 Gas Leak. A single company operated both the West Virginia tunnel project and the
 Bhopal gas plant: Union Carbide. The performance was built out of documentary materials
 from Bhopal and a poetry collection entitled 'The Book of the Dead' by the poet Muriel
 Rukeyser which chronicles the West Virginia disaster. The project explores how the
 documents and poetry can be embodied, bringing to life the historical linkages between
 the tragedies, exploring and interrogating the corporate practices that allow these
 disasters to occur with minimal consequences. The capstone also explores how performance
 can be used as a medium to mobilise the voices of the dead in order to confront systems
 of oppression and participate in acts of collective healing.

Title: I Can't Hear You, My Scooter's On
Abstract:
I wrote and performed a play with music that takes the audience on a musical journey
 through a singer's desires for love, connection, and understanding. The story is circled
 with a love of performance and contains intense scooter choreography.

Title: ñ'e - documentary intermedial microtheater
Abstract:
ñ'e is a documentary intermedial microtheater capstone project. It is based on research
 interviews in Paraguay and storytelling experiments conducted in Abu Dhabi throughout
 2019 and 2020. It explores intimacy as it travels across borders, languages and people
 through the internet. The intimate experiences occur in both digital and analog forms.

Title: Novena
Abstract:
Novena is an original autobiographical performance piece exploring the impact of religious
 social scripts on the performance of the female body. Borrowing aesthetic imagery
 from Catholic performance practices and rituals, Novena depicts a recluse bride who
 isolates herself in a church to atone for her sins. In the piece, she attempts to
 reconcile her feelings of transgressional guilt in contention with her instinctual
 pleasures. This piece is devised from a combination of archival text from my journals,
 observational research conducted in Manila, Philippines, and anecdotal contributions
 from various women of color. Exploring the impact of religious structures on a woman's
 coming of age through prose, song, and dance, Novena dramatizes the process of interrogating
 and outgrowing institutional beliefs ingrained in the female psyche.

Title: Deliberately and In Cash
Abstract:
"Deliberately and In Cash" is a 30 minutes virtual performance that explores the practice
 of collecting Diya (blood money) in the Gulf, and how this practice evolved and persisted
 over time from pre-islamic times till today. The piece looks closely at how the practice
 exists today in the gulf by featuring the case of Hidaya Al Sultan and her Diya which
 is considered one of the highest ever collected in the history of the practice in
 the region. Hidaya, the Kuwaiti journalist was murdered in 1991 for writing an article
 about women of a certain tribe working as paid dancers. The piece argues that what
 makes this practice persist is that it provides a mechanism to distribute the responsibly
 and punishment of the crime on the society that allowed the murder to happen, and
 invites the audience to think about how this mechanism can be used in order to reduce
 potential violent acts.

Title: pillowfort
Abstract:
pillowfort is an interactive theatrical project about radical care. Taking Shaheen
 Bagh as its point of investigation, the piece attempts to shake the academic boundaries
 around the discourse about citizenship to aim at having a more visceral conversation
 about what it feels like to be Indian in the wake of hateful, discriminatory citizenship
 laws coming into existence. Can we go beyond the intellectual and the academic, and
 see ourselves being a community that centers care in the face of fear and apprehension?
 Can we show up for each other, even when we don't fully understand? Can we remember
 what it's like to be together above everything else? Can I hold your hand through
 it all?

Author(s): Costales, David Ponce and Juma, Joseph Bwerwa
Title: Design of Economical Rapid Deployable Structures
Abstract:
Refugee situations call for immediate housing needs. With the numbers of refugees
 rising worldwide aid organizations have limited resources to assist efficiently and
 uniformly. Given that the problems behind the displacement of people are difficult
 to tackle, economical rapid deployable structures are a necessity. For this reason
 this project goes through the design process of such structure from conception to
 the manufacturing of a live scale prototype. The final design was evaluated against
 several criteria including structural stability, cost, transportability, portability,
 ease and speed of deployment and of collapse, protection from the environment and
 aesthetics. Additionally, the proposed solution effectively solves problems such as
 overcrowding providing comfortable housing. The shape allows for modular, close packing
 in a macro scale. This allows concentration of structures without overcrowding the
 living space. The structural framework is designed of aluminum with a resistant and
 light cross section providing durability, strength and making the structure light.
 Additionally the material can be reutilized for other structures as a recycled, modular
 component. The textile exterior is designed of Polycotton canvas making it cool and
 waterproof. The proposed solution has efficiently met most of the set benchmarks with
 a structurally stable, low-cost, rapid deployable structure.

Title: Design for Sustainable Urban Agriculture in Abu Dhabi
Abstract:
In an age of booming population and rapid urbanization, the lack of agricultural labor,
 shortage of arable land, and the increasing dominance of large food corporations all
 pose great challenges on the sustainability of urban food system. Urban agriculture
 might be a potential solution to these challenges. Farming in urban areas addresses
 at least three critical issues facing urban food infrastructure: food security, food
 quality and energy use as represented by food miles. Additionally, urban farming is
 socially beneficial in terms of ecological health, community development, and food
 awareness. In current practice, however, urban agriculture lacks three crucial building
 blocks: 1. Empirical economic studies to prove its economic viability (Glaeser). 2.
 Scalable business model to attract potential stakeholders from both public and private
 sectors. 3. Engineering smart and innovative farms that are adaptive to urban setting.
 This project offers a design for well engineered urban farms that are adaptive to
 the conditions and constraints of cities. Innovative water management, structural,
 environmental and traffic systems that are compatible with existing standards of safety
 and comfort, are proposed. The design allows a cost that will be competitive in the
 marketplace and acceptable to government.

Author(s): Andargie, Maendot Solomon, and Mingzhu Hou
Title: Rapid Replacement Bridge Design
Abstract:
We are designing a rapid replacement bridge located in Upstate New York. The design
 philosophy we are following is American Association of State Highway and Transportation
 Officials (AASHTO) and Load and Resistance Factor Design (LRFD). The AASHTO LRFD Bridge
 Design Specifications are intended for use in the design, evaluation, and rehabilitation
 of bridges, and are mandated by the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) for use
 on all bridges using federal funding. These Specifications employ the Load and Resistance
 Factor Design (LRFD) methodology using factors developing from current statistical
 knowledge of loads and structural performance. The computer software programs that
 we are using include SAP2000 and AutoCAD 2015. SAP2000 is an integrated software for
 structural analysis design developed by Computers & Structures, Inc. AutoCAD is a
 design and documentation software developed by Autodesk, Inc. We use SAP2000 to do
 analysis and design and AutoCAD to produce the final drawing. The calculation methods
 that we adopt include the method of joints, design for tension, design for compression,
 design for joints, concrete footing design, pavement design, and traffic analysis
 and design. The outcome of the capstone project will be a complete design of a replacement
 bridge, with specifications in a drawing produced using AutoCAD.

Author(s): Memon, Nahil Ali, and Brenda Juma Odhingo
Title: Designing Sustainable, Urban Housing in Abu Dhabi, UAE
Abstract:
The aim of this capstone project is to design a sustainable, urban housing complex.
 For this project, we have chosen to focus on UAE and in particular, the emirate of
 Abu Dhabi. This is because Abu Dhabi is one of the most expensive cities in the world
 in terms of rent and property prices. For this reason, it is difficult to obtain decent
 and affordable housing. In 2006, the UAE was announced as the nation with the largest
 per capita Ecological Footprint.After a close examination of the current housing situation
 in the UAE, we chose to focus our project in the Mussafah area. We will design an
 urban complex that will be sustainable, aesthetically pleasing and foster a sense
 of community amongst its residents. Our project will focus on four key areas: structural
 design, foundation design, transportation design and sustainability. The building
 will be designed to withstand all the relevant design loads and to meet the strength
 limits and the serviceability limits outlined in the ACI and AISCI Steel Construction
 Manual. It is also aimed to have a sustainability rating of LEED Silver and Estidama
 Pearl 2.

Author(s): AlMansoori, Maryam, James Gardner, and Paul Ha
Title: Water Treatment Facility in the Northern Emirates
Abstract:
The Northern Emirates face unique and challenging water resourcing; with some of the
 most limited availability in ground water, and a water usage of twice the world average
 at 550 L per person per day, the UAE must have highly efficient waste water recycling
 systems. This project outlines a detailed design of a recycled wastewater treatment
 facility treating 225,000 m3 of water per day located in the Northern Emirates of
 the UAE. The scope of the design includes the water treatment process, structural
 housing, and road access ways with parking facilities. This document includes design
 drawings and analysis alongside project management methods undertaken to complete
 the project. The design chosen is a multistage water treatment process modelled on
 a traditional sewage treatment plant; wastewater undergoes primary, secondary and
 tertiary treatment in the form of coagulation, flocculation and sedimentation, a plug
 flow reactivated sludge line, and dual media filtration plus UV treatment. These
 processes were selected as best practices across the industry. Treated water is at
 a standard to allow for restricted irrigation as per the Dubai Municipality codes.
 This water is ready for distribution and use for irrigation in non-raw crops and landscaping.

Author(s): Abdelkhalek, Hassan, and Noor Ehab Alameri
Title: Sustainable Low-income Housing Design
Abstract:
The project had two main objectives, which were to produce a low cost and sustainable
 design for a 1 story house in Abu Dhabi. Through extensive research, material testing
 and conscious architectural design which efficiently uses the space allocated to the
 project these two objectives were met. The proposed house design costs 47% less than
 an average house of a similar size in the USA, excluding labor cost since it varies
 greatly across the world. Moreover, the materials proposed and tested provide a more
 sustainable and low cost alternative to the conventional building materials used.
 Not only do they decrease the running costs of the house, but they also reduce the
 amount of energy consumed by the household mainly through decreasing cooling costs.

Author(s): Khan, Waqar Younas, and Abdur Mani Rehman
Title: Room Design for Effective Evacuation under Escape Panic
Abstract:
The standards of evacuation design have not changed much in the past half a century.
 Any progress that is being made is so insignificant in value that the adoption of
 the ideas globally is not a priority. The 21st century is about minute detail optimization
 to achieve maximum efficiency. It is this search that is explained in the capstone
 where we try and understand the details and try to morph obstacles so as to help us
 achieve designs that lead to the goals we have set. In order to do this, inspiration
 from Dirk Helbing's work from 2001 was taken that discusses the possibility of improving
 evacuation rates by introducing obstacles in the pathway of an exit. The project delves
 further into this concept by trying to employ one or all of the following; deep neural
 networks, reinforced learning, and VISSIM. Based on the results obtained by Helbing,
 we expect that there is a certain design of obstacles that can improve the flow of
 pedestrians in an emergency evacuation. To answer this question, our research found
 that introducing funnel-shaped exits with a central kite-shaped obstacle produce the
 most efficient room design for evacuation.

Author(s): Okoth, Victor, Raitis Pekuss, and Ylber Roka
Title: Analysis of PWPB Algorithm for Incremental CAV Market Penetration Rates
Abstract:
Connected and Autonomous Vehicles are widely expected to revolutionize urban transportation.
 Their increased presence is expected to mitigate traffic congestions, environmental
 hazards presented by vehicles, reduce the number of accidents while also increasing
 the throughput of traffic networks. However, these benefits will become apparent gradually
 corresponding to the gradual market penetration rates of CAVs. This paper studies
 traffic intersection control of mixed vehicle traffic that consists of CAVs as well
 as human driven vehicles. Specifically, we analyze the Position Back Pressure algorithm
 which is studied to outperform SCOOT - a widely accepted real-time adaptive traffic
 control method - in terms of delays for both low and high demand traffic conditions.
 We address the underlying assumption in the algorithm that all the information about
 vehicles in the network is known. Such a scenario is only possible with a 100% market
 penetration of CAVs and, therefore, does not reflect the real life conditions. To
 address this we vary the amount of known and, consequently, estimated data, which
 is then fed into the traffic simulation. As the result of this we can understand how
 sensitive is PWBP to inputs with varying levels of real and estimated data.

Title: Design of an Optimal Public Transit Network Using Evolutionary Algorithms
Abstract:
Public transit design has been optimized through minimization of an objective function
 made up of the user and agency costs. However, societal costs, such as the environmental
 impact of congestion, has not been fully studied. With increasing environmental concerns,
 assessing the external cost of all transportation modes on the environment is important.
 In this paper, a cost function was created that takes into account the agency and
 user costs as well as the environmental impacts of the transportation system. Through
 the use of covariance matrix adaptation evolution strategy, a methodology for the
 design of public transit networks that minimizes this cost was created and implemented
 using SUMO(Version 1.3.1; Institute of Transportation Systems, 2018) to reflect traffic
 scenarios that were input to the cost function for 5 routes and a headway of 10 minutes.
 When the optimization was initiated with random stops, a minimum value of $3,418,128
 was found. When the optimization was started with sequential stops, a minimum value
 of $1,087,693 was found. Both are higher than the benchmark solution of $734,395.
 Since this methodology did not find a solution more optimal than analytical methods,
 further research on the applicability of CMA-ES to transit design is needed.

Author(s): Joshi, Dhruvi, Doovaraha Maheswarasarma, and Raunak Shrestha
Title: Waste to Energy: Design of a Microwave Induced Plasma Gasification Plant
Abstract:
Waste is defined as the unwanted materials produced by any activity. Waste-to-energy
 technologies provide the necessary tools to redefine waste as a raw material or resource,
 that plays a crucial role in the development of a circular waste economy. Currently,
 landfilling is the most widely practiced waste management strategy which has a large
 and wide range of environmental impacts. This project proposes a sustainable WTE facility
 design with MIPG as its core technology to convert MSW into energy and slag. The circular
 economy created through the facility mimics that of the environment in which resources
 discarded by one organism are used by another organism. The proposed solution can
 be retrofitted on top of existing waste management or WTE systems. The design aims
 to transform waste management into a sustainable and ecologically friendly process.
 The target location selected for the plant is in the Emirate of Abu Dhabi. The design
 of the WTE plant includes aspects of structure, transportation, and waste processing
 which are required to produce energy from waste. The design is further supported by
 an Environmental Impact Assessment that evaluates compliance of the plant with the
 UAE rules and regulations.

Title: Three Dimensional (3D) Printing With Low-Carbon Cement-Based Materials
Abstract:
There is an increasing interest in the 3D printing of cementitious construction materials
 among civil engineering fields. Recent research has defined 3D printing as one of
 the fastest, most efficient and most cost-effective methods of building. 3D printing
 ensures quick repeatability of the construction process as well as lower labor costs
 since a machine now does the work. While this new technology has many advantages,
 it also poses a great risk to the environment due to the high use of Ordinary Portland
 Cement (OPC) in the 3D printing construction industry. Approximately 900 kg of CO2
 are emitted for every production of 1 ton of cement. This makes up more than 8% of
 the man-made emissions of CO2, a potent greenhouse gas. This capstone project aims
 to find alternative sustainable solutions to OPC that would meet the 3D printing standards
 as defined by American Standard of Testing and Materials (ASTM) as well as the Portland
 Cement Association while also reducing the amount of CO2 emission required during
 production. Moreover, the project will involve 3D printing different prototypes using
 the proposed alternative cementitious materials and testing and optimizing the materials'
 strength, flow and microstructure.

Title:
Designing Graphical Visualization of the Maximum Congestion Propagation Speed at the
                                 Network
Abstract:
The Macroscopic Fundamental Diagram (MFD) is a graphical representation that relates
 the weighted flow and density of the urban network. Among several uses of the MFD
 for network traffic analysis, this capstone project focuses on the slopes of the MFD's
 two branches. The left branch of the MFD represents the free-flow speed of the network
 while the right branch shows the speed at which the congestion propagates and/or dissipates
 in the network. Since the introduction of MFD, the main focus of the estimation methods
 of the MFD was on the left branch (free-flow speed). As a result, the right branch
 of the MFD representing the congestion propagation and/or dissipation speed in the
 network has not yet been fully comprehended. The understanding of the right branch
 of the MFD is important because the maximization of the dissipation speed at the network
 is desired to mitigate traffic congestion. Hence, my goal for this capstone is to
 design a graphical visualization tool that could show the relationship between the
 links and the network in terms of the congestion propagation speed.

Title: Design of an Automatic Test Pattern Generation Tool for VLSI Transition Faults
Abstract:
Integrated circuits are extensively and universally utilized. Their applications vary
 from consumer products to mission critical electronics, creating a spectrum of susceptibility
 towards defects that accompany the manufacturing process. Thus, each electronic chip
 undergoes testing that determines whether the chip is defective or defect-free upon
 being manufactured. The testing process encompasses the application of carefully selected
 test patterns that produce an output which is observed and compared to an expected
 output. There are number of fault models that guide the testing process. This project
 aims to create an Automatic Test Pattern Generation Tool, a software tool, targeting
 the transition delay fault model. The test patterns generated by the software tool
 will then be used in the hardware component of the project. The test patterns will
 be applied to a desired circuit uploaded to an FPGA board to verify the output responses.
 The output will be verified by observing the output response to the expected output
 given the circuit under test. This is the test application phase of the project.

Title: Towards the Design of Intelligent 3D Computer Vision
Abstract:
This capstone project aims to design an intelligent framework for addressing such
 challenging issues from ever-growing 3D datasets. We intend to develop a system that
 takes 3D objects and presents them in various robust analytical models. Specifically,
 the proposed framework seeks to develop a cohesive and consistent shape analysis pipeline
 system that can correctly identify and preserve the important features of shapes.
 These important shape features will be processed and modelled into shape correspondences
 for 3D shapes registration, shape descriptors to evaluate the geometric similarities
 between shapes for 3D shape retrieval, and a clustering paradigm for discerning parts
 for 3D shape segmentation. The overall shape analysis pipeline is intended to deliver
 a standard process for capturing 3D object information from different analytical perspectives
 for further field-specific interests, such as categorization, detection, and representation.
 These perspectives are based in one-to-one, one-to-all, and introspective object comparisons
 that provide deep yet generally important understanding of shape features, opening
 them to further studies in matching, relating, and labelling.
