Author(s): Alhosani, Hamdan Ahmed, and Hazem Ibrahim
Title: SFLL-HD Logic Locking Framework
Abstract:
IC netlists are valuable assets by nature since they hold the basic design of electronic
 chips. However, the process of manufacturing chips is complicated as there are multiple
 threats from untrusted users and fabricators. Logic Locking has been perceived as
 a promising and reliable defense mechanism against intellectual property piracy, reverse
 engineering and overbuilding attacks. Stripped Functionality Logic Locking, or SFLL,
 is proven to be resilient to all types of hardware attacks on a netlist in the paper
 Provably Secure Logic Locking: From Theory To Practice. [1] SFLL strips some of the
 functionality of the circuit and hides it in the form of a secret key(s). Thereby,
 rendering the on-chip implementation functionally different than the original netlist.
 Currently, implementing any logic locking framework on a given netlist is complicated.
 In this paper, we propose a software framework that implements SFLL on any Verilog
 netlist. The software will produce a secured netlist that can thwart multiple attacks
 such as, SAT attack, removal attack and sanitization attack. In addition, verification
 of the correct implementation of SFLL security will be completed to ensure the validity
 of the software framework.

Title: A Portable Supercomputer
Abstract:
Supercomputers, while powerful and useful for intensive computing operations, are
 also extremely expensive with high power demands. Combining the processing power of
 these power efficient, low cost, 4 core, ARM processor based Raspberry Pi computers
 will allow for an investigation into creating a cheaper and more power efficient alternative.
 Mounting this cluster onto a portable iRobot base will allow for valuable information
 to be gleaned about the tradeoff between power consumption and performance.

Title: Hardware Accelerator for Visual Memory Reconstruction
Abstract:
In the field of neuroScience, there has been recent research on the reconstruction
 of visual working memory during the representation of items from the activity of neuronal
 populations, particularly focusing on oscillatory activity in the alpha band (8-12
 Hz). The objective of this project is a real time (i.e., less than 500ms) functional
 hardware implementation of memory reconstruction by feeding Magnetoencephalography
 (MEG) or electroencephalography (EEG) of neural oscillations to a Nexys 4 Artix-7
 Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) Trainer Board. This can be realized by converting
 the time-series to frequencies in the alpha region. In this proposal, a Hilbert transform
 with an iterative-pipelined hybrid architecture is chosen to achieve the most optimal
 results in terms of speed, complexity, and available hardware resources amongst various
 other solutions.

Title: Data Visualization and Feature Extraction
Abstract:
Advancements in the field of big data have brought on the need for new tools to understand
 the underlying properties of all this information. Data visualization presents one
 of the most productive ways of tackling this problem. Our solution focuses on extracting
 the key features that effectively describe the dataset and visualizing this information
 on an interactive display.The fundamental aspect of this design is creating a means
 for high performance dimensionality reduction. Whilst many solutions exist that use
 principle component analysis (PCA) or non-parametric algorithms, they struggle with
 generalizing to more complex manifolds and sparse data. Therefore, our approach instead
 makes use of a deep learning architecture. By creating a complex neural network hierarchy,
 we aim to optimize the solution and create a data describing mapping that corresponds
 to the intrinsic dimensionality of the data itself.

Author(s): Annor, Prince, Sampanna Bhattarai, and Alison Waterman
Title: Collaborative Control Design for a Drone Swarm
Abstract:
Simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) allows a drone to navigate and perceive
 its surrounding environment. In the past, drone systems have employed many technologies
 to perform relative localization, including various motion detection systems. With
 the reduced cost of high-resolution cameras and increased computational capabilities
 of on-board computers, computer vision techniques are now being investigated as additive
 sensors to inertial measurement unit systems. Several computer vision techniques
 employ fiducial markers with a recognizable pattern to perform pose estimation between
 the camera and the attached markers in the collaborating drones. This concept is used
 for relative drone localization while each drone performs SLAM using cameras, LiDAR
 and an IMU. In this project, a multi-sensor integration of a LiDAR sensor and a spherical-lens
 camera is used along with a wireless ad-hoc communication channel to assist in a collaborative
 control design for a drone swarm for visual aerial coverage purposes. Using simulations,
 a real-time Voronoi tessellation of the area in NYUAD's Robotics lab for two of the
 designed drones flying at the same height is also derived and the area coverage is
 achieved by commanding each drone to move towards the centroid of its assigned Region
 of Responsibility.

Title: Private Reality Framework Design
Abstract:
In the digital world, the average user works with a large amount of personal data
 on a daily basis that is processed into countless websites and applications, which
 include social media, banking, education and medical services. This data, encrypted
 or unencrypted, is often stored in the user's personal devices. When these devices
 are connected to the internet, there is an opportunity for third parties to digitally
 access such data without the user's permission, which compromises privacy. In the
 first half of 2019, more than 3,800 publicly-disclosed data breaches in companies
 have been recorded, exposing 4.1 billion compromised records. This project serves
 to build a framework using a head-mounted display (HMD) to enable privacy-preserving
 applications by allowing the user to handle his or her unencrypted data without using
 digital communication. An application was developed in the HMD in which data transmission
 was carried out over the visual spectrum, using photons as information carriers to
 eliminate the need for digital connections. It enables the user to scan visually encoded
 ciphertext on a computer screen and view the plaintext in the HMD.

Title: ramen: Design and Development of a Raft Consensus Algorithm Coupled With a IEEE 802
Abstract:
Consensus is a fundamental problem in fault tolerant distributed systems and involves
 multiple nodes arriving at a coordinated decision. Reaching a consensus is challenging
 if the system is dynamic and makes decisions in real time (such as in autonomous vehicles
 and mobile sensor networks). Consensus algorithms ensure that a cluster of devices
 can cooperatively complete its tasks even if the cluster loses its leader. However,
 when a consensus algorithm is built upon a typical hub spoke network topology, the
 algorithm may be rendered useless if the singular network access point fails. A mesh
 network is a non hierarchical topology for local networks where devices can directly
 communicate amongst themselves without a central node for coordination, making them
 resilient to a single point of failure. Our capstone project implements Raft, a distributed
 consensus algorithm, atop a mesh network for use in low power embedded systems. We
 developed an open source software library and prototyped it on a custom printed circuit
 board. Our compiled software library consumes 0.33MB of flash memory and is capable
 of supporting over 100 nodes. During elections, it takes an average of 300ms to elect
 a new leader with insignificant variation as the network size grows.

Title: Design of a Machine Learning System to Quantify Haptic Experience
Abstract:
The objective of the capstone project is to design a system to quantify aspects of
 user haptic experience using brain signals from EEG. We aim to use EEG data collected
 from a previous study at the Applied Interactive Multimedia lab (AIMlab) to quantify
 haptic experience using EEG data and machine learning, in particular the haptic delay.
 Our final machine learning model achieves an accuracy of 83.2 ± 0.573% (reported within
 a 95% confidence level) in detection of a haptic delay in the user experience from
 a single trial EEG data stream using a light gradient boosting machine. Using EEG
 data to quantify haptic experience renders our model more accurate, and objective,
 which will have many applications in designing haptic electronics, attention rehabilitation,
 and neuroscience research.

Title: Visualization Tool for Traffic Data
Abstract:
With more than 1.2 billion cars on the roads worldwide, traffic congestion is one
 of the biggest transportation problems in cities. Congestion has serious economic
 costs; for example, in the United States alone, the freight sector loses more than
 $74 billion annually due to congestion, and costs to individual drivers exceed $88
 billion. Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) produce large amounts of traffic
 data that can be used to monitor, assess, and improve the performance of those same
 transportation systems. Since generated data are largely abstract, unstructured, and
 high-dimensional, it is difficult for researchers to interpret and analyze them. Visualization
 tools can effectively represent data, reveal hidden patterns, and enable to combine
 human capabilities with machine intelligence in deducing new patterns. The product
 of this Capstone project is a novel easy-to-use, scalable visualization tool that
 preprocesses and organizes traffic data, aggregates them into selected levels of abstraction
 (links, nodes, or hexagon grid cells of variable size), and visualizes their properties
 in effective ways at user request.

Title: Design of Arabic Sign Language Interpreter Using Microsoft Kinect
Abstract:
This final report is made for the Senior Capstone Design Project of New York University
 Abu Dhabi. It outlines a proposed solution to overcome a large part of the difficulties
 that hearing-impaired people face when they need to communicate. As a second benefit,
 the solution also facilitates education of sign-language. It also contains information
 related to the progress in implementing the solution.Currently there are no affordable solutions on the market, and previous results are
 either lacking in quality or highly limited in usability. With the help of the next
 generation of hardware sensors, the proposed solution is aimed to greatly improve
 on these shortcomings while bearing an affordable price tag. In addition, the proposed
 solution is the first known of its kind that focuses on Arabic sign language, an area
 where current awareness is low and the room for improvement is vast.The solution consists of an affordable hardware sensor available on the market and
 software algorithms designed in order to process the data acquired by the sensor.
 Together they set up a system that is robust, user-friendly and also possesses the
 potential for a wide reach through its low price point.

Title: FPGA Based Network for Fast Microprocessor Simulation
Abstract:
Simulation and verification are important stages in the manufacturing of modern day
 microprocessors. As digital design systems increase in complexity, the task of running
 an effective software simulation of these systems becomes computationally expensive
 and prohibitive. Such designs contain billions of transistors, while a typical workload
 executes in several million-clock cycles. Thus, workload software simulation to completion
 is infeasible in lower levels of abstraction. In order to bypass the slow software
 simulation speed, a simulation using a network of FPGAs is proposed. FPGAs are reconfigurable
 devices that can implement a digital design. They have hardware speed and reliability
 and don't incur on the large price required for ASIC design. This makes FPGAs ideal
 for implementing simulation of digital devices. However, the size of the digital design
 that each FPGA can simulate depends on the limited number of configurable blocks available
 and the total number of IO located on its banks. In this project, a network of FPGAs
 will be developed that will efficiently simulate a modern microprocessor. A scalable
 system was built and a simulation speed up of 20x software simulation has been achieved.

Author(s): Pacareu, Pablo, and Pedro Gaizka Zufiria Gerboles
Title: Development of a Red-Team-In-a-Box hardware platform
Abstract:
The modernization of critical infrastructure has enabled advanced monitoring and control
 capabilities, through the inclusion of microprocessor computing systems using commercial-off-the-shelf
 integrated circuits and commonly used protocols. Therefore, these systems are susceptible
 to cyber-attacks. The aim of the project was to identify possible entry points in
 order to fortify said systems. An advanced sensing platform was developed, which could
 facilitate physical penetration testing of industrial control systems. The platform
 had its own processing capabilities and operated on a battery in order to achieve
 autonomy. The sensors used were integrated on a custom-built PCB. The goal was to
 maximize the information collected by the platform, while minimizing the power consumption
 and the cost. The resulting platform was able to fingerprint industrial devices, eavesdrop
 on communications and collect other information needed to generate a detailed map
 of the surrounding environment of the industrial control system.

Title: Design of Secure and Testable Chips
Abstract:
Integrated circuit production facilities cost upward of $1billion to build and maintain,
 which is why semiconductor companies are shifting into a more effective fabless model.
 In this system, chip designers create circuit floorplans, but do not manufacture the
 chips in house. Instead, external foundries produce the chip. The purpose of the capstone
 project was to conduct an implementation from RTL to silicon, while addressing concerns
 of a fabless design process. As most chip foundries are substitutable, the IP of chip
 designs is the core value driver in the industry. Thus, the project focused on integrating
 new functionalities with an existing design of an ARM CortexM0 chip. To ensure that
 the chip is easily testable after manufacturing, we enriched it with a JTAG test module
 for functional and scan chain testing. Since providing the chip design to foundries
 around the world raises concerns about illegal chip overproduction and tampering,
 we applied the SARLock logic encryption method. Lastly, we conducted rigorous physical
 implementation. We implemented the physical chip from the RTL description of the ARM
 CortexM0 Microprocessor to the GDSII format.

Title: Automated Fetal kick Monitoring Belt
Abstract:
Monitoring fetal well-being is a crucial procedure in modern obstetrics. Among the
 many methods of checking fetal well-being, fetal movement detection is widely used
 to identify changes in fetal activity and reduce the possibility of fetal distress
 and stillbirth. Doctors also recommend pregnant women to use fetal kick counting as
 a way to monitor their baby's health beginning from the third trimester. Fetal movement
 counting is a method by which pregnant women quantify the movements they feels to
 assess the condition of their baby. While fetal kick can vary on daily bases, a significant
 deviation from the normally expected value, which is 10 kicks in 2 hours, indicates
 that the woman should consult her medical provider. While fetal movement can be observed
 using ultrasound imaging, a non-invasive and home based monitoring system is still
 in development to enable pregnant women perform self-administrated monitoring. In
 this project, an Automated Fetal Kick system will developed by integrating an array
 of force sensors in a maternal belt, and sends information about the number of kicks
 and the frequency to a cell phone via wireless communication.

Title: Improving Wi-Fi for High Density Environments
Abstract:
Due to the improvements made to the wireless standard in the past two decades, wireless
 has overtaken wired as the dominant form of communication today. To meet the future
 data traffic needs, the Wi-Fi standard of today will need to be significantly improved
 in both the quality of service and security. Since the number of Wi-Fi networks in
 both residential and enterprise environments is increasing rapidly, the interference
 between geographically collocated networks is becoming one of the significant issues
 of Wi-Fi, which happens because access points of different Wi-Fi networks operate
 independently. A device located at the overlap of two or more networks may not be
 able to receive data because access points from various networks are interfering.
 This is called the hidden terminal problem. Given that the hardware processing capabilities
 are increasing, in the future, the signal detection threshold of CSMA/CA may become
 a dynamic value. In this paper, we propose using a dynamic CSMA/CA signal detection
 energy thresholds instead of the currently static one. The signal detection threshold
 will utilize the signal strength received from the access point to solve the hidden
 terminal problem more effectively.

Author(s): Elwazir, Yara and Farzan Ahmed Khan
Title: Handwriting Learning Platform
Abstract:
Many studies have shown that incorporating haptic stimulus into education tools expedites
 the handwriting learning process and improves retention. The first prototype of the
 haptic handwriting device was developed in the Applied Interactive Media Lab and experiments
 conducted on the device showed the effectiveness of the tool in teaching non-Arabic
 speakers how to write Arabic letters. The setup consisted of a Novint Falcon Device,
 which manipulated a pen moving over the letters displayed on a monitor. Feedback collected
 from these experiments pointed to some hardware shortcomings, which showed the device
 had significant room for improvement. Feedback fit the following three categories;
 obstruction of line of sight, limited usability to right-handed users and different
 planes of operation of the display and pen movement. This capstone project is aimed
 at revising the hardware design and software GUI to tackle these problems and to develop
 a ready to use haptic learning device for children. The second-generation device will
 then be tested through a revised experimental procedure and the results will be compared
 to the results collected with the first-generation device.

Author(s): Abebe, Alemayehu Mekonen, and Joseph Opey
Title: Design of a Jacket System Displaying Thermal and Vibration Feedback
Abstract:
In this capstone project, the design of a thermo-vibration actuation jacket is proposed
 to display synchronized vibration and thermal cues for interpersonal communication.
 There haVE been several thermal jackets on the market most of which focuse on controlling
 ambient temperature. In this report, a vibro-thermal actuation jacket is designed
 where simultaneous simulation of temperature and vibration is possible. Major implementations
 included wiring up the jacket and including the vibration and thermal actuators with
 control board for the actuators. The wiring of the jacket was successful and thermal
 and vibration activation was successful in the process. The psycho physical study
 enabled us to determine the perceived thermal states (cold, cool, neutral,warm and
 hot) that correspond to an actual temperature within 15 to 40 degree Celsius temperature
 range.

Author(s): Afzal, Muhammad Muneeb, Fahad Ahmad, Muhammad Osama Khan, and Fathur Said
Title: Deep Learning Approaches for Self-Driving cars in an Adversarial Environment
Abstract:
The robustness of the deep learning models YOLO and CurveNet to two types of adversarial
 attacks (one-pixel attack and physical perturbation attack) was investigated in this
 capstone project. The main contributions and findings of this work include the following:
 • A novel curved lane detection algorithm CurveNet was designed.
 • One-pixel attack on the YOLO object detector was found to have a higher success
 rate compared to the physical perturbation attack.
 • Our lane detection algorithm CurveNet was found to be robust to both one-pixel and
 physical perturbation attacks.
 
 Autonomous vehicles, security, adversarial, self-driving, deep machine learning

Author(s): Almarri, Noora, Maha AlMazroui, and Henok Guluma
Title: Designing A Framework for Dental Simulation using Virtual Reality
Abstract:
Dental education has evolved through the years as various technologies were developed
 to provide a smooth transition from the classroom to clinical practical settings.
 Through the years, Virtual Reality (VR) simulators are becoming an essential part
 of modern dental education. Our project aims to design, develop, and evaluate a framework
 for simulating dentist-patient interaction using VR. Our project focuses on designing
 a three-dimensional model, through MakeHuman software, that is animated with different
 facial expressions, body movements, and vocal responses that can tell the dentist
 more about how the patient is feeling. The goal of our system is to present dental
 trainees with the basic communication skills and treatment acts that is required to
 deal with patients. The simulation we created is composed of three parts: pre-treatment,
 during treatment, and the post-treatment. There is a smooth transition between these
 scenarios, where the trainee is being tested on his or her dental performance accordingly.
 The dental simulation offers dentist-patient scenarios that include audio communication,
 visual communication, and an overall evaluation of the dentist's performance. The
 system was built on 3D Unity Game Engine, and was later tested on a group of dental
 students from the University of Sharjah (UOS), Sharjah, United Arab Emirates.

Title: Learning-Based Visual Tracking: Using PTZ Cameras to Track Commercial UAVs
Abstract:
The goal of this capstone is to create a visual processing routine that detects and
 tracks airborne drones for security applications in airports, air bases, and other
 drone frequented locations. The produced platform will realize this function with
 a pan-tilt-zoom mounted Full HD camera for data acquisition and a computer with a
 discrete graphical processing unit (GPU) for image processing. Such camera systems
 have use in automatic surveillance in both indoor and outdoor locations. By embedding
 the zoom into the tracking routine, this project aims to extend functionality to over
 100 m. The system is broken down into dynamic object detection, object identification,
 tracking, and camera controller components. The project aims to provide an integration
 of existing algorithms in each category to realize the outlined goal. Results suggest
 that the framework allows for efficient visual servoing. Unlike most visual servoing
 routines, the proposed mechanism can leverage object detection to expand re-detection
 capabilities.

Title: Muon-Ra: A Cosmic Ray-based Quantum Random Number Generator
Abstract:
Muon decay is a natural phenomenon based on the collision of cosmic radiation with
 Earth's atmospheric particles. A Cosmic Ray Detector can be used to ionize muons striking
 the surface of the detector, thus conveying information about a given muon's position
 of hit, angle of hit and time interval between subsequent hits. Muon strikes are non-deterministic
 and the information they yield can be used as seeds to a True Random Number Detector
 (TRNG). In this work, a Quantum TRNG is proposed that translates position and angle
 of muon strikes into random numbers. Several designs are created and evaluated on
 the basis of the ability of the output to pass randomness tests and rate of throughput.
 The most robust design is incorporated as an online service that can be used to generate
 random numbers in real time.

Author(s): Gebremedhin, Ruth, Ken Iiyoshi, and Mahrukh Tauseef
Title: Design of a Haptic-Audio-Visual Tele-Dental Training Simulation
Abstract:
Over the past two decades, high-speed communication technologies have revolutionized
 applications of Tactile Internet (TI) by allowing low-latency data transfer. This
 has led to the emergence of haptic-based medical simulations that have numerous technical
 and ethical advantages in medical training. Since dental training is a highly haptic
 task, tactile internet has the potential to improve the current dental training techniques
 by allowing communication of motor skills as haptic media. This project designs and
 implements a detailed, virtual-reality based simulation of a periodontal procedure
 using haptic technology and a realistic 3D model of the oral cavity. A communication
 system that allows low-latency transmission of haptic and audio-visual data over a
 network was developed. The local-hosted communication network performed with minimal
 overhead; an average delay of 0.62 ms and jitter of 0.53 ms for haptic data, and round
 trip time of less than 30 ms for audio-visual data. This system enables effective
 supervised training over a physical distance and is more interactive than commonly
 used non-haptic computer simulations.

Author(s): Ahmad, Baleegh, Sohail Bagheri, Prajna Soni, and Antony Tahan
Title: Designing a Predictive Model of Mangrove Health using Remote Sensing in Mumbai
Abstract:
This project provides a novel solution of consolidating aerial imagery and predictive
 modeling as functions of changes in the built and natural environment to provide data-driven
 predictions to help conserve mangrove health in Mumbai's Thane Creek. The final model
 design will provide a better understanding of how pollutant flow information can supplement
 satellite imagery data to better identify sources of polluted discharge that impact
 mangrove health. The project tracks mangrove cover in the region using unsupervised
 classification on satellite imagery through color cluster analysis. It identifies
 a trend line for seasonal variation in mangrove cover, thus allowing for deviations
 due to anthropogenic activities to be identified. A trend line with an error margin
 of 17.9% was calculated, therefore any decrease of mangrove cover greater than the
 critical point would be flagged, allowing the instance to be investigated further.
 The project stems from the lack of an appropriate tool that is able to quantify the
 effect that changes in the local environment can have on mangroves. The proposed tool
 is envisioned to help marine biologists, researchers, and governments understand where
 pollutants flow from and what path they take to impact mangrove health negatively.

Title: Designing Haptic Effects for Touch-Screen Devices
Abstract:
The design of haptic effects caters to the touch-screen market and its users worldwide.
 The goal of our capstone project is to introduce tactile interaction to touch-screen
 devices by designing haptic effects for Graphical User Interface (GUI) elements on
 touch-screen devices and conducting a series of human studies to evaluate them. The
 design concept includes developing a library of haptic effects that are easily integrable
 to GUIs based on analyzing touch interactions and user evaluations. The haptic effects
 library focuses on how users perceive the effects in terms of multi-task interactions
 with touch-screen devices. The library generated via our gradient-based technique
 (friction control) and audio waveforms (click effects) allows better identification
 of GUI elements, hence, meeting our criteria for testing realism and affordance. User
 evaluation was not achieved due to the impact of COVID-19 on this project, however,
 expert evaluation cross-checked the affordance of physical interactions. Usability
 and performance should be carried forward and tested in person for better results.
 Through the implementation of our project, we aim to bring back life to touch-screen
 devices through haptic technology.

Author(s): Ibrahim, Lujain, Munib Mesinovic, and Kai-Wen Yang
Title: Multi-Sensor System for Monitoring Acute Myocardial Infarction using Machine Learning
Abstract:
Cardiovascular disease is the number one cause of death globally, and in the UAE specifically,
 Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI) takes more lives than any other health condition.
 One of the major approaches towards tackling this formidable public health epidemic
 is by raising awareness and developing early-detection mechanisms so that people have
 enough time to preemptively tackle this health challenge. Our Capstone Design Project
 seeks to gather the physiological signals our body exhibits leading up to an AMI by
 using ECG and Pulse Oximetry sensors in a wearable armband and use machine learning
 analysis on the real-time collected data to provide personalized feedback to the user
 on their cardiovascular health and AMI risk condition. A printed circuit board (PCB)
 for the monitoring of cardiovascular parameters was designed and validated by EAGLE
 early-testing. Over 900,000 ECG, age, and sex samples obtained from the ECG-ViEW database
 have been used to train machine learning models, including naive bayes, logistic regression,
 CNN, and RNN, that predict the onset of AMI. High prediction accuracy of 90.5% (CNN)
 and 89.2% (RNN) have been achieved, demonstrating the promising application of early
 identification of AMI.

Author(s): Al-Nuaimy, Qutaiba, Aren Chen, Ghadeer Ghosheh, and Sanja Kastratovic
Title: Non-Contact ECG Monitoring System
Abstract:
Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) have been proven to be amongst the most deadly diseases
 worldwide. The majority of deaths associated with CVDs occurs amongst patients who
 have never been previously diagnosed with any CVDs. Many CVDs, such as arrhythmia,
 manifest their symptoms a long time prior to the onset of any adverse or catastrophic
 event(s), and such the early detection of cardiac abnormalities is incredibly important.
 However, traditional ECG monitoring systems face challenges with respect to their
 scalability and affordability as they require direct contact with the body and cumbersome
 equipment. In this Capstone Design Project, we aim to provide a solution to this problem
 by developing a small-size, non-contact, real-time feedback, and long-term monitoring
 lead-I ECG system. It is paired with an iOS application that receives the data through
 Bluetooth Low Energy and utilizes real-time machine learning analysis.

Title: Design of a Machine Learning System to Quantify Haptic Experience
Abstract:
The objective of the capstone project is to design a system to quantify aspects of
 user haptic experience using brain signals from EEG. We aim to use EEG data collected
 from a previous study at the Applied Interactive Multimedia lab (AIMlab) to quantify
 haptic experience using EEG data and machine learning, in particular the haptic delay.
 Our nal machine learning model achieves an accuracy of 83.2 plus or minus 0.573 percent
 (reported within a 95 percent con dence level) in detection of a haptic delay in the
 user experience from a single trial EEG data stream using a light gradient boosting
 machine. Using EEG data to quantify haptic experience renders our model more accurate,
 and objective, which will have many applications in designing haptic electronics,
 attention rehabilitation, and neuroscience research.

Author(s): Elgamal, Mariam, Yeojin Jung, Mohammed Adib Oumer, and Farida Shaban
Title: Indoor Acoustic Localization of Pests via IoT Technologies & Machine Learning
Abstract:
Museums are fighting a constant battle to preserve their invaluable specimens and
 artwork from pests that can potentially damage them, including the Louvre Abu Dhabi.
 This project aims to develop a sound detection and analysis system to detect, locate,
 and determine the population dynamics of crawling and flying pests (e.g., crickets),
 thereby allowing pest control strategies to be more targeted and efficient. By collecting
 such information about pests, museum facilities teams can target their use of pesticide
 to only the affected areas of the museum and hence reduce the total exposure of the
 museum collections to pesticides throughout the year. Additionally, the collected
 information could be used to identify trends in the population dynamics and aid in
 designing long-term non-chemical pest preventative strategies (i.e., traps, ultrasonic
 pest repellents). Our system utilizes a network of Internet of-Things (IoT) devices
 that would collect and process necessary real-time information on the cloud using
 signal processing, machine learning models and big data analysis methods to aid efficient
 pest-control plans. Ideally, the system will aid museum administrators in decision-making
 by providing real-time analysis and visualizations through a user interface on handheld
 devices such as mobile phones, tablets, and laptops.

Author(s): Garcia, Cristian, Rumail Memon, and Ahmad Nasralla
Title: Design of a non-invasive cell density monitoring device for bacterial batch cultures
Abstract:
The proposed system is a device that enables automated non-invasive monitoring of
 cell density within a biological lab incubator during experiment preparation. The
 proposed device will have an accuracy within 5% of lab-grade spectrophotometers, a
 battery life of over 48 hours, and a component price below 150 USD. The target users
 are biological lab technicians currently required to manually measure, monitor, and
 estimate cell density via sporadic sampling over dozens of hours. The current technique
 is problematic because it consumes time, requires continuous inspection, involves
 human error, and occasionally contaminates or invalidates the experiment preparation.
 Due to time constraints and limitations by the COVID-19 pandemic, full development
 was not complete. However, the current progress serves as proof of concept that a
 device with such requirements is possible.

Title: Fabrication and Control of Robotic Laparoscopic System
Abstract:
Robot-assisted surgery can address the limitations of minimally invasive surgical
 operations and to further enhance the confidence and precision of physicians conducting
 open surgery. Increasingly, the research in the industry has been evolving towards
 the development of completely automated surgical robotic systems. This project focuses
 on minimally invasive laparoscopic surgery and aims to design, implement and utilize
 an assistive surgical robotic system to conduct the necessary incision while enforcing
 the Fulcrum Point. This process entails designing, simulating and fabricating the
 laparoscopic tool while mechanically integrating it onto a commercially available
 robotic system. The performance of the system will be corroborated by a tool-tracking
 methodology to ensure the integrity of the simulated surgical operation.

Author(s): Lin, Wei-Chung, and Sowani, Francis Thomas
Title: Design of Automatic Test Pattern Generation System for VLSI Stuck-at-Faults
Abstract:
Applications vary from consumer electronics, such as phones and computers, to mission-critical
 ones such as those used for medical or avionics applications. Every chip is subjected
 to testing, as the manufacturing process is prone to defects. In the test process,
 a carefully selected set of input patterns are applied to chips, and the observed
 responses from the chip under test reveal whether the chip is good or bad. Today,
 the test process that aims at screening out the bad chips constitutes about 25-30%
 of the overall product cost.The software system that produces the set of input patterns and their expected responses
 is called Automatic Test Pattern Generation (ATPG) system. It takes in a design netlist
 that describes circuit structure and a fault model that describes the targeted types
 of defects, and produces the test patterns. A traditionally used fault model is called
 the stuck-at fault model, which models defects that cause a net (wire) to be always
 stuck at 0 or 1, regardless of the actual value of the net.This project aims at the design, development and evaluation of an ATPG system that
 targets only the stuck-at faults.

Title: Transportation for Smart Cities
Abstract:
Transportation for smart cities, significantly based on modern data Science and traffic
 analytics, is entirely dependent on the availability of accurate knowledge of real-time
 traffic conditions. Accurate data representing real-time traffic conditions is necessary
 for real-time traffic analytics, whose applications can range from network-wide signal
 control, real-time trip planning, to traffic incidents response. However, traffic
 analytics is often encumbered by the fact that real-time data is unavailable for large
 portions of the urban networks at any given instant. Thus data is discontinuous, interrupted
 and quite sparse to reflect the real-time traffic state and to be useful for any real-time
 applications. Therefore, urban traffic state estimation has become the core challenging
 problem for practitioners and researchers in the field. The goal of this capstone
 work is to identify and calculate spatio-temporal correlations in traffic flow that
 can be used for real-time traffic state estimation. The project focuses on developing
 a model for real-time traffic data reconstruction that allows for using the sparse
 data from instrumented road segments to accurately estimate the traffic conditions
 for segments that lack instrumentation.

Author(s): Carelli, Daniel, Jovan Jovancevic, and Kyler Meehan
Title: reefRover
Abstract:
Coral reefs in the UAE are under threat of disappearance due to rising sea temperatures.
 Despite the importance of studying the response of coral and marine life to the changing
 climate, marine researchers are not equipped with the personnel or time to survey
 the reefs on a large scale. Existing methods for coral monitoring are limited, compromising
 either on accuracy and detail, as with remote sensing, or time and efficiency of data
 collection, as with manta tows and SCUBA transects. The reefRover project aims to
 provide a solution to this problem in the form of an autonomous ROV that will perform
 transects along the reef and obtain high-quality images of the coral in the UAE. The
 ROV will be developed in a manner that enables community divers to deploy the device
 while ensuring data quality, and the reefRover project will be kept open-source, allowing
 anyone across the world to develop and deploy the reefRover and expand the available
 data on coral reefs. The team is divided into three main efforts—Underwater Positioning
 System, Image Processing, and ROV Integration—and the vision is to have a fully operational,
 autonomous ROV for deployment in May 2018.

Title: Rapid Sustainable Urbanisation in Peri-Urban UAE
Abstract:
The last few decades have witnessed a global rapid urbanisation trend which is expected
 to reach its zenith mid the 21st century when the global human population will start
 to plateau. The biggest challenge is complexity in planning ahead for the burgeoning
 population with a keen consideration of electricity and water resources management,
 availability of adequate transport and communication infrastructure, and ease of accessing
 these public services. It has been observed that the population bleeds out of urban
 centres into peri-urban regions which are located between urban settings and their
 immediate rural surroundings. These regions are relatively untouched in terms of urban
 planning, but well within the economic reach and influence of nearby cities therefore
 they present a great potential for the next generation of urbanisation. This project
 explores new perspectives that can be brought to the construction industry to aid
 a shift towards a much needed sustainable practice, with emphasis on the environmental
 aspect. The design presented here is informed by background research and experiential
 work in the Solar Decathlon house project, and case studies conducted in Abu Dhabi
 and Dubai to benchmark practices that can be improved on and adopted for future undertakings.

Author(s): Kun, Janos Csaba, and Mohammed Omar
Title: Design of an Inkjet Generator for Metal Oxide Nanostructures
Abstract:
This investigation deals with printing metal oxide nanostructures using inkjet technology
 as it is a much cheaper process than current processes of nanostructure synthesis.
 This is achieved by creating fine aerosol particles with an HP c6614 #20 inkjet cartridge
 and leveraging the so-called "coffee ring effect". Upon their deposition on a heated
 substrate, the aqueous droplets evaporate leaving behind porous nano-membranes. To
 be of any practical use, the inkjet aerosol generator had to create droplets on demand
 that have a diameter of less than 20μm, an initial velocity of 5m/s, a frequency of
 1kHz and it should run for at least one hour continuously. Although, we fulfilled
 the first three specifications using the literature on our inkjet cartridge, the fourth
 was not. Our system however, finally synthesised ZnO porous nanomembranes which laid
 the foundation for future experimentation; our results were sufficient for our proof
 of concept. Future investigations would include studies on optimising the "throw distance"
 (defined as the distance from the inkjet nozzle to the substrate) to create the most
 useful nanostructures as well as creating a system that functions reliably for a practical
 time period.

Title: Design of a Microfluidic Dispensing Unit for C
Abstract:
The aim of the project is to build an automated unit that dispenses one C. elegans
 worm in each cycle of operation from the tip of the device. The unit is built from
 a PDMS structures, a worm-detection system, and a pneumatic valves system. A set of
 experiments to test, evaluate and optimize each of the segments of the unit was fundamental
 for the construction of the unit. The unit should provide a replacement for the time-consuming,
 labor intensive, manual work that currently takes place to obtain one worm from their
 environment. It should also provide a better alternative in terms of precision to
 the high through-put machine that is used to dispense the worms into different wells.

Author(s): Algaribeh, Nour Radi Saleh, Israel Desta, and Nahal Mustafa
Title: Design of a Microfluidic Dispensing Machine for Caenorhabditis elegans worms
Abstract:
The aim of this capstone project is to design and build a microfluidic-dispensing
 device to dispense a single C.elegans worm at a time into each micro-plate well. This
 device comprises microfluidic channels, pneumatic valves, a laser source, and a photodiode
 integrated in a Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) chip. When a C.elegans worm passes through
 the channel and blocks the laser light to the photodiode, a change in light intensity
 is observed and that change is used to detect the passage of the worm. A LabVIEW program
 is developed to detect this change in intensity and actuate the pneumatic valves that
 will allow trapping and disposing of the worm. The prototype accurately detects, traps
 and dispenses a single worm into a well plate.

Title:
High-throughput Micro-Fluidic Chip for Optogenetic Studies of Neuromuscular Diseases
                                 Using C
Abstract:
Human neuromuscular diseases are as common as 1 in 3000 people. Examples of these
 diseases include Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis,
 and these affect people and societies both physically and emotionally. Neuromuscular
 diseases lead to progressive loss in motor function and premature mortality. Vertebrate
 animal models have been for a long time used to study these diseases. These models
 however are expensive and slow. Newer models of using C elegans worms for studying
 neuromuscular diseases are under pursuit and growing rapidly. These models present
 the possibility to carry out the studies in a cost-efficient and high-throughput manner.
 There are challenges associated with the use of C-elegans worms however, due to the
 small sizes of the worms. These challenges include mainly automated handling and precise
 neural stimulation.

Author(s): Mahomed, Abdullah Ismail, Nkoskhona Msimanga, and Eder Munyampenda
Title: Water Filtration Using Plant Xylem
Abstract:
Our capstone project aims to address the global void in cost effective water filtration.
 Every year, millions of people die from waterborne diseases caused by bacteria and
 viruses due to lack of access to clean water. This tragic fact creates a need for
 solutions specifically targeted towards the lower-income demographic in the developing
 world. Based on a research paper published in 2014, gymnosperm plant xylem was identified
 as a suitable filtering material. Plant xylem's inner structure is uniquely suited
 for water filtration due to nanoscale pores located between its water carrying channels
 called tracheids. These nano-pores are the vehicle of filtration capable of removing
 99% of bacteria and particles larger than 100 nm. The goal of the project was to design
 a product that would provide individuals in developing countries with a method of
 taking advantage of xylem's filtering properties in an easy and cost-effective manner.
 The project design ultimately resulted in a two-piece plastic filter containment unit,
 whose cap is permanently attached to a jerry can, and whose xylem holder screws into
 the cap and contains eight holes to place xylem through. This paper describes the
 design process and an analysis of the final product.

Author(s): Abdallah, Said, Jean Edwards, and Tshering Gyaltshen
Title:
Concentrated Solar Powered Stirling Engine for Reverse Osmosis Desalination and Pumped
                                 Storage Hydroelectricity
Abstract:
As of 2009, the UAE had a total primary energy supply of 2,526.8 PJ, of which ~1.0
 PJ was from renewable sources (about 0.04%). The UAE has set goals to increase the
 proportion of renewable energy from the current levels of less than 1% to 25% by 2030.
 The aim of this project is to work towards the attainment of this goal and beyond,
 with a sustainable and cost-effective solution that makes use of the natural resources
 of the UAE. The proposed solution harvests solar energy with the help of Fresnel lens
 powered Stirling engines for both water desalination via reverse osmosis, and energy
 storage via a pumped storage hydroelectric system. Water desalination was addressed
 because it currently accounts for about 10% of the UAE's total energy consumption.
 The pumped storage system makes use of seawater as the working fluid, with reservoirs
 constructed on the UAE's natural Eastern mountain ranges located close to the sea,
 thereby addressing power generation requirements, grid energy storage needs and peak-load
 demands.

Author(s): Chapelle, Witold de la, Ting-Che Lin, and Xiao Lu
Title:
Product Design for Manufacture, Reliability and Marketing of a Device to Predict Plant
                                 Strength
Abstract:
Yield losses in maize (Zea mays L.) due to stalk lodging has significant negative
 economic impact. The lodging resistance in maize could be advanced more rapidly with
 the development of selective breeding tools that accurately predict stalk strength.
 Motivated by the strong correlation between flexural stiffness and stalk strength,
 a device that measures flexural rigidity was developed to predict stalk strength.
 To allow for a wider adaptation of such device, this Capstone aims to produce a second
 iteration of such device that is more accessible and robust. This is achieved through
 the integration of an intuitive graphical user interface, the redesign of mechanical
 structure to improve ergonomic comfort and robustness, and the refinement of electronics
 for more accurate data collection.

Author(s): Aboulhassan, Rami Haytham, Simeret Genet, Sahan Tampoe, and William Young
Title: Solar-Driven Absorption Air Conditioner
Abstract:
The purpose of this capstone project was to design, build and test a single-effect
 absorption refrigeration cycle that uses solar energy as the sole source of energy.
 Design goals were focused on low toxicity, sustainability, reliability and therefore,
 applicability to urban environments. Conventional vapor compression cycles use electricity
 and emit gases that cause air pollution and therefore, there is a strong imperative
 to create an alternative.
 The main drawbacks of the current absorption refrigeration systems, which use ammonia
 or lithium bromide working fluids, are:
 1. Ammonia is highly toxic, flammable and explosive. 2. Lithium bromide is expensive
 and has the issue of crystallization at a range of temperatures, pressures and concentrations.
 Thus, in this capstone project, ethylene glycol was used as an absorption medium for
 the working fluid (water). Specifically, the design process included:
 1. Optimization of the size of the absorber to get a coefficient of performance (COP)
 higher than 0.67. 2. Decreasing the heat loss from the desorber to increase the
 COP. 
 3. Preventing leakages when the cycle runs in a vacuum (pressure range from 1.5 kPa
 to 30 kPa) by using better-designed instruments. 4. Comprehensive data acquisition
 methods to get data from each component in the cycle.
 
 
 Absorber, Desorber, Condenser, Evaporator, Pump, Working fluids, Coefficient of performance,
 Sustainable Cooler, Air Conditioner

Title: Water Filtration system for developing region
Abstract:
Potable or drinkable water is defined as having acceptable quality in terms of its
 physical, chemical and bacteriological parameters so that it can be safely used for
 human consumption. Among the various water pollutants, biological contaminants are
 the most fatal in developing regions. The only possible way to achieve potable water
 is to carry out disinfection processes. According to the research conducted at MIT,
 nano-pores in Gymnosperm plant xylem has been identified as an efficient filter of
 bacteria due to the "short tracheid that would force water to flow through pit membranes".
 The availability of this plant in the region makes it an affordable and reliable source
 to be incorporated in a water filter device. In addition, adding a compartment for
 sand and charcoal each makes the water filter more efficient at filtering out the
 physical, chemical and biological contaminants. In this capstone project, we aim to
 achieve an advanced multi-step xylem-based filter that can filter bacteria and heavy
 metals without blockage problems at an economical cost to people residing in developing
 regions who do not have access to potable water.

Author(s): Aldhaheri, Sara, and Alexander Leigh MacKay
Title: GLiDAR: Design Optimization and Active Stabilization of LiDAR Sensor Payload for Surveying
Abstract:
The GLiDAR Capstone endeavours to enable the production of three-dimensional models
 that support the monitoring of changes to geographical features over time.GLiDAR applies
 advancements in solid-state LiDAR (Light Imaging, Detection, and Ranging) technology
 to address the challenges of expense, iterability, and data collection scale experienced
 in other surveying methods.Developed as an attachment for the Lockheed Martin INDAGO
 3 Unmanned Aerial System, GLiDAR contributes to the field of aerial surveying by enabling
 the generation of high-quality, localized data to support landmass tracking.

Title: , Amal Badri, Veronica Lee, and Ushna Usman
Abstract:
Continuous culture devices can be used for various purposes such as establishing reproducible
 growth conditions or maintaining cell populations under a constant environment for
 long time periods. To more accurately characterize biological systems, researchers
 must turn to static environments, which yield lower noise in quantitative phenotyping.
 A primary tool for culturing cells in a static environment is continuous culture,
 where inoculated growth medium is continually diluted with fresh medium. Turbidostats
 are powerful characterization tools that provide static culture environments; however,
 they are often expensive, especially when purchased in custom configurations, and
 are difficult to design and construct in a lab. Eight culture chambers are controlled
 simultaneously with the proposed configuration, and all components are readily available
 from various sources. We demonstrate that our continuous culture device can be used
 under different modes, and can easily be programmed to behave either as a turbidostat
 or fluorostat. Addition of fresh medium to the culture vessel is to be controlled
 by a real-time feedback loop or simply calibrated to deliver a defined volume. The
 project aims to build a device which is both cheaper and less laborious in comparison
 to the already existing commercial versions.

Author(s): Castillo, Alberto, Pratik Maisuria, and Mahmoud Soliman
Title: Reconstructing the Horologium of Harun Al-Rashid
Abstract:
The following report details the reconstruction of the horologium of Harun al-Rashid
 from an engineering perspective. The purpose of the project is to rebuild the water
 clock in the closest resemblance possible to the original based on existing literature.
 Furthermore, the project aims to capture the essence of the clock as a landmark in
 human achievement. For this purpose the clock is to be reproduced with the same aesthetic
 artistry as the original, as well as the entirety of the operational mechanism. In
 the interest of practicality, the clock will first be built at scale, maintaining
 only the water regulation mechanisms at full size. A marvel of the ancient world,
 the engineered replica will stand a testament to the achievement and technicality
 of Muslim engineers of the ancient world, namely Al-Jazari. In the long term, this
 capstone serves to mark the start of a project into tourism with a focus on the forgotten
 engineering marvels of the ancient Muslim world.

Title: Paper Based Filter For Water Purification
Abstract:
Problems such as the inaccessibility of clean drinking water and the non-recycling
 of paper are very common in today's world. Even though steps have been taken to rectify
 these problems, most of the solutions that exist are either expensive, technical or
 inaccessible in a lot of regions around the world. This project hopes to solve the
 problem of the inaccessibility of clean drinking water by designing a device that
 uses a stack of compressed paper while also making an effort to resolve problems related
 to paper recycling. The aim is to make the device cheap, easy to handle and readily
 available. So far, we have conducted several tests and carried out trouble-shooting
 mechanism to solve leakage issues. Data is being collected to test the filtration-efficiency
 and steps are being taken to improve the flow-rate of the device.

Title:
Design of a continuous monitoring system for the Mineral Nutrient Uptake by Plants
                                 in Hydroponic System
Abstract:
Vertical farming is an agricultural method of growing plants where roots are exposed
 to the water solvent rich in mineral nutrients. It aids in food security by providing
 control over all environmental factors, the preservation of endangered species of
 plants and the conservation of resources such as arable land and water. It is based
 on the finding that plants are best able to absorb particulate nutrients in a distance
 range of 1 to 50 micrometers (μm). Therefore, roots of the plants that are suspended
 within enclosed nutrient rich systems can better absorb and assimilate the minerals
 for more efficient farming with minimal water usage. Out of all available mineral
 nutrients, potassium ion (K+) plays particularly crucial role in plant growth and
 metabolism, and it is also the most abundant cation in plants. The project aims
 to develop a micro scale sensor that monitors the real time uptake of K+ via roots
 that are directly exposed to the nutrient solution. The data collected can be further
 used to optimize the amount of nutrients needed by plant thus minimizing nutrient
 waste and producing crops of higher nutritional value.

Title: Design of a Bio-inspired Lizard Robot Mimicking Tail Autotomy Process
Abstract:
Caudal autotomy is widespread among lizards: around 13 out of 20 families show this
 reflex severance strategy of their tails as a self-defence mechanism either to escape
 the predator's grasp or in anticipation of any life-threatening situation. The detached
 tail continues to wiggle (may go up to 30 minutes) through anaerobic metabolism and
 attracts the attention of the predator, which ultimately gives time to the lizard
 escape the ambush site. The mechanism of autotomy still remains secret. To explain
 this sheer bizarre phenomenon, we have developed a mechanistic model. Bio-inspired
 by the microstructures found on the broken tail surfaces, a bio-interlocking model
 containing an array of hemispherical microstructures was proposed. To test the model,
 a lab test setup was built and experiments on the biomimetic tail part were performed
 for its characterization. Finally, to demonstrate the actuatable interlock mechanism,
 a lizard robot was designed and fabricated. This robot detects incoming danger (incoming
 objects) and releases its tail while running away, as a real lizard would do. The
 robot and its tail shedding mechanism using the actuated bio-interlock was successfully
 tested.

Author(s): Kedia, Raghav, Gjorgji Shemov, and Jotham Varghese
Title: A Radio-controlled Car with Dual Power Sources of Solar and Battery
Abstract:
The project aims to design a 1:10 radio-controlled (RC) car powered by 1 Suoaki photovoltaic
 (PV) panel and 1 5000mAh Gens Ace Hardcase Li-Po battery, using SCX10 II™ 2000 Jeep®
 Cherokee as a model car. Mini projects have been completed by the student in the field
 of designing LiPo battery chargers and simulating car performance in the Gazebo Simulation
 software. A preliminary printed circuit board (PCB) has been designed and is currently
 being refined to be manufactured and tested. Several PV panel mounting structures
 are being prototyped and tested for structural competency and practicality. The car
 must navigate between sets of GPS waypoints with minimal human intervention. This
 requires the car to be driven to a certain level of autonomy by using obstacle detection
 and avoidance maneuvers whilst also relaying this information back and forth with
 the central computer using bidirectional communication over long distances.

Title: Fluidic Injection Thrust Reverser System for High Bypass Ratio Turbofan Engines
Abstract:
Conventional thrust reversers rely on mechanical blockers to block and reverse the
 flow of air. As they are designed to sustain heavy loads, they are bulky and hence
 account for 30% of the nacelle weight (excluding the engine core). This added engine
 weight results in a 0.5%-1% increase in the specific fuel consumption of the aircraft.
 The goal of this project is to design a thrust reverser system for high bypass ratio
 turbofan engines that uses fluidic injection to reverse the flow of air, eliminating
 the need of mechanical blockers completely. The project validates "Blockerless Engine
 Thrust Reversers (BETR)" proposed by NASA Langley and culminates with the construction
 of a working model demonstrating the applicability of optimized design. This report
 summarizes the entire process of building an experimental model of a "Fluidic Injection
 Thrust Reverser (FITR)" system. A detailed experimental investigation showed that
 ~71.5% of the fan flow (mass flow rate) with ~70% injection (in terms of fan flow).
 Operating at these parameters, the net negative thrust force readings reiterated our
 claim of achieving ~78% reversal of thrust through our implementation of FITR.

Author(s): Ali-Hassan, Adnan, Amr El-Ashmouny, and Gladys Mwedzi
Title: Design of Cyclic Tensile Apparatus for Studying Cancer Cells
Abstract:
Studying the effect of mechanical forces on the migratory and biological responses
 of cancer cells is of interest to several fields including drug delivery and metastasis.
 Several stretching devices have been designed and implemented to study functional
 responses of various cells by inducing elastic deformations on them. However, despite
 being helpful in our current understanding of cellular mechanobiology, they entail
 various limitations. This senior undergraduate capstone project aims to develop a
 custommade stretching device that fits in an incubator as well as on a microscope
 stage, yet offers various stretching scenarios during the same experiment. Our device
 constitutes a PDMS chip with multiple wells of different shapes including circular,
 square, rectangular, and oval. A thin PDMS membrane covers the wells-chip and stretches
 upon pressurizing the wells. Our study considered optimizing the wells' sizes and
 shapes, and results show that the membrane stretches differently corresponding to
 each well geometry. Therefore, cancer cells seeded on the PDMS membrane can experience
 different stretching magnitudes, directions, and distributions, within the same setup
 and during the same experiment. Next steps include building and testing the biochip,
 followed by studying the response of cancer cells under these different multiaxial
 stretching scenarios.

Author(s): Alabbasi, Majid, Shahad Badri, and Yuanbei Fan
Title: Design of an Autonomous Wave Powered Desalination Unit
Abstract:
The objective of the capstone project is to design and model an autonomous wave powered
 reverse osmosis desalination unit. Local wave conditions include an average wave height
 of 0.5 m at depths of 21-30 m in the Gulf region. In the unit, a round buoy extracts
 kinetic energy from the heaving motions of the ocean waves and drives a submerged
 positive displacement pump to pressurize seawater through the reverse osmosis membrane
 in the desalination process. The desalinated permeate is transferred into a reservoir
 on shore, while the high concentrated brine is discharged to the ocean. Using the
 "Delbuoy" desalination unit as a benchmark, a more efficient system is developed by
 implementing bistable springs to create a nonlinear stiffness system. This system
 is able to reach resonance with incoming seawaves at different natural frequencies,
 therefore achieves a higher permeate production of 0.252 m^3 /s. The design skips
 the intermediate step of the electromechanical conversion process, therefore utilizes
 no generators or motors, which offers advantages such as reduced cost, simplicity
 in the design and installation process, and increased power efficiency.

Title: 3D Printed Water Purification Filter Based on Paper Lateral Flow
Abstract:
This project develops a novel 3D printed water purification filter that works based
 on water lateral flow within a single paper sheet. This new filter is an advancement
 of a previously invented Paper-Based Water Purification Filter. Although the employment
 of several materials between both projects are similar, this project involves new
 design that solves associated drawbacks with the previous filter. The goal is to be
 able to provide accessible purified water utilizing a simple device. This would be
 brought to areas where clean decontaminated water isn't readily available, as well
 as where there is a demand to remove undesirable chemicals and biological contaminants
 from water. The device will still similarly utilize a paper platform as the core for
 water purification, thus tackling the issue of paper recycling, among the addition
 of new materials such as charcoal. This filter design is completely new, utilizes
 only a single sheet of paper, and solves water leakage problems with a clean-cut route.
 In total, the new filter will be executed in a way that reduces technical past issues
 faced such as paper stacking, water leakage, and purification throughput as well as
 allowing for efficiency in purifying water.

Title: Fabrication and Control of Robotic Laparoscopic System
Abstract:
Robot-assisted surgery can address limitations of minimally invasive surgical operations
 and to further enhance confidence and precision of physicians conducting open surgery.
 Increasingly, the research in the industry has been evolving towards the development
 of completely automated surgical robotic systems. This project focuses on the minimally
 invasive laparoscopic surgery and aims to design, implement and utilize an assistive
 to a surgeon robotic system to conduct the necessary incision while enforcing the
 Fulcrum Point. This process entails designing, simulating and fabricating the laparoscopic
 tool while mechanically integrating it onto a commercially available robotic system.
 The performance of the system will be corroborated by a tool-tracking methodology
 to ensure the integrity of the simulated surgical operation.

Title:
The Effect of Chronic Social Stress on Core Temperature Rhythms and Related Changes
                                 in Gene Expression of RBM3 and HSF1
Abstract:
Individuals affected by mood disorders display dysregulations in circadian rhythms.
 However, it isn't known if these irregularities arise as a result of mood disorders
 or if they play a causal role. Discernment of the nature of the association could
 shed light on potential markers and treatment strategies. Chronic stress can result
 in or aggravate such mood disorders. This project utilized a mouse model and the
 chronic social defeat stress paradigm to investigate the relationship between circadian
 temperature rhythmicity and mood disorders. Surgical implantation of a wireless device
 allowed for core temperature measurements of control, stress resilient, and stress
 susceptible mice to be recorded both prior to and during exposure to the stress paradigm.
 Results ascertained that resilient and susceptible mice exhibit dampened temperature
 amplitudes during chronic social stress. To examine associated molecular changes,
 RT-qPCR was used to determine the expression levels of thermosensitive genes: RNA-binding
 motif 3 (RBM3) and heat shock factor 1 (HSF1) which are linked to temperature decrease
 and increase respectively. No changes were observed in HSF1 levels. However, RBM3
 was downregulated in resilient and susceptible mice during the inactive phase. This
 finding differs from its expected expression patterns.

Title:
A Quantitative Approach to a Fluidic Injection Thrust Reverser Design for Turbofan
                                 Engines
Abstract:
The goal of this project is to design an optimized FITR system and provide a quantitative
 analysis on its efficiency and feasibility. The project will have three main phases
 of development, namely, (1) Simulations (2) Modelling and (3) Testing. In the Simulation
 phase, extensive Computational Fluid Dynamics studies will be carried out on a full
 sized and scaled down model of a turbofan engine with the novel thrust reversal system.
 Then for the Modelling phase, a scaled experimental model will be prototyped via multiple
 iterations and small-scale testing will be done to ensure perfect modelling. Lastly,
 in the Testing phase, the optimal prototype will undergo rigorous testing and the
 results will be used in the conclusions of this report. The following report summarizes
 the concepts and iterations that were followed before reaching the final design as
 well as relevant literature review, project constraints and work management guidelines.

Title:
Implementation of a Peer-Mediated Health Education Model in the United Arab Emirates;
                                 Understanding Risky Behaviors Among Expatriate Teens
Abstract:
In the United Arab Emirates (UAE), tobacco use amongst young people is on the rise,
 and the incidence of type II diabetes ranks the country at 15th in the world. Yet,
 few interventions directly address the risky behaviors that youth engage in, which
 lead to chronic, unhealthy habits. To test if an educational intervention would be
 effective in this cultural setting, we designed two peer-to-peer health workshops:
 one on tobacco use and another on nutrition/physical activity (N/PA). A pre-workshop
 survey was used to provide a baseline on the current attitudes, knowledge, perceptions
 and behaviors of our cohort with regard to tobacco use, physical activity and nutrition.
 We randomly assigned each classroom a workshop and used a post workshop survey to
 assess changes in the student's beliefs for each health topic. Our results provide
 a summary of the current risky behaviors of ninth grade expatriates in the UAE. Moreover,
 we concluded that the tobacco workshop positively affected knowledge, attitudes, and
 perceptions of tobacco use. The N/PA workshop affected the teenagers' level of satisfaction
 with their physical activity. This study provides evidence to support a national adoption
 of a peer-to-peer health education model as a tobacco use intervention.

Title: Mussaffah vs
Abstract:
Major: BiologyAbstract: As the deciphering of algal metabolism becomes increasingly significant
 for algal optimization and its commercial applications, species' response and ultimately
 adaptation to environment becomes of particular practical interest. Because green
 algae can produce and accumulate lipids, the research model organism Chlamydomonas
 reinhardtii has been the subject of a large number of studies, including a genome-scale
 reconstruction of its metabolic network. The present study explores algal adaptation
 of three species, two from the USA and one from the UAE, to environment through temperature
 tolerance, metabolic capability, and genetics. High-throughput sequencing and metabolic
 phenotyping were used to define full metabolic profiles of these species and their
 phylogenetic assignments. Data indicates that while the isolates are closely related
 genetically across locations, and of the same species within the two locations, each
 strain has a unique metabolic profile and temperature range. This hints at epigenetic
 influence within locations, as well as intra-species phenotypic variations. Strains
 in the UAE displayed higher temperature tolerances. Strains from New York City showed
 lower, and different growth temperature preferences. Metabolic differences were observed
 across all strains, including between both strains from New York.

Title: Resolving Date Palm Biogeography through Analysis of the Chloroplast psbA-trnH Sequence
Abstract:
Major: Biology Abstract: Through the process of domestication, humankind has driven evolutionary
 change in a wide variety of plants. The date palm, Phoenix dactylifera, has been cultivated
 in the Middle East and North Africa for approximately 5000 years. In this study we
 employ a phylogeographic approach using DNA sequence variation from one chloroplast
 region, psbA-trnH, to elucidate the evolutionary history of the cultivated date palm
 from across its native range. The evidence suggests that there were at least two
 domestication events in the date palm, one in North Africa and one in the Arabian
 Peninsula region. A third event may have occurred in Iraq.

Title:
The Prevalence of and Attitudes Towards Performance-Enhancing Drugs and Body Supplements
                                 in Abu Dhabi
Abstract:
Major: Biology Abstract: Little is known about the frequency and types of supplements used in the
 United Arab Emirates. With a recent focus on improving healthcare in the nation, much
 importance is given to the emergence of gymnasiums that offer promises ranging from
 weight loss to better athletic performance. The anticipated expectations of accelerated
 results is brought about through the common, yet often uncontrolled, usage of performance-enhancing
 drugs and body supplements. This study aims to analyze the trends pertaining to supplement
 usage and perspectives in the emirate of Abu Dhabi. 200 weight-training participants
 were surveyed across 5 large gyms in the emirate. Results obtained saw high supplement
 usage, ranging from common protein supplements and creatine to suspected anabolic
 androgenic steroids. Major reasons for taking supplements, as reported by participants,
 were to "gain muscle mass", "improve athletic performance" and "reduce onset of muscle
 fatigue". Throughout this study, there appears to be an impetus to develop the "ideal"
 body revolving around the concept of a 'Western aesthetic physique'.

Title: Designing a Drug Delivery System Using Nanoparticle Technology
Abstract:
Major: Biology Abstract: Iron Oxide (γ-Fe2O3) nanoparticles (NPs) had been coated with water soluble
 molecular containers called cucurbit[7]uril (CB[7]).1 The cancer drug Paclitaxel3
 (PTX) was successfully encapsulated in these macrocycles. The NP-CB[7]-Drug complex's
 stability and structure have been studied using characterization techniques such as
 Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR), Thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA),
 and Dynamic Light Scattering (DLS). Moreover, the toxicity of the Iron oxide-CB[7]-PTX
 complex in vitro have also been investigated.

Title: Study of Diabetes and its Complications Through the AGE/RAGE Pathway
Abstract:
Major: Biology Abstract: Globally, 8.4% or 382 million people of the adult population suffer from
 diabetes, and the number is expected to increase in the following years [15]. Diabetes
 prevalence among the UAE nationals were reported to be 24%, and 67% adults were obese
 or overweight, while 57% had central obesity [20,22]. The high prevalence of diabetes
 in the UAE is attributable to changes in lifestyle, yet the specific biochemical mechanisms
 that lead to increased diabetes complications in this population is not known. In
 hyperglycemia, the formation of advanced glycation endproducts (AGEs) through non-enzymatic
 glycation and oxidation of proteins is greatly accelerated [27]. The AGE/RAGE pathway
 has an important implication in the vascular damage that is observed in diabetes.
 This Capstone project is aimed to understand the epidemiology and the burden of diabetes
 worldwide and in the UAE, and to study the biochemical pathways that modulate diabetes
 complications. The first goal was achieved through literature research and clinical
 observation. The second goal was attained through experiments investigating the levels
 of several gene expressions in hyperglycemia and oxidative stress induced conditions
 in vitro. This study found that the expression of those genes changed during those
 conditions.

Title:
Implementation of a Peer-Mediated Health Education Model in the United Arab Emirates;
                                 Understanding Risky Behaviors Among Expatriate Teens
Abstract:
Major: Biology Abstract: Tobacco use amongst young people is on the rise in the United Arab Emirates
 (UAE). The UAE is also ranked 15th in the world for incidence of type II diabetes.
 To test if an educational intervention would be effective in this cultural setting,
 we designed two peer-to-peer health workshops: one on tobacco and another on nutrition/physical
 activity (N/PA). We randomly assigned each classroom either a N/PA or tobacco workshop
 and used a post workshop survey to assess the effect of the workshops on the student's
 beliefs for each health topic. The N/PA workshop acted as a control group for tobacco
 related questions and vice versa. Our results provide a summary on the current risky
 behaviors of ninth grade expatriates in the UAE. Moreover, we concluded that the tobacco
 workshop positively affected knowledge, attitudes, and perceptions of tobacco use,
 with noticeable spillover effects on perceptions of nutrition and physical activity
 as well. The N/PA workshop was only able to affect teenagers' level of satisfaction
 with their physical activity.

Title: The Role of Microbiota in Shaping Host Physiology
Abstract:
Major: Biology Abstract: An altered intestinal microbiome and high-fat diet (HFD) can each contribute
 to obesity, this study tried to elucidate their combined effects on host physiology.
 Mice received sub-therapeutic antibiotic treatment (STAT), whereas control mice did
 not. Both groups were fed normal chow (NC), and at 17 weeks half the mice were switched
 to HFD. STAT elevated total and fat mass in both NC and HFD mice compared to controls;
 a more substantial weight gain was observed when STAT and HFD were combined. To examine
 the effects on the microbiome, DNA was extracted from fecal samples and the V4 region
 of the 16S rRNA gene was sequenced. Principal coordinate analysis revealed that both
 STAT and HFD changed microbial community structure. To determine whether an altered
 microbiota could cause an obesity phenotype independently of exposure to antibiotics,
 the microbiota of 18-week old control and STAT mice was transferred to germ-free mice
 via oral gavage. STAT-recipient mice showed significant increases in total and adipose
 mass compared to control. Histological analysis showed no difference in mean surface
 area or frequency distribution of adipocyte surface area between control and treatment
 groups.

Title: Designing Peptide Based Inhibitors of Amyloid Protein Misfolding and Cytotoxicity
Abstract:
Amyloid diseases, which include neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and
 prion diseases, are characterized by the misfolding, aggregation and toxicity of cellular
 proteins. Segments of prion proteins have been shown to function as cell-penetrating
 peptides (CPPs), which can cross the cell membrane with high efficiency even when
 coupled to large cargoes. In this study, a new peptide composed of a highly charged
 segment (KKLVFF) from the Aβ peptide, associated with Alzheimer's diseases, and a
 targeting sequence, was studied to determine whether it can function as a CPP and
 inhibit the aggregation and toxicity of Aβ. My studies show that the peptide effectively
 inhibited the aggregation of Aβ, was not toxic to cells, and rapidly entered cells
 and localized to the mitochondria, which has been suggested as a target in a number
 of amyloid diseases, including Alzheimer's disease. Significantly, these findings
 give us insight into developing a 'universal inhibitor' of amyloid protein aggregation
 and cytotoxicity.

Title: Audio-Visual Integration in Speech Perception
Abstract:
Major: BiologyAbstract: This study investigates whether speech perception is primarily subserved
 by modality-specific or amodal representations by expanding the work reported by Kim
 et al. (2004). Visual speech was used to prime auditory and written targets across
 four conditions: repetition, non-repetition, same-onset, and same-rhyme. Lexical decision
 task (word vs. pseudoword) reaction times were used to assess the degree of priming.
 Selective repetition priming for both auditory and written LDT's was predicted. Results
 demonstrated facilitatory priming of repetition, same-onset, and same-rhyme conditions
 compared to control for both words and pseudowords in the auditory LDT. In the written
 LDT, repetition and same-onset priming was found to facilitate processing of words
 while repetition priming inhibited priming of pseudowords. Together, these results
 suggest that silent visual articulations do influence language perception, which is
 consistent with an amodal model of language perception dependent on an underlying
 motor bases. It remains unclear whether visual speech simply activates phonological
