 units without lexical-specificity, as suggested by results of the auditory LDT, or
 whether it activates words in the mental lexicon, as suggested by results of the written
 LDT.

Title:
Zelda's Regulatory Role in the Neuroepithelial-to-Neuroblast Transition in the Developing
                                 Drosophila Larval Brain
Abstract:
Major: BiologyAbstract: Zelda (Zld) is a transcription factor that is thought to coordinate the
 neuroepithelial (NE) stem cell network in the Drosophila larval brain. NE cells undergo
 differentiation to become neuroblasts (NB), which divide asymmetrically to maintain
 the correct balance of stem cells vs. differentiated cells. The NE-to-NB transition
 is controlled through the interaction of the EGFR and Notch signaling pathways. zld
 is expressed in NE cells of larval brains, and NE cells lacking Zld show early transformation
 into NBs. As such, we hypothesize that Zld is a possible regulator of the NE fate
 and thus integral to these pathways. The expression patterns of the Bearded (Brd),
 Ocho and escargot (esg) genes were assayed in wildtype and zld mutants as they are
 known to be expressed in NE cells. Zld was found to regulate the expression of Brd
 and esg, but not Ocho, suggesting that Zld only regulates certain genes involved in
 NE-to-NB transition. Many of the regulatory mechanisms involved in controlling NE
 cell fate are conserved between Drosophila and humans. Uncovering the molecular mechanisms
 through which Zld controls the NE-to-NB transition can lead to a better understanding
 of human neurodevelopmental diseases and brain tumors, as well as identifying targets
 for treatment.

Title: Investigating variation in Trichomonas vaginalis cytotoxicity and growth rate
Abstract:
Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated parasitic protist and the causative agent of
 trichomoniasis, the world's most prevalent non-viral STI. Significant variation has
 been observed in the nature and severity of clinical manifestations of T. vaginalis
 infection, with only about 50% of infected women and an even lower proportion of infected
 men exhibiting any observable symptoms of trichomoniasis. The genetic bases for this
 – either in the parasite or the host – remains unknown. This study was undertaken
 to investigate variation in T. vaginalis cytotoxicity and growth rate across 15 different
 global isolates of the parasite. We found significant variation in cytotoxicity across
 different isolates of T. vaginalis. In particular, type 1 isolates exhibited significantly
 higher (p less than 0.05) cytotoxicity than type 2 isolates. Growth rates also differed
 between isolates, however no correlation was found between cytotoxicity and growth
 rate.

Title:
Variation and Parameters Associated with Plasmodium falciparum Malaria Parasitemia
                                 in a Pediatric Cohort in Burkina Faso
Abstract:
Studies have shown that malaria severity positively correlates with parasitemia, which
 depends on host immune status, parasite virulence, and environmental factors. In this
 project, variation and parameters associated with Plasmodium falciparum malaria parasitemia
 in a cohort of 150 children in Burkina Faso were investigated. Quantitative real-time
 PCR (qRTPCR) analysis of saliva samples revealed that detection of parasitemia in
 saliva is possible, but further optimization is required for consistent detection
 of samples with low parasite counts. The non-invasive nature of saliva collection
 and low limit of detection of qRT-PCR can potentially increase earlier detection and
 treatment of malaria infection. Analysis of blood cell counts has shown that platelets,
 neutrophils/lymphocytes ratio and eosinophils were significantly associated with parasitemia
 in infected children highlighting the role these cells play in the immune defense
 against malaria infection. Gene expression profiling of 48 genes, which are involved
 in genetic predisposition and resistance to Malaria infection, revealed 17 genes whose
 expression is associated with parasitemia levels. These results highlight some of
 the factors controlling parasite load during malaria infection and will help understand
 how the disease progresses and what factors modulate children's resistance/susceptibility
 to symptomatic malaria infection.

Title: Cell-Penetrating Peptide Inhibitors of Amyloid Formation And Cytotoxicity
Abstract:
The misfolding and aggregation of protein into amyloid fibrils has been associated
 with major human diseases, including Alzheimer's disease, prion diseases and type
 II diabetes. Here, we study the effect of two novel peptide constructs, NCAM-prion
 and NCAM-Aβ, which are composed of the Neural Cell Adhesion Molecule 1 (NCAM 1) signal
 sequence combined with an 'NLS' like motif from an amyloid protein, to determine whether
 they can effectively inhibit amyloidogenesis. Using ThT assay and TEM, we demonstrate
 that these peptide constructs can inhibit amyloid formation of IAPP and Aβ, proteins
 associated with type II diabetes and Alzheimer's disease, respectively. In addition,
 our cell toxicity assays indicate that NCAM-prion and NCAM-Aβ are effective inhibitors
 of IAPP-induced cytotoxicity. Through confocal microscopy, we also show that the inhibitors
 are cell-penetrating peptides (CPPs) that localize to the mitochondria, which has
 been suggested as a target in a number of amyloid diseases, including type II diabetes
 and Alzheimer's disease. The ability of these peptide constructs to enter cells efficiently,
 and inhibit both aggregation and cytotoxicity of IAPP and Aβ underlines their potential
 therapeutic value. These promising findings also give us insight into developing a
 'universal inhibitor' of amyloid protein aggregation and cytotoxicity.

Title: 16S rRNA Metagenomic Profiling of the Faecal Microbiota in Falcons
Abstract:
Falcons (genus: Falco) are birds of prey. Saker, Gyr, Peregrines, and hybrids of these
 species are the most popular birds used for falconry in the Arabian Gulf. There has
 been limited research on the gut microbiome of falcons though it may help in understanding
 their nutrition and susceptibility to bacterial infections. Here we describe the first
 study of the bacterial communities in faecal matter of Peregrine, Gyr, Saker pure
 and hybrid falcons using 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing. The analysis of 3,694 operational
 taxonomic units showed the most abundant bacteria in falcons' faecal microbiota are
 Clostridia (52.4% std13.8) and Bacilli (14.4% std5.9). Dominance of Clostridia across
 the falcons investigated indicates a major difference in microbial community composition
 between falcons and other avian species. Qualitative comparison of microbial community
 composition shows that the presence and dominance of few major microbial classes is
 largely conserved across the sampled falcon groups and individual falcon variation
 is driven mostly by relative abundance of specific taxonomic units. The results contribute
 to the continually growing database of avian microbiomes that can be used for comparative
 studies and lays the foundation for further systematic evaluations of microbial community
 composition in falcons.

Title:
The effect of seasonal extremes on photosynthetic health of the grey mangrove (Avicennia
                                 marina) in a high latitude arid environment
Abstract:
Mangroves are an essential part of habitats all over the world. They support numerous
 bird and fish species and play an important role in the preservation of coastlines.
 Most mangroves around the world grow in coastal wetlands found in tropical and subtropical
 regions. One such species, Avicennia marina, also called the grey mangrove, grows
 and thrives under extreme conditions of heat and light stress in the Arabian Gulf.
 We sought to address how photosynthetic efficiency changes in response to seasonal
 stress. We analyzed photosynthetic efficiency in A. marina leaves using chlorophyll
 fluorescence on natural and afforested mangroves, and HPLC on targeted metabolites
 in select natural samples. Both our Fv/Fm values and HPLC analyses suggest a significantly
 reduced photosynthetic efficiency in summer natural samples but no significant differences
 between seasons for afforested mangroves. In order to further clarify the metabolic
 changes that accompany stress we characterized the metabolome of A. marina leaves
 in summer and winter samples. We noted the elevation of certain compounds such as
 polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and anti fungal secondary metabolites in summer samples.
 The greater abundance of pheophytin-a in winter sample suggest a higher photosynthetic
 efficiency of A. marina in the winter season.

Title:
Scheduling the End of Neural Progenitor Divisions in the Inner Proliferation Center
                                 of the Drosophila Melanogaster Optic Lobes
Abstract:
Establishing the correct number of neurons is of vital importance to achieve the appropriate
 form and function of the brain by the end of development. One way of controlling the
 number of neurons produced is by regulating the proliferation of their progenitors.
 In the Drosophila central nervous system (CNS) a temporal series of transcription
 factors in the neuronal progenitors, called Neuroblasts (NBs), specifies neuronal
 identity in a birth order dependent manner and schedules the termination of NB proliferation
 by either Prospero-dependent-cell cycle exit or hid/ reaper/grim/sickle-mediated apoptosis.
 In the CNS, the timing of division termination through either process relies on the
 combined activity of members of the temporal series and their indirect feed forward
 targets, Dichaete and Grainyhead. Here we provide evidence that in the developing
 optic lobes of Drosophila, the NBs in the ventral tip of the Inner Proliferation Center
 do not progress though a temporal transcription factor series, yet still manage to
 schedule apoptosis.

Title: Influence of environmental extremes on reef fish trophic ecology: A metagenomics approach
Abstract:
The Arabian Gulf constitutes a harsh environment for marine life. Some of its key
 features 52 are sea-surface temperatures that range from 12 °C in winter to over 36
 °C in summer and 53 hyper-salinity (>40 PSU) year round. One expected consequence
 of these environmental 54 extremes is a variation in the diet of the Gulf's reef fish
 compared with conspecific reef fish 55 from more benign environments, as diet is expected
 to vary as an adaptive response to the 56 seasonal changes in the environment and
 associated food items. Despite its unique 57 environmental conditions limited research
 is available on reef fish feeding ecology in the 58 Arabian Gulf. Using a metagenomics
 approach, we surveyed seasonal variation in the diet of 59 three abundant fish species
 associated with reefs in the extreme southern Gulf (Abu Dhabi, 60 UAE): Pomacentrus
 aquilus, Pomacentrus trichrourus, and Pomacanthus maculosus. The 61 results of this
 study provide the first quantitative assessment of the dietary habits of reef fish
 62 in the Arabian Gulf. Our analyses show that that there are strong compositional
 shifts in diets 63 across seasons in all three species. The overall dominant diet
 content organisms, at the 64 phylum level, were Porifera, Cnidaria, and Arthropoda.
 A variety of items that presented in 65 the content have not been previously associated
 with the dietary habits of these fish in other 66 regions, suggesting that these species
 have developed a distinct feeding ecology that is unique 67 to this region, likely
 as a result of the effects of the extreme environmental conditions in 68 structuring
 food resource availability.

Title:
Development of tumor-specific drug delivery platforms through coupling of liposomes
                                 to pH-sensitive membrane insertion peptides
Abstract:
This project exploits extracellular acidity, a salient feature of the microenvironment
 of solid tumors, to develop a drug delivery system with high specificity for cancer
 cells in order to prevent harmful targeting of healthy tissue and enhance the potency
 of the drugs by accumulating them at the tumors. To achieve this we coupled drug-encapsulating
 liposomes to short peptide sequences, the pH-low insertion peptide (pHLIP) and the
 novel acidity-triggered rational membrane peptide (ATRAM) that interact weakly with
 cell membranes at physiological pH and insert into the lipid bilayer at acidic pH.
 We used cell viability assays, confocal microscopy, and flow cytometry to characterize
 the cellular uptake and drug delivery capacity of ATRAM under physiological and acidic
 pH. We demonstrated that ATRAM promotes cellular uptake of PEGylated liposomes, particularly
 at low pH that mimics the tumor environment. We also found that, similar to pHLIP,
 the C-terminus of ATRAM is the membrane-binding domain, while N-terminus can be utilized
 as a cargo-binding site. Our results show that encapsulating therapeutics in liposomes
 and coupling them to ATRAM is a promising tool for targeted delivery of anticancer
 therapeutics.

Title: Characterisation of Symbiodinium communities in Singapore's marginal coral reef environment
Abstract:
Singapore marine waters are characterized by high turbidity due to widespread coastal
 development. Corals receive over 90% of metabolic energy from photosynthetic symbiotic
 algae (zooxanthallae) that live within the coral. Such light-limited environments
 as Singapore thus represent marginal conditions that should limit reef development.
 However, over 60 coral reefs have been reported across Singapore, containing at least
 255 species of hard corals. Corals' sensitivity to environmental conditions varies
 with different coral-associated symbionts. Given the relatively stressful environment
 it is expected that Singapore's corals likely harbor stress-tolerant zoothanthallae,
 but symbiont communities there are largely unexplored. This study used NGS to explore
 the symbiont composition in five dominant coral species collected from six major coral
 reef sites across Singapore. Out of 19 distinct OTUs identified in this study, just
 two (C_01 and D_01) dominated the symbiont community (average percent coverage >90%
 across all sites and host coral species). BLAST analysis identified C_01 and D_01
 as Symbiodinium sub-clades C30/C27 and D1, respectively. The results of this study
 provide important insights into how coral communities respond to marginal environmental
 conditions in an area characterized by high turbidity.

Title:
Determining the identities and functions of missing temporal transcription factors
                                 in the Drosophila optic lobes
Abstract:
The sequential expression of transcription factors (TFs) in neural progenitors activates
 or represses different genes, and thus generates different types of neurons from a
 homogenous pool of stem cells. In the fruit fly, neuroblasts that give rise to the
 optic lobes sequentially express five TFs to specify different neural fates. However,
 two TFs in the cascade fail to regulate each other's expression, in contrast to the
 other three TFs, which suggests that there exists at least one missing TF that acts
 between them. This study aims to identify the missing TF(s) through a genetic screen.
 After testing the potential of ~190 TFs for being part of the temporal cascade, I
 identified three primary candidates, Nuclear factor Y (NF-Y), homeobrain and max.
 The knowledge of the missing TF will allow us to further examine how temporal patterning
 progresses and contributes to the generation of neuronal diversity in the optic lobe.

Title:
Impact of infection and treatment on epigenetic profiles of malarial children in Burkina
                                 Faso
Abstract:
Malaria is a major public health problem with 3.3 billion individuals at risk in tropical
 and subtropical regions of the world and an estimated 438,000 deaths in 2015. Major
 advances have been made in understanding the epidemiology and pathobiology of the
 disease. However, little is know about the genetic and epigenetic mechanisms modulating
 variation in host immune response against the parasite. In this project, we investigate
 variation in genome-wide epigenetic profiles of circulating immune cells of children
 from Burkina Faso before and during infection, and after treatment using more than
 850,000 epigenetic markers from the Infinium MethylationEPIC BeadChip. Our results
 revealed major and statistically significant changes in the epigenetic profiles of
 children in response both to infection and treatment and the genomic regions underlying
 these changes - including five genes within the human Major Histocompatibility Complex
 (MHC). These results highlight the role epigenetic factors play in modulating response
 to malaria infection.

Title:
Probing the Structure of a Catalytically Active Unique Minimal Hammerhead Ribozyme
                                 and Determining its Biological Relevance
Abstract:
Hammerhead Ribozymes (HHRs) are single-folded RNA motifs that undergo the reversible
 autocatalytic self-cleavage. The RNA motif of interest, N15, was found to carry out
 catalysis despite its stem-loop II structure being shorter. Two structural conformations
 were found to stabilize the core of the minimal N15min7, LCI (loop II-core interaction)
 and LSI (loop II-loop I interactions), which then facilitate catalytic activity of
 the RNA molecule. To further examine the HHR, N15min7 was assayed at 1 mM of MgCl2
 to determine if these interactions are maintained at lower concentrations of divalent
 metal ions. When assaying the wild-type (WT) N15min7, LSI and LCI structures with
 deoxy-base substitution at lower concentrations of MgCl2, no significant difference
 in catalytic activity was observed among these three structures, indicating that an
 alternative interaction is taking place. Our results indicate that despite an overly
 simplistic structure, the N15min7 requires multiple interactions to catalyze self-cleavage
 at varying concentrations of divalent metal ions. Furthermore, the biological relevance
 of the N15min7 motif was determined by extensive computational searches for N15min7-like
 structures in a collection of ~8,000 genomes. The search identified ~100 instances
 of N15min7 sequences that can potentially form catalytically active structures.

Title:
Generation of a Wolbachia Secretome Resource for High-Throughput Analysis of Lymphatic
                                 Filariasis
Abstract:
Lymphatic filariasis is caused by the parasitic nematode, Brugia malayi. These roundworms
 persist in the human host for years, and the suspected mechanism is immunomodulation
 of the human immune system. Most of the filarial nematodes including B. malayi harbour
 an endosymbiotic bacterium, Wolbachia in their lateral chords. The goal of this project
 was to generate a comprehensive resource to enable functional proteomics studies of
 the interactions between Wolbachia and human. We produced an Open Reading Frame (ORF)
 resource for high-throughput experimentation by synthesizing a subset of ORFs of secreted
 Wolbachial proteins. We successfully cloned over 80% of our synthesized ORFs into
 two destination vectors optimized for high-throughput experimentation, namely Yeast
 2-Hybrid screening and protein expression. Gene expression analysis indicated genes
 up-regulated during infectious stages were associated with protein folding and chaperone
 functions, suggesting a likelihood of increased protein production during infectious
 stages. We also conducted in silico protein analysis to understand the function of
 protein products in our subset. Our genome-scale Yeast 2-Hybrid Screen with our cloned
 ORFs against the human ORFeome yielded 3 of the Wolbachial proteins, involved in DNA
 repair, potentially interacting with human gene products.

Title:
Exploring the role of the heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein CBF-A in neuronal
                                 development
Abstract:
Posttranscriptional regulation of gene expression is an essential mechanism that controls
 development and differentiation in cells. Here, we focused on the role of the heterogeneous
 ribonucleoprotein CBF-A, known to regulate mRNA transport by binding the RNA trafficking
 sequence located on the 3' UTR of mRNA transcripts. We applied genome wide approaches
 to MEFs from a CBF-A KO mouse to examine whether CBF-A mediates RNA trafficking at
 an early stage during RNA biogenesis in developing neurons. RNA-seq analysis of CBF-A
 KO and heterozygous (HT) MEFs showed that there are many neuronal genes altered in
 the absence of CBF-A. We then chemically reprogrammed CBF-A KO and HT MEFs into neuron-like
 cells. Immunostaining confirmed differential expression of neuronal markers. To begin
 characterizing the induced neurons, we tested 150 neuronal and fibroblast- specific
 primers on WT MEFs and reprogrammed neurons to create a primer profile for future
 analyses. Results from this study confirm a primary role of CBF-A in RNA biogenesis
 and begins to highlight its importance in achievement of cell fate during neuronal
 development.

Title: Characterizing the Transposable Element Landscape of Date Palm (Phoenix dactylifera)
Abstract:
The date palm (Phoenix dactylifera) is a culturally and economically important crop
 across the Middle East, South Asia, and Northern Africa- yet our understanding of
 its genome remains relatively limited. This study aims to detect and characterize
 the transposable element (TE) landscape in this significant species through a novel
 combination of both library-based (Repeatmodeler) and k-mer based (REPdenovo) computational
 methods. The resulting consensus reads were masked via Repeatmasker and mapped to
 a gene map (NCBI: GCF_000413155.1_DPV01). Of the 500Mb genome assmbly, 38% was annotated
 as repetitive elements, of which LTR Copia and Gypsy were predominant. Comparison
 of element length and divergence indicate that LTR Copia elements are likely young
 and recently active. When mapped against regions upstream and downstream to genes,
 there was a relative abundance of Gypsy upstream compared to Copia, that may suggest
 an innate insertion bias at play. Of the elements uniquely assembled by REPdenovo,
 a majority were identified as plastid-derived sequences. Estimates suggest approximately
 0.2% of the date palm genome consists of such elements, highlighting a category of
 plant DNA often overlooked. Through this study, we provide a TE-level understanding
 of the date palm genome structure that may act as a "roadmap" in future palm studies.

Title: Investigation of Top-down and Bottom-up Signals in Visual Working Memory in V1
Abstract:
Working memory (WM) allows for the maintenance of information over short periods of
 time when the initial source of the information is no longer present. In this study,
 we investigated whether the visual WM signal in the primary visual cortex (V1) is
 top-down or bottom-up using 3T functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). A top-down
 signal would indicate storage of visual WM outside of V1, while a bottom-up signal
 would indicate V1 maintenance. The direction of the signal was operationalized with
 an Attention and Perception task; each one activating distinct neural populations
 within V1. These patterns of activity were then compared using multivoxel pattern
 analysis (MVPA) to the pattern elicited from a visual WM task. The study replicated
 previous results by finding orientation-selective information present in V1 without
 a high-amplitude sustained BOLD response. We also found significant similarity between
 the patterns of the visual WM and Attention tasks. These results suggest a top-down
 signal in V1 during the maintenance of visual WM, consistent with the idea that visual
 WM is not maintained within V1.

Title:
Single-Cell Transcriptome Profiling of the Drosophila Optic Lobe Suggests a Regulation
                                 of Terminal Characters by Cell Type-Specific Transcription Factor Cohorts
Abstract:
Understanding how a system comes to be and what its different components are is critical
 to deciphering its mode of action. In multicellular organisms, it is now established
 that transcription factors expressed during development play a key role in specifying
 cell fate. However, to better encompass cellular diversity, we are yet to understand
 how molecular specification translates into character acquisition. This study takes
 a holistic and unbiased approach to molecularly characterize cellular diversity in
 the adult Drosophila optic lobe based on Drop-seq single-cell RNA-seq of 57,000 cells.
 With unsupervised analysis and differential expression testing, I identified 52 clusters
 of transcriptionally distinct single-cell populations. I annotated several clusters
 by correspondence to known cell types on the basis of canonical markers or by characterizing
 cells' localization and projection patterns using Gal4 lines. Regulatory interactions
 between the transcription factors apterous and traffic-jam and the respective markers
 of cholinergic and glutamatergic neurons, ChAT and VGlut, were confirmed by gene knock-down
 through RNAi. Interestingly, these results, in addition to a weighted gene co-expression
 network analysis (WGCNA), showed that cell types with similar phenotypes do not necessarily
 share the same transcription factor signature, thus suggesting that phenotypic convergence
 is a likely cellular evolutionary model in Drosophila.

Title:
Long-Term Balancing Selection at MHC class I loci in the Ethiopian frog Leptopelis
                                 gramineus
Abstract:
In the defense against diseases, organisms must maintain a repertoire of molecules
 that can respond to the variety of pathogens in their habitat. The variety of pathogenic
 threats present in one's surroundings depends on several environmental variables,
 including climate. Here I isolated and analyzed class I MHC sequences from the Ethiopian
 frog Leptopelis gramineus, sampled across a heterogeneous habitat range, to investigate
 the relationship between demography, population structure and climate in the context
 of immunogenetic variation. I hypothesized that the signature of balancing selection
 is stronger in warmer climates. I used neutral markers to reconstruct the demographic
 history of each clade belonging to L. gramineus, measured genetic diversity, differentiation,
 and gene flow, and simulated these measures against neutral scenarios. While intra-specific
 subpopulation Tajima's D and Fu and Li's analyses revealed strong evidence for balancing
 selection, inter-specific analysis revealed a lack of clear genetic structure at MHC
 class I loci with respect to differences in clade, elevation difference, and geographical
 distance. Instead, the data demonstrate clear effects of long-term balancing selection
 that may predate the spatial dispersal of L. gramineus across Ethiopia.

Title: During differentiation nuclear beta-actin regulates neuronal gene programs
Abstract:
During the process of cellular differentiation global changes in chromatin lead to
 genome organization and the suppression and activation of gene programs. Emerging
 evidence indicates that nuclear β-actin is a major regulator of genome organization.
 β-actin performs this important function by regulating genomic deposition of the BAF
 chromatin remodeling complex. This leads to tethering of heterochromatin to the NL
 while controlling the level of euchromatin. To further study the role of nuclear actin
 in these processes and its potential impact on development and differentiation, here
 we implemented a direct reprogramming protocol on embryonic fibroblasts from a β-actin
 knockout mouse to directly reprogram them into induced neurons. We report differences
 in neuronal morphology between WT, HET, and KO cell lines arising from differential
 gene expression levels. Many of the compromised genes were found to be downregulated
 in a β-acting dosage dependent manner. GO term analysis found that these changes compromised
 programs related to neuronal development. Reintroducing an NLS containing β-actin
 in the KO cells positively affected neuron specific marker expression. Because the
 model organism is embryonic lethal at developmental stage 10.5 we conclude that nuclear
 β-actin helps regulate neuronal gene expression during development.

Title:
Identification of Natural Products from Sponge/Tunicate-Associated Bacterial Species
                                 in the Abu Dhabi Region
Abstract:
Marine invertebrate-associated bacteria are a promising source of natural products,
 especially in harsh conditions (such as Abu Dhabi) where metabolitefacilitated adaptation
 is necessary. This paper outlines a method of advanced bacterial isolation and high-content
 screening of crude bacterial cell extracts and SPE fractions, with the aim of identifying
 biologically active natural products through a process of cytological profiling and
 image analysis. Mammalian cell and C. elegans screens revealed the presence of a significantly
 toxic compound produced by a Vibrio sp. proteobacterium along with several other
 compounds that exhibit some form of phenotypic effect. Liquid chromatography-mass
 spectrometry was performed to provide insight into the potential chemical formulae
 of biologically active compounds. Phenotypic profiles and mass spectra were created
 for all active fractions, providing a solid foundation for future characterization
 of chemical structure and mode-of-action.

Title: Regulation of Transposon Expression by DNA methylation in Zebrafish uhrf1 mutants
Abstract:
DNA methylation is a major epigenetic modification and its loss is associated with
 autoimmune disease, re-expression of oncogenes and the activation of transposable
 elements (TEs). This project aimed to investigate the relationship between TE expression
 and DNA methylation, as well as characteristics of TEs that could be contributing
 to expression. Previous RNA-seq analysis identified the top 10 upregulated TEs in
 uhrf1 mutants as compared to wild type (WT) larvae. Here, I analyzed the genomic features
 of these TEs and their pattern of expression by in situ hybridization (ISH). Bioinformatics
 analysis showed a significant correlation (r=0.6328 for WT and r=0.5871 for uhrf1
 mutants) between read counts and number of full length reads. ISH showed significant
 expression of TEs in both the WT and uhrf1 mutant larvae, particularly in the brain,
 eyes and jaws. In the mutants, we observed a difference in signal in some TEs, but
 not major differences in the pattern of expression between WT and uhrf1 mutants. Phylogenetic
 analysis of the reverse transcriptase domains of the LTR Gypsy elements showed that
 Gypsy117-I_DR expressed the greatest fold change.

Title:
Phylogenetics of date palm (Phoenix dactylifera) and closely related wild species
                                 elucidates the nature of introgressive hybridization between North African date palm
                                 and Phoenix theophrasti
Abstract:
The domestication history of date palm (Phoenix dactylifera), an important staple
 crop in the Middle East and North Africa, is not well understood. The popular model
 of domestication argues that date palm originated from the Middle East and later spread
 westward to North Africa via trade routes. However, higher observed nucleotide diversity
 within the North African date palm population suggests that the North African population
 is not the product of recent colonization, thereby contradicting the model. This study
 of 71 date palm cultivars from across Middle East and North Africa and 6 of its closely
 related wild species reconciles the higher observed nucleotide diversity in North
 African population and the popular domestication model by demonstrating that the North
 African date palm population is a result of introgressive hybridization between date
 palm and P. theophrasti. Linkage disequilibrium analysis and phylogeny of phased haplotypes
 in highly introgressed genomic region provide evidence for intro- gression, whereas
 chloroplast and mitochondrial phylogeny reveals that hybridization occurred through
 pollination of date palm offshoots by P. theophrasti.

Title:
Adaptation of mitochondrial Oxidative Phosphorylation Genes to High Altitude in Leptopelis
                                 gramineus
Abstract:
Harsh environmental conditions are common characteristics of high altitudes, such
 as those in the Ethiopian highlands. This can be detrimental to the survival of maladapted
 organisms, yet these areas continue to be biodiversity hotspots. This alludes to adaptive
 selection that equips high altitude organisms, such as Ethiopian endemic frog Leptopelis
 gramineus , with the capacity to survive in hazardous conditions. The mitochondrial
 genome has been previously shown to be crucial in adaptation due to it comprising
 of rapidly evolving non-recombining sequences. In this paper, I studied the role played
 by mtOXPHOS genes in adaptation to high altitude in L. gramineus using aBSREL, FEL,
 and MEME analytical methods . Diversifying selection was found in codons 42 in ATP8
 and 311 and 317 in ND1. However, this selection could not be attributed to adaptation
 to high altitude considering the individuals who expressed the necessary mutations
 were collected from varying altitudes. The result could also potentially be related
 to incomplete lineage sorting resulting from high mutation rates in the addressed
 codon positions. Therefore, further analysis is needed in order to determine the role
 of ATP8 and ND1 on L. gramineus high altitude adaptation.

Title:
What it takes to be at the top: The complex interrelationship between chronic social
                                 stress and social dominance
Abstract:
Most animal societies are organized in dominance hierarchies that affect an individual's
 reproductive success and access to resources. Exposure to stress is one of many complex
 factors contributing to hierarchy formation, but a hierarchical status itself can
 be stress-inducing. I aimed to elucidate the complex relationship between stress and
 dominance by delineating how social rank predicts vulnerability to social stress and
 whether chronic stress modulates hierarchy establishment. Using the C57 mouse model,
 hierarchical rank is studied using an automated social confrontation tube test that
 is consistent with at least three other dominance measures. Chronic social stress
 is mimicked by the chronic social defeat (CSD) paradigm that induces a depressive-like
 phenotype in stress-susceptible mice. I show that exposure to chronic stress predicts
 higher success in subsequent hierarchy formation. The mice that underwent CSD exhibited
 markedly higher winning ratios than their stress-naïve conspecifics. Results also
 suggest that the differences in social competitiveness are not related to the overall
 differences in stress-susceptibility, but hierarchical status may predispose the subordinate
 ranks to decreased baseline social preference. In contrast, dominant males are liable
 to higher anxious-like behavior following CSD-stress. Furthermore, I also demonstrate
 how individual housing conditions markedly increases a range of anxiety-like behaviors.
 I additionally report preliminary data on a neural circuit potentially underlying
 dominance- and stress-specific signal integration.

Title: CPP-Cargo Complex Translocation in Model Membrane Systems: Experiments and Simulations
Abstract:
Cancer is a disease of multicellular organisms characterized by uncontrolled cell
 division. The vast majority of all human cancers are directly linked to carcinogen
 exposure, which leads to a series of genetic changes that progressively alter the
 growth properties of cells. Chemotherapy relies on the use of chemical agents to disrupt
 cell division as a means of curtailing the proliferation of tumor cells, but in doing
 so they inflict great collateral damage on healthy tissues. One of the most powerful
 capabilities of cell penetrating peptides (CPPs) is their capacity to deliver a wide
 variety of compounds and macromolecules into the cytosol in an active form. Previous
 studies have shown CPPs to be a promising platform for the delivery of conventional
 chemotherapeutics into cells; tumor-targeting has been achieved in-vivo. In this study
 we use molecular dynamics simulations to study the uptake mechanisms of novel CPPs
 derived from Hexokinase II and compare their performance to Polyarginine peptide in
 human breast cancer cell line MCF-7.

Title: Nuclear myosin I is required for chromatin maintenance and transcriptional regulation
Abstract:
Nuclear myosin I (NMI) is implicated in several nuclear processes, such as chromatin
 remodeling by the B-WICH complex, establishment of histone marks, and transcription
 facilitated by RNA Polymerase I and II. However, the the current knowledge of its
 global role in transcription remains limited. Using high-content screening of embryonic
 fibroblasts from NMIknockout (KO) mouse, we report significant changes in histone
 modifications, such as acetylated histone(H)3-lysine-(K)9 and acetylated histone(H)3-lysine-(K)27,
 marker of active transcription and active enhancer regions respectively. Confocal
 microscopy and Western blot analysis confirmed the reorganization of chromatin structure
 and histone modifications in the absence of NMI. Transcriptomic analysis revealed
 that these genome-wide changes in the level of histone modifications are accompanied
 by a significant differential expression of genes associated with cellular response
 to DNA damage and DNA repair. We propose that NMI plays an important role in establishing
 histone modifications through its interaction with chromatin remodeling complexes,
 leading to proper activation of DNA damage response gene programs.

Title: Endoplasmic Reticulum Morphology as an Indicator for Stress Severity
Abstract:
The Unfolded Protein Response (UPR) serves to counteract the accumulation of proteins
 in the Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER) during stress. The initial phases of the UPR are
 adaptive, but chronic activation leads to cell dysfunction and pathology, such as
 steatosis. We reasoned that alterations in ER morphology would occur during an adaptive
 phase, where ER phenotypes could indicate early stress responses. We tested this utilizing
 intravital confocal imaging of 5 dpf transgenic zebrafish expressing a hepatocyte
 specific ER marker. We defined seven ER phenotypes in during various stress conditions
 (tunicamycin, ethanol, trappc11 and nAtf6) and scored for their prevalence. Tunicamycin,
 a well-established ER-stressor, caused motile punctae which retained the fluorescent
 ER label. These emerged at 12 hours and were present in 74% of larvae after 24 hours
 of tunicamycin exposure. Furthermore, the ER punctae colocalised with LysoTracker,
 a fluorescent dye staining acidic structures. Gene expression analysis showed UPR
 target gene upregulation in livers from larvae with extensive ER punctae prevalence,
 compared to those looking like controls. Thus, our ER marker represents a proxy for
 identifying ER stress states, where morphology changes can indicate the fish most
 prone to disease.

Title: Effect of Chronic Social Stress on Homeostatic Sleep Response
Abstract:
A remarkably conserved behavior, sleep is thought to restore neural circuits and their
 synaptic outputs. Clinical findings that sleep deprivation can reverse symptoms of
 depression support putative interactions between mood and sleep/wake regulation. The
 molecular pathways that govern these interactions remain ambiguous. Here, we exposed
 C57BL6/J mice to chronic social defeat stress (CSD), using social interaction and
 sucrose preference tests to determine susceptibility or resilience to stress. Combining
 electroencephalogram (EEG) analysis with transcriptomics of the ventral tegmental
 area (VTA) and laterodorsal tegmental nucleus (LDT) in the midbrain, we investigated
 homeostatic sleep response after 4-hour total sleep deprivation (TSD) in stress-susceptible
 and -resilient mice. Susceptible mice spent an average 9% more time in REM rebound
 sleep, while resilient mice exhibited elevated non-REM (NREM) sleep following TSD.
 Prolonging time awake by TSD had differential effects on expression of synaptic plasticity
 genes Arc and BDNF, potassium channels and neuroinflammatory genes in susceptible
 and resilient groups. Thus, we show that differential response to CSD stress influences
 global sleep architecture as well as localized molecular dynamics.

Title:
Evaluating 'activity-silent' and 'persistent neural activity' models of visual working
                                 memory
Abstract:
Currently there are two competing hypotheses about how neurons keep information active
 in WM. One commonly accepted theory claims that information is maintained in WM through
 'persistent neural activity'. This refers to the idea that neurons keep information
 active through constant firing despite the fact that the information is no longer
 present. Recent evidence indicates that memories are also potentially stored through
 'activity-silent' states, where the functional architecture of the neural network
 is altered in a way that memories instead of being active representations are being
 stored as a silent pattern of synaptic weights. While this 'activity-silent' model
 could provide a compelling explanation for some neural data, it doesn't constitute
 conclusive evidence yet. The overall aim of this research is to propose a novel way
 to evaluate the two potential models of visual WM, thus providing further evidence
 for potential mechanisms that could possibly present in WM. We tested this hypothesis
 behaviorally using a continuous report WM task, and neurally using functional MRI
 (fMRI) and multivoxel pattern analysis (MVPA) to uncover patterns of brain activity
 that contained information about WM items.

Title:
Investigating the Association between Midwakh smoking behaviors and risk factors of
                                 Cardiovascular Disease and Hypertension among UAE nationals: Findings from the UAE
                                 Healthy Future Study
Abstract:
Midwakh is an emerging type of smoking, specifically popular among the youth in the
 Arab gulf region. Research on Midwakh smoking is limited to descriptive statistics
 regarding its spread in addition to simple analysis regarding its content. This study
 considers the association of Midwakh smoking, as compared to Cigarettes smoking, and
 the risk of Hypertension and CVD among a sample of adults in the UAE. 471Participants
 were recruited as part of the UAE Healthy Future Study. Modified Poisson models with
 robust error variance were computed to estimate risk ratios (RRs) and 95% confidence
 intervals (CI) for the associations between smoking behavior (e.g., Midwakh only,
 Dual-use with cigarettes or Shisha, or poly-use of Midwakh, Cigarettes, and Shisha)
 and measures of Hypertension (e.g., Systolic Blood Pressure, Diastolic Blood Pressure,
 and Heart Rate) and CVD measures (Cholesterol, Triglyceride, HDL, LDL, Apolipoprotein
 A, and Apolipoprotein B). Compared to smoking cigarettes, Midwakh smoking was significantly
 associated with increased risk of Apolipoprotein A and Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL).
 Future research should investigate whether this relationship is causal and study other
 health outcomes risks for smoking Midwakh among this high-risk population.

Title:
Population genetics of four commercially important fisheries species in the southern
                                 Arabian Gulf
Abstract:
Overharvesting has resulted in dramatic declines of stocks of commercial fish species
 in the UAE in recent years. Although a variety of management efforts have been put
 in place, there is currently limited information on the population dynamics of fish
 species in the UAE. This information is crucial to guide the development of Marine
 Protected Areas. This study explored the population structure of four commercially
 important fish species in the UAE: Diagramma pictum (painted sweetlips), Carangoides
 bajad (orange-spotted trevally), Epinephelus coioides (orange-spotted grouper), and
 Lethrinus borbonicus (snubnose emperor). Using RADsequencing we report evidence of
 a significant population structure within D. pictum that divides the species into
 two populations across the southern Arabian Gulf. The other three species, C. bajad,
 E. coioides, and L. borbonicus, did not reveal a population structure, suggesting
 that this population homogeneity could potentially be a result of adult spawning aggregates
 or larval dispersal. The results have important implications for informing the design
 of future Marine Protected Areas in the southern Arabian Gulf.

Title:
Jet Lag as a Global Stressor: Effect of Shifting Light on Depressive-Like Behavior
                                 and Stress Susceptibility
Abstract:
Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a disease increasing in occurrence globally. One
 of the most significant factors contributing to the prevalence of depression is disruption
 of natural human circadian rhythmicity due to extended exposure to light in our technologically-driven
 societies. A well-studied stress paradigm of chronic social stress is mimicked by
 the chronic social defeat (CSD) paradigm that induces a distinct, robust depressive-like
 phenotype in stress-susceptible mice. Due to evidence indicating that shifting light
 cycles and mood are interconnected, I aim to investigate whether a chronic jet lag
 paradigm modelled in mice produces depression-like behavior comparable to the chronic
 social defeat paradigm. Although results are not statistically significant, qualitative
 analyses indicate that a chronic jet lag model is a comparable stressor, if not a
 stronger stressor, than chronic social stress.

Title: Investigating IgM response to P
Abstract:
During the blood stage of malaria infection, invasion and multiplication of the Plasmodium
 parasites cause symptoms ranging from fever and chills to vital organ dysfunction.
 One of the most important factors source of variation in the severity of such symptoms
 is the host immune system. Host immune system consists of multiple layers of defense,
 but the ultimate step of an efficient response to clear the parasites is the production
 of immunoglobulins. Here we focus on immunoglobulins M (IgM) with the aim to clarify
 the nature of IgM changes taking place during the course of Plasmodium falciparum
 infection and if these changes are controlled by host genotype. The study population
 is a pediatric cohort in Burkina Faso, consisting of children sampled before infection,
 during asymptomatic infection, during symptomatic infection and three weeks after
 treatment. IgM levels were quantified using ELISA and compared between the four groups
 and tested for association with parasitemia in the symptomatic infection group. Furthermore,
 we report genetic variants in candidate genes associated with IgM levels. Combined,
 these results document changes of IgM levels in vivo in a pediatric cohort in Africa
 and show how host genotype can modulate IgM response to Plasmodium falciparum.

Title: DNA damage dependent regulation of p53 pathway by Nuclear Myosin I
Abstract:
Nuclear myosin 1 (NM1) is an emerging key regulator of transcription and chromatin
 organization. It has been implicated in several nuclear processes involving chromatin
 remodeling and histone modifications. Recent studies have highlighted the role of
 myosins in DNA repair, however how NM1 regulates that pathway is still unknown. Using
 NM1 knockout mouse fibroblasts, we show that NM1 gene deletion leads to differential
 expression of genes involved in DNA damage response and cell cycle. We found that
 genes that are downstream p53 signaling are down regulated and that cells lacking
 NM1 display constitutive DNA damage foci. Based on these observations, we silenced
 NM1 by siRNA to study its function in response to DNA damage. Chromatin immunoprecipitation
 (ChIP) and qPCR analyses on cells subjected to NM1 knockdown revealed that NM1 binding
 to the p21 gene is enhanced upon DNA damage. These results also showed that NM1 facilitates
 the binding of PCAF and Set1 to the p21 gene, leading to active expression of the
 p21 gene. Thus, we propose that NM1 plays a regulatory role in the p53 signaling pathway
 and is recruited across the p21 gene to facilitate recruitment of histone modifiers
 that induces histone acetylation and methylation, facilitating p21 gene activation.

Title:
The role of β-actin in the direct reprogramming of mouse embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs)
                                 to osteoblast-like cells
Abstract:
Actin has many functions in the nucleus. Our lab recently showed that the loss of
 β-actin in mouse embryonic fibroblasts (MEF) leads to differential expression of gene
 programs related to development and differentiation, including neurogenesis. In this
 study, we directly reprogrammed MEFs to osteoblast-like cells. Firstly, we showed
 that mineralization of the extracellular matrix correlates with β-actin level: β-actin-/-
 KO cells show mineralization after 4 days, whereas β-actin+/-HET and β-actin+/+ WT
 cells require 8 and 14 days, respectively. Using Scanning Electron Microscopy, we
 also observed hydroxyapatite-like polycrystalline structures secreted exclusively
 by KO cells on day 4. We also performed RNA-seq analysis on all the CiOsteo cells,
 and found genes related to osteogenesis that are dysregulated between WT and KO CiOsteo
 cells. Lastly, we identified increased heterochromatization at the loci of key regulatory
 genes, such as Msx1 and Mmp13 that are downregulated in KO CiOsteo. In summary, we
 propose that β-actin is required for regulating the chromatin accessibility during
 direct reprogramming: in the absence of β-actin, key regulatory genes remain heterochromatinized
 and thus not transcribed, resulting in a hypermineralization phenotype.

Title:
Speciation and transposable element amplification in the Ethiopian frog species Ptychadena
                                 neumanni
Abstract:
Transposable elements (TEs) exhibit high variation in diversity and copy number in
 vertebrates, which has important evolutionary implications as they constitute a source
 of evolutionary novelties. The dynamics of TEs are strongly affected by factors such
 as host demography. In small populations, genetic drift opposes the effect of negative
 selection and can result in the fixation of TE insertions that would be eliminated
 in large populations. The carrier subpopulation hypothesis predicts that population
 subdivision caused by vicariance or dispersal may trigger fixation of TE families
 by genetic drift. We used the Ethiopian Ptychadena neumanni species complex to test
 this hypothesis and to investigate any relation between speciation and TE amplification.
 Using a high-quality genome sequence for P. cf. neumanni 2, we identified 2342 repeat
 families de novo using RepeatModeler and characterized the repeat landscape of the
 frog using RepeatMasker. Resequencing data from six closely related frog species were
 used to identify mobile element insertions that differ among species. Our analysis
 revealed that the amplification of TEs is consistent with the evolutionary history
 of the host inferred by SNPs. We also observed substantial differences in the rate
 of amplification of TEs between species.

Title: Targeted Delivery of Therapeutics for Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
Abstract:
Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) is a cancer characterized by increased growth of granulocytic
 precursors. Currently, there are two therapeutic strategies to CML: imatinib mesylate,
 and a combination of arsenic trioxide and IFN-α. Imatinib is effective in controlling
 the chronic phase of the disease, but it is not curative since most of patients who
 discontinue the therapy relapse. The combination of arsenic trioxide and IFN-α is
 a novel treatment, which has been shown to reduce the clonogenic activity of CML cells
 ex vivo, and prolong the survival of primary CML mice. However, the major downside
 of this combinatorial treatment is its lack of specificity. The present study aims
 to overcome this lack of specificity by creating BSA-PLGA nanoparticles which encapsulate
 arsenic trioxide and IFN-α. To specifically target CML cells, Y-R-A-P-W-P-P sequence
 (CML cell-associated peptide) was conjugated to BSA surface.In vitro, these nanoparticles
 showed to be more effective in inducing apoptosis in CML cell lines than the current
 therapeutic strategies to CML. In vivo, the nanoparticles depleted all GFP-positive
 CML cells from CML mice blood.

Title:
Atf6-mediated Transcriptomic Signatures in Cellular Environments of Unfolded Protein
                                 Response Activation
Abstract:
The accumulation of misfolded proteins in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) triggers
 the unfolded protein response (UPR); activating transcription factor 6 (Atf6) mediates
 one of three branches of this signaling pathway. UPR induction, however, can manifest
 heterogeneously across distinct conditions, generating variable molecular signatures
 and pathogenic phenotypes. This study aimed to elucidate the role of Atf6 in mediating
 UPR induction in zebrafish livers by characterizing Atf6-regulated transcriptomic
 signatures under distinct stressors. Putative Atf6 target genes were curated via a
 predicted consensus sequence and scraping transcription factor databases. UPR genes
 were similarly identified by compiling genes annotated for relevant Reactome and Gene
 Ontology terms. Curated gene lists were analyzed using RNAseq data from an atf6-overexpressing
 transgenic model of UPR induction; Atf6 was sufficient to cause differential expression
 of 23.6% of Atf6 target genes and 34.5% of UPR genes. RNAseq data from livers exposed
 to ethanol and arsenic was integrated to identify downstream genes inducible under
 environments of ER stress. Thus, by analyzing transcriptomic patterns and their biological
 relevance, we found that Atf6 mediates distinct forms of UPR activation through complex
 regulatory programs dependent on cellular environment.

Title: Optimisation of Palmitic Acid Production in Chloroidium sp
Abstract:
The algae Chloroidium sp. UTEX 3007 is a potential sustainable alternative for palm
 oil production. A large proportion of the lipids produced by Chloroidium sp. UTEX
 3007 are palmitic acid, the fatty acid which is the main constituent of palm oil.
 Chloroidium sp. UTEX 3007 has been found to only produce palmitic acid during stationary
 phase, which is a limiting factor for large-scale production. This study optimises
 palmitic acid production during growth phase in Chloroidium sp. UTEX 3007 via a workflow
 of UV mutagenesis and sorting for high-lipid producing mutants with FACS. Two rounds
 of mutagenesis and FACS selection were conducted, resulting in a population of high-lipid
 producing cells. Alongside FACS data, fluorescence microscopy results indicate increased
 lipid content in the mutant cells. FT-ICR/MS, GC-MS and Confocal Raman Microscopy
 were used to characterise the lipid composition of the mutant strains. Palmitic acid
 was found to be consistently produced in the mutant, and the saturation status of
 the mutant was unchanged relative to the wildtype.

Title:
Behavioral responses of coral reef fish from the thermally extreme Persian/Arabian
                                 Gulf to temperature and time of day
Abstract:
Tropical coral reef fish are under extreme thermal stress in the Persian/Arabian Gulf
 (PAG), with annual thermal fluctuations from winter lows of 12°C to summer highs of
 36°C. Coral reef fish are exclusively ectotherms, so their physiological performance
 is directly tied to environmental temperatures and behavioral modulation is critical
 for ectotherms to regulate internal body temperatures. This study examined the effects
 of temperature and time of day on fish behavior in model fish from PAG, Lutjanus ehrenbergii
 (Blackspot snapper) and Scolopsis ghanam (Arabian monocle bream), at 18°C, 27°C, and
 35.5°C between morning (07:15), noon (12:55), and evening (18:35). Specifically, five
 ecologically important behaviors: relative swimming speed, activity, exploration,
 sheltering, and sociability. Results showed that there were significant interactions
 between time of day and temperature on relative swimming speed, activity, and exploration,
 where each measure would increase as temperature increased and had peak values in
 the evening. Conversely, there were only interactions with temperature for S. ghanam,
 where sheltering was lowest at the thermal optimal 27°C. These behavioral modulations
 may be used to acclimate to extreme thermal stress within the region.

Title:
Characterizing Genetic And Epigenetic Modifications Of An Alga With Increased Lipid
                                 Accumulation Phenotype
Abstract:
The Salehi-Ashtiani lab has been optimizing the lipid content of microalgae, specifically
 the Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, to efficiently produce compounds that can serve as
 substitutes for fossil fuels. Previously, the lab has shown that through cycles of
 mutagenesis and selection, strains that accumulate high levels of lipid can be obtained.
 The broad objective of this project is to explore the hypothesis that there are specific
 epigenetic modifications involved in regulation of transcripts and can lead to increased
 lipid accumulation in the unicellular microalga under certain environmental conditions.
 To investigate, we carried out bisulfite sequencing and analyzed the results for a
 subset of 112 transcripts encoding 10 genes, which are involved in C. reinhardtii's
 lipid production pathways. Although there isn't substantial differences in methylation
 levels collectively between the parental C. reinhardtii (CC-503) strain and the CC-H5
 mutant, there were two genes that showed significant differences in methylation levels.
 Given that this study focused on a subset of genes, we can expect to find more genes
 that are their epigenetic status are different in the two strains.

Title: Development of delivery vehicles for the specific targeting of solid tumors
Abstract:
One drawback of chemotherapy is nonspecific targeting of normal cells by therapeutic
 molecules. This project focuses on developing and testing two drug delivery systems
 that exploit the low extracellular pH of the tumor environment to specifically target
 cancer cells, thus reducing harmful localization of therapeutics to healthy tissue,
 and increasing the potency of therapeutics. To achieve this pH sensitivity, drug-loaded
 carriers were coupled with a novel acidity triggered rational membrane (ATRAM) peptide
 which at physiological pH, lies parallel to the cell surface but at acidic pH, undergoes
 conformational change that drives insertion into the lipid bilayer. The first system
 is a Doxorubicin (Dox)-encapsulated, ATRAM N-coupled POPC-DSPE-PEG liposome system.
 The second system is a Dox encapsulated nanoparticle system consisting a poly (lactic-co-glycolic
 acid) (PLGA) core, a bovine serum albumin (BSA) shell crosslinked in situ with glutaraldehyde,
 and coupled ATRAM peptide. Cell viability assays show that ATRAM facilitates pH-dependent
 uptake of liposomes and NPs, and delivery of their cargo which leads to specific toxicity
 of Dox to cells at low pH conditions.

Title:
Stress, sleep and sleep deprivation: How social defeat stress and sleep architecture
                                 affect each other
Abstract:
Accumulating evidence suggests that depression is tightly associated with sleep. This
 interaction has been unsuccessfully modeled in mice due to a failure to adhere to
 common behavioral models of stress. Given the need to reliably investigate this relationship,
 the social defeat model of depression was used to determine how stress affects sleep
 architecture and sleep regulation, and how sleep can prevent or induce stress susceptibility.
 Combining EEG with transcriptomics of the medial prefrontal cortex, we found that
 mice susceptible to chronic social defeat (CSD) stress displayed fragmented NREM sleep
 with intrusions of wakefulness, which may be explained by differential expression
 of serotonergic receptors Htr1a/2a and afternoon blunting of Slc29a3 adenosine transport.
 Exposure to CSD increased the proportion of REM sleep at the beginning of the light
 cycle through more frequent but shorter bouts, which were associated with blunted
 morning expression of serotonergic signaling enzyme Prkcd and myelin function gene
 Mobp. Furthermore, manipulating sleep through TSD or REM deprivation (REMD) suggested
 that recovery sleep after REMD, but not TSD, may promote resilience to stress. Findings
 from this Capstone project therefore support the notion that susceptibility to stress
 and adaptive sleep responses mutually affect each other.

Title:
Phenotypic divergence and marked population structure in the Arabian gray mangroves
                                 (Avicennia marina)
Abstract:
Population differentiation involves both selective and neutral factors and here we
 study patterns of neutral genetic divergence and phenotypic differentiation in the
 Arabian gray mangrove using genome-wide markers and a suite of leaf-associated morphological
 traits between the Arabian Sea, where oceanic conditions exist, and the geographically
 isolated stands from the Arabian Gulf, one of the hottest and most saline seas in
 the world. Multivariate analyses based neutral SNPs revealed marked population structure
 between and among the Arabian Gulf and the Arabian Sea, suggesting strong genetic
 drift and limited gene flow. Our analyses also showed that leaf stomatal density was
 27% lower in populations inside the Arabian Gulf compared to those outside, an adaptive
 response to cope with the higher temperature and salinity of the Persian/Arabian Gulf.
 These results suggest that the combined effects of natural selection and drift in
 isolation are driving population divergence in the Arabian gray mangroves.

Title: ATAC-Seq Profiling of Peripheral Blood Mononuclear Cells in response to P
Abstract:
Malaria is a blood born disease that affects 300 million people annually and is caused
 by parasitic protozoans of the genus Plasmodium. Upon infection, transcriptional activation
 of host immune cells is required to mount an efficient immune response. Both genetic
 and epigenetic mechanisms are involved in the regulation of transcription, but little
 is known about these effects in malaria. Here we focus on documenting the temporal
 changes in chromatin accessibility of circulating immune cells at three stages: before
 infection, during asymptomatic parasitemia, and during symptomatic parasitemia. First,
 an Assay for Transposase-Accessible Chromatin ATAC-seq protocol was developed and
 optimized to frozen Peripheral Blood Mononuclear Cells PBMCs collected from malarial
 African children. Sequencing of bulk and single-cell ATAC-seq libraries generated
 high quality sequencing data that was analyzed using multiple pipelines. These analyses
 generated the first ATAC-seq data in malaria and provided genome-wide insight about
 temporal changes in chromatin accessibility and cell-types implicated during infection.
 scATAC-seq data revealed accessibility patterns that are masked in bulk analysis.
 These PBMCs accessibility maps are the foundation for future epigenetic studies aiming
 to better understand host in vivo immune response to malaria.

Title: dnmt1 Mutation Causes Senescence in the Livers of Zebrafish Larvae
Abstract:
DNA methylation is an epigenetic modification that suppresses transposons and stabilizes
 the genome, and nearly all cancers are characterized by global DNA hypomethylation
 and, in some cases, hypermethylation at promoters of tumor suppressor genes. Given
 that one of the first responses to widespread oncogenic signals is the activation
 of tumor-suppressive processes, including cellular senescence, we asked whether global
 DNA hypomethylation activates oncogene and leads to senescence. We used 5 days post
 fertilization (dpf) zebrafish mutants that lack a key DNA methylation component, DNA
 methyltransferase 1 (dnmt1), to answer this question. Through our experiments and
 RNAseq analysis, we found that there's global DNA hypomethylation, senescence, up-regulation
 of immune response pathway genes, but no significant altered expression of oncogenes
 in dnmt1 mutant livers. We concluded that dnmt1 loss induces senescence in zebrafish
 hepatocytes, but this is not oncogene-induced. Alternatively, it could be activation
 of transposons that causes senescence in this case.

Title: Circadian Regulation of Mood Disorders
Abstract:
Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) is a mood disorder that is defined by the World Health
 Organization as the feeling of sadness, guilt and of low self-worth, loss of pleasure,
 appetite and concentration and sleep disturbances. Though it has been established
 that depressed patients exhibit aberrant circadian rhythms, little is known about
 the mechanism behind this phenomenon. In fact, it is still unclear whether circadian
 dysregulation is a cause or consequence of mood disorders. Understanding this relationship
 will help in the development of novel therapeutics for the treatment of mood disorders.
 This study, therefore, investigated the effect of stress on the oscillation of an
 SCN output molecule, Prokineticin-2 (PK2). We studied the differential expression
 of PK2, the clock gene Period1 and the PK2's receptor, PKR2, in stress-susceptible
 and resilient mice at different times of the light-dark cycle in both the SCN and
 LHb at the mRNA level using quantitative PCR. Our study shows that stress-susceptible
 mice have upregulation of PK2 in the LHb, while stress-resilient mice exhibit a phase
 advance in Per1 rhythmicity in the LHb.

Title:
Have Reef Fishes in the Arabian Region Adjusted to the Extreme Temperature Variations
                                 through Gill Remodeling
Abstract:
Global warming has caused a rise in sea surface temperatures (SST). The rise of SSTs
 reduces oxygen to be dissolved in water, while simultaneously increasing the metabolic
 oxygen demand in fishes. The purpose of this study was to investigate whether gill
 remodeling occurred in tropical fish, specifically in Scolopsis ghanam, in relation
 to temperature change. Gill remodeling could increase oxygen uptake and transport
 by increasing the surface area available for absorption. S. ghanam was assessed at
 three different temperatures representing the natural range of temperatures for the
 Arabian Gulf, 18 ˚C (winter), 27 ˚C (shoulder season), and 35.5 ˚C (summer). Using
 histology images, five gill parameters were measured (filament length, number of lamellae,
 perimeter of lamellae, lamellae base thickness, and intralamellar cellular mass).
 With the exception of lamellae perimeter, all measured traits showed significant variation
 with temperature. This is the first study to demonstrate gill remodeling in tropical
 reef fish in response to temperature change, with important implications for how fish
 throughout the tropics may respond to future climate change.

Title:
Into the Dark: How Chronic Social Defeat Affects Homeostatic Sleep Following Sleep
                                 Deprivation in the Dark Phase
Abstract:
Major Depressive Disorder is a global burden with symptoms such as low moods and irregular
 sleep. Sleep presents itself as a symptom and cause in mood disorders. In this project,
 Chronic Social Defeat was used to induce stress-susceptible or stress-resilient subjects
 through physical stress. Behavioral tests determine phenotypes, then mice were subjected
 to sleep deprivation either during the day or night. Although mice are nocturnal,
 their polyphasic sleep patterns can be disturbed through night-sleep deprivation.
 Following sleep deprivation, homeostatic sleep response was observed. Through electroencephalography/electromyography
 recordings, vigilance states and sleep propensity were recorded. Mice were either
 deprived during the day or the night, then their homeostatic sleep recorded for 24
 hours. The sleep propensity marker in stress-susceptible mice was blunted when compared
 to stress-naïve/resilient mice after daytime-sleep deprivation. Night-deprived mice
 showed similar sleep-propensity response during the day as day-deprived mice. Our
 data concludes that sleep deprivation during the night alters proportions of REM sleep
 in stress-susceptible mice most notably, with REM sleep decreasing during the night
 and increasing during the day compared to the other phenotypes.

Title: Effects of alpha-helix mimetics on mutant p53 aggregation in pancreatic carcinoma
Abstract:
Mutations in p53 occur in more than 50% of human cancer types, with a vast majority
 of these mutations taking place in the DNA-binding domain of p53. Recent research
 has shown that many of these mutations cause aggregation of p53 with its wild type
 form and other proteins in the pathway, resulting in loss of ability to arrest the
 cell cycle and induce apoptosis. alpha-helix mimetics have been shown to inhibit amyloid
 aggregation of Ab and IAPP, which are associated with Alzheimer's disease and type
 II diabetes, respectively. Here, we show that ADH-6 acts as a potent, specific mutant
 p53 inhibitor that can abrogate p53 aggregates and rescue its function in pancreatic
 carcinoma. Rescued p53 recovers its cellular functions, particularly cell cycle arrest
 and apoptosis. Overall, the study shows that A-beta inhibitors can target p53 aggregation,
 suggesting similarities between the self-assembly processes of these proteins.

Title: Chronic Social Stress Blunts Temperature Amplitude and CIRP Expression
Abstract:
Patients diagnosed with major depressive disorder show significant aberrations in
 circadian temperature rhythms. To elucidate the putative connections between temperature
 rhythmicity and depression, core body temperature was recorded using wireless telemetry
 in stress-naïve, resilient and susceptible mice exposed to chronic social defeat
 stress (CSDS), a rodent model of depression-like behaviour. RT-qPCR was used to measure
 the expression of cold-inducible RNA-binding protein (CIRP), a temperature-sensitive
 gene which acts as a circadian regulator. Levels of Clock and Per1 in the suprachiasmatic
 nucleus (SCN), lateral habenula (LHb) and dorsal raphe nucleus (DRN) were also assessed
 as they are downstream targets of CIRP. Amplitude of temperature rhythms was blunted
 more severely in susceptible mice. As a result, CIRP was only up-regulated in susceptible
 mice, leading to loss of CIRP rhythmicity in the SCN and LHb. These initial findings
 suggest that rhythms in temperature and CIRP expression could be used as markers of
 mood disorders.

Title:
Impact of the microbiome and Perilipin-2 overexpression on hepatotoxicant and mutation-induced
                                 unfolded protein response activation and lipid accumulation in zebrafish larvae
Abstract:
Stress in the form of alcohol abuse, high fat diet and environmental toxicant exposure
 leads to activation of signaling pathways. The response to unfolded protein accumulation
 in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is critical to cellular homeostasis and mediated
 by the unfolded protein response (UPR). Chronic UPR induction is maladaptive and known
 to cause diseases. Steatosis is the accumulation of lipid droplets in hepatocytes,
 and while not pathological, steatosis is a requisite for the more severe steatohepatitis.
 I leveraged models of steatosis in zebrafish to further understand if the microbiome
 could influence the UPR. There was no significant impact of the germ-free rearing
 on ER structure or steatosis severity in stressed hepatocytes. To assess lipid accumulation
 and its influence on the UPR, I used a transgenic zebrafish line overexpressing the
 lipid droplet protein Perilipin-2 in hepatocytes (Tg(fabp10a:EGFP-hPLIN2)). Lipid
 droplet accumulation was significantly higher in Perilipin-2 zebrafish compared to
 wild-type controls. Overexpression of Perilipin-2 also reduced the incidence of aberrant
 ER morphology. This supports the conclusion that stabilization of lipid droplets by
 Perilipin-2 protects against ER deformity in the liver.

Title: Single Cell Analysis of Immune Response to Infection in Malaria
Abstract:
Malaria is one of the world's leading causes of infection-related deaths, disproportionately
 affecting children aged under five in the African Region. Efforts to develop novel
 therapeutic drugs and an effective vaccine are hampered by considerable inter-patient
 variation, which is still poorly understood due to an overall lack of understanding
 of the host immune response to infection. Here, we developed experimental procedures
 adapted for PBMC samples collected in the field in Africa and performed single-cell
 RNA-seq (scRNA-seq) on matched samples from four children before and after symptomatic
 P. falciparum infection to determine how malaria shapes the landscape of circulating
 immune cells during blood-stage malaria. Twelve immune cell types were identified
 based on classical gene markers. Matched individual-level analysis revealed significant
 inter-individual variation. Together, these results strongly suggest that inter-individual
 variation in the symptomology of malaria originates from variable alterations in both
 innate and adaptive cells in response to infection. Furthermore, the datasets generated
 will serve as foundational scRNA-seq PBMC maps of malarial children for future studies
 of host immune response in malaria.

Title:
The Role of Microtubule Associated Protein 4 (MAP4) in The DNA Damage Response/Repair
                                 Pathway
Abstract:
DNA damage and the inability of cells to faithfully repair it can lead to inhibition
 of cell cycle progression, apoptosis and many disorders such as cancer, neurodegenerative
 diseases and developmental defects. Cells have therefore developed a complex defense
 mechanism, known as the DNA Damage Response/Repair (DDR) pathway, in order to detect
 and repair these damages. While various proteins have been identified as key players
 in the DDR pathway, a complete understanding of the pathway is still elusive, suggesting
 the involvement of as yet unidentified additional proteins. Here, we report for the
 very first time that Microtubule Associated Protein 4 (MAP4), which was thought to
 be cytoplasmic and only involved in regulation of intracellular transport by promoting
 microtubule polymerization and stability, is a nuclear protein that interacts with
 key players of the DDR pathway upon induction of double-strand DNA breaks. Further,
 we show that over-expression of its microtubule binding domain leads to a faster recovery
 from DNA damage. Our findings place MAP4 at the hub of the DNA repair pathway, which
 may hold key to further understanding of the DDR mechanisms. Understanding the DNA
 repair pathway may provide novel therapeutic approaches to alleviating the risk of
 disorders caused by DNA damage.

Title: The Role of NM1 in Neuronal Development and Disease
Abstract:
Previous research reveals the role of nuclear myosin 1 (NM1), a cytoskeletal protein
 found in the nucleus, which is also a component of the B-WICH transcriptional assembly
 and an agent that responds to DNA damage. Experiments with brain tissues from neurodegenerative
 disease patients found increased oxidative DNA damage in nuclear and mitochondrial
 DNA in these tissues, alluding to a potential role of NM1 in the disease etiology.
 We aimed to identify the connection between NM1 and common neurodegenerative diseases
 by generating NM1 KO cell lines from primary MEFs. We found an over-representation
 of genes related to neurodegenerative disease and oxidative phosphorylation in GO
 analyses. While most nuclear-encoded genes were down-regulated in the KO cells, a
 few were up-regulated along with some genes encoded in mitochondria. CRISPR-generated
 NM1 KO cells exhibited a smaller amount of OXPHOS subunits compared to the WT, but
 also showed an increase in both ATP and hydrogen peroxide levels. GO analysis on those
 CRISPR NM1 KO cells reveals an over-representation of genes related to axon guidance
 and neurogenesis, indicating that NM1 might be implicated in other neuronal development
 processes.

Title: The Epidemiology of Arterial Stiffness in the Emirati Population
Abstract:
Arterial stiffness has shown large prognostic value as a biomarker for all-cause mortality
 and the onset of severe cardiovascular events, independent of other CVD risk factors.
 Forty percent of deaths in the United Arab Emirates is attributable to cardiovascular
 disease, highlighting the need for greater investigation into potential biomarkers
 that may point to mechanisms underlying CVD risk in this population. Due to the limited
 number of studies on arterial stiffness in the region, this study investigates the
 epidemiology of arterial stiffness in the UAE population, using augmentation index
 (AIx) as a surrogate measure. Baseline descriptive statistics were calculated for
 3,856 Emiratis aged ≥18 years. The analysis identified sex, blood pressure measurements
 and cholesterol as large drivers of variation in the data and found that females and
 older aged individuals had significantly higher average AIx values than males. AIx
 positively correlated with blood pressure measurements, smoking, anthropometric measures
 and CRP in both males and females, yet variations in relationships and correlations
 did exist across sex. These sex-differences as well as the accelerated vascular aging
 identified in aging females compared to males suggests that different mechanisms may
 be underlying arterial stiffness between males and females.

Title:
Systems Level Metabolic Characterization of Sickle Cell Disease Using Computational
                                 Models of Red Blood Cells
Abstract:
Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) is a heritable hemoglobinopathy caused by a point mutation
 in the β-globin protein of the tetrameric hemoglobin protein resulting in the sickle-shaped
 RBC. Presently, metabolomic differences between SCD patients and healthy individuals
 have been partly studied. This study generated constraint-based models of RBC based
 on a baseline iDEA-RBC-1494 model to characterize the metabolic phenotype in SCD and
 healthy controls. The iDEA-RBC-1494 model is a 5-fold expansion in the number of genes
 of a previously published iAB-RBC-283 model using Recon 3D and the latest RBC proteomic
 dataset. In silico perturbations to non-trivial metabolic reactions in our SCD model
 resulted in the prediction of potential drugs that could rescue the SCD phenotype.
 Bioenergetic analysis resulted in the identification of target reactions, which we
 used to query the Drug Gene Interaction Database for potential drugs. We identify
 candidate drugs that revert the SCD bioenergetic phenotype and which can be evaluated
 further for the clinical treatment of SCD. The significantly expanded network model
 for RBC offers an enabling, quantitative resource for studying blood metabolism and
 blood-related disorders.

Title: Interethnic Analysis of Host miRNA Response to Malaria
