Abstract:
Malaria continues to be a major global public health problem, with young children
 in sub-Saharan Africa bearing a disproportionate burden of malaria-related deaths.
 Despite multitudinous endeavors to eliminate the disease, a limited understanding
 of mechanisms underlying variation in host immune response to malaria hinders the
 potential of developing effective anti-malarial drugs and vaccines. Previous studies
 have shed light on the impact of post-transcriptional regulation and host genetic
 control of miRNA expression during malaria infection. Here, we generated miRNA profiles
 of children from two sympatric ethnic groups with varying levels of susceptibility
 to malaria in Burkina Faso (Mossi and Fulani) during natural P. falciparum infection
 and assessed interethnic differences in their miRNA transcriptomes at multiple levels.
 The results of my study highlight variation in post-transcriptional regulation and
 ethnic-specific effects of host genotype on miRNA expression as potential mechanisms
 driving interethnic differences in host susceptibility and immune response to malaria.

Title:
Studies on the Role of β‐actin in Expression of the Long Noncoding RNA Meg3, and Its
                                 Potential Impact on Cell Identity
Abstract:
Differentiation occurs through activating and repressing various gene programs towards
 a given cell identity, done in part by regulating chromatin states using chromatin
 modifiers, some of which use long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs). β‐actin is also important
 in differentiation, regulating chromatin and overall gene expression, like as part
 of certain chromatin remodelers. This study used RNA-seq, ChIRP-seq on the lncRNA
 Meg3, and ChIP-seq for the Meg3-interacting chromatin remodeler Prc2, on wild-type
 and β‐actin depleted mouse embryonic fibroblasts. With β‐actin loss: several lncRNAs
 were differentially expressed, including Meg3; Meg3 occupancy changed across specific
 chromosomal locations, impacting expression of several genes related to differentiation;
 and no differentially expressed genes shared Meg3 and Ezh2 occupancies. Overall, both
 expression and genomic deposition of Meg3 are β‐actin-dependent. Also, Meg3 genomic
 association is likely mediated in an β-actin-dependent manner through mechanisms independent
 from the Prc2 complex. These alterations likely impact expression of genes involved
 in cell fate.

Title: The Transcriptional Role of Nuclear Myosin 1 During Neurogenesis
Abstract:
Previous studies have shown that cytoskeletal proteins regulate and maintain chromatin
 organization and gene regulation. Nuclear Myosin 1 (NM1) as a part of the BWICH multiprotein
 transcriptional complex is involved in the regulation of gene transcription and DNA
 integrity. Regulation and coordination of the chromatin are crucial for the activation
 of specific gene programs during differentiation. Given that NM1 is involved in transcriptional
 complexes, NM1 could also be potentially involved in regulating differentiation. This
 study aims to investigate the transcriptional role of NM1 in neuronal differentiation.
 Using a small chemicals cocktail we transdifferentiated Mouse Embryonic Fibroblasts
 (MEFs) to neurons and found that neuronal specific genes in MEFs were mostly downregulated
 in the absence of NM1. Further, we investigated the impact of NM1 in neurons by observing
 the change in morphology during the neuronal induction period. Through RTqPCR and
 immunofluorescence, we assessed the differences in neuronal expression levels in presence
 and absence of NM1. Our results showed that in absence of NM1, neurons tend to have
 a higher survival rate and different morphology. The loss of NM1 resulted in irregular
 axon connections, an increase in dendrites, and a potential delayal in differentiation
 or potential formation of oligodendrocytes.

Title:
Understanding the Evolutionary Dynamics of the Major Histocompatibility Complex in
                                 Ethiopian Grass Frogs
Abstract:
Understanding the evolutionary landscape of the major histocompatibility complex (MHC)
 lays at the core of immunology and has strong implications for conservation. The latter
 claim is particularly true in the case of amphibians, an understudied vertebrate class
 that remains severely impacted by emerging infectious diseases. Here, I investigated
 the evolutionary dynamics of the classical MHC genes in the grass frogs of genus Ptychadena
 that are endemic to one of the world's biodiversity hotspots – the Ethiopian Highlands.
 Using intra- and inter-specific whole-genome resequencing datasets, I conducted phylogenetic
 inference, selection tests, and population genetics analysis to characterize the evolutionary
 forces that shaped the evolution of the classical MHC genes. The results revealed
 characteristic signatures of balancing selection, such as excess of nonsynonymous
 polymorphisms and above-average nucleotide diversity, amongst the MHC class I loci,
 whereas the patterns of diversity at class II loci were not consistent with balancing
 selection. The signals at the class I loci point towards recent balancing selection,
 which did not result in trans-specific polymorphisms. Based on the conducted analysis,
 I discuss several challenges related to using low-coverage resequencing data for studies
 of the MHC, which may aid in the execution of similar studies in the future.

Title: Investigating the Transcriptional Landscape of Dendritic Cells in 3D Culture
Abstract:
Monocyte derived dendritic cells (DCs) play an essential role in bridging the innate
 and adaptive immune responses through their efficient antigen presenting abilities.
 They have recently been shown to exhibit enhanced immune potency when differentiated
 and activated on 3D collagen matrices compared to traditional 2D cell culture environments.
 However, the transcriptional immune response of DCs differentiated and matured on
 various scaffolding remained unexplored. This study investigated the transcriptomic
 differences of DCs differentiated and activated on 3D collagen matrices with a DESeq2
 analysis pipeline in an aim to provide insight into the transcriptional regulation
 and mechanisms behind the previously observed increase in immune potency. The findings
 revealed that the 3 mg/ml collagen concentration provided a supportive microenvironment
 for the differentiation and activation of DCs with antigen-specific cellular response
 transcriptional pathways activated. The same specific immune response pathways failed
 to be activated in DCs cultured in traditional 2D cell culture plates. Most unexpectedly,
 the 1 mg/ml collagen matrix was found to prematurely activate mDC-like transcriptional
 level immune responses in the absence of maturation factors, possibly suggesting a
 mechanosensitivty of DCs to soft substratum mimicking wound tissue.

Title:
Prion protein-derived cell-penetrating peptide inhibits type II diabetes-associated
                                 islet amyloid polypeptide aggregation and cytotoxicity
Abstract:
Amyloid diseases are conditions including Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease whose
 pathologies are caused by the mis-folding and aggregation of one of many amyloid proteins.
 This in turn results in toxic gain of function (GoF) and cell death. One such amyloid
 protein is islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP), whose aggregation and toxic GoF is implicated
 in the loss of beta cells associated with type II diabetes. As in other amyloid diseases,
 there is currently a dearth of therapeutics aimed at addressing IAPP aggregation and
 cytotoxicity. In this study, we test the efficacy of a cell-penetrating peptide (CPP)
 composed of the nuclear localization sequence (NLS) of the prion protein (PrP) conjugated
 to the signal sequence of neural cell adhesion molecule 1 (NCAM) against IAPP aggregation
 and toxic GoF. This construct has already been shown to be effective against the amyloid
 (A) peptide, which is implicated in Alzheimer's disease. We report that the construct
 is effective against IAPP aggregation and toxic gain of function and suggest that
 this makes it a promising potential amyloid inhibitor.

Title: Dual RNASequencing of the human host and Plasmodium falciparum parasite
Abstract:
Almost half of the world population is at risk of malaria infection, and Plasmodium
 falciparum, the deadliest malarial parasite, stands as one of the most serious threats
 to global public health accounting for the large majority of all estimated malaria
 cases and mortalities. P. falciparum malaria afflicts children unpredictably with
 high levels of symptomatic variability during the blood development stage of the parasite
 life cycle. Investigating the natural dynamic variation in transcriptional response
 of both the human host and Plasmodium parasite has the potential to elucidate the
 mechanisms that drive inter-individual variability in host immune response at the
 transcriptional level. This study presents an optimized experimental and bioinformatic
 approach for dual RNA sequencing of the human host and P. falciparum parasites using
 blood samples collected from a symptomatic malarial African pediatric cohort. The
 procedure generates a quantitative readout of host-parasite transcriptomes. The host-parasite
 transcriptional data was used to identify cross-correlated host-parasite transcripts
 and transcripts associated with parasitemia. This study lays the foundation for population-scale
 integrative joint transcriptomic analysis of in vivo host-parasite interactions and
 provides data and tools to apply in the context of other infectious diseases to elucidate
 the complex architecture of host-pathogen interactions at the transcriptional level.

Title: Neural Encoding of Thermal Stimulation
Abstract:
Thermal stimulation and perception has been explored in several studies through self-reports
 (Filingeri et al., 2014; El Ali et al., 2020; Watanabe et al. 2014) and positron emission
 tomography (PET) (Craig et al. 2000). Neural techniques such as electroencephalography
 (EEG) have the potential to provide brain correlates associated with thermal stimulation.
 The literature, however, does not provide any information on the event related potential
 (ERP) formation when performing a thermal recognition task. In the current study,
 four different temperature stimuli were delivered to 15 healthy participants and
 their brain activity was measured using EEG. We found the P200 ERP component in the
 middle frontal cortex and the central parietal cortex and the P100 ERP component in
 the occipital cortex. Interestingly, in the middle frontal and the central parietal
 cortices, the highest temperature (41°C) had the lowest activation compared to the
 lowest temperature (23°C), while, in the occipital cortex, the activation for the
 two conditions was inverted. Future research is needed to explain the differences
 in activation patterns found between the occipital region and middle frontal and central
 parietal cortices when participants receive higher and lower temperature stimuli.

Title:
Novel cancer combinatory therapy using drug-loaded, active-targeting, nanoparticles
                                 functionalized with immune checkpoint inhibitors
Abstract:
Despite the global efforts to cure cancer, it remains a leading cause of death worldwide.
 Chemotherapy has many limitations: multidrug resistance, poor solubility, and lack
 of targeting specificity. Nanoparticles as a delivery vehicle for chemotherapeutics
 have been shown to have increased in-blood circulation, biocompatibility, and targeting
 specificity. Moreover, a promising line of research known as immune checkpoint therapy
 inhibits the PD-1/PD-L1 interaction between cancer cells and immune cells. This approach
 has shown promising and more long-lasting results as it potentiates the immune system.
 Therefore, this project combined these two lines of research and developed a doxorubicin-loaded,
 lipid-coated, PD-L1 inhibitor and active targeting peptide-conjugated mesoporous silica
 nanoplatform that aimed to treat cancers that over express PD-L1. Cell viability MTS
 assays showed that the loaded nanoparticles were more toxic to MIA PaCa-2 cells than
 doxorubicin alone. This demonstrates the potential that the proposed system has for
 treatment of tumors expressing PD-L1.

Title: Nuclear Myosin 1 (NM1) regulates mitochondrial gene expression and dynamics
Abstract:
Nuclear Myosin 1 (NM1) regulates gene expression through a chromatin-based mechanism.
 Previous research has established its role in transcriptional activation and chromatin
 remodeling. Gene Ontology (GO) analysis of published RNAseq data from CRISPR-generated
 NM1 KO MEFs reveals multiple mitochondrial processes to be enriched in the absence
 of NM1. This led us to investigate differences in mitochondrial dynamics and bioenergetics
 in WT and NM1 KO MEFs. We report NM1 KO cells to have lowered expression of OXPHOS
 genes and dysregulated mitochondrial metabolites. Absence of functional NM1 in cells
 is also associated with decreased mitochondrial mass, perinuclear mitochondrial distribution,
 and underdeveloped mitochondrial morphology. Overall, our results suggest NM1 KO MEFs
 to resemble a mitochondrial phenotype similar to that of rapidly proliferating cells
 such as Stem Cells. Based on our results, we propose a model where NM1 controls mitochondrial
 gene expression through a chromatin-based mechanism and regulates key cellular differentiation
 pathways.

Title:
Zooxanthellae Symbionts of Acropora corals in Saadiyat Island Coral Reef Across Seasonal
                                 Changes
Abstract:
Coral reefs are globally in danger of extinction because of warming waters. Coral
 mass extinction is particularly concerning in the Arabian Gulf because sea surface
 temperatures (SST) are amongst the hottest in the world. Symbiosis between corals
 and dinoflagellates sometimes confers heat resistance to corals by preventing symbiont
 death. Identification and classification of coral-associated dinoflagellates uses
 degenerate amplification of genetic markers. In this study, I uniquely identified
 the thermoresistant Symbiodinium thermophilum strain in Abu Dhabi coral colonies of
 Acropora downingi collected at three different SSTs (27°C, 32°C and 34°C) using metagenomic
 analysis and subsequent mining of five genetic markers: ITS2, psbA, cp23S, LSU and
 cob. Symbiodinium thermophilum was significantly more abundant in 34°C samples compared
 to 27°C SST. These results confirm high fidelity of A. downingi-Symbiodinium interactions
 in the Arabian Gulf across temperature fluctuations. This study also reveals that
 improvements are needed to identify coral-associated photo symbionts using metagenomics.

Title:
Design of an Experimental Setup for Direct observance of Containerless Processes in
                                 Acoustically Levitated Droplets
Abstract:
Major: Chemistry Abstract: Ultrasonic levitation can provide a unique tool to study processes of light
 emission such as triboluminescence, as the material can emit light under contactless
 acoustic impact. The design of an experimental setup to study the effects of acoustic
 energy on ultrasonically levitated triboluminescent materials suspended in liquid
 droplets is reported here. The setup was utilized to record an absorption spectrum
 from a levitated droplet of aqueous solution of organic dye. Two metal coordination
 materials with structure-independent (blue light due to nitrogen discharge) and structure-specific
 emission (secondary emission due to ligand-metal charge transfer) were synthesized
 and suspended in a liquid. Droplets of this suspension were levitated and examined
 for visible emission. However, no visible emissions were observed, even in a darkened
 room. Although this shows that ultrasonic levitation cannot be used as a tool for
 examining triboluminescent materials, it has interesting implications for theories
 of sonoluminescence.

Title: Stabilization of Thermally Sensitive Vaccines and Medicines for Transport in Hot Climates
Abstract:
Major: Chemistry Abstract: The expenses related to the "cold chain" required for transportation of
 thermally labile medicines to remote locations remains as one of the greatest challenges
 for developing countries with hot climate. In this work, three different proteins,
 green fluorescent protein (GFP), H1N1 influenza neurminidase, and H1N1 hemagglutinin,
 were included as guests and stabilized in crystals of -lactose monohydrate, maltose,
 and sucrose as crystalline matrices. The proteins were then analyzed with fluorescence
 microscopy and gel electrophoresis, before and after an hour of incubation at 60 °C,
 to determine whether denaturation had been retarded by the inclusion of the proteins
 in their host matrix. Sucrose failed to crystallize properly on the scale necessary
 for the experiment and so could not be analyzed on its success as a host. Similarly,
 maltose failed to crystallize with hemagglutinin. Lactose and maltose appeared to
 readily crystallize and effectively protect GFP against denaturation, and gel electrophoresis
 (SDS-PAGE) results showed lactose including hemagglutinin and protecting it from denaturation.
 Results regarding neuraminidase inclusion in both dissacharides are inconclusive due
 to concentrations of that protein which were too low in all samples to produce bands
 in SDS-PAGE.

Title: Smart Hybrid Polymer that Responds to Humidity, Light and Heat
Abstract:
Major: Chemistry Abstract: A conceptually new smart hybrid polymer material that responds to humidity,
 UV light and heat was fabricated and its pho-to-, thermo- and hydro-responsive properties
 were studied. The prototypic material was prepared by introducing azobenzene units
 into a polymer chain by condensation polymerization. The product thus obtained was
 combined with a hydrophilic polymer as a flexible matrix that provides elastic environment
 for facile isomerization of azobenzene moieties. In the result-ing hybrid films, cis-trans
 isomerization of the main polymer chain leads to contraction or expansion, thereby
 inducing re-versible macroscopic deformation of the film. The hydrophilic component
 is capable of exchange of water with the sur-roundings, causing periodic contractions
 and expansions that appear as rapid locomotion of the film over a moist surface. Moreover,
 the hybrid film also exhibits rapid mechanical response by bending of nearly 180o
 when exposed to UV light or when heated anisotropically. The new smart material could
 be utilized in a variety of actuating devices, including soft robot-ics, medical prosthetics,
 and in printing.

Title: Enhancing Anion Binding Properties of a Zinc(II)-based Trefoil Knot
Abstract:
Major: ChemistryAbstract: Recently, a stream of research into synthetic receptors has focused on recognizing
 oxoanions, particularly because of their environmental impacts. For example, phosphate,
 an oxoanion, builds up through the excessive use of fertilizers resulting in eutrophication
 of water bodies, while sulfate is used in the separation of nuclear wastes. Our group
 succeeded in simultaneously assembling three remarkable zinc-based complexes in water:
 the 2-catenane ([2]C), trefoil knot (TK), and Solomon link (SL). TK is interesting
 because of its cavity that can recognize a wide range of anions. We have now synthesized
 an analogous TK based on urea groups that preferentially recognize oxoanion pollutants
 such as phosphate and sulfate. Urea groups equip the cavity of TK with improved hydrogen
 bond donor capabilities, allowing it to interact better with oxoanions.

Title:
Computational Study of How β-loop Dynamics Regulates HCV Polymerase Activity in the
                                 Presence and Absence of a Thumb-site-II Inhibitor
Abstract:
The Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infects around 150 million people globally, and chronic
 infection causes cirrhosis and cancer. The replication of the viral genome is carried
 out by NS5B, an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase. NS5B has become a major drug target
 over the past years, yet its inhibition mechanism remains a mystery. We used MD simulations
 to study the dynamics of NS5B, focusing on the β-loop. Microseconds simulation of
 NS5B with varying RNA lengths resolved the microstates accessible to β-loop both in
 initiation and elongation. We carried out further simulations to study the mechanism
 of inhibition of a thumb-site-II molecule, Filibuvir. Filibuvir serves to allosterically
 rigidify the β-loop, inhibiting the transition to elongation. Consistent with HDX
 experiments, our results showed that upon binding of Filibuvir, the enzyme enters
 an inactive state that rigidifies the β-loop by burying it within the active site.
 Through identifying residues that play a role in β-loop dynamics, we were able to
 propose mutagenesis experiments that controlled the enzyme's action. Our study shows
 how integration of experiments and simulations provide deeper insight into the mechanism
 of replication of viral polymerases.

Title:
Computing the kinetics and thermodynamics of biological processes from all-atom MD
                                 simulations
Abstract:
Molecular Dynamics (MD) simulations are invaluable in obtaining an atomic-level description
 of biomolecular processes. Despite the many recent advances, the dynamics of complex
 systems operating on long timescales still evades researchers due to the high computational
 demand. We developed a suite of programs to study biological processes across a range
 of timescales using short trajectories, providing a coarse-grained representation
 of relevant conformational states. This method was applied to two systems: (1) the
 rapid ion incorporation conformation in HIV Reverse Transcriptase; and, (2) the complex
 conformational transition of the Hammerhead-like ribozyme. Using only a one-dimensional
 reaction coordinate, ion incorporation was found to be a spontaneous and favorable
 process, with a free energy change of -3.37 kcal/mol. The structural switch mechanism
 of the Hammerhead-like ribozyme was also discovered in atomic detail, using both a
 low- and multi-dimensional configuration space definition. This higher-dimensional
 partitioning was shown to reliably describe the complexity of the system, but was
 found to be subject to poorer statistical convergence. Further development of this
 method may unlock new insights into the structure and dynamics of complex biological
 processes.

Title:
Synthesis of Triphenylphosphine-modified Gold Nanoparticles for an Effective Cytotoxic
                                 System to Cancer Cells
Abstract:
We developed a green and innovative synthetic route for gold nanoparticles, surface
 coated with therapeutic agent triphenylphosphine (TPP) and stabilized with Pluronic
 F-108 polymer (F-108@TPP-AuNPs) for an effective cytotoxic system to cancer cells.
 Gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) can selectively target cancer cells, image tumors, and
 induce hyperthermia. Gold(I)phosphine complexes such as TPP gold(I) chloride are cytotoxic,
 suggesting that TPP-AuNPs can be used in chemotherapy. Pluronic F-108 enhances the
 circulation time of the TPP drug and stabilizes the AuNPs, avoiding their aggregation.
 F-108@TPP-AuNPs were synthesized under microwave irradiation by heating an aqueous
 solution of TPP gold(I) chloride in presence of 1% Pluronic F-108 in basic conditions
 at 105°C for 20 minutes. UV-Vis, PXRD, TEM, DLS, EDX, and XPS confirmed the formation
 of spherical AuNPs surrounded with TPP molecules and stabilized with a polymeric shell
 of F-108. The biological assessment of the F-108@TPP-AuNPs on HeLa cancer cells showed
 superiority of the NPs over free TPP gold(I) chloride by two folds.

Title: Bacterial Phytohormones Regulate the Growth of a Blooming Cosmopolitan Diatom
Abstract:
Interactions between diatoms and bacteria are an essential part of aquatic environments
 that influence many oceanic biogeochemical cycles. One synergistic pathway is through
 biosynthesis of indole-3-acetic acid (IAA)—a phytohormone—by diatom-associated bacteria
 from diatom-secreted tryptophan that triggers nutrient exchanges between both taxa.
 The role of other phytohormones in diatom-bacteria interactions remains largely unknown.
 Here, several strains of bacteria associated with the cosmopolitan bloom-forming diatom
 Asterionellopsis glacialis were isolated and cultivated to establish the roles phytohormones
 play in diatom physiology. IAA alone did not enhance the growth of A. glacialis, but
 did so in combination with two other phytohormones, gibberellic acid and kinetin.
 Analyzing the metabolomes of F5, F10, and F28 using UHPLC-Q-ToF-MS showed that out
 of 74 known phytohormones, auxins, jasmonates, and a cytokinin were produced by all
 associated bacteria, with higher auxin production in F5 and higher jasmonate production
 in F10 and F28. These results suggest that a unique combination of hormones may enhance
 the diatom growth and that, in a complex microbiome, multiple phytohormone production
 by one or more bacteria, could cooperatively regulate or initiate diatom growth.

Title:
Purification and structural elucidation of a thiazole-based molecule from Cleome rupicola
                                 fruits exhibiting antioxidant and potential anticataract activity
Abstract:
Cataracts are the leading cause of blindness worldwide; however, there is currently
 no drug-based treatment. Plants that exhibit antioxidant properties have shown promising
 anticataract effects, likely because they supplement the activity of glutathione,
 the major antioxidant in lens cells. Cleome rupicola, a plant found in the United
 Arab Emirates, has traditionally been used to treat cataracts. Phytochemical screening
 of the aqueous plant extract established the presence of phytochemicals such as flavonoids,
 tannins, steroid derivatives, and reducing sugars. A novel antioxidant isolated from
 the fruit of C. rupicola was purified and structurally elucidated using chromatographic
 and spectroscopic techniques such as high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC),
 mass spectrometry (MS), and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. The compound
 is an enantiomerically pure thiazole derivative, 4-ethyl-2-methyl-4,5-dihydrothiazol-4-ol,
 assigned by the 1H NMR spectra and through-space hydrogen interactions visualized
 by two-dimensional NMR spectroscopy of the purified and synthesized compound. The
 structural elucidation of this compound serves as the first step in the development
 of an anticataract drug and verifies the modern relevance of a historically significant
 medicinal plant.

Title: Optimising Photolabile Protecting Groups for Incorporation into Biological Probes
Abstract:
Understanding physiological processes is vital for scientific advancement in many
 areas, from disease control to technological developments. While much progress has
 been made, particularly with the help of bioimaging techniques, a full knowledge of
 human physiology remains distant. To narrow the gap in knowledge, there is a need
 to develop more biological probes for studying the dynamic nature of physiological
 processes. Using light-dependent probes is effective as they provide tight control
 of the timing and location of events. In this category, photolabile protecting groups
 (PPGs) are of particular interest because of their simplicity of use. PPGs activated
 through the simultaneous absorption of two photons are especially useful for investigations
 in whole animals. However, the lack of PPGs activated by absorption of two photons
 is an impediment to their use. This project aims to optimise the 8-cyano-7-hydroxyquinolinyl
 PPG for higher sensitivity to two-photon absorption.

Title:
Rapid and Efficient Removal of Perfluorooctanoic Acid from Water with Fluorine-Rich
                                 Calixarene-Based Porous Polymers
Abstract:
Because of its non-biodegradable nature and persistence in the environment, perfluorooctanoic
 acid (PFOA) accumulates in water resources and poses serious environmental issues
 in many parts of the world. Adsorption is the most frequently used water decontamination
 method but the common drawbacks of adsorbents used (e.g. activated carbon) include
 low adsorption capacity, limited regeneration ability, and slow pollutant uptake.
 Here, we present the development of two fluorine-rich calix[4]arene-based porous polymers,
 FCX4-P and FCX4-BP, and demonstrate their potential utility for the removal of PFOA
 from water. FCX4-P removes ~99% of PFOA at environmentally relevant concentrations
 with higher affinity than the commercial activated carbon and with comparable kinetics.
 Given the structural and chemical versatility of porous polymers containing the calixarene
 macrocycle in their backbone, our findings herald the advent of a new generation of
 materials that can be successfully used for water purification.

Title: Chemical Screen Exploring the Role of mel-28 Nucleoporin Gene in C
Abstract:
Nucleoporins (NUPs), components of nuclear pore complexes (NPCs) that regulate transport
 of proteins and RNA across the nuclear envelope, are indispensable for cell function
 and are at the center of several human diseases. The MEL-28 protein in C. elegans
 (ELYS in vertebrates) is a NUP with numerous essential cell cycle functions that are
 conserved in humans, including a role in DNA replication licensing. Zebrafish Elys
 mutants are highly sensitized to treatment with DNA replication inhibitors such as
 Cisplatin, suggesting that MEL-28 could be used as a cancer therapy target. To test
 this hypothesis, we characterized a C. elegans mel-28 thermosensitive mutant strain
 and screened the Spectrum Collection small molecule library to identify chemicals
 that cause enhancement in a mel-28 sensitized background. We identified seven compounds
 that specifically enhance mel-28, some of which are known to affect microtubules.
 We then tested whether the selected compounds act in a synergistic way with Cisplatin
 in the mel-28(ts) and wildtype genetic backgrounds and observed synergism with three
 compounds specifically in the mel-28(ts) strain. Interestingly, one of them, Mitotane,
 is already used in combinatorial drug therapy with Cisplatin in patients with adrenal
 carcinoma, thus providing proof of concept for our experimental approach. Our results
 confirm MEL-28/ELYS as a candidate chemotherapy drug target, establish C. elegans
 mel-28 as a model for identifying new cancer drugs, and demonstrate that known chemicals
 could potentially be repurposed for combinatorial chemotherapy. Finally, we identified
 compounds not previously described to affect wild-type worms that could provide leads
 for new broad-spectrum anthelmintics.

Title: Crown-ether Calix[4]arene Porous Organic Polymer for Lithium Enrichment
Abstract:
Because of the premature depletion of lithium resources due to the extensive battery
 production, extracting it from various and uncommon resources is a vital need to maintain
 a growing industry of electric devices and vehicles. Here, we synthesized two crown
 ether calix[4]arene-based porous organic polymers, C-CX4P and CP-CX4P, and investigated
 their potential utility for the adsorption of lithium from water. C-CX4P shows a remarkable
 lithium uptake capacity of 941.69 mg g −1. In addition, both polymers exhibit specificity
 to lithium in the presence of competitive sodium ion in excess, such that a 0% removal
 of sodium is obtained for CP-CX4P. These preliminary results demonstrate the potential
 use of carefully designed porous organic polymers as a new generation of materials
 which can be used for lithium adsorption from various sources.

Title:
Spectroscopic study of the interactions between asphaltenes and prospective scale
                                 inhibitors in solution
Abstract:
Asphaltene precipitation, which leads to asphaltene deposition, has proven to be highly
 catastrophic for the oil industry. Scale inhibitors, chemical inhibitors which can
 prevent the formation of asphaltene deposits in oil wells and pipelines, are of particular
 interest. The scale inhibitors currently in use have low efficacy and several shortcomings,
 which increases the need to extend research into novel chemicals. In this study, we
 test various aromatic inhibitors with different functional moieties. Fluorescence
 studies and Hill analysis demonstrated that inhibitors X3 and Y3, which were surfactant-like
 with strongly acidic and electron-withdrawing moieties, showed the lowest dissociation
 constants (Kd) over time and across different sources of asphaltenes. These inhibitors
 showed the highest affinity to different types of asphaltene molecules and are, therefore,
 most likely to form complexes with asphaltenes, preventing them from further aggregating.
 Additionally, quartz crystal microbalance with dissipation (QCM-D) analysis revealed
 that inhibitor X3 was able to remove 70% of the adsorbed mass of asphaltenes from
 carbon steel, which mimics actual surfaces in oil wells and pipelines. The results
 indicate that aromatic inhibitors with acidic and electron-withdrawing moieties are
 good scale inhibitor candidates; they can be effective in interacting with asphaltenes
 and potentially preventing them from aggregating further.

Title:
Investigation of relationship between material properties and self-healing in crystals
                                 of boronic esters and disulfides
Abstract:
Degradation and loss of integrity are among the biggest shortcomings of materials
 that are exposed to mechanical impact. One of the possible solutions to confront this
 problem was the discovery of materials that are able to autonomously repair the damages,
 and recover their integrity. The developments in this area were, however, restricted
 to ceramics, as well as the soft-materials, such as polymers and hydrogels, and only
 a limited research was done in a solid state crystalline chemistry. In this project
 we aimed to examine the relationship between mechanical properties and the self-healing
 on the examples of selected boronic esters and disul-fides, the Young's modulus and
 stiffness were measured for selected crystals and the self-healing experiment was
 attempted. Var-ious issues such as hydrolysis, fracturing during manipulation and
 the solvent encapsulation within the crystal limited the assess-ment of self-healing
 for several crystals. From the Young modulus of the crystals that exhibited self-healing,
 we could observe that self-healing percentage is higher in softer crystals.

Title: Thermodynamic Characterization of HK3
Abstract:
Tumor cells utilize a high glycolytic flux known as the "Warburg effect" to sustain
 their high proliferation rates. The activation and further metabolism of glucose are
 initiated by hexokinase, a focal point of metabolic regulation. Hexokinase 2 (HK2)
 is significantly overexpressed in many cancer types and hence, it is a vital point
 in the development of inhibitors. The human hexokinase 3 (HK3) is not significantly
 overexpressed in tumors. However, biochemical differences in HK2 and HK3 could be
 exploited in improving the potency and specificity of current HK2 inhibitors. Here,
 we report the thermodynamic characterization of HK3. Experimental results reveal that
 both the melting temperature and calorimetric enthalpy change of wild-type HK3 are
 higher than for HK2. The identification of structural and biochemical differences
 between HK2 and HK3 could potentially be used in the development of new and more effective
 cancer therapies.

Title: Online Feedback Profiles for Digital Privacy Awareness
Abstract:
Major: Computer Science Abstract: The public is largely unaware that third-party trackers actively collect
 their data. In turn, the application of data mining and machine learning to utilize
 this data is largely a mystery to users without a background in information technology.
 This paper proposes the use of a built-in browser application that actively collects
 user data and renders it to create a privacy feedback profile to the user. The feedback
 page focuses on informing users that third parties can monitor their data, along with
 making inferences on the user so they're aware of how telling their data can be. In
 a weeklong study, users of the application showed increased levels of concern and
 awareness for their digital privacy. These results encourage the use of such applications
 as viable ways of educating individuals and encouraging safer online browsing habits.

Title: Displayer
Abstract:
Major: Computer ScienceAbstract: Many public spaces, including university campuses, have an abundance of
 public screens displaying information relevant to a particular site, such as upcoming
 events, student work showcases, general announcements, infographics and other relevant
 media. Displayer focuses on proposing and implementing an easy-to-use system that
 provides a front-end interface to create and schedule tasks that include but are not
 limited to displaying pictures, videos and slideshows. While many of such public screens
 focus on simply displaying information, the proposed system also allows for creating
 more interactive tasks, e.g. a video-portal between two displays. The project discusses
 a working implementation of such a system, while also outlining possible future extensions,
 e.g. connecting systems like the Microsoft Kinect to allow the creation of more complex
 tasks, such as signing up for events by showing a student ID. While the working implementation
 performs a variety of those simple tasks, the system's back-end is built around the
 idea of allowing future (possibly user-written) extensions.

Title: Reaching Out to You (in my own ways)
Abstract:
Reaching Out to You (in my own ways) is a multimedia art project comprised of three
 pieces of artwork that individually combine analog and digital ways of communication
 in order to prompt the viewers to think about how the level of engagement changes
 according to different ways of communication. The artworks introduce analog and digital
 interventions to explore the formation and interaction of human relationships and
 suggest new ways of communication by intertwining both methods together. This project
 provides spaces in which viewers can compare the analog and the digital methods used
 in each of the artworks in delivering the intended messages in the most genuine way.

Title: In Game Assistance Methods
Abstract:
One of the most important factors when it comes to making a multiplayer competitive
 game is ensuring that players are evenly matched. When skill differences are extreme,
 weaker players become frustrated and there is not enough of a challenge for the stronger
 player to stay engaged. Earlier papers on the topic establish that assisting weaker
 players works extremely well in reducing the score differences. In this paper we explored
 different types of assistance methods and specifically their effects on player enjoyment
 and perceived competence. Overall we see that assistance methods very significantly
 reduce the score disparity and affect several aspects of their gameplay experience.

Title: Sentiment Analysis in Tweets
Abstract:
This capstone project is about the detection of sentiment and stance in individual
 tweets. The task encompasses two subfields in Natural Language Processing: Sentiment
 Analysis and Stance Detection, both of which are related. The main objective is
 to use the Conditional Random Fields, the statistical modelling method, to build a
 system(s) that automatically determines from a tweet, with high efficiency, an author's
 general sentiment or sentiment towards a given target. Every iteration of the system
 is tested against a gold standard to gauge its efficiency. The reason for the use
 of CRFs is test how it fairs in non-sequential data classification tasks. The approach
 is feature-based, improved by optimized CRF parameters. A set of lexical feature combinations
 are tested and the top scoring feature combinations is tested again with sets of CRF
 parameter value combinations. The top scoring values, combined with the top scoring
 lexical features make up the system for dataset in question. The results show that
 CRFs perform well at non-sequential classification. Moreover, if sequential contexts
 are added to these tweets (i.e. tweets in a conversation thread), the efficiency of
 CRFs increases.

Title: Spatial Distortion Approach to Traffic Congestion Visualization
Abstract:
The field of traffic congestion visualization relies heavily on colorcoded topographical
 maps; little work has been done, however, to examine the merits and possible weaknesses
 of this approach, and to evaluate its performance in comparison to alternative visualizations.
 This paper presents a new approach to visualization of traffic congestion that uses
 spatial distortion instead of color to present traffic information in a fundamentally
 different manner. A user study was employed to empirically evaluate the ability of
 each of the two visualization approaches to influence the users' routing decisions
 in a given traffic network.

Title: Autofocus System for Cinematic Applications
Abstract:
Unlike video camcorders, phone cameras, point-and-shoot, and DSLRs, cameras and lenses
 used for cinema do not come with any autofocus capabilities. Instead, a dedicated
 person on a film set (the focus-puller) is in charge of manually measuring the distance
 from the camera to the subject and focusing the lens. Although this allows for complete
 artistic control over the focus, there are situations in which perfect focus is hard
 to achieve by focus-pullers (e.g. actors missing their positions, actors moving around
 within their positions) or a situation in which having a dedicated focus-puller is
 difficult (e.g. budgetary constrains, tight spaces). This project will attempt
 to design and create an autofocus system that will aid the focus-pullers to get the
 right focus through the use of software and hardware development. This intuitive system
 should be able to out perform inexperienced focus-pullers as well as making focus
 pulling easier for certain environments such as low contrast and dark locations. Our
 current prototype of the system is slow but relatively accurate and functional as
 an initial proof of concept.

Author(s): Abalo, Jacqueline; Andrew Callender, Cristhian Munoz, Jaehurn Nam, and Mark Surnin
Title: Structure Identification in PDF Documents
Abstract:
Up until the present day, there has not been a reliable, consistent, and easily available
 tool with which to identify and extract structural elements within documents. This
 is due to the fact that PDFs do not conform to any conventions in terms of document
 structure and that PDF generators tend to use different rules for assembling the documents.
 A solution that can allow users to retrieve structured information from a document
 in a form that is easily manipulated can have a noticeable positive impact for professionals
 across a broad spectrum of industries. The framework put forward in this paper, Texture,
 uses diverse heuristic techniques in order to extract structural elements (lists,
 titles, headers and footers, paragraphs, figures and tables) from PDFs. They are assigned
 different weights that lead to robust and accurate extractors. Texture also introduces
 a domain specific language that allows users to query documents using natural language.
 We demonstrate that Texture has potential to perform as well as the manual labeling
 process while being much easier to use than any labor crowdsourcing platform. Texture
 is also cheaper, quicker, and more scalable than hiring crowd workers to handle the
 same extraction tasks.

Author(s): Ahmad, Muaz; Dana Abu Ali, Hayat Al Hassan, Ming Hu, Paula Dozsa
Title: Time-offset Interaction Application
Abstract:
This paper presents a bilingual (Arabic-English) interactive human avatar dialogue
 system. The system is named TOIA (time-off set interaction application), as it simulates
 face-to-face conversations between humans and digital human avatars recorded in the
 past. TOIA is similar to a conversational agent, or chatbot, but differs in that it
 is based on an actual human being and can be used to preserve and tell stories. The
 system is designed to allow anybody, simply using a laptop, to create an avatar of
 themselves, thus facilitating cross-cultural and cross-generational sharing of narratives
 to wider audiences. It also supports cross-lingual dialogues in Arabic and English.

Title: Esfera: A Scalable peer-to-peer video broadcasting architecture overlaying WebRTC
Abstract:
Due to the increasing accessibility of the Internet, and live video streaming platforms
 like YouTube and Facebook, the demand for live video broadcasting is growing rapidly.
 Public figures, news channels, and sports event with followers numbered in millions
 receive up to a million views in their livestreams and the number is growing. The
 current broadcasting infrastructures rely on large and expensive networks of media
 servers and edge caches that are distributed around the globe to maintain network
 efficiency, quality, and reliability. In this paper, we present Esfera, a light-weight,
 scalable, peer-to-peer live video broadcasting infrastructure that utilizes the potentials
 of WebRTC, a set of APIs that allows ultra-low latency browser-to-browser communication
 without external plugins. Commercial platforms such as Facebook Messenger, and Google
 Hangouts have successfully tested and deployed their VoIP services on WebRTC, and
 broadcasting is the next milestone in the success of WebRTC. In this paper, we provide
 a detailed analysis of the design and implementation of Esfera and present an evaluation
 of its performance. Finally, we discuss the limitations and future challenges that
 are posed by peer-to-peer live broadcasting using WebRTC.

Title: Insulin Pump Vulnerabilities and Design for Secure Device Communication
Abstract:
Advanced health technology promises to bring considerable advances to patient care.
 However, there are great security risks which can have disastrous health consequences.
 Several studies show that implantable medical devices (IMDs) have vulnerabilities
 enabling man in the middle attacks that could disclose patient data or even inflict
 patient harm. Insulin delivery systems, which are commonly used IMDs, are vulnerable
 for this reason. All communication between the continuous glucose monitor (CGM) and
 the insulin pump is unencrypted, and protective PINs are passed in plain text. While
 there is existing research that documents this vulnerability and proposes solutions,
 these provide only suggestions for device modification that could be implemented by
 the manufacturer in future models. In this paper, we propose a design for a fully
 backwards compatible external device that ensures authenticity and integrity of communication
 between the CGM and the insulin pump. The design employs friendly jamming techniques
 to provide access control by jamming unauthenticated communication.

Title: On Problems Related to Epsilon-Nets
Abstract:
This capstone presents results on problems related to epsilon-nets in the plane; a
 method to approximate a set of data points with a small number of points. We contribute
 to the literature by improving the bounds for several simple cases. Speci cally, we
 obtain a tight lower bound of 2/3 on two-point strong epsilon-nets with respect to
 both halfspaces and disks closing two open problems in the literature. We also obtain
 tight bounds for all k-sided objects in the dual setting for nets of size 1, and a
 tight bound of 2/3 for nets of size 2 with respect to halfspaces. We show the two
 following elegant results: Given a set of points and a set of disks in the plane,
 if every three disks intersect in a common input point, then two of those points hit
 all disks; and, given a set of points and a set of halfspaces in the plane, if every
 three points belongs to a halfspace then two halfspaces cover all points.

Title: Epsilon-nets and related problems
Abstract:
Given a family of geometric objects S and a set of points P, we would like to prove
 that all objects in S that contain more than a certain fraction, epsilon, of points
 in P, can be hit by a small number of points in a set called the epsilon-net. By this
 we mean that if an object s in S contains more than a fraction epsilon of the points
 in P, then the object must also contain one or more of the points in the epsilon-net.
 In this capstone paper, we explore a variety of problems related to epsilon-nets.
 We improve the bounds on epsilon for disks and half-spaces when the epsilon-net contains
 2 points. We also improve the bounds for disks and half-spaces for dual epsilon-nets.
 There are two additional proofs we provide related to hitting sets. We prove that
 if every three points is contained in a half-plane, then two half-planes must cover
 all points. We also prove that if every three disks intersect at a point, then two
 points hit all disks.

Author(s): Chen, Wei Peter; Shehroze Khan, Jihyun Kim, Tarik Zulfikarpasic
Title: Qutr: A Cross-lingual Messenger with Keyword Searchable Phrases for the Travel Domain
Abstract:
We present Qutr (Query Translator), a smart cross-lingual communication application
 for the travel domain. It is a real-time messaging app that automatically translates
 conversations while supporting keyword-to-sentence matching. Qutr relies on querying
 a database that holds pre- translated phrases in different languages with the use
 of keywords. The application addresses common cross-lingual communication issues such
 as translation accuracy, speed, personalization and privacy.

Title: Classifying face representations with noise tolerant deep learning
Abstract:
Many massive sociological studies could be enabled by efficient machine learning on
 large scale online dataset. The main problem in the domain is that classification
 requires uniform data with accurate labels, but online collected image datasets cannot
 provide pose, illumination or resolution invariance and the assigned labels have a
 high error rate. We surveyed the current state-of-the-art methods in generating face
 representations from online datasets, and tested them with noise resistant machine
 learning architectures. We applied the findings on a dataset of 30 million images
 to aid research at Princeton University on racial discrimination in career progression
 in corporate structures. Our final architecture: From the input images we generate
 low level face representations using the Openface neural network to overcome the invariance
 in our dataset. These representations are then fed into a base neural network which
 has a denoising layer attached to it that attempts to correct the error in the labels.
 Our approach reached 0.79 f1-score on the FERET dataset. The novelty of the project
 is two-fold: it adds to our understanding of machine learning under noisy conditions,
 and proposes a computationally efficient approach to classify millions of faces.

Title: Reimagining Privacy in Online Social Networks
Abstract:
There has been growing interest in the field of longitudinal exposure of the user's
 publicly available data on social media platforms. While the privacy of current postings
 has been the subject of multiple research groups, the re-evaluation of the privacy
 settings for these posts down the line is a new area of interest for people. In regard
 to recent episodes such as the Facebook Cambridge Analytica scandal, discussions have
 revolved around the value we associate with the old postings. Whereas different platforms
 try to offer options to have some control over the accessibility of our information,
 their effectiveness relies on the extent to which users understand those options.
 Through this study, we aim to explore the relation between a user's perception of
 their profile privacy settings and their actual settings. Our study, based on the
 participant pool of 91, reports that there is a significant mismatch between the actual
 exposure to the posts versus the user's perception of the privacy settings. We also
 investigate the impact old postings can have on friend circle expansion. The findings
 show how the aged information, relevant or irrelevant, finds a way to influence the
 user's behavior in the current context.

Title: Detection and Analysis of Devices Used to Censor Networks
Abstract:
This capstone sought to better understand the state of censorship in the world today.
 By fingerprinting a BlueCoat ProxySG, scanning the internet for identifiers and analyzing
 current censorship data and statistics, the research found a presence of censorship
 devices in more than 65 countries. These devices are being used in a range of industries
 and institutions including telecommunications companies and governments. They are
 being used to censor different types of content, including political discussion, western
 news sources and social commentary. Additionally devices were found in nations under
 US sanctions that limit them from procuring such devices and raise questions about
 how such devices are being acquired.

Title: User Authentication for In-Flight Captive Portal Wireless Networks
Abstract:
The drastic increase in IEEE 802.11 compatible mobile devices in recent years has
 been complemented by a widespread adoption of public WLAN (PWLAN) infrastructure.
 Open PWLANs are now a standard part of the global Internet infrastructure and are
 becoming a standard in-flight amenity on many commercial airplanes. Public networks,
 including in-flight Wi-Fi hotspots, are typically implemented as open wireless hotspots
 with user authentication and connection control implemented via redirection of HTTP(S)
 traffic from unrecognized devices to a captive portal. In this paper, we describe
 an exploit in which captive portal networks are exposed to authentication bypassing
 by unauthorized, selfish clients. We then describe a spoofing detection and mitigation
 suite designed to protect PWLANs against this class of spoofing attacks. In the context
 of in-flight wireless networks, captive portal circumvention by unauthorized users
 is especially critical given the high latency, low bandwidth physical layer that this
 type of network relies upon. The ultimate goal of this paper is to outline the construction
 of a comprehensive spoofing attack defense mechanism.

Title:
Machine Learning technique for extraction of phase for the Indian monsoon intraseasonal
                                 oscillation (MISO)
Abstract:
Climate scientists use methods of decomposition of Outgoing Longwave Radiation (OLR)
 signal obtained through satellite imagery in terms of orthogonal basis functions which
 are determined from the data and find both time series and spatial patterns to construct
 Monsoon Intraseasonal Oscillation (MISO) phases. In this project, I attempted to
 train Outgoing Longwave Radiation (OLR) data without providing temporal information
 using standard Artificial Neural Networks, Convolution Neural Networks and Support
 Vector Machines. My attempts to train neural networks were unsuccessful. Having been
 able to predict MISO phases using Support Vector Machine by providing less information
 suggests that daily mean OLR data might have more MISO signal than previously thought
 and it suggests the possibility that we would be able to construct a long term time
 series of MISO phases using rain gauge data.

Title: Permanent Marker
Abstract:
Permanent Marker is a decentralized news application that employs the blockchain data
 structure as a building block for its security. Specifically, it employs the immutability
 and availability of the Bitcoin blockchain network as a way to create a platform that
 can share and access information in a way that cannot be altered or hindered by a
 single entity. Permanent Marker allows users to interact with the Bitcoin network
 directly, allowing individuals to upload their articles of varying lengths as well
 as read such articles through the blockchain. Permanent Marker has the functionality
 to create and share articles of upto 4.8 Mbs. It is expected that Permanent Marker
 will provide an effective platform against censorship, allowing users to freely share
 and access information without the concern that their articles will be modified or
 destroyed.

Title: Synner: The Design and Implementation of a Usable Data Generation Tool
Abstract:
Testing data analytics tools is crucial in order to avoid incurring the high cost
 of post-release bug fixing. Test data is also useful for demonstrating product features
 or for creating educational material. Since real data may be confidential or difficult
 to obtain and wrangle, engineers and researchers rely on synthetic data generators.
 Existing data generators may be platform or programming language specific, difficult
 to use, and may often generate unrealistic-looking data because they do not allow
 users to adequately customize inputs and generated data. We present Synner, a data
 generation tool which focuses primarily on usability. Synner allows users to sketch
 custom input data distributions and specify relationships or dependencies between
 fields. In the spreadsheet interface, users can select from a various data types,
 domains and functions and see a preview of records. Since ultimately data is generated
 probabilistically, it is imperative to communicate this uncertainty in probabilistic
 data generation to users. We perform a user study to determine visualization techniques
 to suitably communicate probabilistic uncertainty. We allow users to enter examples
 of data and generate data that matches these examples by inferring the type, distribution
 and proportion of the examples provided by the user.

Title: Combining Keystroke and Mouse Dynamics for Stronger and More Usable Authentication
Abstract:
Traditional approaches to strengthening authentication systems come in the form such
 as Multi-Factor authentication (MFA) schemes, One-Time-Passwords (OTP), new password
 policies, etc. Even though these measures tend to improve authentication methods in
 theory, they come at a huge cost in terms of usability and practical security. This
 project investigates and proposes a combined implementation of keystroke and mouse
 dynamics for increasing the usability of current authentication schemes by making
 authentication systems more intelligent and user-centric. Consequently, instead of
 blindly posing challenges to authenticators, our approach allows for the authentication
 system to make real-time decisions as to if there is a necessity for new challenges
 in the form of MFA or other forms of traditional approaches.

Author(s): Al Dhaheri, Ali Saif Gharib Salem
Title: Bulbul: An Online Application for Testing Arabic Dialect Knowledge
Abstract:
My project aims to educate native Arabic speakers as well as advanced non-native Arabic
 speakers on some of the basics of the numerous Arabic dialects through the use of
 a web application. The application will incorporate three main functionalities which
 are as follow: 1) Multiple Choice Questions and True/False Questions 2) Personal Accounts
 3) Point system. Users will be able to go through the questions where they will be
 tested on their ability to identify certain Arabic dialectal words and phrases. The
 multiple choice and true/false questions are automatically generated uniquely by the
 application. By registering and logging in, users may save their progress of the questions.
 Questions will have points based on users' attempts at answering them. Lastly, I hope
 to bring natives and non-natives together in better understanding the fluidity of
 the Arabic language as well as its dialectal ambiguity through the help of this web
 application.

Title: Empirical Comparison of Heuristics for the Discrete Disk Cover Problem
Abstract:
We empirically examine the performance of two heuristics that return an approximate
 solution to the discrete disk cover problem. Given a set of disks D of varying radii
 and a set of points P, we attempt to choose the subset of minimal cardinality D′ ∈
 D that covers all the points of P. We made two heuristics to test which we called
 the probability and random solvers. A third heuristic, called simple solver, is used
 to as a metric to examine how much the first two heuristics beat the fastest feasible
 solution. Finally, we also compare the results to that provided by the GNU Linear
 Programming Kit in order to see how close the heuristics came to what we consider
 the best possible solution. We find that the heuristics return solutions within one
 disk until the ILP reaches a threshold where calculation time is no longer feasible.

Title: Paper and digital data collection in New York: challenges and possible solutions
Abstract:
The digital revolution is happening today in every field, including the business,
 non-profit, and politics world. The same relates to the offline data collection. This
 research is to find the best solution to conduct offline data collection in the metropolitan
 area of New York City, as well as develop a mock product for it. This is based on
 the research that was conducted over the Summer 2018 through methods similar to those
 used in customer discovery, as well as the later findings in the appropriate literature.
 The participants that helped develop this final report were huge non-profit organizations,
 political organizers, and businesses. Based on the results a list of biggest disadvantages
 of current paper data collection was created. Many of them proved to be similar to
 researches carried out in the same filed in different places and organizations, which
 might indicate that they are universal. However, there were also specific cases that
 were characteristic of highly congested metropolitan areas. Based on the input and
 the results, a mock-up software was created to address the issues faced by these organizations.

Title: Inferring Evidence-Based Processes from Outcomes and History
Abstract:
In this paper, we propose a system for analyzing Intensive Care Unit (ICU) visits
 and thereby supporting the diagnosis and treatment of patients in ICU settings. The
 goal of the system is to infer recommendations for actions that medical staff should
 perform on a given patient. To achieve this, we find patients in similar conditions,
 and devise a number of strategies for recommending actions that should improve a patient's
 medical state. These recommendations are derived from the set of similar patients
 and a patient's most recent test results. Currently, our system is trained on data
 collected from ICU patients admitted for pneumonia. In the future, it can be extended
 to accommodate a variety of diseases. We compared our system against a random sampling
 of actions. Our highest-performing strategy yields a mean F-score of 0.417 after three
 days, outperforming the mean F-score of the random sampler by 0.150 (p-value 0.026).

Title: Gender Awareness and Modification in English-Arabic Machine Translation
Abstract:
The rapid development of Natural Language Processing (NLP) has increased awareness
 of some of the biases these systems have with regards to gender identities. Nearly
 half the world's languages are gender-dependent, yet current machine translation systems
 do not indicate the gender of the characters that appear in the translated phrases.
 This is largely due to the fact that they are built on gender ambiguous human-generated
 data which reflect social biases, as well as the fact that these systems are designed
 to give one output. Providing the system with access to user preferences is the ideal
 seamless solution; but giving the user clear alternatives to select from is a good
 alternative. We propose an approach to designing a gender-aware machine translation
 system through gender identification and gender translation that can be used together
 with any NLP application that generates text interfacing with users. We focus on English-Arabic
 sentence pairs in the first-person where the gender identity needs to be specified.
 We develop a first-of-its-kind gender-labeled corpus for training and evaluating first-person
 gender identification and gender translation.

Author(s): Diugan, Raluca-Georgia, Guyu Fan, and Xin Tong
Title: Timbre: A Decentralized Forum with Blockchain-based Distributed Data Store
Abstract:
Much of the public discourse today takes place online on social media platforms. However,
 these platforms are typically subject to censorship because centralized storage of
 user content allows for monopoly of moderation power. For example, posts on Facebook
 and tweets on Twitter may be removed at will by the service providers, and threads
 on Reddit may be locked or deleted by subreddit moderators. In response to this issue,
 we design and implement Timbre, a Blockchain-based distributed data storage system
 for decentralized online forums. In Timbre, forum content is distributed to different
 nodes, and a blockchain that records the complete history of user data storage and
 transactions for data retrieval is propagated across the peer-to-peer (P2P) network.
 Ultimately, we aim to provide an open and censorship-resistant system for public online
 discourse.

Title:
Understanding Money in the Digital Age: A Crypto-economic Investigation of Bitcoin
                                 Transaction Tips
Abstract:
This paper aims to contribute to the limited literature on Bitcoin tips to better
 understand what technological constraints and monetary properties drive them; this
 would potentially ameliorate regulatory decisions and design considerations for government
 sponsored cryptocurrencies. A two-stage linear regression is used to model the effect
 of the following drivers on Bitcoin transaction tips: mining difficulty, Bitcoin velocity,
 Bitcoin illiquidity using Amihud's illiquidity measure, block reward, exponentially
 weighted moving average volatility, and the estimated block size from the first-stage
 regression using WTI crude oil and natural gas futures prices as instruments. The
 instruments serve as a proxy for electricity costs to partial out the supply-side
 costs of mining. Statistically significant (at 95% confidence levels and higher) results
 show that transaction volume, velocity, and volatility have positive effects on Bitcoin
 transaction tips while mining difficulty and block reward have negative effects.

Title: The Effectiveness of Simple Hybrid Systems for Hypernym Discovery
Abstract:
Hypernymy modeling has largely been separated according to two paradigms, pattern-based
 and distributional methods. However, recent works utilizing a mix of these strategies
 have yielded state-of-the-art results. This paper evaluates the contribution of both
 paradigms to hybrid success by evaluating the benefits of hybrid treatment of baseline
 models from each paradigm. Even with a simple methodology for each individual system,
 utilizing a hybrid approach establishes new state-of-the-art results on two domain-specific
 hypernym discovery tasks and outperforms all non-hybrid approaches in a general hypernym
 discovery task.

Title: SateNet: Pixel-Level Segmentation of Satellite Images
Abstract:
Recent work in semantic segmentation has shown the effectiveness of context encoding
 in allowing neural networks to model spatial context for better performance. We set
 out to apply this development to the field of remote sensing. Our focus is to develop
 a new approach for semantic segmentation of Very High Resolution (VHR) images. This
 class of aerial images is often difficult to attain high quality semantic labels for,
 given the distinct challenges that come with images that have been remotely sensed
 via satellite or other aerial mechanisms. We make use of a lightweight architecture
 of convolutional neural networks, combined with context encoding to attain strong
 performance on the Vaihingen 2D semantic labeling competition. Our approach attains
 a competitive overall accuracy, as well as a strong classwise performance.

Title: GoodLiving: An Amenity- and Location-sensitive Cross-city Property Search Tool
Abstract:
GoodLiving (https://goodliving-beta.herokuapp.com/) is a system that supports new
 features for property search. GoodLiving specifically provides users the ability to
 find properties near places that they would like to visit (e.g. specific tourist destinations)
 or utilize (e.g. specific ethnic restaurants) and far from places they want to avoid
 (e.g. train stations). We built GoodLiving focusing both on creating an easy to use,
 simple and intuitive user experience, and on offering as many searchable attributes
 as possible. We then conducted a preliminary pilot user test, which despite being
 affected by imperfections in the prototype, showed great promise for GoodLiving and
 our proposed features (see complete data and scripts here), leading us to strongly
 recommend further work being done on developing GoodLiving and generally good location-based
 search parameters for property search. GoodLiving is open source (https://github.com/emilgoldsmith/GoodLiving)
 to allow further development.

Title: Emerge: a content creation and distribution application
Abstract:
The increased development and use of smartphone technology are contributing greatly
 to social empowerment and economic growth in emerging countries. However, despite
 this, smartphone users are still facing major challenges. Access to the internet in
 these regions suffers from slow load times, poor performances, and limited opportunities
 dedicated to local content creation and diffusion. Therefore, there is no chance for
 relevant information to be easily distributed. For my computer Science capstone project,
 I have developed an Android mobile application, known as EMERGE, to enable the diffusion
 of locally produced content in emerging countries. It has a series of templates that
 members can use to efficiently publish content in the form of articles. These articles
 are organized into several categories that help members easily find information that
 is most relevant to their interests. The application has been tested in three communities
 in Central Mexico: Juriquilla, La Barreta, and Colon. Through behavior analysis and
 a feedback survey, data has been gathered, processed, and presented in this paper.
 We believe that the results have been generally positive with people praising the
 features of EMERGE. Nonetheless, there have been several suggestions to improve the
 application, which will be implemented in the near future.

Title: Lifting Squares to Half-spaces: a Specific Case of Lifting Pseudo-disks
Abstract:
A half-space in R3 is either of the two parts separated by a plane. Because of some
 helpful properties that exist in half-spaces, it is often useful to map geometries
 in a plane to half-spaces in R3. We attempt to prove or disprove the existence of
 a mapping from a family of squares in a plane to a family of half-spaces in R3 such
 that all points inside each square are mapped to points inside the corresponding half-space
 and all points outside each square are mapped to points outside the corresponding
 half-space. If such a mapping can be shown to exist, we attempt to provide a mathematical
 description of it and an algorithm that performs the mapping.

Title:
Connected Home Devices: IoT Standardization Efforts to Advance Interoperability and
                                 Business Intelligence
Abstract:
QLM is a whole-of-life lifecycle management technique which leverages the ability
 of devices to connect to the Internet of Things to extend traditional PLM to include
 detailed information about device state and usage in each stage of the product life.
 This report identifies and compares the emerging technical standards of data collection
 and communication between connected home devices in the ever-growing Internet of Things
 to support broad adoption of standardization efforts by the manufacturers of such
 devices. The report highlights the importance of technical specifications and open
 standards in the IoT industry, reviews and analyzes existing formal standards and
 frameworks by The Open Group, bIoTope, NIST, and W3C. The report gives recommendations
 for the creation of cross-industry, cross-platform and cross-organizational services
 by fostering interoperability and openness between manufacturers and within product
 categories, as well as highlights areas for further improvement and optimization of
 the existing efforts. Ultimately this research will contribute to the ideation and
 development of a set of capabilities for extracting business knowledge from the information
 streams provided by the devices in the Internet of Things, adapting the PLM approach
 for the IoT context.

Title: Digital Forgetting with Audience Awareness
Abstract:
The content uploaded to social networks is only relevant for a limited amount of time.
 As a response to this, online Social Networks (OSNs) like Instagram and Snapchat have
 introduced features that allow user content to be deleted after a predetermined amount
 of time. However, this system is inflexible as it only provides one option for the
 amount of time a users content will be available online (24 hours). Other time-based
 revocation protocols have been proposed such as Neuralyzer which introduces the concept
 of flexible expiration times in which data is deleted based on different heuristics
 with one of them being drop of interest. None of these models account for the fact
 that users have different audiences in mind when they post content online, which can
 range from close friends and family to the general public depending on the occasion.
 The aim of this capstone project is to create a time-based revocation model based
 on the drop of interest heuristic presented by Neuralyzer but that is also aware of
 the intended audience of the users content.

Title: Supervised Segmentation of Electronic Dance Music
Abstract:
In this research, I provide a case study for the segmentation of Electronic Dance
 Music. First, the chroma feature is employed to obtain the harmonic content of a song.
 The information gained from the chroma feature is then used to construct the self-similarity
 matrix. Using the self-similarity matrix, the novelty curve is calculated. The data
 consist of fifty arbitrary chosen songs in the genres of Electronic Dance Music, including
 Big Room and Future House. For the sake of simplicity, all the songs have the beats
 per minute (bpm) of 128. The performance of the algorithm is determined by calculating
 its F1 score, and the implications of the research are discussed in the paper. Utilizing
 the algorithm, I created an interface for the DJs to efficiently make a playlist for
 their performance. The interface provides recommendations for the next song to play
 and when to mix. The recommendations are based on its bpm, energy level, and segment
 types. I believe that this will change the workflow of making the playlists for the
 DJs.

Title: Analyzing JavaScript in Modern Webpages Using Machine Learning
Abstract:
Javascript is the most popular web-based programming language and is also unfortunately
 a major reason why the performance of modern web pages has been deteriorating. My
 main objective is to create the most accurate and robust machine learning classifier
 for third party JS scripts that will be deployable on a client system that does not
 have many available computational as well as disk resources. I focus on tree-based
 algorithms and, in particular, on performance differences between top bagging and
 boosting ensemble classifiers. The abundance of JS scripts used for tracking, advertising,
 beautification, and unnecessarily heavy content in the form of images or videos, put
 a heavy burden on users that lack either computational or internet data resources.
 By accurately identifying such scripts, the classifier was then successfully deployed
 in a two web-simplification focused pieces of software.

Title: Identity vs
Abstract:
It has been shown that when playing against a bot opponent in the Prisoner's Dilemma,
 a human is less likely to cooperate than if they were playing against a fellow human.
 This behaviour is detrimental to the progress of Artificial Intelligence because if
 humans are unwilling to cooperate with autonomous agents due to bias, then the usefulness
 of such agents is severely diminished. In an original controlled experiment, we will
 utilize a four-player iterated version of the public goods game to determine the extent
 to which humans are willing to cooperate with another participant who is labelled
 as a bot and whether that cooperation (or lack thereof) is based on the label or the
 behaviour of the 'bot' participants. The results of this research has important implications
 for the fields of Artificial Intelligence and Human-Robot Interaction. Understanding
 humans' attitudes towards interacting with autonomous agents at a fundamental level
 would shape how such agents are designed and implemented in the future.

Title: Evaluation and Validation of an SQL Teaching Tool
Abstract:
The ability to write and understand data query languages is an essential skill for
 anyone that requires the use of databases, be it in an academic or commercial context.
 However, learning SQL has been identified as posing a number of difficulties to beginners.
 This project aims to design, prototype, test, and validate an SQL teaching tool and
 interface. Specifically, we aim to articulate a set of features extrapolated from
 the needs and challenges of the broader space that achieve an improved pedagogical
 efficacy. After an evaluation of the existing landscape, we present an interface that
 provides a visualization of query processing and allows users to view intermediate
 results at each step.

Title: Building Ideology Language Models Using Twitter Network Data
Abstract:
Past research on political ideology of text has typically used supervised machine
 learning, where the training data must first be labelled by human coders or according
 to its source. This data collection process may incorporate its own subjectivity and
 bias and is not easily scalable or generalisable. In this paper I build an unsupervised
 language model which uses social media data to learn to identify the ideology of text.
 I find that it is possible to rely on Twitter networks to build language models, and
 identify challenges with interpreting such models and utilizing them for diverse applications.

Title: Comparing Random Forest and Linear Regression Models in Predicting Housing Sales Prices
Abstract:
This paper investigates the research question: can a random forest outperform a linear
 regression model for cross-sectional and time-series data partitioning in a 10-year
 random sample of San Francisco housing sales? The data-set is engineered, selected,
 and encoded producing optimized data-sets for each model. The key metrics: r-squared,
 RMSE, MAE, and mean error are then estimated for both time-series and cross-sectional
 data using 5-fold cross-validation. The metrics indicate that random forests outperform
 linear regression for both data approaches and that cross-sectional outperforms time-series
 data partitioning approaches. The learning curves, feature importance, and normalized
