 regression coefficients from both models prove that random forest models better estimate
 complexities in the housing sales function and identify important features. The paper
 aims to convince the reader that random forest models are more flexible, can capture
 more complex relationships between variables, and thus perform better in predicting
 future sale prices and cross-sectional home values.

Title: Reducing Client-Side JavaScript Evaluation with JSAnalyze
Abstract:
JavaScript evaluation is one of the most costly and time-consuming parts of loading
 a web page. This project introduces a tool called JSAnalyze which automatically analyzes
 a web page to determine what JavaScript can be removed without impacting the user
 experience. JSAnalyze allows users to better understand the scripts present in their
 webpages and verify or alter the script removal choices made by the tool before saving
 the simplified page to an external proxy for future retrieval. Analyzing 100 popular
 web pages using JSAnalyze showed a reduction in overall Page LoadTime of more than
 30% on mobile devices while retaining more than 90% of the original page content,
 as evaluated by a user study of 22 users.

Title: An Online Arabic Readability Leveled Thesaurus
Abstract:
In this project, we developed the first ever readability leveled Arabic thesaurus
 interface. The effort built on and connected two existing resources: (a) AWN (the
 Arabic WordNet) [2] which provided synonymy information and alternative phrasings,
 and (b) the Standard Arabic Morphological Analyzer [4] which allows us to abstract
 from inflected forms of Arabic words to their possible dictionary entry forms. Moreover,
 we supported the building of a third necessary component: a readability-labeled lexicon
 for the dictionary entries. Finally, we designed and implemented a public online interface
 to navigate our database. A user can also choose to search our database by Arabic
 words, Arabic lemmas in our standard representation, Arabic roots or English glosses.
 The interface provides information on part of speech, root, English gloss, a readability
 rating on a five-level readability scale and a list of synonyms. This database and
 interface are made as part of the NYUAD funded project SAMER (Simplification of Arabic
 Masterpieces for Extensive Reading) where it is intended to aid scholars who are tasked
 with simplifying Arabic literature to reach a wider audience with varying Arabic abilities.
 However, we believe that this interface will benefit anyone with an Arabic writing
 task.

Title: SynnerDB: A Scalable Database System for Synthetic Data Generation
Abstract:
Synner is a synthetic data generator, developed to meet the rising demand in high
 quality data, which are scarcely available in public. Under current Synner's capacity,
 sophisticated datasets can be produced realistically in a simple manner. However,
 Synner stores data by row, which may bring question in its scalability performances,
 especially when users want to produce big data. Big data is particularly scarce making
 it difficult for students to test the machine learning techniques they learned outside
 of a classroom, let alone initiate their own projects. Additionally, startups can
 also face difficulty to test their products due to the lack of large datasets that
 are specific to their business. While Synner's current engine allows these two groups
 to produce realistic data that meet their circumstances, due to Synner's row-oriented
 storage, producing terabytes of data can raise data generation speed issues. In this
 paper, we further improve Synner's function by adding more tools and specifications
 for users to generate sophisticated dataset, and also improve Synner's scalability
 by integrating a column-oriented DBMS, MonetDB.

Title: Wireguard: An Efficient Solution for Securing IoT Device Connectivity?
Abstract:
With the increasing number of automated and manual cyber-attacks in recent years due
 to the growing number of devices connected to the Internet, the introduction and then
 the rapid adoption of the Internet of Things (IoT) like smart home devices have further
 increased pertinent risks. Virtual Private Networks (VPNs) are usually used to protect
 from classical MITM and other attacks. However, for weak and low resource IoTs like
 a smart thermometer connected to the Internet, using a VPN is often rendered impractical
 by the overhead it adds. In this project, we consider different ideas put forward
 to solve this problem, discuss their drawbacks, and show that a new VPN called Wireguard
 drastically reduces the attack surface for hackers in comparison to other popular
 solutions, and also provides a compelling reason to be used as the solution. It will
 provide them with reliable security that usually only more powerful machines benefit
 from. In this paper, we have tested Wireguard in the context of weak devices that
 mimic IoT devices and derive promising results in terms of performance.

Title:
Simplifying the Web: Optimized Network Architecture and User Interface for improved
                                 Internet access in Developing Regions
Abstract:
The Internet has grown exponentially since its inception. To support this growth the
 developed world has deployed high-speed networks that compensate for the Internet's
 complexity. This leaves developing regions with a sub-par and cost-prohibitive Internet
 experience, as most users access the Internet through mobile data. We provide an optimized
 Network Architecture and User Interface for developing regions. Our research focuses
 on deploying Man-In-The-Middle (MITM) Proxies on Edge Caches that are close to the
 users and store cached pages, which are optimized through our JavaScript simplification
 software. We also provide a light-weight User Interface that allows users to search
 our database of cached pages through relevant keywords, thanks to our word-ranking
 algorithm. Our Results showed our solution provided significant improvements in (PLT),
 Page Size, and Number of Requests.

Title: Quantifying Editors' Role in Academic Publication
Abstract:
As the most important metric for scientific impact, citation is as valuable for journals
 as it is for scientists. To be published in a more prestigious journal means that
 a paper is likely to receive more citations, and to publish potentially impactful
 papers will in return boost the reputation of a journal. The fate of a paper is determined
 in the peer review process, where editors play a critical role. However, due to the
 lack of comprehensive data regarding journal editors, there has been little quantitative
 research dedicated to them. This research studies editors from about 2000 Elsevier
 journals, and uncovers patterns of interaction between scientists, journals, and editors.
 We generated a first-of-its-kind temporal dataset of editorial board members, and
 showed that being an editor positively affects a scientist's impact but negatively
 affects one's productivity.

Title: Policy optimization to control epidemics
Abstract:
We present an epidemic management framework that combines an epidemic model with reinforcement
 learning. This framework focuses on the interaction between the epidemic and a decider
 who uses tools (vaccines, isolation etc) to counter the epidemic. We demonstrate the
 reproducibility and capability of this framework in designing flexible public health
 interventions as well as how to train the decider to control the epidemic. Finally,
 we apply the framework to show qualitative results that support: Aggressive travel
 restriction and social distancing strategies help to delay and lower the peak in an
 epidemic, Early action matters a lot more than late action, Contact tracing plays
 an important role in controlling the epidemic.

Title: An Empirical Comparison of Code Similarity Algorithms
Abstract:
As the usage of JavaScript libraries becomes more prevalent, so does the adoption
 of bad and careless practices, such as including multiple versions of the same library
 within the same document. These bad practices negatively impact the page load times
 (PLTs) of the web pages. Thus, an intuitive way of reducing page load times is removing
 these duplicate scripts. There are four main categories of duplicate detection techniques:
 metric-based techniques, token sequence-based techniques, tree-based techniques and
 PDG-based techniques. However, PDG-based and metric-based techniques have already
 been proven to be costly and not very accurate, respectively. Thus, suitable candidate
 algorithms must be found within the realm of tree-based and token-sequence based techniques.
 In this paper, three algorithms are explored: two token- sequence based algorithms
 and one tree-based algorithm. These algorithms are compared and evaluated to find
 the best algorithm for use in a light-weight tool meant to help reduce page load times
 by cutting out unnecessary JavaScript.

Title:
The effect of air-pollution and Republican vote share on police performance and racial
                                 bias
Abstract:
Extensive research has been conducted on the topic of racial bias in policing, ranging
 from traditional surveys to large-scale data analysis. This existing research largely
 focuses on evaluating police behavior towards minority groups while controlling for
 socioeconomic factors such as neighborhood characteristics, vehicle type, poverty
 rate, and income level. Our research takes a less traditional approach in evaluating
 human behavior and racial bias by evaluating how police performance is affected by
 environmental factors such as air pollution and temperature. We show that higher temperatures
 and lower air quality are associated with higher efficiency rates among police officers.
 Our findings further suggest that these environmental conditions may also be associated
 with increased bias rates towards Blacks. We then explore the link between the proportion
 of votes for a Republican president against police performance and bias. We find that
 increased proportions of voters in support of a Republican candidate are associated
 with superior police performance. Nevertheless, we find no evidence suggesting that
 increased vote share in favor of a Republican president is associated with discriminatory
 behavior by the police.

Title: AutoTag: Metadata Automation for Film Post-Production
Abstract:
Film post-production can be time- and money-inefficient. A lot of the work involves
 a person or group of people, called metadata taggers, going through each individual
 piece of media and marking it up with the relevant tags, such as the scene number,
 transcripts, and the type of shot for video footage. Such a task is particularly time-consuming
 for films with high shooting ratios (i.e., footage shot/footage shown). The average
 high production movie has a shooting ratio between 100:1 and 1000:1. A metadata tagger's
 task is to watch all of these media and tag it. Assuming the most popular runtime
 of a movie, 101 minutes, and a conservative shooting ratio of 100, the time it would
 take for a single person to achieve this task is 168 hours, without even taking into
 account the audio recording associated with each piece of video. This is at least
 21 days of a person working full-time, both delaying the post-production process significantly
 and placing a significant burden on independent filmmakers who often have a small
 budget. AutoTag automates much of the tagging process, saving both time and money.
 We describe the algorithms and implementation of AutoTag and report on some case studies.

Title: Arabizi-to-Arabic Transliteration using Sequence-to-Sequence Models
Abstract:
While online Arabic is primarily written using the Arabic script, a common Roman-script
 variant called Arabizi is often seen on social media. Although this representation
 captures the phonology of the language, it is not a 1-to-1 mapping with the Arabic
 script version. Due to the different sound-to-letter rules of English and Arabic,
 there are complex mappings between the two writing systems. This issue is exacerbated
 by the fact that Arabizi on social media is Dialectal Arabic which does not have a
 standard orthography. Moreover, many people writing Arabizi are bilinguals, so they
 code switch between Arabic and a foreign language such as English in the same sentence.
 To map Arabizi text to Arabic script in the context of complete sentences or utterances,
 previous published works have utilized finite state machines, n-gram language models
 and morphological analyzers. In this project, we present a sequence-to-sequence deep
 learning model for the task. We employ a large dataset of Egyptian Arabizi words that
 have been transliterated to the Arabic script. Our best model beats the best previously
 reported results in this task.

Author(s): Shibly, Maahir UR Rahman Mohamed, and Mingyang Wang
Title: Timbre: A Censorship-resilient Online Platform
Abstract:
A large and growing part of our public discourse is taking place over online platforms.
 These platforms create a bottleneck to freedom of speech as a consequence of censorship
 policies imposed by corporations, governments, and private entities. While the ability
 to moderate content is pertinent, today's centralized platforms allow content to be
 removed by platform owners and moderators without real recourse or accountability.Timbre
 is a distributed decentralized discussion forum that aims to preserve freedom of speech
 while allowing 'moderation', all the while preventing itself from being re-centralized
 by adversaries.Timbre strikes a balance between freedom of speech and moderation by
 allowing all content to be posted and by decentralizing censorship power. A Timbre
 forum is indexed by a blockchain while the content itself is stored separately by
 distributed data stores. Moderation is implemented as published streams that users
 can selectively apply as filters onto raw forum content. Timbre prevents blockchain
 re-centralization and 'buy-outs' through the use of a proof-of-stake consensus algorithm
 in conjunction with periodic epochs that essentially enable us to reset any form of
 power centralization that may occur over the course of the epoch.

Title: Ensemble AutoDecoder CompNets for 3D Point Cloud Pair Encoding and Classification
Abstract:
Since the inception of LeNet5, Yan LeCun's first Convolutional Neural Network for
 handwritten digit-recognition in 1998, Neural Networks have come a long way in classifying
 2D images and extracting their features. However, since we live in a 3D world, it
 is natural to ask if we can classify 3D shapes and extract their shape descriptors.
 This turns out to be rather difficult given the exponential increase in complexity
 with the added third dimension. To perform this classification efficiently, we propose
 an ensembled encoderless-decoder and classifier neural network to learn the latent
 encoding vectors for 3D point-cloud pair transformations. This ensemble extracts the
 feature descriptors of the transformations without a parametric encoder or a lossy
 2D projection. We also empirically demonstrate the effectiveness of our ensemble model
 through a benchmark comparison on a 3D point cloud classification task for the PointNet
 and ModelNet dataset. Finally, we discuss the applicability of our 3D shape descriptor
 learners and classifiers as preprocessing techniques for eventual 3D object classification,
 segmentation, and database retrieval tasks.

Title: Bounding Neural Mutual Information Estimates via Additive Noise
Abstract:
We study the problem of estimating mutual information (MI) between a data distribution
 and the pushforward distribution induced by a differentiable black-box transformation.
 We show that, despite that the problem is ill-defined for deterministic transformations,
 the straightforward change of introducing additive noise not only fixes said issue,
 but also enables both neural and parameter-free MI estimates that sandwich MI by bounding
 it above and below. We propose novel neural MI upper bounds that this change enables,
 and to use them in conjunction with existing neural MI lower bounds in order to strengthen
 evaluations of MI estimates across the literature. Studying these different neural
 MI estimators and their accuracy under fixed neural architectures and datasets, we
 highlight their necessity as parameter-free methods struggle to scale to high dimensions
 and high MI settings. We also showcase a simple study of MI maximization and how our
 methodology can be used to measure the mutual information achieved by different unsupervised
 learning methods.

Title: EPDNet: Encoder-less 3D Shape Descriptor Extraction
Abstract:
Existing 3D shape descriptor extraction methods based on neural network encoders have
 not been able to replicate the same success of its 2D counterpart, due to the increased
 time-space complexity brought by the extra dimension and the unstructured nature of
 point cloud data. To tackle this challenge, we propose EPDNet (Encoder-less Point
 Drift Net), a novel formulation based on auto-decoder networks that allows us to extract
 joint shape descriptors of 3D point cloud shape pairs without needing an encoder network,
 by directly optimizing latent shape descriptors for the self-supervised coherent point
 drift task. We show that by using this formulation, we can bypass the difficulty of
 designing encoders for 3D data and directly obtain informative shape descriptor vectors
 that capture the relationship between a pair of 3D shapes. We further demonstrate
 the effectiveness of our method by applying the extracted shape descriptors in other
 computer vision tasks such as classification.

Title: Detecting and Preventing GPS Spoofing Attacks in Vehicular Networks
Abstract:
In this paper, we investigate possible attacks on civilian GPS systems and focus on
 spoofing attacks. In light of existing research, we chose to focus on spoofing attacks
 on GPS-dependent vehicular networks. Building upon previous GPS error modelling, we
 propose an extension to existing error models that would allow for groups of vehicles
 in motion to coordinate and detect spoofing attacks against individual members of
 the group, requiring as little as two independent vehicles, subject to constraints
 related to their individual and relative velocities, achieved via analytical modelling
 and verified with a simulation.

Title:
Murjan: A Web Platform for Monitoring & Predicting Coral Bleaching Events in the Arabian/Persian
                                 Gulf
Abstract:
Corals exist in substantial numbers in the Arabian Gulf due to its shallow nature.
 However, because of climate change and a rise in sea temperatures, the number of coral
 bleaching events has drastically increased. Corals in the Arabian Gulf are most susceptible
 to bleaching because of the shallow conditions of the Gulf - rendering it difficult
 for corals to mix with deeper, cooler waters. While climate change is the main culprit
 of coral bleaching, other reasons include dredging and land reclamation, practices
 that are common in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) due to the rapid development. As
 such, corals, especially those that are close to the coast, are at high risk of bleaching
 and possibly, mortality. To decrease stress on corals, we propose a web platform,
 Murjan, that will use seasonal weather forecasts and a water-column model, the General
 Ocean Turbulence Model (GOTM), to assess and predict the likelihood of coral bleaching
 in advance by producing forecasts of sea-bottom temperatures and other relevant variables.
 Murjan would enable its audience, one of which is government agencies, to suspend
 construction work when the likelihood of coral bleaching is shown to be high.

Title: Improving Traffic by Exploiting Autonomous Vehicles
Abstract:
Congestion can easily be induced by any bottlenecks on road, including lane closures
 and on-ramp merging sections. When enough aggressive drivers do not give way to merging
 vehicles, the length of traffic further increases and through put decreases leading
 to a longer travel time. For this reason, we propose exploiting the advanced radar
 technology of autonomous vehicles in order to record and punish aggressive drivers
 who are not giving way in order to push them to give way.

Title: Terrorist Activity Correlated Indicator Tracker (T
Abstract:
Over the past decade, terrorists killed an average of 21,000 people each year. Since
 then, the United States of America alone has spent 2.8 trillion dollars on counter-terrorism
 efforts. Although these efforts have curbed several uprisings of major terrorist organizations,
 preemptively predicting acts of terrorism with much detail has continued to prove
 exceedingly difficult over the years. The reasons behind the struggles of law enforcement
 and counter-terrorism agencies across the globe is the lack of clarity behind deep
 terrorist motivations and the lack of access to historical and real time data on terrorism.
 We used meticulously analyzed, clustered, and classified historical global governance
 and terrorism data to formulate models that highlight key indicators that had significant
 correlations to past spikes in terrorist activity. Once we identified such indicators
 and established a pattern, we displayed the results on an interactive web application.
 As such, this project has three main deliverables: a synthesized dataset tracking
 thousands of different global indicators arranged in an intuitive 2-axes format, a
 terrorism activity prediction model generated using a Least Absolute Shrinkage and
 Selection Operator on the dataset, and a web platform that enables users to visualize
 and extract data.

Title: Developing a Post Processing System to Improve Arabic OCR
Abstract:
Arabic Optical Character Recognition (OCR) remains a challenging problem due to the
 cursive nature of the language, and contemporary Arabic OCR systems struggle to achieve
 high word accuracy rates. In our capstone, we created a novel post-processing system
 that works on the output of a pre-existing OCR system and reduces the word error rate
 (WER) from 46\% to 13\%, producing state of the art results. The system utilizes an
 n-gram based letter disambiguation technique to fix the issue of word segmentation
 and letter substitution in Arabic OCR. Unlike other hybrid methods, our system relies
 on little to no human intervention.

Author(s): Bendevski, Filip, Jumana Ibrahim and Tina Krulec
Title: Predicting Narrative Coherence
Abstract:
Stories people tell about themselves and how they recall their experiences reveal
 a lot about who they are and their mental well-being. Psychologists have identified
 this and created the Narrative Coherence Coding Scheme (NaCCS); a set of guidelines
 for annotating the "coherence" of a narrative in terms of its theme, chronology and
 context. Upon annotating narratives in accordance with the NaCCS, psychologists have
 found a significant correlation between the coherence score of a narrative and independently
 collected mental health markers of the narrator. Currently, all anno-tation for coherence
 is done manually; a time-consuming task, which drains vital resources that could have
 otherwise been spent elsewhere. Our Capstone project aims to make use of natural language
 processing (NLP) and machine learning (ML) techniques to directly predict a narrative's
 coherence score. We explore a number of different techniques for this task, ranging
 from traditional machine learning models such as Support Vector Machines (SVM) to
 pre-trained language models such as BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from
 Transformers).

Title: Spottr: A parallel shot boundary detection tool for audio post-production
Abstract:
The audio post-production industry is constantly evolving, yet its workflows remain
 outdated. The process of spotting is one of them, requiring repetitive, manual, and
 time-consuming work for an automatable procedure. This project presents a tool prototype
 that automates this process by procedurally detecting shot boundaries on a given video
 file, storing each exact boundary location, and exporting them into an AAF file, which
 allows these markers to be imported by Pro Tools, or any other DAW or video editing
 software intended for post-production. A dual-stage shot boundary detection (SBD)
 algorithm [3] for abrupt and gradual changes was implemented and refined to further
 improve accuracy. Parallel computing techniques were used to boost performance by
 creating an enhanced parallel version for multi-core processors with OpenMP.

Title: Extending the Dollar Auction: The Power of Artificial Intelligence in Shaping Conflict
Abstract:
The aim of this capstone project is to investigate the extent to which Artificial
 Intelligence can shape conflicts. The topic is of high importance because besides
 filling in a gap in literature, it allows us to model how the outcome of conflicts
 will be affected if a state acquires the ability to automate decision making when
 facing other states. Based on Martin Shubik's Dollar Auction and previous related
 work, we look into how humans' decision-making process changes when their opponent
 is an algorithm, and not another human being. Moreover, we control for the levels
 of spitefulness in both humans and bots. Our results give insight into which experimental
 condition incentives players to stick to the optimal strategy, which players win more
 often and how they feel towards their opponent.

Title: Building a Pipeline to Decode Mental States from Cortical Activity
Abstract:
This project built a pipeline to decode perceptual states from neural activity in
 the human brain's visual system. An uncertainty-based inverted encoding model (TAFKAP)
 was trained on the brain's processed BOLD response to different stimuli, measured
 through MRI. The project relied on a dataset where subjects observed dot clouds moving
 in different directions in the horizontal (xz) plane while their brain activity was
 measured. Using a new algorithm TAFKAP, the brain was modeled through uncertainty-based
 methods that could capture these correlations. While uncertainty-based decoding techniques
 have been used before, they have predominantly been applied to 2D orientation (rather
 than 3D motion). Neurons responsive to retinal orientation exist at an early stage
 of the visual hierarchy and as such are thought to be easier to decode, whereas 3D
 motion sensitive neurons are thought to exist later in the visual hierarchy and are
 therefore more difficult to decode. This project found that 3D motion could be successfully
 decoded from several ROIs (regions of interest like V1, V2, hMT, IPS) at an accuracy
 of greater than 50% (baseline chance at 12.5%).

Title:
Hide and seek! Browser Fingerprinting Data Set Deanonymization via Feature Set Optimization-Based
                                 Linkage Attacks
Abstract:
Web providers today can track users with or without their permission using stateless
 fingerprint tracking. This method works by obtaining a combination of browser attributes
 (or features) from the browsing environment of the user and producing a fingerprint
 ID. The fingerprint ID is subject to change as attribute(s) in the system are updated.
 Pugliese et al. [7] conducted a three-year long study that resulted in the collection
 and analysis of fingerprints. This paper proposes the first entropy analysis done
 on the data set consisting of 37,762 fingerprints and 854 users (a subset of the entire
 data set from Pugliese) which helped identify key attributes and combinations of attributes
 that help with user deanonymization. Among the deanonymization attack methods we propose,
 we present the results of one such attack. Our dynamic deanonymization attack algorithm
 produced 86.2% accuracy in matching anonymized fingerprints with just 25 of the total
 available 216 attributes that were selected based on the entropy analysis. Identifying
 the specific attributes that require more protection [3] would aid in the mission
 of ensuring web privacy and serves as a starting point for privacy policy development
 that is integrated into the browser environment.

Title: Approximations for Covering in a Streaming Setting, Covering with Orthants
Abstract:
We present approximations schemes for local variations on the unit disc covering problem
 in a streaming setting. We give a 2-approximation algorithm to find a hitting set
 of size 2 when there exists a hitting set of size 1 for the half-space variation.
 After that, we give a 1.5-approximation algorithm for the dual problem of the interval
 covering problem when the solutions size is 2. For the lower bound, we show a 1.5
 lower bound for the square variation and a 2 lower bound for the half-space variation.
 For covering with orthants, we first give a construction method to solve the uniform
 single connection with one type of orthant problem. We then show that using only one
 type of orthant is equivalent to the planar graph. Furthermore, we worked towards
 showing arbitrarily large size cliques cannot be made using exactly zero and one intermediary
 points.

Title: Data Analytics and Visualisation of Terrorism Data Using Self-Organizing Maps
Abstract:
This project attempts a new search for a terrorist profile taking into consideration
 two of the main limitations in previous research: the lack of primary data and limited
 quantitative techniques. To solve the lack of primary data, two databases are used
 in this project: 1) Terrorists Survey Database (TSD): A database made by surveying
 more than 12,000 terrorists in Sri Lanka gathered by Professor Jocelyn Belanger 2)
 Global Terrorism Database (GTD): a database that contains information about terrorist
 activities from 1970 until 2019, prepared by The National Consortium for the Study
 of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START). To solve the limitation of the quantitative
 techniques, a powerful deep learning technique called Self-Organizing Maps (SOM) is
 used to analyze both databases. SOM is a type of Artificial Neural Network that uses
 competitive learning to create low-dimensional views of high-dimensional datasets.
 The current results show interesting correlations that lead to potential hypotheses
 about terrorism. Furthermore, the clusters created by SOMs contain characteristic
 features that are potential candidates for the terrorist profile. The implication
 and meaning of the current results will be studied during the psychological evaluation
 of the results.

Title:
Imagined Communities in Multilingual Wikipedia: Evaluating Theories of Ethnic Nationalism
                                 with Geographic and National Data
Abstract:
We argue that in addition to the traditional definitions of bias, there are other,
 more subtle forms of bias that exist within articles about the same people written
 in different languages and we use the terms "crowd" or "community" bias to label this
 phenomenon. This research has employed a combination of structured information from
 Wikidata and information extraction from Wikipedia entries using spaCy pipelines in
 Python in order to assess nationality appropriation in knowledge-sharing communities,
 corresponding roughly to what is known as the historical phenomenon of "Polonization".
 Using subsets of the data acquired from English, German and Polish Wikipedia we use
 geo-visualization of birth and death places of famous people as well as birth and
 death dates and their declared nationality as a way of evaluating to what extent language
 communities produce "imagined communities" within Wikipedia. Our method builds on
 a literature regarding bias in Wikipedia, but instead of linguistic markers of bias,
 we look to a combination of nationality markers derived from part-of-speech analysis
 and geographic information.

Title:
A Computer Vision Based Tool to Evaluate Structural and Functional Comparison between
                                 Webpages
Abstract:
The increasing complexity of web pages has attracted a number of solutions to offer
 simpler versions of these pages. These solutions have been quantitatively evaluated
 to show significant speed-ups in page load times, bandwidth and memory consumption.
 However, what these solutions fail to evaluate is the qualitative impact on their
 generated pages. Additionally, due to the lack of a unified qualitative metric, it
 is nearly impossible to fairly compare results obtained from different user studies
 campaigns. This capstone demonstrates the lack of qualitative evaluation metrics,
 and propose QLUE (QuaLitative Uniform Evaluation), a tool that automates the qualitative
 evaluation of web pages using computer vision. Our results show that QLUE computes
 comparable content and functional similarity scores to those provided by human evaluators.
 Specifically, for 90% of 100 pages, the human evaluators gave content similarity scores
 between 90% and 100%, while QLUE shows the same range of similarity scores for more
 than 75% of the pages.

Author(s): Hensley, Tyeece Kiana Fredorcia and Wahib Kamran
Title: TOIA 2
Abstract:
Time-offset interaction applications (TOIA) allow simulating conversations with people
 who have previously recorded relevant video utterances, which are played in response
 to their interacting user. TOIAs have great potential for preserving cross-generational
 and cross-cultural histories, online teaching, simulated interviews, etc. Current
 TOIAs exist in niche contexts involving high production costs. Democratizing TOIA
 presents different challenges when creating appropriate pre-recordings, designing
 different user stories, and creating simple online interfaces for experimentation.
 We open-source TOIA 2.0, a user-centered time-offset interaction application, and
 make it available for everyone who wants to interact with people's pre-recordings,
 or create their pre-recordings.

Title: Refusing Predictions to Enhance Accuracy
Abstract:
This Capstone project implemented the idea of using refusals to enhance accuracy using
 the meta-algorithm for online learning. SafePredict provides probabilistic asymptotic
 bounds on error rates. As part of the Capstone, I implemented a complete software
 package compatible for inclusion in the popular Python machine learning library scikit-learn.
 The advantage of using SafePredict has been demonstrated using this scikit-learn implementation
 for different online learning scenarios. A brief example using the MNIST digit recognition
 dataset is shown to provide an intuitive understanding of the refusal mechanism of
 SafePredict. This example also shows how the scikit-learn implementation can be used
 out-of-the-box for a simple application. A similar example with a changing data distribution
 using the cod-rna dataset demonstrates SafePredict limiting the error rate of accepted
 predictions despite the base estimator having an unbounded error rate due to a change
 in the data distribution. An example forecasting the returns of publicly traded companies
 from the OEX-100 is used to shown how the package can be extended for more advanced
 applications and the advantages of using SafePredict through an intuitive measure
 of an average profit gain of 37 percent for a trading strategy across 97 companies.

Title: Developing a Post Processing System to Improve Arabic OCR
Abstract:
Arabic Optical Character Recognition (OCR) remains a challenging problem due to the
 cursive nature of the language, and contemporary Arabic OCR systems struggle to achieve
 high word accuracy rates. In our capstone, we created a novel post-processing system
 that works on the output of a pre-existing OCR system and reduces the word error rate
 (WER) from 46% to 13%, producing state of the art results. The system utilizes an
 n-gram based letter disambiguation technique to fix the issue of word segmentation
 and letter substitution in Arabic OCR. Unlike other hybrid methods, our system relies
 on little to no human intervention.

Title: SynnerDB - A system for generating synthetic datasets
Abstract:
Based on the specific design choices of Synner, we out-line a language for data generation
 - Syddel - examining the valid space of relationships that a user can and cannot express.
 Given a valid plan, we further investigate strategies for optimizing data generation
 when creating billions of synthetic data points. We present some strategies for generation
 speedup, including the use of columns instead of rows, pushing down predicates, evaluating
 sampling across table joins, as well as caching results when incrementally creating
 columns. A set of experiments were run to assess the validity of these strategies
 within the various generation units of SynnerDB.

Title: Link Predictions Using Pytorch-BigGraph and Gensim
Abstract:
I continued my work with knowledge graph link prediction using the PBG model, with
 the central idea being the utilization of trained embeddings for link prediction.
 Through frameworks such as PBG and Gensim, I aimed to leverage machine learning inference
 using the matrix of embeddings and the mapping between entities and their entries
 in the trained model. Given the structure of the graph, the model was able to infer
 missing links when given an entity and relationship, showing optimal performance when
 trained with 200 dimensions and 200 epochs. Ultimately, the model allows users to
 query the model for some movie name and relationship, or multiple movie names, and
 returns the predicted result of the query, even if that particular movie-relationship
 tuple is not present in the graph.

Title: Intelligent Question Generation for Time-Offset Interaction Applications
Abstract:
Time-offset interaction applications (TOIA) allow simulating conversations with people
 who have previously recorded relevant video utterances, which are played in response
 to their interacting user. TOIAs have great potential for pre-serving cross-generational
 and cross-cultural histories, online teaching, simulated interviews, etc. Current
 TOIAs exist in niche contexts involving high production costs. Democratizing TOIA
 presents different challenges when creating appropriate pre-recordings, designing
 different user stories, and creating simple online interfaces for experimentation.
 We open-source TOIA 2.0, a user-centered time-offset interaction application, and
 make it available for everyone who wants to interact with people's pre-recordings
 or create their pre-recordings.

Title: Predicting Narrative Coherence
Abstract:
Stories people tell about themselves and how they recall their experiences reveal
 a lot about who they are and their mental well-being. Psychologists have identified
 this and created the Narrative Coherence Coding Scheme (NaCCS); a set of guidelines
 for annotating the "coherence" of a narrative in terms of its theme, chronology and
 context. Upon annotating narratives in accordance with the NaCCS, psychologists have
 found a significant correlation between the coherence score of a narrative and independently
 collected mental health markers of the narrator [7]. Currently, all annotation for
 coherence is done manually; a time consuming task which drains vital resources that
 could have otherwise been spent elsewhere. Our Capstone project aims to make use of
 natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning (ML) techniques to directly
 predict a narrative's coherence score. We explore a number of different techniques
 for this task, ranging from traditional machine learning models such as Support Vector
 Machines (SVM) to pre-trained language models such as BERT (Bidirectional Encoder
 Representations from Transformers).

Title:
Muzeel: A Dynamic Event-Driven Analyzer for JavaScript Dead Code Elimination in Mobile
                                 Web
Abstract:
Today's mobile web pages are becoming computationally intensive due to their focus
 on appearance, interactivity, and data collection in order to enhance the user experience
 and increase the user retention and engagement. To support the plethora of functionalities,
 web developers rely heavily on JavaScript, specifically large general-purpose third-party
 libraries. Although this tends to accelerate the development cycle, it increases the
 overall page complexity by bringing additional functions that might not be utilized
 by the page but are unnecessarily processed by the browser. In this paper, we propose
 Muzeel; a solution for eliminating JavaScript functions that are not used in a given
 web page–this is commonly referred to as dead code. Despite the fact that dead code
 is never executed, it impacts the overall performance of the web page since it is
 downloaded and processed by the browser. Muzeel extracts all of the page event listeners
 (upon page load), emulates user interactions using a bot that triggers each of these
 events, and then generates a comprehensive function call graph in order to eliminate
 the dead code of functions that are not called by any of these events.

Title: Breast Cancer Screening via Microbiome Classification
Abstract:
Recent findings have proven that the abundances of specific microbiota found in the
 human tissue can be associated with the growth of cancer. In line with this discovery,
 this project explored breast cancer prediction by classifying microbiomes of the breast
 and of the gut. We found that feature dimensionality reduction methods, especially
 Hierarchical Feature Engineering, allowed for better and consistent performance across
 the four selected machine learning algorithms—Random Forest, Logistic Regression,
 Naive Bayes, and Decision Tree. Random Forest performed best in all our datasets when
 used with a feature set with HFE applied. From our extracted feature sets, certain
 OTUs matched the microbiomes found to be more abundant in breast cancer cases, supporting
 some of the findings in previous breast cancer metagenomics research. We found that
 g_Bacteroides had higher abundances in the gut microbiota of breast cancer samples
 than in controls. This result overlapped with the finding of Byrd et al., suggesting
 that the bacteria may be an informative biomarker in screening breast cancer. This
 research assessed the potential of microbiomes in breast cancer prediction, to produce
 a practical, cheap, and non- invasive screening tool that can ultimately be used for
 efficient cancer diagnosis.

Title: Public Cooperation in a Human-Bot Society
Abstract:
This study employs the Iterated Public Goods Game (IPGG) in which the best strategies
 for maximum individual gain and maximum group gain are contradictory. Literature has
 shown that people would contribute more when there is punishment on free-riders. There
 is also research [20] showing that when both punishment and reward options are available,
 reward leads to increased contribution, whereas punishment has no effect on contribution.
 This study introduces a human- bot element to the IPGG and examines how people behave
 in group cooperation with the presence of punishment and/or reward when playing with
 human peers v.s. when playing with AI/bots. This study would also expand our understanding
 on human-bot interaction in group settings as current studies have focused on two
 player scenarios in dilemmas exclusively.

Title:
Assessing training data quantity for optimum performance of LiDAR object classification
                                 models
Abstract:
Classifying objects within aerial light detection and ranging (LiDAR) is an essential
 but time-consuming task to which machine learning is being increasingly applied, especially
 neural networks specifically for 3D data. However, there has not been an examination
 into the quantity of data required to train a reliable, high performing model. It
 is found that the underlying assumptions about training data for such networks remain
 largely uncovered and unaddressed. Generating training data from LiDAR point clouds
 necessitates significant manual labour, so there is an incentive in establishing the
 minimal model requires to achieve acceptable performance levels. This project assessed
 the impact of quantity of training data on classification accuracy of PointNet, a
 deep learning framework tailored for 3D point clouds. A PointNet implementation was
 trained on subsets of a large data set called ModelNet that spanned from 40 to 2000
 objects which included 40 different types of objects. Accuracy improved logarithmically,
 with convergence typically beginning at approximately 600,000 training points. This
 work provides a framemark for subsequent development by establishing a learning curve
 for 3D-focused classification models and suggests how much data should be manually
 labelled and used for training when the model is used on new data.

Title: Iruka: Accelerated Mobile Pages Through Classifying and Blocking Non-critical JavaScript
Abstract:
The average page size has been increased from 1720 Kilo- bytes In 2016 to 3077 Kilobytes
 in 2021, where Javascript is increasingly contributing to the total page size (from
 24% in 2016 to 27% in 2021). In comparison to equivalent-sized web resources, JavaScript
 is more expensive to process due to the requirement of parsing, interpretation and
 execution. This cost significantly contributes to the increasing complexity of modern
 mobile pages, which becomes a critical performance bottleneck for low-end smartphone
 devices and ultimately leads to lesser user engagement. Hence, in this paper I propose
 a tool which uses a machine learning algorithm to classify JavaScripts into different
 categories from which are used as a basis point to block non-critical Javascript,
 with the aim of reducing the amount of JavaScripts in a fully loaded web-page. The
 tool is a form of browser plugin that is privacy-preserving, since it offers an independent
 client-end solution that does not require any external interaction with any third-party
 service. The proposed plugin is empowered by a neural network model which detects
 categories of JavaScript elements used in web pages with an accuracy of 89.33%.

Title:
TREEsearch: The Utilization of Decision Trees in Order to Decrease the Amount of Global
                                 Research Debt
Abstract:
Researchers of today's world are cursed with a vast amount of complex and valuable
 scholarly data. They are faced with long lists of search results, with articles ranging
 in the thousands, making filtering through and summarizing such volume an extreme
 burden. How to utilize the vast quantity data becomes a critical problem to be tackled.
 With the rapid growth of digital publishing and harvesting, how to visualize, how
 to utilize the vast quantity of data becomes a critical problem to be tackled. We
 propose an NLP driven decisiontree based Visualization tool where someone can search
 for an area of study/discipline, and our application displays a map/geography of all
 the relevant scientific literature in that research field. Such a visualization tool
 has the power to lay out and present the state of the world's scientific knowledge,
 as well as having many other applications in the research world.

Title: Learning Entity Embeddings from Wikipedia and Wikidata for Entity or Article Prediction
Abstract:
In this era of big data, there has been a proliferation of knowledge graphs (KG) and
 knowledge bases (KB) such as Wikidata and Wikipedia. The existence of such knowledge
 graphs and bases means there is a lot of data to our disposal to be used for several
 purposes. However, without proper embeddings of the entities in these knowledge graphs
 and bases, it is difficult to take full advantage of the rich and vast amount of data
 available to us. Learning useful representations or embeddings from such graph entities
 is useful for a variety of machine learning applications, including but not limited
 to, natural language processing, entity prediction and relation prediction. Besides
 reducing the engineering effort, these representations can lead to greater predictive
 power. Although there have been recent works in embeddings of knowledge graphs and
 bases there haven't been any yet that take advantage of the cross-lingual nature of
 Wikipedia and Wikidata. To this effect, our Capstone project focuses on learning embeddings
 of entities and articles Wikipedia across multiple languages. These embeddings will
 then be used to create a tool for article or entity prediction across multiple languages.

Title: Audio-Based Hierarchical Structure Analysis for Evaluating Music Similarity
Abstract:
Structure is an important compositional element in music. Analyzing the structure
 of musical pieces is a common practice among musicians and musicologists, but even
 among them here isn't always agreement on the exact segmentation and granularity of
 it. It is, therefore, challenging to automatize the task of constructing a representation
 of structure from the audio of a piece and to measure the structural similarity between
 pieces while accounting for repetition patterns at different levels of granularity.
 This problem exists at the core of the more general question of how to define the
 similarity between musical pieces. In this work, I propose methods for measuring the
 structural similarity between musical pieces by decomposing them hierarchically and
 comparing their structure at different levels of granularity. The proposed decomposition
 relies on encoding global and local repetition patterns within a piece and constructing
 low-rank approximations of them using techniques from spectral graph theory. The behavior
 of different decomposition configurations and structural similarity metrics is investigated
 under several audio perturbations and for the task of cover song identification. Subsequently,
 methods are suggested for using this structure representation to define more meaningful
 music similarity metrics.

Title: Revisiting the Uncanny Valley using Generative Adversarial Networks
Abstract:
The "uncanny valley" is a phenomenon first described by Masahiro Mori as the observation
 that when non-human beings appear more human-like, they become more appealing to humans,
 but only up-to a certain point. After that point, the affinity felt towards such beings
 steadily decreases into a trough, and gradually rises again. This paper describes
 an exploratory attempt to re-create the uncanny valley starting with an uncanny image.
 We will propose a novel solution using a generative adversarial network (namely, StyleGAN)
 to transform images that lie at the bottom of the valley to appear more human and
 further enhance those images using the same deep learning model to make them perfectly
 human.

Title: Towards Machine Learning Defensive Mechanisms in LTE and 5G Security
Abstract:
Research in the field of LTE network security has exposed a variety of inadequate
 security measures in the Radio Resource Control and Non-Access Stratum protocols.
 Through the 5G standard, the 3GPP alliance attempted to create new defense mechanisms
 that can detect abuse of these protocols. However, we argue that not all messages
 exchanged within these two protocols are efficiently protected by these novel countermeasures.
 We highlight cases where protocol messages could be attacked indirectly, despite being
 encrypted and integrity-protected. These attacks results in unexpected network disruptions
 affecting the security of the system and privacy of the users. Thus, adding an extra
 layer of prevention and detection in this security network can make the network more
 resilient to attacks. We introduce a Machine Learning model that can detect active
 cellular attacks based on the disruption of the network. By using tractable data points
 from benign and attacked traffic, the model will learn the inconsistencies of an attacked
 network, ultimately detecting the attack. We investigate 8 attack scenarios proven
 possible by past research reports, which are analyzed in order to derive the appropriate
 training features and traceable parameters that can be used as input to the ML technique.

Title: In Search for Optimized Collective Variables for Molecular Dynamics Simulations
Abstract:
This report summarizes the progress and achievements of the capstone project in analyzing
 and improving the effectiveness of artificial intelligence algorithm applied for dynamic
 Collective Variable (CV) sampling in Molecular Dynamics (MD). The computational chemistry
 is being strongly limited by the time scale factor of the MD simulations due multitude
 of their degrees of freedom. Currently applied way of improving the efficiency is
 by introducing a set of CVs, from which the most significant ones can be indicated
 as the reaction coordinates, greatly reducing the complexity of the simulations. Since
 the knowledge of CVs a priori is a daunting task, most of the contemporary approaches
 remain subjected to the trial-and-error methods. In this project several alternatives
 were analyzed, heavily embracing machine learning and automatizing the process of
 CV sampling as the simulation is running, that is 'on the fly'. The significance of
 CVs in characterizing the conformational transitions and enhancing the conformational
 sampling of biomolecules was thoroughly investigated and used to develop a state-of
 art linear regression algorithm based on the cross-entropy minimization.

Title: Revisiting the Uncanny Valley using Generative Adversarial Networks
Abstract:
The "uncanny valley" is a phenomenon first described by Masahiro Mori as the observation
 that when non-human beings appear more human-like, they become more appealing to humans,
 but only up-to a certain point. After that point, the affinity felt towards such beings
 steadily decreases into a trough, and gradually rises again. This paper describes
 a exploratory attempt to re-create the uncanny valley starting with an uncanny image.
 We will propose a novel solution using a generative adversarial network (namely, StyleGAN)
 to transform images that lie at the bottom of the valley to appear more human, and
 further enhance those images using the same deep learning model to make them perfectly
 human.

Title: On The Shape of The Numerical Range for Some Tridiagonal Matrices
Abstract:
Major: Mathematics, PhysicsAbstract: In this paper, we provided several new proofs of some known theorems regarding
 the condition of ellipticity for tridiagonal matrices with n = 3 and n = 4. Some new
 results regarding the numerical range of matrix with n = 6 and analysis of the at
 portions situation is also included in this paper.

Title: Inferring Effective Synaptic Connectivity from Neural Spike Trains
Abstract:
Major: Mathematics Abstract: Neural networks with unknown interactions among individual neurons are common
 in research on biology and neuroscience. The dynamics of the population often depends
 on the presence or absence of individual interactions, the strength of neuron couplings
 and the effective excitatory or inhibitory relationship between each pair of interacting
 neurons. However, it is difficult to detect all of these directly in experimental
 settings. We present a method for reconstructing the interaction topology from spike
 trains data. The reconstruction method based on the leaky integrate-and-fire model
 is reviewed and discussed. Simulations show that the general reconstruction method
 achieves a high accuracy. We additionally propose a reconstruction method based on
 the quadratic integrate-and-fire model.

Title: Flat Portions on Boundaries of Numerical Ranges of Tridiagonal Matrices
Abstract:
Major: MathematicsAbstract: This project paper discusses the classification of the number of pairs of
 flat portions on the boundary of the numerical range of tridiagonal matrices of a
 particular form.

Title: A novel method to predict low-altitude cloud temperature using solely infrared images
Abstract:
An infrared thermographic camera produces brightness temperature of an object in its
 view based on the total spectral radiance incident on its lens. A ground camera pointed
 at the sky registers the total spectral radiance it receives but cannot distinguish
 the separate contributions of radiance by outer space, the atmosphere and any clouds
 that may be present. This poses a challenge in determining the temperature of clouds
 simply by looking at infrared images of the sky since the brightness temperature is
 often different from the true temperature of clouds. This paper presents a novel and
 simple model that uses infrared images solely to single out the spectral radiance
 due to the low-altitude clouds present and thereby retrieve true cloud base temperature.

Title: Algebraization of Probability and Boole's Work
Abstract:
We consider recent development of the foundation of probability theory, namely, "algebraization"
 of finite probabilities. This method allows one to check consistency of any set of
 assumptions concerning finite probabilities and, in theory, solve any problem involving
 finitely many events. It consists of algebraic procedures, some parallel to the method
 of Cartesian coordinates in elementary geometry, and is based on transforming given
 problem into a set of algebraic equations or relations. We then consider mathematician
 George Boole's little understood work on probability and verify that its aim was indeed
 algebraization of finite probabilities. Boole had clearly understood the possibility
 of realizing his aim and had identified appropriate methods in terms of normal disjunctive
 form and algebraic relations. However, he had been unable to carry out algebraization
 due to inappropriate selection of events, which forced him to add improper conditions.
 In this study, we limit ourselves to the case of finitely many events to avoid the
 complications of countable additivity, which would not add much novelty and simply
 make the exposition more cumbersome. Moreover, we note that Boole had considered only
 the linear case in his work.

Title: Spectral Clustering
Abstract:
In recent years, spectral clustering has become one of the most popular modern clustering
 algorithms. It is simple to implement, can be solved efficiently by standard linear
 algebra software packages, and very often outperforms traditional clustering algorithms
 such as the k-means algorithm [19]. My capstone report aims to serve as introduction
 to spectral clustering and explains cases where spectral clustering works better than
 k-means. The report also describes the shortfalls of spectral clustering, current
 efforts to improve these shortfalls and my own contributions to the area.

Title: On the Normalized Numerical Range of Normal Matrices
Abstract:
My capstone explores the normalized numerical range of normal matrices. We consider
 two cases: when 0 is inside the normalized numerical range, and when 0 is outside
 the normalized numerical range. The result shows that the normalized numerical range
 of normal matrices is sometimes bounded by some hyperbolic arcs. At other times, the
 normalized numerical range can be bounded by a straight line and some hyperbolic arcs.

Title: Explicit Computations of Characteristic Classes and Genera
Abstract:
This paper provides explicit expansions of the Chern classes, Pontrjagin classes,
 Chern character, as well as the Chern character and Chern classes of a tensor product
 of two vector bundles. One will also find expansions of the Aˆ -genus, Lgenus, Todd
 genus, their twisted forms, as well as relations among the three genera. Computational
 methods are explained throughout.

Title: On the maximal numerical range of some matrices
Abstract:
The maximal numerical range of a matrix A is the (regular) numerical range W(B) of
 its compression B onto the eigenspace L of A*A corresponding to its maximal eigenvalue.
 So, the maximal numerical range of a matrix is always a subset of the numerical range
 of that matrix. We establish conditions under which the maximal numerical range has
 a non-empty intersection with the boundary of the numerical range, in particular when
 they coincide. We also describe the maximal numerical range explicitly for matrices
 unitarily similar to direct sums of 2-by-2 blocks, and provide some insight into the
 behavior of the maximal numerical range when L has codimension one.

Title: Determination of RNA structures using SAXS data
Abstract:
This project extends a computational method to determine the structure of proteins
 using small-angle X-ray scattering data and applies it to determining the structure
 of nucleic acids in explicit solvent. Equations for the coupling of experimental SAXS
 data to classical molecular dynamics simulations were parameterized and extended,
 and another theoretical framework was assessed for comparison purposes, the maximum
 entropy principle. To further analyze the quality of the SAXS-guided molecular dynamics
 simulations, specialized software was used to calculate SAXS parameters from the newly
 determined nucleic acid structures.

Title: The Random Current Representation For The Discrete Gaussian Free Field
Abstract:
Statistical mechanics is a discipline at the intersection of physics and mathematics:
 its purpose is to establish models, notably based on probability theory, that describe
 the average behavior of thermodynamic systems. This paper focuses on lattice models,
 placing a particular emphasis on the Ising Model and the Discrete Gaussian Free Field
 (DGFF). Exploiting certain formal similarities between these two models, we extrapolate
 the random current representation, a geometric representation of the ferromagnetic
 Ising Model, to the DGFF in an effort to provide a different perspective on the latter
 model, one that can potentially be useful to compute quantities of interest. Note
 that a random current representation similar to that for the Ising model and that
 developed in our paper was derived for a Markov Field by Camia and Lis (2016).

Title: Numerical Range and Product Numerical Range - Ratio of the Volumes
Abstract:
We examine the numerical range $W(A)$ and its modification - the product numerical
 range $W^\otimes(A)$ - of a square matrix $A$ defined in an inner product space with
 a tensor product structure. It is known that $W^\otimes(A)$ is a subset of $W(A)$
 and it has been conjectured in a WONRA 2018 Conference presentation by Jakub Czartowski,
 Konrad Szymański and Karol Życzkowski {On Restricted Numerical Range}, that for Hermitian
 matrices of order 4, $\frac{1}{2} \leq \frac{volW^\otimes(A)}{volW(A)} \leq 1$. We
 prove the conjecture for a few families of matrices: diagonal matrices, tridiagonal
 matrices of a specific form, special case of anti-diagonal matrices, and two different
 groups of matrices having non-zero elements on both diagonal and anti-diagonal.

Title: The Numerical Range and Convex Hull Of Ellipses
Abstract:
In this report we will study some particular families of matrices that are of size
 n > 3. We will be doing so in two ways. Firstly, we will be using theorems 1 and 2
 to study a particular family of reducible matrices whose
 numerical range is an elliptical disk or the convex hull of multiple ellipses. Secondly,
 we will look at an approach to compute the determinant of block matrices by using
 Schur's complement and we will apply this to show that a certain family of matrices
 has an elliptical disk as its numerical range. Before doing so, however, we will use
 the next section to introduce a particularly useful tool to studying the numerical
 range of a matrix - the boundary generating curve.

Title: Optimization: The theory and application to Kendrick-Taylor model
Abstract:
This paper studies the Kendrick-Taylor model and its optimization realization. Topics
 covered include the Gateaux and the Frechet derivatives, the calculation of gradients,
 the second derivative test. A clear understanding of them needs to be developed to
 complete the goal of this paper. While it is complicated to find the general solution
 to the model, this paper aims to develop the theory to prove that an optimal situation
 of the model does exist, can be achieved in real life, and find out the explicit solutions
 under specific conditions.

Title: Wu classes, Steenrod Algebra, & Related Operations: A Computational Toolkit
Abstract:
We develop a computational toolkit to calculate explicit expansions that relate Wu
 class, Stiefel-Whitney Class, Pontryagin Class, Steenrod Algebra, and Milnor Operations.
 The paper contains an introduction to relevant concepts, a list of such expansions,
 and documentation of the open source code.

Title: Mathematics of Finance - The Black-Scholes Equation
Abstract:
This project studies the Black-Scholes model which is a Partial Derivative Equation
 that determines the variations of option price over time. The model was developed
 using Ito calculus through stochastic process. The equation is named after Myron Scholes,
 and Fischer Black who published their seminar paper together with Robert Merton on
 option pricing in 1973, hence the name Black-Scholes model. Though Robert Merton's
 name is not included in the equation but he has equally contributed to the model.
 The project focuses on derivation of the model through Ito Calculus, the history of
 the model, it's application in finance, and how the pricing model is largely used
 by option traders who buy options that are priced under the formula calculated value
 and sell options priced higher than the Black-Scholes calculated value.

Title:
Computer-aided study of double extensions of restricted Lie superalgebras preserving
                                 the non-degenerate closed 2-forms in characteristic 2
Abstract:
A Lie (super)algebra with a non-degenerate invariant symmetric bilinear form B is
 called a nis-(super)algebra. The double extension g of a nis-(super)algebra a is the
 result of simultaneous adding to a acentral element and a derivation so that g is
 a nis-algebra. Loop algebras
 with values in simple complex Lie algebras are most known among the
 Lie (super)algebras suitable to be doubly extended. In characteristic 2
 the notion of double extension acquires specific features. Restricted Lie (super)algebras
 are among the most interesting modular Lie superalgebras. In characteristic 2, using
 Grozman's Mathematica-based package SuperLie, we list double extensions of restricted
 Lie superalgebras preserving the non-degenerate closed 2-forms with constant coefficients.
 The results are proved for the number of indeterminates ranging from 4 to 7 — sufficient
 to conjecture the pattern for larger numbers. Considering multigradings allowed us
 to accelerate computations up to 100 times.

Title: Mathematical Model of Resilience of a Tropical Forest to Selective Cutting
Abstract:
The method of selective cutting is currently perceived as a less harmful option for
 obtaining wood resources from tropical forests than clear cutting despite the lack
 of scientific research on the long-term effects of selective cutting. This project
 aims to address this gap in scientific knowledge and provide insight about the ability
 of a forest to recover after a selective cut by modeling the dynamical system of the
 coexistence between trees and vines subject to disturbances. We suggest that depending
 on the shape of the basin boundary, a selective cut can shift the system from the
 healthy to the unhealthy basin of attraction. This would mean that with time, the
 forest does not recover to its initial healthy state but falls into a long-lasting
 degraded state implying that selective cutting can have a long-term negative impact
 on the forest ecosystem.

Title: Simulation of sinking spheroidal phytoplanktons
Abstract:
We speculate that the sinking fraction of plankton cells can vary with respect to
 their shapes. The corresponding microscopic and macroscopic analysis are important
 to understand as they can have further ecological implications on the evolutive advantages
 for non-spherical planktons. The purpose of the capstone research is thus to quantify
 the sinking fractions of planktonic cells with different shapes and sinking velocities
 to understand the physics and the ecology of the sinking processes for different 
 phytoplankton species.

Title: Clustering and Spatial Markovianity in Finance Based Models
Abstract:
We discuss the type of dependency in different finance models for herding behavior
 in financial markets, with a greater focus on Cont Bouchaud Model. We observe that
 while Cont Bouchaud Model ensures cluster formation as in real markets, it faces a
 lack of spatial Markovianity in the agents' behaviour. On the other hand, models based
 on ferromagnetic models (Ising and Potts) do not have real cluster formation but they
 exhibit social imitation only. However, clustering and spatial Markovianity, both
 are highly desired properties of a model depicting real life market scenarios. We
 verify that if clustering is done by the less intuitive Random Cluster Model, an intermediate
 model can be formed that incorporates real cluster formation as well as social imitation.

Title: Random Fractal Percolation on 2D Honeycomb Lattice
Abstract:
This is the final report of the capstone research project on Random Fractal Percolation
 on 2D Honeycomb Lattice, with professor Federico Camia. The paper consists of three
 sections. In the first section, we introduce some basic concepts involved in this
 research and briefly explain the construction and properties of Mandelbrot's fractal
 percolation model, from which our research object is derived. Then we present the
 construction of a random fractal percolation model on the 2D honeycomb lattice. In
 the last part, the paper discusses some interesting findings about this model and
 some possible directions for future study.

Title: A Study of the Black-Scholes Option Pricing Model: its Derivation and Applicability
Abstract:
The financial markets have gone through an enormous development over the past 50 years.
 One of the rising challenges in finance is that the complexity of financial instruments
 and markets has led financial engineers to seek and employ increasingly sophisticated
 mathematical tools to address financial issues, such as the pricing of financial derivatives.
 The Black-Scholes option pricing model has become the firm basis for financial mathematics
 which finds adequate solutions to the pricing of a world-wide rapidly increasing number
 of derivatives. Many option pricing models have been developed since Black and Scholes
 published their work in 1973. In this paper, we study the original Black-Scholes option
 pricing model for European call options in terms of its derivation and applicability.
 By constructing a riskless portfolio taking positions in bonds (cash), option, and
 the underlying stock, we derive the Black-Scholes partial differential equations without
 and with dividends for European calls. With a series of changes of variables, we transform
 the Black-Scholes equation to the heat equation and obtain a closed-form solution
 to the original equation, known as the Black-Scholes formula. The applicability is
 evaluated through a comparison of the Black-Scholes model and the real market data.

Title: Ellipticity of the Numerical Range
Abstract:
Let $A$ be an $n \times n$ matrix. The numerical range of $A$ can be defined as $W(A)=\{x^*Ax
 : x \in \mathbb{C}^n, x^*x=1\}$. The shape of the numerical range can be determined
 through the associated ternary polynomial $F(t, x, y) = \det(tI_n + x(A + A^*)/2 +
 y(A - A*)/2i))$. In this research, a series of necessary and sufficient conditions
 will be given to determine when a tridiagonal matrix where $a_{ij}=a_{ji}^{-1}$ for
 |i-j|=1 and zero otherwise will have an elliptical numerical range. Moreover, this
 project provides a condition on the entries of matrices H and Z so that they can be
 factored into matrices C and D where $H = C^*C + DD^*$ and $Z =DC$.

Title: On the Maximal Numerical Mass and the Center of Mass
Abstract:
The maximal numerical range of a matrix and the Aluthge transform of a matrix are
 topics previously worked on by David Rose and Ali Hamed, professor Spitkovsky's former
 students. In this paper, the limit of the maximal numerical range under the Aluthge
 transform for 2 × 2 matrices and matrices with a distinct largest eigenvalue by magnitude
 is established and the limit for 3×3 matrices is conjectured. Some results for the
 unitary reducibility of the Aluthge transform and the geometric shape of the numerical
 range under an iteration of the Aluthge transform are also obtained. The center of
 mass of a matrix is introduced and renamed as the Stampfli point. The Stampfli point
 is described completely for 2 × 2 matrices and results regarding the inclusion of
 Stampfli Point in the numerical range and the convex hull of spectrum are obtained.
 Finally, a condition for the Stampfli being equal to zero for a triple eigenvalue
 matrix in terms of the off-diagonal entries are established.

Title: Chern-Simons Theory
Abstract:
This Capstone project studies the Chern-Simons Theory from perspectives arising from
 Geometry and Topology, Physics, and categorical (axiomatic) Topological Quantum Field
 Theory (TQFT). The Chern-Simons form was studied, and relevant combinatorial formulas
 were derived. Computations of the Chern-Simons invariant of the Thurston geometries
 were performed, leading to results on the conformal embedding of these in Euclidean
 space. Then, the Physical Chern-Simons theory was studied from the traditional QFT
 picture, and in specific its geometric, and path integral quantizations. It was subsequently
 studied from the point of view of Category Theory via axiomatic TQFT and its generalization,
 extended TQFT. This led to an extensive exploration on the relevant categorical objects
 and results, especially those concerning monoidal categories in a broad sense. The
 argument for the partial extension of Chern-Simons as an extended TQFT was studied
 closely, specifically in relation to geometric quantization, and the Reshetikhin-Turaev
 TQFT's.

Title: Stability of Self-similar Solutions of Inviscid Burgers Equation
Abstract:
This paper is based on the stability of self similar solutions, that describe the
 formation of shocks for Burgers equation, using energy methods in Eulerian coordinates.
 The Burger's equation is a classical example of a nonlinear hyperbolic equation for
 which smooth solutions can become singular in finite time. My capstone then is based
 upon the analysis of these smooth solutions and their behaviour near the shock formation
 time. We establish some results regarding the analytic profiles of the self-similar
 solutions particularly that they are a diffeomorphism onto their image and they are
 of order similar to their implicit equation near origin. We also study the spectrum
 of the linearised operator that is suitable to the self-similar variables and then
 use these results to establish that a perturbed self similar solution will converge
 to the self similar profile provided that the perturbation is small enough initially.
 The result is shown using a method of characteristics and bootstrapping argument and
 thereby the stability of the solution is proved.

Title: Precise Determination of Cellular Uptake of Cell-Penetrating Pepties Using FACS-FCS
Abstract:
Major: PhysicsAbstract: We combine fluorescence activated cell sorting with fluorescence correlation
 spectroscopy to measure cellular uptake of small molecules in moles per cell both
 quickly and accurately, while taking into account confounding factors such as cell
 death. Test measurements with this method were twice as accurate as the next most
 accurate method and speed was comparable – omitting cell counting and comparing by
 measurement step alone, it was 10 times faster.

Title: Similarity Measure in Origami Crease Patterns
Abstract: Major: Physics, Computer Science Abstract: A metric of similarity between origami crease patterns was proposed.

Title: Cloud opacities in the atmosphere of highly irradiated short-period exoplanet HD189733b
Abstract:
Major: Physics. Abstract: HD189733b is one of the most extensively studied exoplanets
 to date. The Jupiter sized gas giant orbits close to its host star with a two day
 period, and due to tidal locking, one side is constantly and heavily irradiated. Transmission
 spectra and secondary eclipse observations of HD189733b suggest that mineral dust
 clouds are prominent in the upper atmosphere. Cloud formation and dust opacities,
 however, are generally omitted from global circulation models. We present radial dust
 opacity profiles of HD189733b based on a 3D radiative-hydrodynamical simulation and
 a kinetic cloud formation model specifically tuned for the planet. We find that (1)
 optical properties of clouds are dominated by iron condensates on the dayside and
 by silicates on the nightside; (2) cloud formation is restricted to low pressures
 in the atmosphere; and (3) cloud structure varies significantly with longitude and
 wavelength. The observed trends might be valid for other hot Jupiters as well, and,
 if incorporated into general circulation models, could lead to improved understanding
 of the atmospheric circulation of extrasolar planets.

Title: Characterization of Muon Events in XENON100 Dark Matter Detector
Abstract:
Major: Physics, MathematicsAbstract: The XENON100 dark matter experiment is designed to detect xenon nuclear
 recoils resulting from the scattering of dark matter Weakly Interacting Massive Particles
 (WIMPs). The muon flux is suppressed to 1.04 ± 0.02 m−2 hr−1 by an average 3100 meters
 water equivalent (m.w.e.) of rock overburden at the underground installation of the
 detector. An efficient WIMP search in ultra-low radiation background would benefit
 from proper characterization of such muon events and understanding of the aftermath
 of its ionization track. I present few candidate signals for the passage of muons
 through the detector. The direct scintillation signal (S1) and the amplified charge
 signal (S2) detected by the photomultiplier tubes (PMTs) for these events satisfy
 all the expected characteristics of large energy deposition by muons.

Title: A Novel Two-Station Seismic Method to Locate Glacier Calving
Abstract:
Major: Physics, MathematicsAbstract: A novel method of determining glacier calving location using hyperbolas
 from two local seismic stations is presented. The wave arrival time difference is
 used to define a locus of possible origins, which intersects uniquely with the calving
 front. This method is motivated by difficulties with traditional seismic location
 methods that fail due to the emergent nature of calving, which obscures the P and
 S-wave onsets, and the proximity of the seismometers, which combines body and surface
 waves into one arrival. A mix of tidal and seismic data and satellite imagery are
 used to confirm a list of calving events at Helheim Glacier from August 2013 to August
 2014. In particular, two events in the week beginning August 11 2014 that were seen
 in person are used to calibrate the method, which is then applied to other calving
 events. An extension of this method with one more station would allow for triangulation
 location that would not depend on satellite or camera imagery.

Title: A Background Analysis of XENON100 Calibration Data using Compton Scattering
Abstract:
The aim of the XENON experiment is to directly detect cold, non-baryonic Dark Matter
