 (DM) in the form ofWeakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) that recoil from Xenon
 (Xe) nuclei. These weak nuclear recoils could be a_x000B_ected by background events
 arising from neutrons and electrons that also interact with the Xe nuclei. This capstone
 work addresses the issue of electronic recoil (ER) leakage into the WIMP search region
 in XENON100. Caesium-137 (137Cs) and Cobalt-60 (60Co) run 12 calibration data have
 been used to analyze a hypothetical category of ER or Compton scatter leakage events,
 reconstruct their kinematics and produce selection criteria to eliminate these events
 from the DM search region. These results could be used for future analyses in XENON100
 or XENON1T, which is scheduled to operate this year.

Title: Detecting Potential Jupiter-Analog Exoplanets In The Archival Kepler Dataset
Abstract:
While exoplanet research has made rapid progress in recent years, there is a shortage
 of research in detecting long orbital period exoplanets. Just as our Solar System's
 evolution was affected by the presence of a large long orbital period planet, Jupiter,
 these exoplanets may therefore serve as an indicator of a complex planetary system
 like our own. Using the archival Kepler data, a publically available dataset generated
 by the NASA Kepler space observatory, we conduct a search for potential novel Jupiter-Analog
 exoplanets. A modified and simplified box model, a line segment model, was used to
 search through the entire 1TB dataset in 4 days. The algorithm returned 672 stars
 out of 206,111 stars in the entire dataset. While there were more than 600 false positives,
 18 stars have potentially new transit events. We propose that follow-up observations
 are made on these 18 stars to confirm or deny potential exoplanets.

Title:
Amelioration of an X-ray Fluorescence Scanning Spectrometer for Applications to Cultural
                                 Heritage Studies
Abstract:
X-Ray Fluorescence is a powerful nuclear technique for analyzing elemental composition
 and is well suited for non-destructive, in situ investigations of art and artifacts.
 The technique offers interdisciplinary applications and can be used alone or as complementary
 to other techniques such as Raman spectroscopy. In collaboration with the LABEC laboratory
 in Florence, Italy, we have modified an existing XRF scanning spectrometer by integrating
 a laser telemetry sensor into the system hardware and software. Positional feedback
 from the sensor was used to automatically regulate scanner-to-specimen distance during
 an areal scan. With this regulation in place, X-ray elemental distribution scans were
 able to be performed for a widened range of non-planar sample geometries without sacrificing
 data quality or posing risks to analyzed specimens. Dedicated tests at LABEC, the
 Opificio Delle Pietre Dure, and in Abu Dhabi have confirmed the upgraded versatility
 of the XRF system in analyzing a range of Cultural Heritage specimens.

Title: Charecterization of Multi Pixel Photon Counters for particle detection purposes
Abstract:
A comprehensive characterization of novel Multi Pixel Photon Counters (MPPCs) was
 performed to assess their potential as a substitute for the type of light detectors,
 photomultiplier tubes (PMTs), currently used for applications such as liquid noble
 gas particle detectors and gamma ray spectroscopy. The study was focused on their
 response to light with wavelengths in the vacuum ultraviolet range like that obtained
 from the liquid xenon and argon scintillation utilized in particle detectors. In order
 to recreate the conditions of said detectors part of the study was realized under
 cryogenic conditions. The wide yet precise range of wavelengths used was obtained
 by using a state-of-the-art monochromator. To further evaluate the performance of
 the MPPCs they were used in the analysis of scintillation light emitted by LYSO crystals
 and its response to temperature changes.

Title: Cleaning XENON100 Waveforms With Supervised Machine Learning Algorithms
Abstract:
We use two supervised machine learning techniques, multilayer perceptron and boosted
 decision tree, to increase signal efficiency in data from the XENON100 dark matter
 experiment. Existing techniques for distinguishing between signal and background involve
 making threshold cuts on a quantity called entropy. Throughout the life of XENON100,
 this approach has become less efficient, particularly for run 12. Instead of using
 events as my basic data analysis unit, we use individual waveforms. After characterizing
 these waveforms in terms of high and low level variables, we train a Theano implementation
 of MLP and the TMVA implementation of BDT. Out physically well motivated choice of
 training data significantly outperformed a control training dataset, for both methods.

Title: Cubesat Raad for the Study of Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flashes
Abstract:
Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flashes (TGFs) are sudden bursts of gamma ray radiation triggered
 by lightning or thunderstorms and are channeled above the Earth's atmosphere and into
 outer space, and thus cannot be detected from Earth. The current leading model that
 is used to explain the mechanism behind TGF production is Relativistic Runaway Electron
 Avalanche (RREA) phenomenon, but this model is being challenged by some of the most
 recent key TGF observations, including AGILE and FERMI observations, which suggests
 that this may not be the best model to explain TGF emission. CubeSat Raad is a proposal
 for a study to identify a useful experiment for TGF Science, which can be miniaturized
 and eventually integrated on a cubesat. The instrumentation proposed for the purpose
 of the experiment is a 3U cubesat and a gamma-ray detector in the $\mathrm{10 keV
 - 1000 keV}$ range. The goal is to explicitly target events connected to low energy
 gamma rays emitted from the earth's atmosphere and in turn collect and analyze data
 focused and specific on this phenomenon to improve correlation studies with lightning
 and other atmospheric parameters.

Title:
Electromagnetic fields around neurons interact with T-cells in the CNS and initiate
                                 autoimmune response: a parallel between multiple sclerosis and ischemic stroke
Abstract:
Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease where a mutation in the gene encoding
 for a protein belonging to the NLR Family Pyrin Domain Containing 12 (NLRP12) enables
 the T-cells to penetrate the blood-brain barrier and damage the myelin sheath. Expanding
 upon Dr. Bjorn Nordenstrom's "Biologically Closed Electrical Circuits", this paper
 utilizes computational electrodynamics in Matlab and an in vivo MRI cell tracking
 study to hypothesize that negative charge on the surface of the T-cell gets attracted
 to the electromagnetic fields generated around the nodes of Ranvier and initiates
 the autoimmune response. By manipulating the electromagnetic forces of attraction
 between the cells, the MRI study showed that T-cell's mobility was impaired post-glucocorticoid
 receptor antagonization. The electrodynamic modeling determined the spatial and temporal
 progression of the electromagnetic field to quantify the nature of its interaction
 with the T-cell's surface charge and its role within the context of MS etiology. The
 potential implications of this research could lead to better understanding of the
 disease's symptoms and provide a framework to explain its uncertain times of onset.

Title:
Monte Carlo simulations of intracellular transport by teams of kinesin-1 molecular
                                 motors
Abstract:
We develop a new computational model of cargo transport by multiple kinesin-1 motors
 which incorporates recent findings involving the asymmetric force-run length relations
 of single kinesin. By analyzing trajectories simulated with an assisting force applied
 to the cargo, we find that the velocity of the cargo is solely determined by the dynamics
 of the leading and lagging motors of the team hauling the cargo. This "two-motor model"
 reduces to a one-motor model under high assisting forces, allowing the development
 of an analytical expression that captures cargo dynamics under these conditions. This
 expression incorporates the single motor properties and therefore allows us to extract
 these properties by fitting the cargo velocity response to force. This provides a
 powerful framework for measuring individual motor properties in vivo where cargo are
 typically hauled by teams of motors.

Title: Optimizing Trigger Parameters for the Detection of Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flashes
Abstract:
In this paper, a description of Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flash (TGF) simulation method
 will be provided as well its usage for determining mission parameters and trigger
 criteria. A database of 1000 TGFs at different radial distances (up to 1k km) was
 created for 4 different configurations of CeBr3-crystal, γ-ray detectors. The expected
 TGF count rate within 1000 km was determined to be roughly 1.64 per day, with mostly
 very few to no counts observed. The expected background was also simulated; the external
 background was derived from the background accumulations of the Fermi satellite, and
 the intrinsic background determined in the laboratory. The total background count
 rates were as follows: 9.600, 38.399, 86.399, and 172.797 counts/second for the 1,
 4, 9, and 18 crystal arrays respectively. The simulations were tested for optimum
 trigger criteria- such as energy thresholds, trigger window sizes, and count rates
 per trigger window.

Title:
RAAD CubeSat Mission for The Study of Terrestrial Gamma-ray Flashes: Space Qualification
                                 Document
Abstract:
Terrestrial Gamma-Ray Flashes (TGFs) are sudden bursts of gamma rays that occur in
 the Earth's atmosphere and escape into outer space which are triggered by lightning
 or thunderstorm activity. Previous detectors used to study TGFs were limited by their
 slow response times and therefore more observations are needed to construct a model
 to describe this phenomena. The proposed detector is based on Cerium(III) Bromide
 crystals coupled to a compact (Hamamatsu R11265U-100) photomultiplier tube. This instrument
 will have a faster time response, high resolution (3.5% at 661 keV) and a high density.
 Given the limited power consumption on a Cubesat (2-6W), the aim is to develop a low
 cost detector with extremely low power requirements and a response time of less than
 100 ns that can be standardized to fit within 1U of a CubeSat. This describes the
 characteristics of the prototype unit detector such as linearity, voltage gain, and
 the gain as a function of temperature for the crystal and PMT.

Title: Automatization of Faint NEO Follow-Up
Abstract:
In this paper we describe a method to improve the follow up process for near earth
 objects (NEOs), especially for faint and fast moving NEOs. Current follow up procedures
 typically use imaging with telescope in sidereal rotation and as a consequence the
 image of the moving NEO is a linear track instead of a point source. This makes it
 difficult to recover faint or fast moving sources. We propose a new follow up method
 where the telescope tracks the NEO rather than tracking with sidereal motion, and
 therefore focuses the image onto a smaller number of pixels. In order to explore the
 effectiveness of such a method, we have created simulated images which accurately
 depict the images that would be found if this method were applied, and determined
 the recovery rate of NEOs for such simulated images under varying conditions. We have
 also identified future work that should be done in order to improve these recovery
 rates, and laid out a framework for making a complete statistical evaluation of the
 method, which would give a description of the recovery rate of the method as a function
 of the magnitude and velocity of an NEO.

Title: Constraining nature of dark matter with high redshift galaxies
Abstract:
Warm Dark Matter (WDM) models provide a promising alternative cosmological scenario
 to the standard Λ Cold Dark Matter (CDM) model. Numerous studies have employed cosmological
 numerical simulations to constrain the allowed mass of WDM particles based on low-redshift
 observational data. When restricted to this range, viable WDM models produce indistinguishable
 predictions at low redshift that are in agreement with CDM. In this work, galaxy formation
 at z = 6-10 was studied in the framework of the NIHAO project, comparing 3keV WDM
 to CDM. Halo mass functions were calculated from dark-matter-only simulations of the
 CDM and WDM scenarios, and fitted using Markov Chain Monte Carlo. Simulations of galaxy
 formation using hydrodynamics were used to construct stellar mass - halo mass relations,
 which were then fitted with power laws. Those simulations were also used to calculate
 the fraction of galaxies that do not form stars as a function of halo mass. Finally,
 the above calculations were used to construct stellar mass functions for the two models
 at redshift 6-10, with the hope that the James Webb Space Telescope may be able to
 discriminate between the two models after its launch in 2020.

Title: Deployment of a Multidetector X-ray Fluorescence Spectrometer
Abstract:
We present a multidetector X-ray fluorescence spectrometer, developed in collaboration
 with the Laboratory for Cultural Heritage (LABEC) in Florence. Principally, the mechanics
 and the software of the instrument were modified so as to allow the incorporation
 of an additional detector. Additionally, through the optimization of the digital pulse
 processor acquisition and shaping parameters, an improvement to the energy resolution
 of a factor of two was attained. Further debugging, customization, and optimization
 allowed for the improvement on the acquisition times by a factor of ∼100, and the
 instrument's portability. Finally, we reflect shortly on the ongoing work during this
 current stage of instrumental development and on the future applications of this X-ray
 fluorescence spectrometer to cultural heritage research projects at NYUAD.

Title: The Effect of Radiative Feedback on Galaxy Structure
Abstract:
Simulations of galaxy formations rely on different feedback mechanisms in order to
 reproduce the observed galaxy baryonic scaling relations and morphology. Although
 the explosive feedback can reproduce many of the observed properties of the galaxies,
 such as the stellar mass-halo mass relationship, it creates disks that are too thick.
 In this paper we present a study of the effects of the radiative feedback on gas cooling
 inside the simulations and its effects on the galaxy structure. This includes the
 ionizing radiation coming from young and old stars. In addition, a new model for the
 UV background radiation, represented by the radiation coming from other galaxies or
 active galactic nuclei, has been implemented, which proved to have a lower feedback
 effect compared to the old NIHAO implementation. The star formation rate is reduced
 after the introduction of the new local photoionization effect, due to an increase
 in the cooling time of the gas. However, due to the above-mentioned effect of the
 new UV background, most of the properties of the newly simulated galaxies have attained
 values similar to the ones in the old simulations. The thickness of the disk was not
 significantly affected.

Title: Nature versus Nurture: Star Formation Rates in NIHAO
Abstract:
I study the star formation rates of galaxies throughout their lifetimes using a large
 sample of hydrodynamical, cosmological simulations. I show that blackhole feedback
 is successful in quenching star formation in the largest galaxies. I construct a new
 quantity, Δ log Star Formation Rate, that relates the star formation rate of individual
 galaxies to galaxies similar to them in age and mass. I find an inverse correlation
 between halo formation time, measured through galaxy concentration, and Δ log SFR.
 Galaxies with halos that form earlier tend to underproduce stars throughout their
 lifetimes, while late bloomers tend to be chronic overproducers of stars. This is
 evidence that dark matter may play more of a role in driving star formation than previously
 realized.

Title: Mapping the Warped H2O Maser Disk in the Low-Mass Galaxy IC 750
Abstract:
We present the first map of water masers in the active galactic nucleus (AGN) of the
 dwarf galaxy IC 750. Water masers at 22 GHz can penetrate the obscuring dust around
 Type 2 AGNs. Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) images of the central parsec
 of IC 750 reveal a nearly edge-on, warped disk of diameter ~0.22 pc x D / 13.8 Mpc.
 The disk lacks emission around the galaxy recession velocity of 701 km/s, so we fit
 Keplerian rotation curves for a 0.5 x 0.5 mas grid of possible dynamical centers.
 By accepting only centers for which the masses determined separately from each side
 of the disk agree within 5%, we determine a best-fit BH mass of 8.0 +0.8 / -0.4 solar
 masses. This mass constitutes the lowest-ever such measurement for a water maser system
 or obscured AGN.

Title: Black Holes in NIHAO
Abstract:
Several black hole growth models have been proposed in the literature that present
 different black hole evolution dependencies. For the purpose of this project, we studied
 the behavior three accretion models in the NIHAO simulated NIHAO galaxy population.
 We studied the Bondi-Hoyle accretion model coupled with black hole feedback, the gravitational
 torque accretion model, and the viscous disk accretion model which both do not require
 black hole feedback. For each of the models, we probed the interaction between black
 holes and their host galaxies through investigating black hole-host galaxy scaling
 relations and examined the observed co-evolution of galaxies and their black holes.
 This was accomplished through running numerical simulations of galaxy formation, post-processing
 analysis, and utilizing observational data sets to constraint the model's parameter
 space. We report that all models match observations down to redshift 1, and note that
 the viscous disk model shows the strongest co-evolution between the black hole mass
 and the stellar mass, the gravitational torque model shows co-evolution at high black
 hole masses, while the Bondi-Hoyle model shows no co-evolution.

Title:
A Method to Probe the Mechanical Properties of Cells and Nuclei Using Optically Trapped
                                 Microstructures
Abstract:
The cell and the cell nucleus are highly dynamic systems that can generate and detect
 forces through the cytoskeleton. By exerting piconewton forces on them and observing
 their deformations, one can detect changes in their organization and composition.
 To improve the versatility of optical tweezers often used for mechanical characterization
 of cells and nuclei, specifically designed and optically trapped handles with designated
 trapping and sample-attachment sites were fabricated and used as handles to manipulate
 a sample of cell or nucleus. By sandwiching the sample between two handles, the design
 of the handles uniquely allows for the exertion of compression, extension, shear,
 and twist forces while detecting the sample's response. In addition, the design prevents
 photodamage of the sample and allows for a variable contact area and shape. The handles
 are 3D-printed through two-photon laser lithography and functionalized with streptavidin
 to for specific attachment with biotin-functionalized samples. In this report, the
 method was demonstrated using beads as test samples. Towards applying this method
 to mechanically characterize nuclei with different lamin mutations, cell nuclei were
 isolated, functionalized with biotin, and their attachment with streptavidin-functionalized
 handles demonstrated.

Title:
Optical Fiber Fluorescence Correlation Spectroscopy (OFFCS) for Remote Measurements
                                 in Tissue
Abstract:
Fluorescence Correlation Spectroscopy (FCS) measurements are invaluable in obtaining
 the quantitative parameters of molecular processes such as diffusion. Access to these
 parameters is essential in designing and testing novel drug delivery strategies. Obtaining
 these parameters deep inside tissue is still an experimental challenge. Despite the
 many recent advances, the optical-fiber-based FCS method is yet to be extended for
 deep tissue measurements. To address this issue, we have been developing an Optical
 Fiber FCS (OFFCS) method that will allow for deep tissue measurements. We have built
 and demonstrated the OFFCS method, based on a versatile and easily constructed schematic
 of the setup. We have demonstrated the feasibility of the setup and the performance
 of FCS measurements by achieving a low background compared to sample measurements.
 Further development of this method may unlock its use for measurements in biological
 settings.

Title:
Revealing the Salt-Dependent Free Energy Landscape of a Helix- Junction-Helix RNA
                                 Model through Well-Tempered Metadynamics Simulations
Abstract:
RNA's capability to fold into specific conformations allows it to fulfill numerous
 biological functions. Since RNA structure often consists of rigid double-stranded
 helices connected by flexible single-stranded junctions, the helix-junction-helix
 (HJH) system serves as a viable model to study RNA dynamics. Available experimental
 data on this model has shown that metrics such as radius of gyration and helix-to-helix
 distance do not follow a monotonic trend when ionic concentrations increase. For this
 reason, all-atom molecular dynamics simulations at various concentrations of KCl were
 carried out to investigate the conformations of the RNA HJH model. The conformational
 ensemble of the RNA was explored by molecular dynamics and well-tempered Metadynamics
 simulations. Results allowed computing the free energy surface and populations of
 stable states, providing a direct comparison between experiments. Ensemble averages
 computed from conformational ensembles closely match experimental results, providing
 a verified source of atomically detailed conformations for the HJH system. Analysis
 of ion distribution and base stacking was performed to understand their contributions
 to modulate the conformational states and the non-monotonic changes reported upon
 changes in ionic strength.

Title:
An Analysis of the Optical and Near-Infrared Variability of Super Fast X-Ray Transient
                                 IC 10 X-2
Abstract:
Two large flares of IC 10 X-2 were observed by Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF) in
 2018 that are of a comparable magnitude to a flare observed in October 2013. An analysis
 of the flare events is presented and constraints on the behavior of the system are
 proposed through an analysis of the light-curves in both g- and R-band from ZTF, as
 well as g', r', and i' data from Las Cumbres Observatory (LCO) in 2019. By analyzing
 the optical and near-infrared light curve alongside a color analysis of IC 10 X-2
 we conclude that the system is an HMXB with a relatively long period and little interaction
 between the massive star and its companion. We also determine the LBV to currently
 be in outburst.

Title: The Cosmic Ray Production of Supernova Remnant Kes 17
Abstract:
While supernova remnants are promising candidates for cosmic ray production, they
 must produce on average ∼10^{50} ergs of energetic particles to sufficiently account
 for the cosmic ray protons ≤ 3 PeV population. Moreover, supernova remnants that show
 direct observational evidence for proton accelerations to high energies are rare,
 and it is unclear under which circumstances remnants efficiently produce these particles.
 Kes 17 is a remnant that shows evidence of efficient particle accelerations. In this
 project, we analyze its γ-ray and X-ray spectra, with the goal of measuring the total
 energy of its cosmic ray population, spatial variations in the properties of the thermal-ray
 emitting plasma, and constraining any non-thermal X-ray emission. We found no evidence
 of non-thermal X-ray emission. The X-ray emitting plasma is out of thermal equilibrium
 suggesting that the remnant is young. The temperature profile shows that the mixed-morphology
 of Kes 17 is caused by the thermal conduction scenario. Thermal conduction requires
 that Kes 17 is 2700 to 5900 years old, consistent with the global X-ray spectrum.
 The spatial spectral variations suggest that Kes 17 is in a complex environment. In
 addition, we found recombination continua in the South-East, indicating that the plasma
 there is overionized.

Title: Low Mass X-Ray Binary Outbursts
Abstract:
A low mass X-ray binary (LMXBs) is made up of a regular star and a neutron star/blackhole.
 When the accretion disc of the system becomes unstable, an outburst takes place, resulting
 in the emission of X-rays. For the first part of the project, an alert system- using
 Python scripts- was created. This system detects the LMXB outbursts in real time.
 It also sends email alerts whenever there is interesting activity taking place in
 a LMXB. For the second part, a specific black hole system- SWIFT J1910.2-0546- was
 studied. This binary system has an unusual extreme flaring which was previously unknown.
 I wrote Astronomer's Telegrams to notify the community of interesting behavior in
 order to get multiwavelength data on the objects. Then, X-ray-optical correlations
 and color magnitude diagrams of SWIFT J1910.2-0546 were plotted to deduce the temperature
 and behavior of the object. Based on the results, the flickering behavior and temperature
 changes indicate waves of ionization of hydrogen. This is probably due to the star
 heating up and dumping more matter onto the disc, increasing the mass accretion rate
 temporarily.

Title: Plucking the Web: Searching for Spider Pulsars Using a Jerk Search Algorithm
Abstract:
Searches for pulsars in the error boxes of gamma-ray sources identified by the Fermi
 Mission have been immensely successful in the past decade. However, 1000s of gamma-ray
 sources still remain unassociated with any astrophysical object. It is believed that
 many of these could be millisecond pulsars (MSPs). One reason for their non-detection
 is that acceleration searches used to account for the orbital motion of the pulsar
 are only effective when the observation time is less than 1/10th of the orbital period.
 We have been using the novel jerk search algorithm implemented in the PRESTO software
 package to re-search Fermi sources that remain unidentified. Jerk search is sensitive
 to changes in the period of the pulsed signal up to its second derivative caused by
 the orbital motion, resulting in increased sensitivity to tight binary systems. Searching
 radio data gathered from the Green Bank Telescope at 820 MHz for unassociated Fermi
 sources, we have discovered 4 MSPs, one of which has been confirmed to be a tight-binary
 system belonging to the Black Widow class of pulsars.

Title: Molecular Conformation In Crowded Media
Abstract:
Macromolecular crowding is known to have several effects on the bio-molecular properties,
 and can therefore lead to their cellular function diverging from that in dilute in
 vitro experiments. In this work, we use a simple system which consists of a crowder
 and a molecule of interest consisting of single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) to investigate
 how the size of the molecule changes with crowding. We find that depending on its
 length, ssDNA can behave in two completely opposite manners: either compressing or
 expanding under the influence of crowding. The later part of this work outlines an
 attempt to explain this behavior, considering the impact of the statistical conformation
 of different ssDNA lengths as the main factor that is responsible for this behaviour.

Title: Multilayer Dielectric Haloscope for Dark Photon Detections
Abstract:
Non-thermal production mechanisms could generate light bosonic dark matter (DM) particles.
 Such DM candidates, the dark photons (DP), would interact with the standard model
 (SM) matter via the kinetic mixing parameter. Dielectric haloscopes, which consist
 of thin dielectric layers with alternating high and low refractive indices, can convert
 dark photons into SM photons when the DM Compton wavelength matches the periodicity
 of the target. For this capstone project, we developed an SiO2/Si3N4 dielectric haloscope
 coupled with a single photon detector for the detection of dark photons. We optimized
 the dielectric stack so that the DP-SM photon conversion would be maximum at 809 nm
 and explored different stack configurations to enable conversion over a wider range
 of masses around 1.5 eV. The optimization was done analytically using the transfer
 matrix formalism. We also obtained an upper limit at 90% confidence level on the dark
 photon-SM photon kinetic mixing parameter under different estimates of background
 rates. In the experimental setup, we use a single-photon avalanche diode as our photosensor
 and collect counts from the sensor with and without the stack to obtain test statistics
 for the upper limit.

Title:
Physics in the Service of History: An Interdisciplinary Project Between Physics and
                                 Archaeology
Abstract:
This interdisciplinary joint project between the departments of Physics and History
 centres around the development improvement of a scanning macro x-ray fluorescence
 spectrometer and its application in the study of archaeological and art-historical
 artifacts. Specifically, two new detectors were implemented so as to drastically increase
 the quality of the measurements along with a novel heat management system based around
 a gyroidal 3D printed steel heat sink. Furthermore, helium-injection functionality
 was designed and implemented to markedly lower the elemental detection threshold of
 the device. The device was applied (in combination with a host of complementary analytical
 techniques) in studing metallurgical slag samples from the Central Asian steppe and
 the nature of the processes which gave rise to them were conclusively determined.
 Working in collaboration with the Louvre Abu Dhabi, an ancient Egyptian Funerary portrait
 in their collection was extensively characterised using the instrument as part of
 the international APPEAR Project.

Title: Prototype Field Deployable Environmental Background Radiation Monitoring Station
Abstract:
According to an investigation conducted by the United Nations Scientific Committee
 on the Effects of Atomic Radiation in 1993, 80% of all radiation received by the human
 population on Earth is from natural radiation sources. There are only a handful of
 studies and detector networks dedicated to the collection of background radiation
 spectra and subsequent correlation with weather and environmental phenomenon. This
 paper describes the process of refurbishing and re-deploying a gamma spectrometer
 on campus grounds for constant and accurate energy spectrum collection to allow for
 statistical analysis and correlation with environmental data such as rainstorms and
 lunar cycles.

Title:
Investigating the State of Conservation of Ancient Mummies and Bones Using Mobile
                                 NMR and CT
Abstract:
The aim of this project was to assess the state of conservation of a set of ancient
 mummies and bones by examining their proton depth profiles, acquired using mobile
 NMR. This was achieved by performing CPMG experiments on the samples, and using the
 T2 decay curves in order to arrive at a measure of proton density. For the skulls,
 it was found the skulls of the frozen mummies were particularly well-conserved. On
 the other hand, the tibia of Charlemagne and the left B16 tibia were found to be the
 best-conserved among the samples under consideration. The secondary aim was to determine
 whether the same information about the structural integrity of the bones could be
 ascertained from CT and mobile NMR. This was achieved by acquiring cross-sectional
 CT scans of the samples at the same locations where NMR measurements were made, and
 comparing the two. It was found that the two techniques do result in the same information
 about the proton density and consequently, the state of conservation. Considering
 the limitations of CT, mobile NMR was concluded to be a viable instrument to replace
 CT for cultural heritage purposes.

Title: Radio Quiet AGN in the North Ecliptic Pole
Abstract:
We present initial results from the 4.8 GHz VLBA radio survey of the North Ecliptic
 Pole (NEP) deep field. An analysis of 12 VLBA sources with their IR counterparts shows
 a correlation between the radio/IR emissions and the physical properties of the AGN
 and their host galaxies. A ratio of 1to1 VLBA to JVLA flux densities indicates a compact
 source (parsec scale) produced the detected radio emission. Brightness temperatures
 (TB > 10^5 K) confirm an AGN is the main source of this emission. VLBA flux density
 lower than the JVLA flux density indicates the radio emission is distributed across
 the galaxy, in the kpc scale. These predictions agree with the IR colors classification
 of the WISE counterparts.

Author(s): Al Neyadi, Layla Mohamed Sultan Mohamed
Title:
Cross-Cultural Perceptions of the Hijab: How Middle Easterners and Westerners Respond
                                 to Veiled Women
Abstract:
Major: Psychology Abstract: Numerous qualitative studies have investigated why Middle Eastern women
 may choose to veil. The work suggests that many women veil for reasons other than
 religious obligation. Some of their reasons include veiling as a means to protect
 their individuality and sense of agency, a claim in direct conflict with Western stereotypes
 of veiling as an oppressive and objectifying practice. Do these reports signal important cross-­‐cultural
 differences in a perceivers' spontaneous responses to veiled women? To address this
 issue, the current investigation explored the rapid objectification of veiled and
 unveiled women by Middle Eastern and Western perceivers, using two standard measures
 of implicit associations. While the results did not provide evidence of objectification,
 they signaled the dehumanization of veiled women across cultures. Both Middle Eastern
 and Western perceivers considered women who veiled as less human than non-­‐veiling
 women. In addition, Middle Easterners also dehumanized women more than Westerners,
 regardless of their headgear. A second task, however, did not support these conclusions,
 potentially due to poor test validity. The obtained results provide tentative evidence
 for cross-­‐cultural consistency as well as divergence regarding the perception of
 (veiled) women.

Title:
Intergroup Contact and its Effect on Social Identification: The Case of Filipina Workers
                                 in the UAE
Abstract:
Major: Psychology, Visual Arts Abstract: The possible effects of contact, relative to the interactions according
 to location, have been examined on group-based identities of Filipina women in Abu
 Dhabi and Manila. The study shows significant relationship between the increase ingroup
 national and religious identification with Filipinas and the increase in identification
 with Arabs in the host community, Abu Dhabi. However, the same relationship does not
 exist with Filipinas working in Manila. Although we do not measure contact directly,
 the results points to the possible influence of contact with outgroup members that
 can be explored in future studies.

Title: Culture-Dependent Internal Face Processing
Abstract:
Major: Psychology Abstract: Decades of research on face recognition with Western observers suggest that
 during the processing of unfamiliar faces perceivers rely more strongly on external
 facial features (e.g., hair and face outline) than internal facial features (e.g.,
 eyes and nose). Recent evidence indicates, however, that this processing preference
 may be culture-dependent. Egyptian perceivers, for instance, show the opposite face
 processing pattern; an effect argued to reflect their frequent exposure to faces void
 of external facial features (i.e., female faces covered by headscarves). To further
 examine this claim, spontaneous recognition accuracy for internal facial features
 was assessed, using a standard part-whole face recognition task, in Western perceivers
 living in New York and Middle Eastern perceivers living in Abu Dhabi. Accuracy scores
 were submitted to a 2 (perceiver culture: Western vs. Middle Eastern) x 2 (target
 face race: Caucasian vs. Arab) x 2 (face probe: part vs. whole) mixed measures analysis
 of variance. As predicted, Middle Eastern perceivers outperformed Westerners with
 regard to recognition accuracy. Merely on trials that required recognizing isolated
 face parts of Caucasian faces, both groups of perceivers performed equally well. Importantly,
 Middle Easterners also reported higher exposure to covered faces in everyday life
 than Westerners. In combination, these findings provide evidence that culture-specific
 face environments can impact basic aspects of face recognition.

Title: Processing Code Switch in Highly Proficient Korean-English Bilinguals
Abstract:
Major: Psychology Abstract: Code switching is a cognitive aspect of bilingualism. Code switching has
 been linked to a processing cost, with the inhibitory mechanism in language selection
 leading to an asymmetrical switching cost in low proficiency bilinguals, but a symmetrical
 cost in high proficiency bilinguals. Given the limited literature on intra-sentential
 code switching that high proficiency bilinguals have been reported to do, as well
 as on bilinguals of genealogically distinct languages, this study used the self-paced
 reading paradigm to investigate the presence, extent, and symmetry of a switching
 cost in highly proficient Korean-English bilinguals. The results showed that there
 was no overall switching cost, but instead a marginal advantage when switching from
 Korean to English. Because there was no switching cost, there was no symmetry or asymmetry
 to be interpreted in light of the inhibitory mechanism.

Title: Auditory Speech Priming as a Means of Exploring Linguistic Storage Mechanisms
Abstract:
Major: PsychologyAbstract: This paper examines theories of lexical access, particularly regarding morphological
 decomposition of spoken words. Two competing theories of lexical access, William
 Marslen-Wilson's Cohort theory, and James McClelland's and Jeffrey Elman's TRACE model,
 differ mainly in their treatment of phonology in lexical access. Marslen-Wilson (1994)
 has also posited that morphemes are the most basic unit of lexical storage. To test
 these, and other more recent models, we used a subliminal auditory speech priming
 method designed by Kouider and Dupoux (2005) to determine the roles of phonology,
 morphology, meaning, and lexicality is lexical access. We find no effect of morphology,
 and posit that lexical processing, beyond determining whether an utterance is a word,
 requires that utterances enter consciousness before unconscious parsing can take place.
 We also find an inhibitory effect of pseudowords, which suggests that lexical access
 is not a serial process and that familiarity with words may also play a role in processing.

Title:
Examining the relationship between motivation and aspiration: The effect of home and
                                 school environment on educational aspirations
Abstract:
Major: PsychologyAbstract: Previous studies demonstrated a relationship between motivation and aspirations
 in school-aged children (Mertens, 2012), the present study reveals the intricacies
 in this relationship. This study examines the effect of manipulating motivation on
 students' educational aspirations. Participants were 169 students in 5th, 7th, and
 9th grade from schools in Chennai, India who completed a questionnaire that included
 two conditions: positive outcome focus (i.e., reaching the goal) and negative outcome
 focus (i.e., failing to reach the goal). After the manipulation, students reported
 their predicted performance levels during and after the school year. The results support
 our hypothesis of motivation having an effect on aspiration where students in the
 positive outcome focus condition reported having higher short-term and long-term aspirations.
 Our results also showed an interaction effect between motivation and perceived student
 support. Students who reported having low perceived student support had significantly
 higher short-term aspirations in the positive outcome focus condition than students
 in the negative outcome focus condition. The results might help school counselors
 and teachers to increase the motivation of students in secondary schools and therefore,
 increase their aspirations.

Title: Comprehension of Verbal Negation in Early Childhood as a Cue to Logical Inferences
Abstract:
English-learning infants were shown to have "no" in their active vocabulary for almost
 a year before they understand it as truth functional negation (e.g. Feiman et. al,
 under review). The present study investigated three hypotheses concerning the acquisition
 of truth functional negation cross-linguistically: 1) a conceptual shift is required;
 2a) it is dependent on mastering sentence structure; 2b) negation is hard for children
 because of its conceptual and linguistic complexity. Experiment 1 compared Hungarian
 20-month-olds' understanding of "nem" ( "no/not") and English-learning 20- and 24-month-olds'
 understanding of "no/not" through a search task. While English-learning 20-month-olds
 ignored the negative operator in negative trials, their Hungarian peers and American
 24-month-olds were marginally above chance and performed better not only on negative
 but also on affirmative trials. Experiment 2 compared 18-month-old English- and Hungarian-learners'
 comprehension of nonexistence ("all gone"/"nincsen") through a task devised by Szabo
 and Kovacs (in preparation). While Hungarian infants performed better on the task,
 both groups' performance was above chance on the first test trial and overall. Results
 from experiment 1 and 2 suggest that Hungarian-learners are developmentally ahead
 of their English-learning peers on the comprehension of both affirmation and negation,
 ruling out hypothesis 1) and supporting hypothesis 2a).

Title: Cross-Cultural Differences in the Perception of Facial Trustworthiness
Abstract:
Previous research has shown that people habitually extract social information from
 faces. Yet, conflicting findings regarding cross-cultural consensus in face-based
 personality judgments have been reported in the literature. Using a reverse correlation
 task, the current study asked American and Emirati participants to make trustworthiness
 judgments in response to Arab and White faces. Results were analyzed using both quantitative
 and qualitative methods. A quantitative analysis of agreement rates within and across
 perceiver groups is suggestive of a perceiver culture by face race interaction. Furthermore,
 a qualitative inspection of composite faces based on participants' trustworthiness
 judgments revealed evidence in favor of both a main effect of perceiver culture as
 well as a perceiver culture by face race interaction. The findings add to a growing
 body of work that challenges the notion of high cross-cultural consensus in face-based
 personality judgments.

Title: Academic Achievement Motivation in the Context of Tertiary Education
Abstract:
The study investigated similarities and differences in academic achievement motivation
 of students (N = 503) from three different contexts of tertiary education. The study
 examined how motivation to learn, future-oriented motivation and emotional component
 of motivation varies across public/private and local/international educational setting,
 gender and experimentally induced cognitive mindsets. Participants were randomly assigned
 to four conditions for the experimental mindset induction. Afterwards all participants
 responded to questionnaires about academic motivation. Female students in a local
 public setting scored significantly higher on emotional component of motivation than
 the male students. Furthermore, the female students in the deliberative mindset condition
 scored significantly higher on emotional component of motivation than the female students
 in neutral mindset condition and control group. The analysis of motivation to learn
 and future-oriented motivation revealed a consistent pattern of results, where the
 students from the local public setting differed significantly from the students from
 the local private and the international private settings. Main effects of gender showed
 that overall female students displayed higher motivation to learn, while male students
 scored higher on future-oriented motivation. The findings have implications for helping
 educators improve academic motivation of the students.

Title: The effects of dopaminergic modulation on the stability of working memory representation
Abstract:
Working Memory (WM), the temporary retention of information that was just experienced
 or just retrieved from long-term memory is thought to underlie goal-directed behavior.
 WM relies heavily on the prefrontal cortex (PFC), and specifically dopaminergic input
 to the PFC. Studies employing distractor stimulus in the delay period of WM tasks
 have indicated that the memory of the target stimulus can be corrupted by such distractors.
 The mediation of distracting effects may involve the PFC and the dopaminergic system.
 The aim of this research project is to quantify the effects of physiologically realistic
 dopamine modulation (via manipulations of reward) on the behavioral and neural effects
 of distraction during WM using behavioral modeling and magnetoencephalography (MEG).

Title: Does our trust of other races change with exposure?
Abstract:
We make automatic judgements about the trustworthiness of an individual based on the
 appearance of their face. These trustworthiness judgements are important because they
 guide our decisions, such as approaching or avoiding an individual. Some research
 has been conducted on trustworthiness judgements made across racial groups. This research
 has found that raters of the same-race as a target face make significantly different
 trustworthiness judgements than other-race raters. This research has also suggested
 the differences in judgements could be due to experience with other races, but this
 has not been measured. In my research I will control for the experience of raters
 with other-races. I hypothesize that increased experience will strengthen the correlations
 of the trustworthiness judgements made by same-race and other-race raters.

Title:
The interaction of the visual properties of logos: How font and shape influence preference
                                 and attention
Abstract:
We constantly perceive many types of visual stimuli that may attract our attention
 and influence the way we interact with the environment. Several critical categories
 that tend to attract attention include texts and shapes. Research conducted independently
 on word and shape processing has revealed that distinct regions in the ventral visual
 stream are more responsive to words or shapes, respectively. However, visual elements
 in the world do not appear alone, and the processing of various information must be
 combined to form a coherent percept. This study investigated how visual information
 from shapes and texts interact with each other to influence preference and attention
 towards novel company logos which consisted of a shape and a word. We manipulated
 the properties of the shapes and words (preferred or disliked shapes or font as rated
 in a pilot study) to determine what kinds of visual properties were more influential
 in affecting participant's preference. Furthermore, to investigate whether visual
 preference towards certain stimulus properties might influence visual attention allocation,
 we recorded eye movements to the logo components. This data examined regarded first
 fixations, first fixation duration, total number of fixations, and total dwell time.

Title:
The Effect of Diversity of Subordinates' Need for Closure and Willingness to Comply
                                 with Power Tactics
Abstract:
Diversity is progressively becoming ubiquitous in the workplace. Although it has been
 touted as a business advantage fostering creativity and innovation (Rizy, Feil, Sniderman,
 and Egan, 2011), research has skirted how diversity may impact supervisor-subordinate
 interactions. Based on prior work, we hypothesized that diversity increases people's
 need for closure and thus impacts their willingness to comply with their supervisors'
 soft and harsh power tactics in the workplace. To test for this hypothesis, we conducted
 an experiment manipulating perceived diversity and measuring diversity salience, need
 for closure and willingness to comply with social power tactics. We found a significant
 indirect effect of perceived diversity on willingness to comply with harsh power tactics
 through need for closure. No indirect effect was found on people's willingness to
 comply with soft power tactics. This research contributes to our understanding of
 diversity in the workplace and its influence on supervisor-subordinate interactions.
 Implications for management are discussed.

Title:
Do Different Types of Script Induce Differences in Hemispheric Lateralization During
                                 Reading? Evidence from a Cross Linguistic MEG Study
Abstract:
There is a debate about the mechanism behind the hemispheric specialization for M170
 response. The left lateralization effect commonly found in alphabetical reading has
 been attributed either to the process of mapping the pronunciation to words (sound
 mapping hypothesis), or to an expertise acquired in the visual domain (familiarity
 hypothesis). We tested these two hypotheses using a cross-linguistic design comparing
 the reading of Chinese with English. To isolate any script difference from the language
 difference, we used Pinyin, an auxiliary alphabetic system for transliterating Chinese
 words into the Latin script. Moreover, we also recruited a group of English Chinese
 learner. Chinese readers reading Chinese characters exhibited a trend towards left
 lateralization, which was not statistically significant. A left lateralized response
 was obtained for both the English group and the learner group during Pinyin reading,
 but not during Chinese reading. In addition, the Chinese group showed the same trend
 for left lateralization during Pinyin reading, but it was not statistically significant.
 Overall, the results were more aligned with the predictions of the sound mapping hypothesis,
 but we discuss the limitations of the study in terms of statistical power, and the
 ways which the conclusion could be reversed.

Title:
Don't let your emotions get the better of you: The Relationship Between Passion, Emotions
                                 and Cognitive Performance
Abstract:
Passion is commonly understood as a strong inclination toward a self-defining activity
 that is highly valued and to which a considerable amount of time and effort is directed
 (Vallerand et al., 2003). The present research investigated the relationship between
 passion for academics, emotions, and cognitive performance. Results indicated that
 students with an obsessive passion – a strong internal pressure to engage in the activity
 — experienced high levels of negative emotions while taking a cognitive test, which
 impaired their cognitive performance. Students with a harmonious passion — a strong
 desire to freely engage in the activity — experienced low level of negative emotions,
 which facilitated their cognitive performance. Implications for positive psychology
 and educational interventions are discussed in the way in which positive psychology
 elements reduce negative emotions for harmonious passion, and improve cognitive performance.
 The promotion of these positive psychology elements can be done through school environments
 and classroom activities.

Title: Interpersonal Consequences of Self-Sacrifice
Abstract:
Significant research has been devoted to understanding the personal motivations of
 ideological activists. This study, however, focuses on group dynamics by investigating
 how the behavior of one activist impacts the actions of other ingroup members. We
 hypothesized a positive relationship between one individual's self-sacrifice and the
 willingness of other group members to make similar sacrifices. Specifically, we predicted
 that costly (vs. non-costly) sacrifices by a fellow environmentalist would increase
 people's admiration for that person, which in turn would lead to greater identity
 fusion with the group and increase people's willingness to fight and die for the environmental
 cause. Results supported our hypotheses. Implications for future psychological research
 on ideological groups, as well as for terrorism and counterterrorism studies, are
 discussed.

Title:
With a Little Help from My Friends! : Effects of Social Support and Cultural Orientation
                                 on the Formation of Narrative Identity
Abstract:
As born story-tellers, we are constantly engaging in the process of creating autobiographical
 memories, i.e. our memory for specific life events in the past with a high level of
 personal significance. In the following study, we hypothesized that seeking out social
 support during such impactful life events can predict positive perceptions of said
 events. We also hypothesized that participants identifying as relatively more individualistic
 would make more negative self-event connections due perceived low quality of social
 support. Our participants included 180 undergraduate students from New York University
 Abu Dhabi and Western Washington University representing 7 ethnicities. We used 3
 types of personal narratives and 2 questionnaires—the MSPSS and the RIC scales—to
 collect data. Results showed that participants indicating higher levels of seeking
 social support during impactful life events did indeed make more positive self-event
 connections and participants identifying with an individualistic cultural self-aspect
 made more negative self-event connections. Significant gender effects were also found.
 Social support is an essential part of the human experience and this research was
 done in hopes of strengthening the scientific foundations on which we can build these
 arguments.

Title: Do Attention And Visual Working Memory Share A Common Search Template?
Abstract:
Our ability to selectively decide on and search for a specific item in space is made
 possible through the interaction of two cognitive processes; attention and working
 memory. Recent literature has proposed that the two processes may be interdependent.
 Studies have shown that the template used during visual search is maintained and influenced
 by the contents of visual working memory (VWM). This study used a task that combines
 memory and search demands for a single target item. Depending on the type of trial,
 participants were asked to either search for the stored item amongst similar distractors,
 or to adjust a sample line to match the orientation of the stored item. Previous research
 has shown that explicit knowledge about the context an item will appear in can modulate
 search away from expected distractor items to improve performance. Based on these
 assumptions, if the search template and VWM representation rely on a single template,
 then adjustment away from the context in a search task will bias the representation
 of the item in working memory in the same direction. These findings suggest that the
 two tasks do not exclusively draw on a common, single template.

Title: Now You See It, Now You Don't: Effects of Interference on Unconscious Working Memory
Abstract:
Working memory (WM) is traditionally considered to be a conscious process during which
 information is currently being used. It is where information is held while we complete
 a task, or recollect an old memory. Recently, studies have shown that it is possible
 to maintain information in working memory even in the absence of conscious awareness.
 This means visual information from the environment may be processed without the awareness
 of the individual and we can also process them in the presence of distractors which
 require attentional resources. This study consists of three spatial WM tasks which
 aim to understand the limits on unconscious WM by testing the effect of interference,
 and compare these effects to the effects on conscious WM. We predicted an attractive
 effect of participants' responses to the object of interference in each experiment.
 As such, we found that there was a trend in attraction of the participants' responses
 towards the position of the presented sample on the current trial due to proactive
 interference, and also a trend in attraction of responses towards the location of
 the distractor due to retroactive interference. However, there was no significant
 difference between unconscious and conscious WM for the different tasks.

Title: Cultural Differences in Mothers' Visual Attention During Mother-Child Play
Abstract:
Mothers' visual attention plays a large role in in children's interactions during
 early development. Using two samples of mothers from India (n=34) and Germany (n=34),
 this paper explores the distribution of maternal visual attention during mother-child
 play. The study will tackle two research questions: (1) Is mothers' visual attention
 consistent in frequency across different types of play? And (2) are there cultural
 differences in German and Indian mothers' visual attention during free or structured
 play? For the first question, it was hypothesized that mothers direct their visual
 attention more at the child in free than structured play, and more at the object in
 structured than free play. For the second question, it was hypothesized that Indian
 mothers look more at the child than German mothers, while German mothers look more
 at the object. Results supported the first hypothesis, but provided no support for
 the second hypothesis as there was an insignificant interactional effect of type of
 play and culture. Culture showed a significant main effect on maternal visual attention.
 Implications and limitations are discussed.

Title:
Investigating Early Lexical Processing Using Script Changes: Evidence from Arabic
                                 and Arabish
Abstract:
In language experiments, priming, particularly in conjunction with the lexical decision
 task, has assumed access to the mental lexicon. However, this assumption has been
 challenged by findings of priming effects for pseudowords, and some researchers suggest
 that pseudoword priming is mediated by different underlying mechanisms which may be
 found using high-temporal resolution neurimaging techniques. The present study is
 based on Almeida and Poeppel (2013) found similar behavioral priming for words and
 pseudowords, but different electrophysiological responses. We designed an EEG lexical
 decision experiment using words and pseudowords written in Arabic and Arabish, expecting
 N400 priming responses and a word- and orthography-specific P2 response. We found
 robust behavioral priming for both words and pseudowords, but EEG results were generally
 not significant. Limitations are discussed.

Title:
The Relationship between Traditional Gender Role Attitudes and Acceptance of Different
                                 Types of Lesbian Relationships in China
Abstract:
The study investigated the relationship between traditional gender role attitudes
 and people's acceptance of different types of lesbian relationships in China. Specifically,
 I looked at how participants' endorsement of either hostile sexism or benevolent sexism
 is related to their acceptance of four types of lesbian relationships in China. Chinese
 undergraduate students from Sichuan province (N=550) filled out an online survey.
 I found a main effect of benevolent sexism, gender, and type of lesbian relationship
 on people's acceptance of lesbian relationships. The results showed that 1) acceptance
 of lesbian relationships in general was negatively associated with endorsement of
 benevolent sexism, but not hostile sexism, 2) compared to men, women overall found
 lesbian relationships more acceptable, 3) lesbian relationships with a masculine lesbian
 and a feminine lesbian were the most acceptable, and lesbian relationships with both
 masculine lesbians were the least acceptable among the four types of relationships.
 The results suggested that it is important to differentiate between men and women'
 attitudes, as well as between different types of lesbians or lesbian relationships.
 It also highlights the importance of studying gay men and lesbians not only as individuals,
 but also in relationships.

Title:
Examining the Lasting Effects of Daycare on Attachment Security: An 18-Year Prospective
                                 Longitudinal Study
Abstract:
Early childhood experiences are crucial when it comes to developing attachment representations
 with primary caregivers. Although attachment theory addresses a universal aspect of
 human development, many of its properties go unstudied. The goal of this study is
 to address the gap in literature by examining the enduring effects of early daycare
 experiences on attachment in adolescence. Thus, this study further investigates a
 subsample (N = 673) of the NICHD Study of Early Child Care and Youth Development (SECCYD)
 cohort. This study examines the associations between early daycare experiences (i.e.
 quality and quantity) and attachment security (i.e. secure base script knowledge)
 at age 18 years. It was hypothesized that there would be a significant association
 between quality and quantity of care on secure base script knowledge in adolescence,
 such that higher quality care would result in positive developmental outcomes. Results
 indicated a small association between daycare quality and attachment security at age
 18 years, but this effect did not hold when accounting for critical demographic and
 caregiving variables (i.e. maternal and paternal sensitivity). These results suggest
 that early daycare experiences are transient, leaving no significant effects on attachment
 in adolescence.

Title: Investigating the Effect of Bilingual Education in the United Arab Emirates on Emiratis
Abstract:
Modern Standard Arabic (MSA) has been traditionally used in the educational setting
 in the Arabic-speaking world, while local dialects of Arabic are used in daily informal
 settings, including in the United Arab Emirates. However, English-medium education
 is becoming increasingly more popular in the UAE among the Emirati population. We
 conducted a survey to investigate how the effective competition between MSA-medium
 versus English-medium education in the UAE affects the construction of Emirati identity
 in nationals and their linguistic attitudes towards MSA, Emirati Arabic and English.
 Results indicated that Emiratis educated primarily in private English-medium schools
 reported a negative attitude towards MSA, but a positive view of both Emirati and
 English. Emiratis educated in MSA-medium public schools reported a positive attitude
 towards MSA and Emirati. Daily Emirati usage and promotion of Emirati Arabic in the
 public and private spheres were considered important to all participants, including
 in the construction of their personal identity. Similar positive attitudes towards
 MSA, however, were highly correlated with the amount of MSA-medium schooling participants
 had, with primarily English-medium graduates reporting only a positive attitude towards
 Emirati, not MSA.

Title:
Backlash Against Equality: How Threats to the Gender Hierarchy Affect Attitudes Toward
                                 Reproductive Freedom and Violence Against Women
Abstract:
Desire to preserve the traditional gender hierarchy is linked to beliefs that women
 should be controlled non-violently (i.e., giving men more control over women's reproductive
 rights) and violently (rape myth acceptance and minimization of severity of sexual
 and physical violence). Study 1 (N=199) found that hostile sexism (HS; which assesses
 negative attitudes towards non-traditional women) is positively associated with both
 non-violent and violent forms of control, above and beyond general attitudes toward
 abortion. Study 2 (N=1178), participants read a paragraph depicting the gender hierarchy
 as "stable" (men hold more power than women), "changed" (women already achieved equality),
 or "changing" (women currently in the process of advancement towards bridging the
 gender gap). Results showed that when the gender hierarchy is perceived to be changing
 (vs. stable or already changed), people were higher on rape myth endorsement, especially
 those high on HS. Both studies unexpectedly showed that the biggest predictor of rape
 acceptance and partner violence was attitudes about abortion access (people who opposed
 abortion were more likely to minimize violence).

Title:
A Cross-National Investigation of the Relationship Between Sexism and Attitudes Towards
                                 Gay Men and Transwomen
Abstract:
Non-heterosexual and transgender people are usually the target of discrimination and
 violence. Past research, which has primarily focused on Western samples, has found
 that sexism is associated with negative attitudes toward sexual minorities. In the
 current work, I used data from 23 countries and compared attitudes toward sexual minorities
 between Western and non-Western countries. Attitudes towards gay men and transgender
 women were highly correlated. People in Western countries report more positive attitudes
 toward gay men than transwomen, while the opposite is true for people in non-Western
 countries. Overall, people in Western-countries have more positive attitudes than
 in non-West. Women tend to have more positive attitudes than men towards both gay
 men and transwomen. There is negative, significant correlation between both hostile
 sexism and benevolent sexism and liking of gay men and transgender women in Western
 countries. However, in non-Western countries only hostile sexism has positive, significant
 correlation with attitudes. I also tested whether gender moderates the relationship
 between sexism and attitudes. Only in Western countries, benevolent sexism was better
 predictor of women's attitudes towards transwomen than it was for men.

Title: The Effect of Implicit Racial Bias on Recognition of Own- Versus Other- Race Faces
Abstract:
Recognition of own- and other- race faces might be modulated by observers' face recognition
 ability, social experience, and implicit social biases. Caucasian participants (N=53)
 completed a memory task for Caucasian and Asian faces, an implicit association test,
 a questionnaire on social experience towards Caucasians and Asians, and a face recognition
 ability test (Cambridge Face Memory Test). During the memory task, eye-tracking was
 used to track participants' eye movements. The memory performance for own-race faces
 was positively predicted by increased face recognition ability only, whereas the memory
 performance for other-race faces were positively predicted by increased face recognition
 ability, social experience with Asians, and negatively predicted by increased positive
 bias towards Asians, which was modulated by an interaction between face recognition
 ability and implicit biases with the effect of bias observed only in observers with
 high face recognition ability. Eye tracking data revealed an interaction between race
 and fixation location. These findings suggest the complexity in understanding the
 perceptual and socio- cognitive influences on the other-race effect.

Title:
Teacher Stress and the Quality of Teacher-Child Interactions as Mediated by Teachers'
                                 Executive Functions
Abstract:
The present study explores the relationship between teachers' physiological and subjective
 stress and the quality of teacher-child interactions. The main objective was to investigate
 whether teachers' executive functions (EFs) mediate the relationship between teacher
 stress and the quality of teacher-child interactions. Participants were 53 kindergarten
 teachers (Mage = 39 years, SD = 10.87) recruited from 14 early childhood education
 (ECE) centers in Ukraine. Data was collected using self-report measures, saliva sampling
 and computer-based tasks. Results indicated that there were no significant associations
 between teacher stress and the quality of teacher-child interactions, nor were the
 prerequisites met for the association to be mediated by EFs. Significant positive
 associations were found between teachers' subjective stress and self-reported EFs,
 and between teaching experience and the quality of teacher-child interactions. Implications
 for study of teacher stress and the quality of teacher-child interactions in low-resource
 contexts are discussed.

Title:
Goal-Pursuit Across the Life-Span: Examining the Relationship between, Age, Autonomy,
                                 and Selectivity
Abstract:
Effective goal-pursuit has far-reaching implications across the life-span, yet a growing
 body of evidence suggests that people's strategies to attain their goal changes over
 time. The present study examined this topic by investigating the relationship between
 age and goal-pursuit strategies. We hypothesized that autonomy — feeling free to make
 decisions and to behave in ways that express one's true interests — may be the psychological
 mechanism explaining this relationship. A mediational study provided support for our
 hypotheses. Specifically, age was positively related to autonomy which in turn was
 positively associated with goal facilitation and negatively associated with goal interference.
 These results provide support for the growing claim that older adults are also subject
 to developmental gains.

Title:
The Influence of Early Childhood Attachment Quality on Secure Base Script Knowledge
                                 Development in Chinese Children
Abstract:
Attachment theory argues that the quality and consistency of parental sensitivity
 and responsiveness to their children is internalized as a mental representation of
 attachment relationships. Interestingly, all longitudinal studies on the development
 of attachment representations to date have been conducted in Western contexts. Leveraging
 data from a longitudinal study of child development in Nanjing, China, we conducted
 the first test of the hypothesized link between early caregiving and later development
 of attachment representations in a non-Western context. We analyzed data collected
 from subsample of an ongoing prospective longitudinal study of Chinese families (n
 = 78). Observations of mother-infant interactions were recorded when the infants were
 age 14 months. Attachment security was assessed at age 10 years using the attachment
 script assessment adapted to the Chinese context. Partial correlations revealed significant
 positive correlations between maternal sensitivity and maternal positive regard observed
 at age 14 months and secure base script knowledge at age 10 years. Maternal intrusiveness
 during play was not significantly related to secure base script development. Overall,
 results supported the culturally universal prediction from attachment theory that
 the quality of early caregiving impacts the development of a secure attachment in
 the child.

Title:
Mothers' goals and strategies for toddlers in gift reception across three cultural
                                 communities
Abstract:
The study investigates how mothers across three cultural communities describe goals
 and strategies for toddlers during gift reception, specifically with regard to their
 autonomy and relatedness. Mothers of two-year-old children from New York City, USA
 (n = 36), Chennai, India (n = 33), and Muenster, Germany (n = 36) participated in
 the study. The mothers' responses to a semi-structured interview were quantified by
 coding them into different types of autonomous goals, autonomous strategies, relatedness
 goals, and relatedness strategies using a coding manual. The majority of goals described
 by mothers were autonomy-focused, while the majority of strategies were relatedness-focused.
 Mothers differed significantly in their autonomy goals for their toddlers (F (2, 102)
 = 5.152, p = .007), and there was a marginal significant difference in their relatedness
 strategies (F (2, 102) = 2.621, p = .078). The findings highlight the coexistence
 of autonomy and relatedness-focused goals and strategies both within and between communities.

Title: Does Ensemble Perception Require Conscious Awareness?
Abstract:
Ensemble perception refers to the ability to extract summary statistics, such as averages
 and variances, from sets of stimuli with similar properties. A recent proposal implicates
 ensemble perception in visual phenomenology. However, a key assumption of this proposal
 – that ensemble perception can occur even in the absence of conscious awareness of
 the items in the ensemble – remains untested. To test this assumption, this study
 investigated whether ensemble perception of spatial location can occur unconsciously.
 In Experiments 1a and 1b, participants reported the average spatial location, or centroid,
 of ensembles of dots presented either within or beneath their threshold of conscious
 awareness; in Experiment 2, participants reported the spatial location of a single
 dot within the ensemble. We found that participants were able to accurately report
 the centroid of unconsciously-presented ensembles when the dots were clustered closely
 together, but when the dots were presented as two separate clusters, they appeared
 to report the centroid of a single cluster rather than the centroid of the entire
 ensemble. Furthermore, participants could not accurately report the location of individual
 dots within unconsciously-presented ensembles. Taken together, our results offer preliminary
 evidence that unconscious ensemble perception is possible, but limited.

Title: The Role of the Parahippocampal Cortex in Scene Integration
Abstract:
Humans perceive a coherent visual world across time and space. To update incoming
 sensory information while maintaining a stable representation of the environment,
 previous studies have suggested the role of the parahippocampal place area (PPA) in
 scene processing and ensemble processing. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging,
 we examined how the PPA might integrate information by relying on continuous spatial-temporal
 sequence of information flow, or mere shared elements in a scene. We used scene images
 that were divided into three segments, with 66% overlap between the first and second
 segments and 33% overlap between the first and the third segments. Participants viewed
 the three scene segments either sequentially or in a displaced order, identical segments
 for three times, or three completely different scenes. We found that the left and
 right PPA not only showed significantly stronger activations for different scenes
 than identical scenes, but also for different scenes than three segments originating
 from the same scene. Moreover, the sequence order of the three segments did not affect
 the response magnitude. These results suggest that although the PPA may not be sensitive
 to the sequence of information flow, it appears to integrate segments with shared
 elements to form a coherent representation.

Title: Automatic Post-Editing for Arabic to Japanese Machine Translation
Abstract:
Machine Translation research had made impressive improvements in the last two decades;
 however this success has not spread equally to all language pairs, with some language
 pairs receiving a lot more attention in terms of research, and resource and system
 development.Arabic-to-Japanese is a pair that has not received much attention.In this
 project, we present results from, and detailed linguistic analysis of the output of,
 an automatic post-editing system for Arabic-Japanese machine translation that exploits
 a corpus of Arabic-Japanese news articles. Our results improve over a very strong
 (but domain/genre agnostic) state-of-the-art system.

Title:
Objectification in Music Videos: The Impact of Sexualization and Infantilism on Attitudes
                                 about Sexual Violence Against Women
Abstract:
Media channels like music, television, and film can reinforce or challenge the status
 quo, and influence attitudes by virtue of what they portray. This study examines the
 impact of objectified portrayals of females in music videos on viewers' sexual beliefs,
 and the potential role of sexism as a moderator. Six-hundred Amazon MTurk participants
 were randomly assigned to view South Korean pop ("K-pop") music videos with sexual,
 infantile, or neutral depictions of women, after which they responded to questions
 assessing their acceptance of date rape and male sexual dominance. Exposure to sexualized
 and infantilized (vs. neutral) videos was found to decrease date rape condemnation
 and increase pro-male dominance beliefs at higher levels of benevolent and hostile
 sexism only for women. Experimental conditions had no effect on men's attitudes. However,
 for both men and women, benevolent and hostile sexism were positively correlated with
 acceptance of date rape and male sexual dominance. Implications for objectification
 theory, and media and sexual violence research are discussed.

Title: The Eﬀect of Various Perturbation Frequencies on Reaching Performance
Abstract:
We make decisions constantly, both consciously and unconsciously. In order to examine
 the strategy people use to cope with unexpected stimuli, we have used the method of
 perturbation. In the experiment, participants were required to reach for and touch
 the target in one of the two possible locations with their index ﬁngers. They were
 presented with either the unperturbed target or the perturbed target and when they
 were provided with the perturbed target, they were required to make online corrections
 in their movements to cope with the target jump. Our main focus was on the perturbation
 of frequency. In other words, we wanted to systematically examine how well people
 cope with the increasing perturbation frequency. Participants' responses were measured
 and recorded using a motion capture system. Data show that participants take the increasing
 proportion into account in the trajectory of their movements. As the perturbation
 frequency increased along with the progression of blocks, the initial direction moved
 more and more toward the perturbed target on the left, and for the perturbed trials,
 the participants made online corrections earlier on in the movement. This study is
 the ﬁrst to systematically provide increasing frequency of perturbation.

Title: Narrative Themes and Language Usage in the Dualistic Model of Passion
Abstract:
Passion is commonly defined as a strong inclination towards a self-defining and highly
 valued activity toward which an individual devotes considerable time and energy (Vallerand
