 et al., 2003). Vallerand's Dualistic Model of Passion (DMP) divides passion into the
 two distinct categories of harmonious passion – which involves an autonomous internalization
 of and engagement with one's passion – and obsessive passion – which involves a controlled
 internalization of and engagement with one's passion. The present research explores
 the relationship between passion and themes of narrative identity – i.e. a person's
 internalized and evolving life-story (McAdams, 1985)), especially with regard to the
 themes of agency, communion, redemption, and contamination (McAdams, 1996). Results
 revealed a strong positive correlation between harmonious passion and themes of communion.
 Obsessive passion was not significantly correlated with any narrative theme. In addition
 to discussing the implications of the relationship between harmonious passion and
 themes of communion, the present study provides a foundation for future research to
 investigate the applicability of qualitative analyses on psychological constructs
 like passion, which are usually studied quantitatively in social psychology.

Title:
Estimating working memory maintenance-related activation with functional magnetic
                                 resonance imaging
Abstract:
The working memory field (WM) is increasingly employing multivoxel pattern analysis
 (MVPA) techniques with functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to identify the
 neural correlates of WM maintenance. These techniques are used with the delay task,
 which consists of contiguous encoding, maintenance (or delay), and report epochs.
 WM MVPA analyses use estimates of the blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) response
 to the maintenance epoch of the delay task to determine whether different experimental
 conditions produce distinct patterns of activity due to differences in maintenance.
 However, because of the protracted nature of the hemodynamic response, these estimates
 can mistakenly capture the BOLD response to the encoding or report epochs, potentially
 producing false positive or false negative classification results down the line. Given
 the consequential nature of obtaining faithful estimates of delay activity, we evaluate
 and compare three different methods of estimating the delay response and identify
 which are optimal for WM MVPA studies. (Full abstract in Capstone paper.)

Title: The Effects of Mood & Language on the Prevalence of Antisocial Personality Traits
Abstract:
The present study was designed to examine the effects of mood (positive vs. negative)
 and language (Arabic vs. English) on the prevalence of antisocial personality traits
 in different individuals. The following hypotheses were produced: 1) When primed with
 the negative condition, participants in the English condition are likely to score
 higher on the MACH-IV scale than participants in the Arabic one, 2) When primed with
 the positive condition, participants in the Arabic condition are likely to score lower
 on the MACH-IV scale than those in the English one, and 3) Participants that received
 the positive manipulation will have a higher score on the items of the PANAS used
 to measure positive affect (PA), while participants that received the negative manipulation
 will have a higher score on the items of the PANAS used to measure negative affect
 (NA). Although results showed no statistical significance with the effects of prime
 and language on mood, there was an interesting causal relationship between the positive
 manipulation and mood. The study showed noteworthy implications of the effects of
 mood on the way people perceive the world around them.

Title: Attitudes toward Undocumented Immigrants: A Function of Perceived Reliance
Abstract:
This study measures U.S. citizens' attitudes toward immigrants and immigration policies.
 Immigrants and immigration incite strong, divided sentiments and opinions in the U.S.
 population. These sentiments and opinions correspond with and influence public policy
 and legislation in the U.S. and hence, it is important to examine them regularly in
 empirical studies to develop a better understanding of which factors affect them.
 I analyze data from a study in which participants were either reminded of American
 society's reliance on undocumented immigrants or its independence from themr. I find
 support for the hypothesis that making society's dependence on immigrants salient
 can reduce negative emotions and evaluations as well as decrease support for anti-immigrant
 policies and laws. However, the condition did not have a significant impact on increasing
 positive emotions toward undocumented immigrants. I also demonstrate that this effect
 is moderated by political conservatism, such that conservatives were more likely to
 express increased ratings of immigrants' competence and warmth, decreased support
 for hostile policies, and reduced negative emotions. Results were consistent with
 previous research findings on the effects of perceived interdependence on attitudes
 toward immigration.

Title: Self Regulation Ability in Kenyan Children and Academic Performance
Abstract:
The present study investigated the direct association between self-regulation and
 academic performance within a sample in Kenya. It also investigated the extent to
 which the student-teacher relationship and the home learning environment mediated
 the association between self-regulation and academic performance, after controlling
 for income, gender, age, parental education and non-verbal intelligence. The Tower
 of Hanoi was used as a measure of cognitive self-regulation and the researchers completed
 the PSRA Assessor Report Examiner Rating Scale after which measured for emotional
 self-regulation. The teachers completed the Child-Behavior Rating Scale (CBRS) and
 the Student-Teacher Relationship Scale (STRS), which measured for behavioral self-regulation
 and the student-teacher relationship construct, respectively. The parents provided
 information of the home learning environment by completing the StimQ PreSchool Assessment.
 The Hayes macro PROCESS was used to run the mediation analysis. Results indicated
 that behavioral and emotional self-regulation were significantly associated with academic
 performance in both mathematics and language. Overall, the study showcases an uncommon
 sample of Kenyan children, which eventually supports the importance and understanding
 of self- regulation and academic performance.

Title: Retrieval Noise Reduces Accuracy in Visual Working Memory
Abstract:
Visual working memory (VWM) is the ability to briefly store and manipulate information.
 This ability is important as it helps us to function in the constantly changing environment
 we live in. VWM capacity has long been under investigation. Its limitations occur
 from noise in three stages of processing: encoding, maintenance, and retrieval. In
 this paper, I focus on the retrieval noise of VWM. I created an analytical model to
 differentiate between the shared noise of encoding and maintenance and the retrieval
 noise. This model was first based on data generated by a computer simulation and then
 on behavioral measures obtained experimentally. For the purposes of the experiments,
 we created a new type of VWM task. It required participants to make multiple responses
 about the same target item instead of the commonly used single response. Data were
 collected from 32 participants in two different experiments. Results from applying
 the analysis model on the participants' data were not significant. Nevertheless, this
 is one of the few studies focusing on retrieval noise, and further research with large
 samples is needed.

Title: Manual Asymmetries in Grasping Movements Under Visual and Visuo-haptic Control
Abstract:
Visual input is typically used for the completion of grasping movements. However,
 the execution and planning of movements in everyday life is also aided by haptic information
 when objects are held by the other hand. We present a study investigating the sensorimotor
 integration process by exploring how hand dominance influences grasping behavior.
 We compare dominant and non-dominant hand grasping movements towards an object using
 visual or visuo-haptic information. This gives further insight on whether there is
 a preferred role of each hand in grasping or if there is a generic benefit of haptic
 information in grasping. There was no difference in kinematic data collected between
 the dominant and non-dominant hand in either condition, with the only exception being
 shorter duration in the initial segments of the movement when using the dominant hand.
 However, we also confirm the benefit of adding haptic signals to grasping movements
 to movement accuracy, as seen in the visuo-haptic condition. We therefore conclude
 that haptic information aids in grasping performance, and that the generic availability
 of additional sensorimotor signals aid in movement, as opposed to the role of specific
 hands.

Title: The Effects of Expertise and Word Valence on Holistic Word Processing
Abstract:
Holistic processing was initially studied as a face-specific phenomenon. Recent findings
 suggest that it could be tied to expertise. People are experts at word-processing,
 thus studying holistic word-processing became the new focus of this research. There,
 however, are further factors influencing this phenomenon. This study investigates
 the influence of expertise and emotional state on holistic processing. Participants
 were required to respond to four-letter Hungarian words. Congruent and incongruent
 word pairs were constructed, with the task-relevant and the task-irrelevant parts
 either aligned or misaligned. The factor of expertise was manipulated by recruiting
 native Hungarian and non-Hungarian speakers. We tested the effect of the emotional
 state by using words of positive and negative meaning. Both groups performed well
 in both valence conditions. We did not find the expected interaction between Alignment
 and Congruency. Congruency effect was present in both alignment conditions, which
 suggest obligatory processing. Valence affected the performance of novices only.

Title: Early Maladaptive Schemas and Adolescent Depression
Abstract:
Early maladaptive schemas (EMS) are self-defeating, emotional, and cognitive patterns
 established in childhood, that remain stable throughout life (Young, Klosko & Weishaar,
 2003). Existing research has hypothesized that EMS can be a risk factor (Stopa et
 al., 2001) or a vulnerability marker for depressive disorders (Dozois et al., 2009).
 In this paper, we use data from a longitudinal study to examine the stability of these
 maladaptive schemas across adolescent development. We examine whether EMS can reliably
 predict depressive symptoms in adolescence. Participants were administered the Young
 Schema Questionnaire – Short Form (YSQ-SF; Young, 1998; Brenning et al., 2012) with
 itemized categories to identify schema domains. This data was correlated with psychopathological
 information collected from a Child Depression Inventory (CDI; Kovacs, 2015; Timbremont
 & Braet, 2002) administered to the participants. The results indicate that EMS is
 stable across adolescence and early-onset EMS can be used as a reliable predictor
 of adolescent depression.

Title: Talking About Thoughts: Mothers Metacognition Across Play Contexts
Abstract:
Maternal metacognition encompasses mothers' beliefs and self-perceptions about their
 parenting which affects the quality of mother-toddler dyadic interactions. This study
 examined the types of metacognitive statements prevalent in mothers' metacognition
 across play contexts, their levels of complexity and the influence of mother and toddler
 characteristics on the consistency of the aforementioned features of metacognition
 across play contexts. During home visits, 36 U.S. American mother-toddler dyads were
 video-recorded during free-toy play, guided-educational play and a book-sharing activity,
 and mothers completed Retrospective Think-Aloud (RTA) interviews. In the absence of
 applied RTA data within parenting research, this study adapted the teacher professional
 vision framework (Seidel & Stuermer, 2011) to develop a coding manual investigating
 metacognitive complexity in RTA transcripts by classifying statements as Descriptions,
 Explanations or Predictions. Findings indicate that mothers metacognition may reflect
 the different demands of play interactions and thus, adjust to play contexts.

Title: Indirect Measures of Attitudes to Colloquial Dialects of Arabic
Abstract:
Linguistic prejudice gets less attention than other forms of prejudice and Arabic
 linguistic attitudes are even more understudied. For a long time, quantitative Arabic
 sociolinguistics compared attitudes to Modern Standard Arabic and the colloquial dialects;
 and occasionally compared attitudes to different dialects within a country. Recent
 qualitative studies have started to examine the hierarchy between Western and Eastern
 Arabic dialects, but the status differences between the Eastern Arabic dialects are
 underexplored and no quantitative analysis has been done on the topic. This paper
 presents an indirect quantitative measure of status and solidarity rating differences
 between Egyptian and Emirati Arabic, as perceived by Egyptians and Emiratis living
 in the UAE. Results suggest that the Egyptian dialect might be uniformly viewed higher
 both on status and solidarity measures, at least among young women, who constituted
 the majority of participants and were solely represented in the stimuli. Directions
 for future methodological improvements are proposed to increase the generalizability
 of indirect quantitative language attitude measures.

Title: Passion for an Activity: A New Predictor of Sleep Quality
Abstract:
Previous research has proposed a dualistic model of passion. This model distinguishes
 between two types of passion: harmonious versus obsessive. The difference between
 the two lies in how the individual's passionate activity is regulated with other life
 domains. A large body of research has provided evidence of an association between
 one's type of passion and their physical as well as mental well-being. However, no
 studies have looked into the potential relationship between passion and sleep, a vital
 component of overall well-being. The present study aimed to fill this gap by looking
 into how the way individuals engage in their passionate activities can affect their
 sleep quality and, consequently, their overall health. We hypothesized that individuals
 with high levels of obsessive passion will experience overall worse sleep quality
 compared to individuals with high levels of harmonious passion. We carried out multiple
 regression analyses to examine this relationship in a sample of 1,506 individuals
 who responded to our online survey, with the results confirming our hypothesis.

Title: The Effect of Case Marking on Agreement Attraction in Nepali
Abstract:
Some theories of agreement processing postulate that subject-verb agreement errors
 are resolved by a cue-based retrieval process in memory. According to these theories,
 the presence of a subject case-marker should decrease the rate of memory retrieval
 errors. The reason behind this predicted decrease is that case-marking would provide
 another retrieval cue to match or mismatch the retrieval process started when the
 verb is encountered. Here, using a Speeded-Acceptability Judgement task, the effect
 of the case-marking on the specific phenomenon of subject-verb agreement attraction
 was studied in Nepali, a language in which the subject-marking can be manipulated
 as a function of the verb aspect. No significant evidence of such a modulation on
 agreement attraction was found. However, there was a weak link between the presence
 of a marked subject and the acceptability of a sentence. Comparison with the fillers
 and feedback from participants indicated that the presentation rate of the experiment
 was too fast. More research with larger samples needs to be conducted to establish
 more conclusive results in Nepali, a language that is understudied in language sciences.

Title: The Effects of Long-Term and Short-Term Reading Experience on Perception of Faces
Abstract:
This study examined the potential overlap between face and word perception by asking
 whether long- or short-term reading experience might influence face processing. Specifically,
 observers tend to judge that a chimeric face made from two left half-faces is more
 similar to the original face than that made from two right half-faces, suggesting
 a 'left-side bias in face perception. To study the effects of long- and short-term
 reading experience on face processing, the present study compared native Arabic readers'
 (who are bilinguals) right-to-left reading direction, and native English readers'
 left-to-right reading direction, on their judgment of the chimeric faces that is most
 similar to the original face. They were tested before and after doing a reading task
 (reading a novel either in English or Arabic). In contrast to our prediction, all
 participants, regardless of their short- or long-term reading experience, were more
 likely to choose the right chimeric faces, suggesting that there is a right-side bias
 and no left-side bias, unlike previous studies predicted.

Title:
You say you want a revolution?: An Analysis of Tweets Before and After the Sudanese
                                 Revolution
Abstract:
Although recent history has seen an upheaval of political uprisings, scholarship has
 not yet addressed questions surrounding the effects of mass protest on people's social
 values and ideology. As such, this study looked into pre- and post- revolution Twitter
 data from Sudan to explore whether the breakdown of a sociopolitically oppressive
 regime through protest has pronounced effects in shifting individuals' personal values.
 To test our hypothesis, we used the Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count (LIWC) software
 to analyze the language content of over 20,000 tweets produced by Sudanese users 6
 months before and 6 months after the revolution. Results indicated that in the months
 following the revolution, tweets emanating from the Sudanese population were moving
 in a more progressive direction and included a lower proportion of words typically
 associated with "conservation" values, and a higher proportion of words pertaining
 to "openness" values as well as "anti- system" values. These findings offer a novel
 perspective on unstable political systems and illuminate that overthrowing a political
 regime can have far-reaching consequences on the psychology of individuals and extend
 beyond shaping a country's political framework.

Title: Perceptual Competition Between Musical Notation and Letter Processing
Abstract:
Many forms of perceptual expertise have been examined in previous research, yet there
 is much less research on perceptual expertise of music. Researchers have observed
 perceptual interference in experts between two different object categories. We were
 interested to observe perceptual competition between musical notation and letter processing
 due to musical notes bearing meanings as letters. The goal was to examine perceptual
 competition in the brain between musical notation and letter processing within musical
 experts, though not within musical novices. We hypothesized reading musical notes
 and reading letters may also compete for similar processing resources, causing competition
 for experts, but novices would be unaffected. We tested participants online on 2 expertise
 tasks to distinguish skill levels, and 2 RSVP tasks, for identifying letter and symbol
 targets among musical distractors to observe perceptual interference within experts.
 We found that experts performed significantly better than novices within the letter
 search condition than novices. These results suggest that the experts' experience
 in music improved their performance in the tasks due to their encountering familiar
 objects than novices. Acquisition of a new skill may not compete for the same processing
 resources but may instead enhance performance in similar skills.

Title: The support of multisensory information during obstacle avoidance
Abstract:
Vision and haptics(touch and proprioception) are essential to navigate through our
 environment and avoid obstacle collisions. Their multisensory integration has been
 shown to improve performances such as reaching and grasping. However, exploring whether
 or not it can help optimize obstacle avoidance –especially when the haptic input is
 provided by the non-target object– and aid grasping movements by reducing need for
 clearance around the obstacle, is limited. Here we investigated the lateral distance
 of the object from the obstacle, its velocity when overtaking the obstacle, and endpoint
 variability in an obstacle avoidance task. Participants moved the object around the
 obstacle from the start to end position in one condition(Visual), and did the same
 whilst holding the obstacle with the contralateral hand in the other condition(Visuo-Haptic).
 Our results showed only a moderate difference between visual and visuo-haptic information,
 with velocities at the obstacle being slightly higher in the Visuo-Haptic condition.
 In sum, holding the obstacle allows moderately faster movements toward the target
 position. Although these findings suggest that obstacle avoidance movements aided
 by only visual or both visual and haptic information are very similar, the question
 of whether haptic inputs from the non-target object can optimize obstacle avoidance
 remains open for exploration.

Title: In the Mind of the Passionate Ideologues: How do they Morally Reason?
Abstract:
This study examines the role of moral reasoning in the relationship between passion
 and political activism. Building on prior work guided by the dualistic model of passion,
 we hypothesized that obsessive passion (OP) for an ideology would predict support
 for violent activism, while harmonious passion (HP) would predict support for peaceful
 activism. We further posited that the relationship between passion and support for
 different political behaviors would be mediated by moral reasoning. More specifically,
 we hypothesized that utilitarian reasoning would mediate the relationship between
 OP and violent activism, while deontological reasoning would mediate the relationship
 between OP and mainstream activism. Results from members of the Democratic Party in
 the US (N = 209) supported these hypotheses. These findings shed light on one of the
 factors that play into radicalization, and offer theoretical avenues for interventions
 to prevent violent extremism.

Title: Eating disorder symptoms and dopamine dependent working memory subprocesses
Abstract:
Eating disorders are serious psychiatric illnesses with high morbidity and mortality.
 Our understanding of their development from a cognitive and neurobiological standpoint
 is poor due to a number of limitations in the available literature including confounding
 effects of the ill state and flawed conceptualizations of the proposed contributing
 factors. The present study addressed these limitations by utilizing a non-clinical
 sample, a dimensional view of eating disorder symptoms, and a basic science approach
 to the proposed contribution of working memory (WM) in emergence of eating disorder
 symptoms. In a series of three experiments, we aimed to quantify the behavioral and
 neural association between dopamine dependent WM subprocesses and eating disorder
 symptoms. Although we found no significant associations, our findings have identified
 some differences in brain activation that may distinguish individuals with high eating
 psychopathology from controls. We discuss directions for further research to investigate
 these brain activation differences while also accounting for some of the existing
 limitations of research in the field of eating disorders.

Title: Is Selection in Working Memory Cost Free?
Abstract:
Attention can be directed to relevant information from the perceptual environment
 or to working memory (WM) representation. Research reveals that the process of selecting
 WM content has attention-like properties that are seen in the prioritization and de-prioritization
 of perceptual information. Given that ongoing attention tasks are known to disrupt
 WM, if the internal selection of WM content overlaps with attention, we would expect
 a general impairment in WM storage because of attentional selection processes. We
 designed a continuous delayed estimation task in which we manipulated the frequency
 of testing of items, thereby the selection process during maintenance of items in
 WM, to investigate how the process of selectively attending to items held in WM influences
 WM performance. Critically, we designed three retro-cue conditions in which we assess
 whether the retro-cue effect is present and whether selection has a cost on WM performance.
 We compared WM performance on the un-informative-medium and informative-medium conditions
 and found WM performance was reduced in the informative-medium cue condition, suggesting
 there might be a cost associated with internal selection of WM content.

Title: Neural Correlates of Working Memory and Mental Imagery
Abstract:
People have the exceptional ability to recreate and transform visual content in their
 mind. Working memory and mental imagery are two abilities associated with mental representations
 supporting goal-directed behavior. While both abilities rely on the active retention
 and manipulation of content in mind, it is unknown whether the two share the same
 neural mechanisms. In an attempt to reconcile empirical and theoretical findings concerning
 the neural correlates of working memory and imagery, existing research has predominantly
 focused on the shared characteristics, with findings suggesting shared content of
 representations in early visual areas. In the current study, we aim to investigate
 the degree to which the two abilities overlap, by creating an experimental design
 which reflects the distinct theoretical constructs of working memory and imagery.
 To assess the degree to which the two overlap, we used multivoxel pattern analysis
 (MVPA), where we trained four classifiers to decode the identity of the stimulus and
 identity of the task between working memory and imagery.

Title:
The Life Satisfaction of Working Women in European Countries: Leadership, Gender Attitudes,
                                 and Gender Equality
Abstract:
The current study explores the effect of gender role attitudes (individual-level)
 and gender equality (country-level) on the life satisfaction of women in paid employment.
 The study made use of the European Values Study to assess progressive gender role
 attitudes (PGRA) and life satisfaction, and the Global Gender Gap Index to categorize
 33 countries based on their gender equality scores. The initial hypothesis that the
 main relationship between life satisfaction and PGRA is moderated by both job level
 (leadership vs non-leadership) and gender equality (high vs low GGGI) was partially
 confirmed. The data indicated that the main relationship is only moderated by the
 level of gender equality at a national level but not the job level. Even though the
 results did not fully confirm the initial hypothesis regarding the role of leadership,
 they provide opportunities for new research directions.

Title: Passion for a Cause and Political Violence: The Role of Need for Closure
Abstract:
The present research examines the relationship between passion for an ideology, need
 for cognitive closure (NFC), and political activism. Building on the dualistic model
 of passion (Bélanger, 2021; Vallerand, 2015) and recent theorizing on political activism
 (Webber et al., 2018), we predicted that obsessive (but not harmonious) passion would
 increase individuals' need for cognitive closure (NFC), which in turn would be positively
 related to support for violent political activism. Conversely, we predicted that NFC
 should be unrelated to peaceful political activism. Experimental results supported
 these predictions. These findings extend the literature on the underlying cognitive
 mechanisms related to the workings of radicalization.

Title: Learning To See in Virtual Reality
Abstract:
Motion perception is the process of detecting and perceiving objects based on visual,
 vestibular, and proprioceptive cues. Although real-life provides plenty of cues for
 individuals to intercept objects and perceive their surroundings, perception in virtual
 environments represents a novel field that is not yet fully explored. In virtual reality
 (VR), motion perception can be examined through visual cues such as monocular, binocular,
 and the combination of both cues. Previous research indicated that combination cues
 provide the highest sensitivity for the observers to detect accurate motion-in-depth.
 Moreover, recent research has demonstrated that the addition of vestibular cues improves
 participant sensitivity to motion-in-depth in VR. Here, we first further explored
 the role of vestibular cues on participant accuracy of motion perception by entirely
 eliminating them and, second, explored gender as a variable in motion perception sensitivity.
 We first determined that visual-vestibular cue conflicts induced by mismatched display
 and expectation of visual consequences of head movement are not significant enough
 to influence participants' performance. Second, we found that participants with smaller
 interpupillary distance (IPD) have a higher sensitivity to motion perception. Surprisingly,
 our results have also shown that men have a higher sensitivity to motion perception
 despite their larger IPD.

Title:
Assessing the Predictive Value of Maternal Parenting Behaviors On Attachment Security
                                 in the Chinese Context
Abstract:
The maternal sensitivity hypothesis posits that attachment security is an evolutionarily
 adaptive outcome from responsive and supportive caregiving. However, our understanding
 of attachment security in child development has largely been theorized and substantiated
 by Western scholarship. Critics suggest a culturally sensitive approach of considering
 attachment. We assessed the veracity of both claims on attachment security utilizing
 data from a 10-year longitudinal study conducted in Nanjing, China. Mother-child dyads
 were video recorded engaging in a play activity when the child was 14 and 24 months
 old. Using both waves, our study looked at maternal sensitivity behaviors, positive
 parenting and intrusiveness, and culture-sensitive socialization goal-oriented behaviors,
 encouragement of autonomy and connectedness. At age 10, the child completed a Chinese-adapted
 Attachment Script Assessment. Significant positive correlations were found between
 positive parenting, child's biological sex, and maternal education level with attachment
 security. Stepwise regression analysis revealed that positive parenting had a significant
 and robust effect on predicting secure base script knowledge while neither encouragement
 of autonomy nor connectedness added predictive value to the statistical model. Results
 suggest that secure attachment is constructed through positive contingent responsiveness
 as opposed to initiating direction from the caregiver.

Author(s): Al Mazrui, Shamma Sohail Faris Ghanem
Title:
Expectations and Aspirations of Educated Emirati Females in the Transition from School
                                 to Work
Abstract:
Even though initiatives to increase the number of Emiratis in the private and public
 sector have been in place since 1980s, the results in the private sector are not impressive.
 Existing literature argues that Emirati workforce participation in the private sector
 is due to structural and attitudinal factors. Few studies exist that identify and
 explore Emirati females' attitudes towards and expectations of the labor market. This
 paper reports the results from a survey of 107 educated Emirati females who are in
 the transition from school to work. Their responses indicated an expectation to work
 and contribute to society. The findings show a great deal of similarity of attitudes
 towards the private and public sector. In contrast to previous research, the findings
 unveiled an inclination towards a multicultural environment, a perception of education
 and experience as important factors for obtaining a job (as opposed to wasta and "family
 background") and a lack of information on government initiatives and private sector
 opportunities. The findings lay the foundations for policy recommendations that would
 integrate this untapped pool of talent into the labor market.

Author(s): Al Shaikh, Huda Abdulrahman Abdulla Abdulrahman
Title:
The Effect of Family and School Environments on Skill Development: A Case Study of
                                 the UAE
Abstract:
The UAE has witnessed a period of vast economic growth and development that spurred
 after the discovery of oil. One of the main areas of focus right now is in the investment
 of human capital especially for UAE nationals. Some research suggests that school
 attainment and school quality are the main factors behind adequate skill development.
 This paper argues that both school quality and family environments are equally significant
 determinants in developing both skills and cognitive achievement. Using PISA 2009
 data for the UAE, the study finds that positive school environments and certain family
 characteristics do have a positive impact on student achievement.

Title: Global Wage Structures in the Context of the Nineties' Economic Liberalization: 1991-2004
Abstract:
In many economies, wage structures underwent drastic changes during the nineties.
 During this period, a rapid and deep process of trade liberalization was implemented.
 This paper studies industrial wage structures in a group of advanced and developing
 economies from 1991 to 2004. Workers' industry affiliation provides an important channel
 through which trade policies can affect the wage structure and inequality between
 skilled and unskilled workers. Specifically, this paper tests whether those sectors
 where import penetration deepened are also the sectors in which, ceteris paribus,
 a higher effect on wage structure is observed. Several significant results emerge
 from this analysis: (1) import penetration and tariffs are more correlated with wages
 for unskilled workers. (2) In unskilled- intensive industries, import penetration
 is positively correlated with wages. (3) In skilled-intensive industries, the correlation
 between import penetration and skilled workers is positive only to a certain cut-off
 level of tariff where it then becomes negative. (4) There is an overall convergence
 in skilled-unskilled industry wages, more so in advanced than in developed economies.

Title: To What Extent Has Trade Liberalization Reconfigured the Mexican Economy?
Abstract:
In this paper, I look at GDP and TFP growth rates from manufacturing sectors of the
 Mexican Economy to show how trade liberalization has reconfigured the country's economy.
 While standard trade theory predicts that labor-intensive sectors would benefit from
 trade liberalization, my findings indicate the opposite. There has been a divergence
 between labor and capital-intensive sectors; that is, capital-intensive sectors have
 flourished while the labor-intensive ones have stagnated. Additionally, I propose
 that the Chinese presence in the U.S. import market has prevented labor-intensive
 sectors to reap the benefits of NAFTA.

Title: Analysis of Sector Shares of GDP During the Global Economic Crisis
Abstract:
In this paper, I compare how the sector share to GDP of advanced, emerging, and developing
 economies relate to GDP growth during the crisis period of 2007-2010. The main result
 of the paper is that emerging economies have shown considerable resilience to the
 adverse effects of crisis by maintaining their sectoral shares while the agriculture
 sector in advanced economies and industry sector in developing economies suffered
 during this period, which also impacted the country GDP growth. I reconcile these
 results by proposing a potential theory to explain these results.

Title: Mixtures of t-distributions for Finance and Forecasting  A Comment
Abstract:
This paper focuses on students' t-distributions and explores their application for
 option pricing. Generally, options are priced using Black-Sholes-Merton formula (BSM),
 but that methodology is inherently flawed: it pre-supposes the lognormal nature of
 returns for the underlying security. Many researchers have attempted to formulate
 better approximations. The paper, Mixtures of t-distributions for finance and forecasting
 written by Giacomini, Gottschling, Haefke and White (2008), is of particular relevance
 where the usage of Student's t-distributions for option pricing is analysed. With
 fatter tails these distributions would resemble the actual stock options data more
 closely. However, after an attempt to replicate the results derived in the paper many
 discrepancies have been found. Hence, a comparison shall be made between our results
 and the aforementioned variations delineated.

Title: Leaders Do Matter: Brief Analysis on Leader Constraints and Economic Performance
Abstract:
In this paper, we tried to understand the fundamental difference between democratic
 and autocratic systems, and after exploring the gap between the two, analyzes market
 performance for given autocratic systems based on the leader characteristic, represented
 by their exit strategy. The paper explores the possible relationship between the leadership,
 constraints placed on the selectorates, and the market performance. This research
 contributes to the current debate of institutional influence in economic performance
 by looking into the relationship between leadership characteristics and the exogenous
 market variables such as, but not limited to, military and R&D expenditure, public
 health spending, and foreign direct investments on the economy.

Title:
Labor movements in the European Union: the determinants of East-West migration flows
                                 and the impact of transitional arrangements
Abstract:
This study examines the determinants of immigration from the EU 8 and Croatia to the
 EU 15 by expanding the model of Mayda (2010) with insights from Kahanec and Fertig
 (2013) . I empirically test the effects of transitional arrangements, and destination
 countries' xenophobia. I proxy the latter by a dummy variable that is based on the
 length of delaying free access to their labor market after EU accession. By extending
 the years examined and incorporating more of the potential drivers of the labor movement,
 an improved out-of-sample forecast can be achieved. EU membership, the transitional
 periods, xenophobia, unemployment rates, relative inequality, and immigrant stock
 in destination country from both origin countries in analysis and the rest of the
 world were found to be significant factors.

Title: The Effect of Savings on Economic Growth
Abstract:
I study the relationship between output level, output growth and the savings rate
 using a specific characteristic of language as an instrumental variable. I find that
 an increase in savings leads to an increase in the level of output in the long run.
 For the effect of savings on the growth rate of output, my tests are inconclusive.
 While a level effect of savings is in line with the neoclassical growth model of Solow
 (1956), my coefficient estimates are higher than what the textbook model would suggest.
 To contextualize the empirical findings, I present a theoretical argument that weakens
 the case for a crucial assumption of the Solow model: the one of decreasing marginal
 products.

Title: Estimating Human Capital in the Context of Global Development
Abstract:
This paper attempts to measure the global human capital by looking at both qualitative
 and quantitative side of demographics based on population by educational attainment
 dataset and wage by educational attainment dataset. Pre-tax gross wage serves as the
 proxy to measure the quality of human capital while population by educational attainment
 acts as the measurement of the quantity of human capital. The regression estimation
 model explores the role of institutional factors such as rule of law, government effectiveness
 and corruption from Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI) in determining wage for
 population in different educational level. Despite institutional factors appear to
 be statistically insignificant in predicting wages, prediction results enjoyed similar
 college premium level to actual data and related literature. The paper yields preliminary
 results of global human capital estimation: the growth rate of human capital in developed
 countries is plateauing as emerging countries become drivers of human capital growth.

Title: The Social Impacts of the Gezira Scheme on the Sudanese Economy from 1911 to 1950
Abstract:
This paper analyzes the social benefits of the Gezira Scheme in Sudan. The Gezira
 Scheme carries major importance for the Sudanese Economy, making it possible for Sudan
 to produce cash crops for exports for the first time. In contrast to most public projects
 under colonial schemes, the Gezira Scheme in Sudan served an important role in Sudan's
 modern economic development. Using the Internal Rate of Return analysis with the original
 data from Gaitskell (1959), the paper shows that the project has contributed significantly
 (8.9% of the return) to the development of the Sudanese economy since its completion
 in 1925.

Title: The Supplier Network of the U
Abstract:
This paper analyzes the network of international suppliers to the US auto and retail
 industries. The distribution of shippers can have various important implications in
 terms of the propagation of shocks. I find evidence that the network of shippers to
 both industries can be approximated by a power law distribution, suggesting that large
 firms with many shippers are not uncommon. Evidence for the power law relationship
 is stronger in the auto industry.

Title: Chinese Aid in Sub Saharan Africa and its Relationship with Economic Growth
Abstract:
This research focuses on understanding the relationship between Chinese investments
 and economic growth in Sub Saharan African (SSA) in short and medium term. In particular
 I focus on the relationship between Chinese Aid-like investments and GDP per capita
 growth rates within SSA countries. Using the standard definition of aid laid out by
 the Development Assistance Committee to identify aid flows I use panel data analysis
 to measure the impact of Chinese Aid-like investments on economic growth in SSA countries.
 Using a robust fixed effects model this research finds that Chinese Aid has a negative
 correlation with growth in Sub Saharan African countries between 2000 and 2012 even
 after controlling for other factors affecting GDP growth in the short and medium term.
 I find that Chinese Aid is negatively correlated with economic growth in SSA. The
 results of this seemingly counter intuitive results are explained further.

Title: Does Skilled Migration Function as an Incentive to Human Capital Formation
Abstract:
This paper examines the effect skilled emigration has on human capital formation in
 developing countries. Previous papers have shown that skilled emigration positively
 affects human capital formation, using data up to the year 2000. This paper uses newly
 available data to test if the theory still holds for the period 2000 – 2010. The results
 show that this positive effect of skilled emigration on human capital formation is
 no longer perceived in the past decade. In addition, the paper examines the effect
 of some other variables such as GDP growth, unemployment and corruption have on this
 migration-education mechanism. Of the three variables, corruption appears to be the
 variable most significantly affecting skill formation in developing countries when
 controlling for the brain drain effect.

Title: The Effect of Financialization on Economic Growth
Abstract:
A high volume of economic studies and research have been undertaken to ascertain the
 factors that affect Economic Growth. Sets of factors that have been studied in a fair
 amount of detail and with rather interesting and conclusive findings are the factors
 that comprise financialization of the economy. This paper explores the effect of Financial
 Development on Economic Growth with the initial hypothesis that greater Financialization
 results in more growth over time. The differences in the effects will be evaluated.
 Furthermore, the role Financialization plays in the growth of Muslim countries will
 be explored in the search for solutions to development issues and particularly issues
 within the financial services sector.

Title: Remittances and Consumption of Public Services: Empirical Evidence from Pakistan
Abstract:
Remittances are now one of the largest forms of foreign direct investment, providing
 a stable form of private aid to households in developing countries. While much of
 academia has focused on the positive impact of remittances in the area of development,
 less attention has been given to the political economy implications of such unearned
 foreign income. Studies discussing the negative impact of remittances on government
 behavior have assumed that remittances encourage a sectorial glide towards greater
 use of private substitutes to public services (ie. private schools versus public schools).
 This means that an increase in remittances should be correlated with a decrease in
 public services. Using cross-sectional household survey data from 2004-2005 and 2010-2011,
 this research study shows how remittances do not have a significant economic impact
 on the usage of public versus private schools and hospitals in Pakistan.

Title: Pareto Distribution of Russian Stock Market Returns
Abstract:
This thesis is looking into which statistical trends the returns of Russian Stock
 Index (RTS) follow. It turns out that RTS standardized returns converge in tail to
 Pareto distribution. The same is true for the stock markets of developed countries.
 The analysis goes into the precise characteristics of such distribution for RTS and,
 as the result, the power coefficient of Pareto distribution for RTS is significantly
 lower than that of developed countries, which implies higher volatility and higher
 frequency of "extreme events" for Russian market which is expected, given the features
 of Russian political and economic system.

Title: VAR approach to the sectoral analysis of FDI - Economic growth relationship in Kazakhstan
Abstract:
Foreign direct investment (FDI) is speculated to have a positive effect on growth
 by policymakers in many developing countries. Kazakhstan faces many of the issues
 that have been experienced by post-Soviet economies transitioning to capitalist regime.
 In this paper, we study the relationship between GDP growth and total as well as sectoral
 FDI flows in Kazakhstan. We compute impulse response functions of FDI flows by employing
 a Vector Autoregression approach. The main result shows that there is no relationship
 between GDP growth and total or sectoral FDI flows. Finally, we provide potential
 reasons driving these results.

Title: Trust Over Convenience In Sharing: The Case of Airbnb
Abstract:
Recent innovations in information technology have given people the option of sharing
 rather than owning physical assets. In the sharing economy, trust and reputation not
 only offer a premium, but also are necessary for transactions to take place. Consequently,
 digital peer-to-peer marketplaces like Airbnb that facilitate these transactions must
 consider how their platform's various mechanisms and features impact trust within
 their marketplace. This paper considers Airbnb's Instant Book option, a feature emphasizing
 convenience at the expense of trust, and shows how users opting in to this feature
 may face a discount by unknowingly signaling they are not as trustworthy. Understanding
 the relative importance of and dynamics between trust and convenience in these new
 digital peer-to-peer marketplaces will make for more robust platforms.

Title: Induced Travel Demand and Induced Roadway Supply in the United States
Abstract:
This paper utilizes the simultaneous equation model (3SL2) to determine the relationship
 between travel demand (as measured by vehicle miles traveled) and travel supply (the
 availability of local lane miles). The data is from the Federal Highway Administration
 and National Governor's Association and contains 935 observations from the 50 US states
 from 1993-2011. The initial results of the Simultaneous Equation Model showed an induced
 travel demand effect, where an increase in roadway supply led to an increase in travel
 demand but did not ensure an induced investment effect, where an increase in travel
 demand would lead to an increase in roadway supply.

Title: Demand Side Management in the UAE's Residential Sector
Abstract:
This paper studies the effect of awareness and relative performance on the consumption
 of water and electricity of students residing in the New York University Abu Dhabi
 dormitories. Students of the university, like many other residents in the United Arab
 Emirates, have little incentive to refrain from wasteful consumption. The dormitory
 residents are divided into two groups, control group and intervention group. The control
 group received no treatment, whereas the intervention group signed consent forms for
 participation in the experiment (first type of intervention) and received letters
 with information of where does their electricity and water consumption stand against
 their peers (second type of intervention). Consent form and a sample of peer comparison
 letters can be found in the appendix. The results show that the intervention group
 consumes more electricity but less water than the control group does. The asymmetry
 of electricity and water consumption can be explained with elasticity of demand and
 change in outside temperature. The structure of the experiment is simple and transparent
 suggesting that such project can be implemented on a larger scale for institutional
 purposes.

Title: A new model to measure Chinese GDP An Empirical Analysis
Abstract:
In 2012, the Chinese economy reached $8.4 trillion, making it the world's second largest
 economy (after United States at $15.7 trillion). The increasing concern about Chinese
 statistics reliability is not a new story. There have been professional attempts to
 develop a proxy for the Chinese economic activities. Yet there has been insufficient
 justification for the reliability of these proxy variables. This paper develops a
 new model to measure the Chinese GDP with the reference to a cross-country analysis
 from 1960 to 2012. The new estimation shows that the Chinese GDP is much more volatile
 than the official GDP figures.

Title: The Quantity-Quality Trade-off of Fertility: An Empirical Study in India
Abstract:
Several studies have sought to empirically test the theoretical model on the quantity-quality
 (Q-Q) trade-off of children in a family, first introduced by Gary Becker. Using a
 representative sample of data from three surveys in India (National Family Health
 Surveys), I conduct an empirical examination of the Q-Q trade-off of children. I use
 both linear and non-linear specifications of family size and study the nature of the
 trade-off both across time and the rural-urban divide. Furthermore, I adopt the use
 of an instrument (sex of the first born child) for family size to address the issue
 of endogeneity. My results suggest that the Q-Q trade-off holds and that the trade-off
 is surprisingly higher in urban areas. In addition, the trade-off appears to be declining
 over time, but marginally. The results have to be assessed with caution, especially
 when studying the estimates across time (survey) as the instrument appears to be weak
 and even invalid in some specifications.

Title: Self-Confidence in Decision-Making (Experimental Methods and Evidence)
Abstract:
Do individuals interpret ambiguous feedback optimistically or pessimistically when
 their self-esteem is at stake? Ertac (2011) finds that generally people overweigh
 negative performance feedback which leads to overly-pessimistic beliefs about ability.
 If these results are valid and generalizable, more studies are necessary to study
 the effects and extent of pessimism. Towards this end, I have replicated Ertac's experiment
 with a number of differences in methodology (performance groups, signal and payment).
 In confirmation of her findings, after participants received an accurate yet negative
 signal, there was a significant pessimistic effect in belief updating. This paper
 also compares belief-accuracy across two types of belief elicitation mechanisms –
 the quadratic scoring rule and the crossover mechanism. There is no significant difference
 in belief accuracy between the two mechanisms.

Title:
Student Loans: What are the Economic Benefits of Investing in Higher Education in
                                 the United States and is it Worthwhile for Students Taking out Student Loans?
Abstract:
College as an investment, is it worth it? People decide to pursue higher education
 because of the expectation of future economic success based on educational attainment.
 Assuming that higher education will have the following benefits: higher annual entry
 wage, lower unemployment rate and higher wage growth, many pursue it. More so, students
 are driven to take out loans and apply for financial aid to invest in attaining a
 higher education. However, will the economic benefits of attaining a higher education
 degree compensate for the amount of debt that student in the U.S will graduate with?
 This research illustrates the economic value of an education by measuring the added
 value of a high school or college degree. Exploring the relationship between educational
 attainment and lifetime earnings and how has the relationship changed over the years
 2009 – 2013 considerably.

Title: Debt Mispricing in Leveraged Buyout (LBO) Transactions
Abstract:
Debt constitutes a major portion of the capital structure of leveraged buyout (LBO)
 transactions undertaken by private equity firms, generating a prospective setting
 for analyzing its pricing dynamics. Through the use of large, global LBO transaction
 details from March 1987 to September 2014, we discover that issuers and debtors of
 high-yield debt differ in their perception of risk, indicating debt mispricing. As
 private equity firms arbitrage from the mispricing, we find that they increase the
 valuation of their target companies by 0.0317% – 0.0486% given a decrease of the cost
 of borrowing high-yield debt by 1%. Furthermore, higher magnitude of debt mispricing
 is associated with LBO transactions of larger absolute size that exclude equity in
 their financing package.

Title:
Effect of Information on Consumer Perception: Evidence from Restaurant Hygiene Grades
                                 Cards in New York City
Abstract:
This study examines the effects of increasing provision of hygiene quality information
 on consumer assessment of restaurant quality. In July 2010 New York City introduced
 mandatory hygiene grade cards to be displayed in restaurants. I show that both an
 A grade and better inspection scores are correlated with higher ratings in food, decor,
 service and price, with the former having a larger impact. These results suggest that
 consumers give much credence to the information provided by hygiene grade cards but
 the underlying scores might not reflect the true hygiene quality of restaurants.

Title: A Multifactor Analysis of the Effect of Socially Responsible Stocks in a Market Portfolio
Abstract:
This paper empirically analyzes the effect of the inclusion of stocks listed in a
 sustainability index in a market portfolio. I use the S&P 500 Index to construct my
 market portfolio and the Domini Social Index to generate a socially responsible investing
 (SRI) dummy. My empirical results suggest that there is no difference in excess returns
 between SRI stocks and non-SRI stocks in the sample. However, in applying a generalized
 version of the Fama-French three-factor model to explain abnormal returns, my results
 indicate that only the market risk factor and the size premium factor are relevant
 for SRI stocks. The value premium factor, which is significant for non-SRI firms,
 is insignificant for SRI firms.

Title: Corporate Takeovers and Activist Hedge Funds
Abstract:
This research evaluates whether hedge fund activism to force the sale of a target
 firm generates higher cumulative abnormal returns for the shareholders of the acquiring
 company than an acquisition through a tender offer? Using an event study, I evaluate
 the cumulative abnormal returns around the announcement date for the shareholders
 of the acquiring company and compare the results for the two different acquisition
 processes. The results indicate that relative to tender offers, hedge fund activism
 to force a sale tends to generate higher cumulative abnormal returns for the shareholders
 of the acquiring company. This paper contributes to the debate surrounding hedge fund
 activism and its economic implications.

Title: Raising Funds 101? Groups, Individuals, and the "Identified Victim" Effect
Abstract:
Many NGOs rely on empathic arousal to raise funds. A common source of such arousal
 is a victim's story and image. In my paper, I study individual and group contributions
 made towards helping Moke, a 7-year-old child living in Democratic Republic of Congo,
 suffering from a dermatological condition. In my experiment, I control levels of identification
 by offering the image, name, and age of the victim to the treatment. My experiment
 confirms the existence of the "Identified Victim" effect in individuals: individuals
 contribute more towards helping an identified victim than an unidentified victim.
 Importantly, I extend the study to groups to find, surprisingly, that groups contribute
 more towards helping an unidentified victim than identified victim. Finally, the results
 also demonstrate that groups are less selfish than individuals: i.e. compared to individuals,
 groups contribute more towards the unidentified victim. To explain the findings, I
 propose a new theory that draws on the empathic altruistic hypothesis and the social
 comparison theory.

Title:
Difference Between Veteran and Civilian Real Wage Distribution from 1980 to 2010 in
                                 the United States
Abstract:
Veteran and civilian wage difference is an important topic in labor economics and
 public policy. This research seeks to answer two questions. First, is there a significant
 difference between veteran and civilian real wage from 1980 to 2010? Second, if there
 is, what are the potential reasons that can explain the real wage discrepancy? The
 empirical evidence reveals that veterans in fact earn higher real wage than civilians
 from 1980 to 2010. The fluctuation of the veteran real wage premium is correlated
 with shifting composition of veterans from different wars. Evidence regarding social
 work, working hours, and racial heterogeneity of veterans is insufficient to explain
 veterans' higher real wage than civilians.

Title: Traditional Institutions or Geography: Determinants of Health Outcomes in Sierra Leone
Abstract:
Sierra Leone is one of the poorest countries in the world with one of the weakest
 health systems and lowest health statistics. Traditional institutions play an important
 role in large parts of the developing world. In Sierra Leone, the Paramount Chief,
 in particular, performs many essential formal duties such as tax collection, public
 service provision etc. Geography also plays an important role in health outcomes as
 areas near big cities and roads have more access to health resources and health professionals.
 This paper studies the impact of the quality of traditional institutions and geography
 on Sierra Leone's health outcomes. I will use an instrumental variable strategy to
 make causal claims about traditional institutions' impact on health outcomes and I
 will argue that geography is exogenous to make causal claims about geography's impact
 on health outcomes. I find that quality of traditional institutions does not have
 a significant impact on health outcomes, contrary to the results obtained by Acemoglu
 et al in 2013. Proximity to nearby roads also does not have an impact on health outcomes.
 Proximity to a big city, on the other hand, has a significant, negative effect on
 3 of my 7 health outcomes.

Title: Bargaining Over Risk: The Effect of Strategic Uncertainty On Fairness Concerns
Abstract:
We study how social preferences are affected by the presence of risk in bargaining
 contexts. We use a modified dictator game to differentiate between two types of fairness
 concerns, ex ante (probability-based) and ex post (outcome-based), and observe whether
 preferences can be explained exclusively by one of these types. We also adapt this
 modified game to include strategic uncertainty, in order to investigate how giving
 decisions change when both players have bargaining power. We predict that a combination
 of ex ante and ex post fairness concerns will best explain subjects' giving decisions
 under risk and in the presence of strategic uncertainty.

Title:
The Effect of Announcements Regarding Interest Rate Changes on Asset Trading and Price
                                 Bubbles
Abstract:
This paper studies the impact of interest rate change announcements on asset trading
 and price bubbles in experimental asset markets. The study employs an experimental
 limit order asset market, in which each participant is endowed with cash and dividend-paying
 assets (shares in our case) that can be traded in the market; the unused cash earns
 interest after trading in each period and dividends are paid on each share. We look
 at how the uncertainty about future interest rates impacts the trading price relative
 to the flat fundamental value of the share, as well as the trading volume. We compare
 the results in the treatment and the baseline groups after an announcement tells the
 subjects in the treatment groups how the interest rate will change. We find that the
 uncertainty regarding interest rate changes does not have an effect on the price bubbles,
 but significantly reduces the volume of trade.

Title: Paying for the Tag: The Effect of Luxury Brand Labels on Willingness to Pay
Abstract:
In economics, many theories were proposed since Veblen's (1899) analysis of conspicuous
 consumption to better understand the mechanisms that allow luxury brands to charge
 high prices for their products. While luxury markets continue to grow all around the
 world, little experimental research has been done to support those theories. The purpose
 of this research is to identify whether a presence of a brand label on a luxury good
 affects willingness to pay. Contrary to hypothetical survey settings used previously
 on this topic, this experiment is designed to offer real life incentives for revealing
 the true value people attribute to a brand label with low brand prominence. Using
 lotteries to elicit willingness to pay, our aim is to investigate to what extent the
 hedonic value of luxury consumption contributes to the price premium of luxury brands.

Title: How Corruption Affects GDP Recovery?
Abstract:
In this paper, we study the linkages between corruption and economic resilience. In
 particular, our main question is how corruption affects GDP recovery after financial
 crisis. To study this question empirically, we use a sample of thirty-one economies
 primarily in Europe, from the period of 2005-2014 which captures the aftermath of
 the financial crisis of 2007-2009. We apply both the linear model and non-linear effects
 and conclude that corruption does negatively affect growth in the period of recovery
 from crisis. Moreover, we find that the crisis puts governance institutions at the
 risk of underperformance not only in highly bureaucratic but also in moderately bureaucratic
 economies.

Title: Ranks or Scores: Does Giving Ordinal Instead of Cardinal Rank Feedback Deter Sabotage?
Abstract:
This paper studies unethical behavior under a flat-wage scheme in a lab experiment.
 I investigate the role of status seeking on effort and sabotage under two different
 settings: giving cardinal ranks versus giving ordinal ranks. The experiment seeks
 to study intrinsic competitiveness and was meant to determine which of these two incentive
 mechanisms induces the most effort and the least sabotage. The results show that there
 is no difference in amount of sabotage between the different forms of feedback while
 holding all else constant. When sabotage is introduced, however, giving ordinal rank
 feedback decreases effort both overall and over time.

Title: An Alternative Model and Experimental Design for Choice Overload
Abstract:
Choice overload is a cognitive process in which people have a difficult time making
 a decision when faced with many options. A variety of experiments have been performed,
 intending to either prove or disprove the existence of choice overload. Still, there
 is a mixed result of success in these experiments. This paper attributes the inconsistency
 of the experimental findings to a lack of clear theoretical framework on this topic,
 as many theories remain to be largely descriptive and vague. This paper proposes that
 some consumers suffer from choice overload because they want get the best attributes
 available and their inability to do so creates dissatisfaction. The description of
 this mentality is written quantitatively, with the intention of spelling out the assumptions
 and introducing definitions that have been implied in many previous works. The paper
 consists of a theoretical section and an experimental design section, which describes
 the experimental procedures to test the hypotheses derived from the model.

Title: Tobacco Consumption: Economic Losses to an Indian Household
Abstract:
This paper uses survey data from the National Survey of Household Expenditure and
 Family Welfare from 2009 to 2010, incorporating the Global Adult Tobacco Survey of
 Indian Households from 2009 to 2010, to investigate how the household expenditure
 share is affected if there is at least one tobacco consumer in the household. The
 expenditure shares examined are for food, education, rent and healthcare. My goal
 is to use a fixed effects model to control for the differences in province. Control
 variables used are household size, characteristics of household head (gender, education
 level and occupation), household demographics (whether rural or urban), number of
 income earners and household facilities (including washing machine, TV, flush toilet
 and car); in an effort to prove that expenditure shares are allocated differently
 across provinces. The main finding is that having at least one tobacco consumer in
 the household results in a negative effect on the expenditure shares of food, education,
 rent and healthcare. I expect all parameter estimates to be statistically significant
 except for expenditure shares allocated to the bare necessities, thus basic food items.

Title: Nudging Individuals to Healthier Decisions
Abstract:
The United Arab Emirates, currently the 16th highest country with diabetes, is hoping
 to lower the high levels of diabetes in the country by 2021. It has been proven that
 the most common type of diabetes, which is Type 2, can be prevented by behavioral
 and lifestyle factors. In this study, I aim to test the effectiveness of presenting
 information, in the form of nudges, to identify whether certain presentation of information
 will motivate individuals to make better decisions concerning their health. I have
 collaborated with the UAE Healthy Future Study conducted by the Public Health Research
 Team at NYUAD to perform an experiment to prove the effectiveness of using the model
 of nudges in providing information.

Title: Effect of Entering Domestic Partnerships and Marriages on Voting Behavior
Abstract:
This paper highlights the importance of considering a new dimension to study the effect
 of marital status on voting participation in the U.S. Domestic partners vote differently
 than married couples and these effects vary over age, religious attendance, income,
 education, ideology, political interest, the presence of a child, and residential
 mobility. Falling marriage rates and increasing domestic partnerships drive up the
 salience of domestic partnerships as important family structures in predicting voter
 turnout. The paper focuses on the differences between domestic partnerships and marriages
 as it relates to voter turnout. The paper further explores how the effect of various
 turnout-predictors varies for the two relationship types. The paper shows that domestic
 partners are more vulnerable to negative effects of low income, low education, the
 presence of children, high residential mobility, and low religious attendance. The
 research aims to help create more efficient models to predict voter turnout, voting
 results, and campaign fund allocation.

Title: CSR Trumped?
Abstract:
The triumph of Donald J. Trump as the 45th President of the United States of America
 on November 8th, 2016 was an unexpected election outcome. This paper examines the
 impact of the election on stock returns of the Standard and Poor's 500 (S&P500 hereafter)
 constituent firms, as a function of corporate social responsibility (CSR). I hypothesize
 that more socially responsible firms underperformed relative to their industry peers
 in the immediate aftermath of Trump's victory. To this end, I apply an event study
 based on regression estimation of abnormal returns using both Fama and French Three
 Factor Model (FF3F) - adjusted returns and Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM) - adjusted
 returns. I find that, contrary to expectation that high CSR firms would be "trumped"
 or disproportionately punished, the coefficient for the interaction between the event
 dummy and ESG (Environmental, Social and Corporate Governance) performance is positive
 and significant, meaning that mean abnormal returns increased with CSR.

Title: An Economic Examination of the Bitcoin Network
Abstract:
This paper examines the Bitcoin Network through the lens of Economics. The understanding
 of the backbone of Bitcoin is not as prevalent as knowledge of its recent trends.
 Through this paper, I will attempt to provide a detailed description of the processes
 underlying Bitcoin. The paper breaks the process of bitcoin mining into distinct processes
 - namely the creation of bitcoin and the spending of it. Within these processes, I
 describe the cryptographic elements of the currency, which in turn lay the foundation
 for the incentive structures that exist. The cryptographic elements will be approached
 with a view to describe rather than to discuss the algorithms used. In examining in
 detail the incentive structures and the strategic scenarios that arise, this paper
 aims to provide a fuller understanding of the Bitcoin Network.

Title:
The Impact of Transportation Costs on Deforestation in the Democratic Republic of
                                 the Congo
Abstract:
This article investigates the impact of transportation cost on deforestation in the
 Democratic Republic of the Congo. Specifically, it assembles a new deforestation data
 set using satellite imagery and analyses deforestation levels for 193 cities over
 a period of 16 years. The article then creates a panel data fixed effect model to
 measure the relationship at question. The results indicate that decreasing transportation
 cost by 1% increases deforestation by 0.3%. Complementing this main finding the article
 identifies a data time trend whereby deforestation increases by 0.1% annually. In
 doing so this article aims to provide data for enabling more informed legislative
 decisions and reducing the grey area of 'uncertain environmental effects' which often
 result from new infrastructure projects. The data herewith presented should hopefully
 aid in guiding a more sustainable and informed approach to Congo's development, one
 which takes greater care of the Congolese rain forests, currently occupying 46% of
 Congo's total land area.

Title: The Oil Curse: Oil and Economic Growth
Abstract:
This paper seeks to examine the impact that the presence of oil as a natural resource
 has on the economic growth of a country while taking into consideration the type of
 governing regime. It hopes to dispel the evidence of the oil curse, which states that
 oil rents often undermine democracy, and slows down economic growth by promoting corruption
 and state instability. This research builds on that of Sala-I-Martin's I Just Ran
 Four Million Regressions by adding oil and political factors to the empirical growth
 model that he uses. This research employs ordinary least square regression with economic
 growth as the dependent variable during the period 1990 – 2014. The main findings
 of this research was that the countries in this dataset show that oil did not have
 a negative impact on growth even when controlling for the type of political regime
 in the country during the period.

Title: Sovereign bond spreads in emerging market economies and their macroeconomic fundamentals
Abstract:
This paper tests several hypotheses. One is whether the financial crisis of 2008 breaks
 the link between emerging markets sovereign bond yields and their macroeconomic drivers.
 The research paper shows that there is a strong correlation between the bond yields
 and macroeconomic variables such as debt-to-gdp over the period of 2000-2007. It also
 finds that the effect of debt-to-gdp is statistically insignificant on the sovereign
 spreads in post-2008.

Title:
The Effect of Intensified Import Competition from China on Labor-Market Outcomes and
                                 Voter Attitudes in Europe
Abstract:
China's share of world manufacturing has more than quadrupled after it became a member
 of the World Trade Organization in 2001. How has the intensified import competition
 from China affected unemployment, regional wage receipts, and voter attitudes in the
 European Union, its largest trading partner? Analyzing labor market and electoral
 data from 25 European countries at the NUTS 2 regional level between 1999 and 2016,
 I find that Chinese import competition is associated with lower general and long-term
 unemployment rates as well as higher regional wage receipts for the manufacturing
 sector and across sectors. Nevertheless, voters in the exposed regions express stronger
 protectionist and anti-centralization sentiments as well as more favorable attitudes
 towards domestic free trade policies. I use an instrumental variable approach to
 isolate the supply-driven component of the Chinese trade shock and find that the results
 are robust to specifications that use current and lagged imports to different groups
 of high-income countries. The results imply that import competition from China benefits
 the exposed regions at the aggregate level, but still leads voters to adopt economic-nationalist
 sentiments.

Title:
Bitcoin: The Ultimate Speculative Asset? Justifying the Unusual Price Evolution of
                                 Bitcoin (2012-2017)
Abstract:
Bitcoin's price increased by 275,900% between January 1, 2012 and December 31, 2017,
 and the root of this remarkable price growth remains largely unexplored in economic
 literature. This paper sets out to fill this gap by providing a comprehensive investigation
 of the price behavior of Bitcoin, the most valuable and liquid cryptocurrency in existence.
 The paper takes a threefold systematic approach by addressing three key questions
 pertaining to the unusual price evolution of Bitcoin. First, what are some long-run
 determinants of Bitcoin's price formation between 2012 and 2017? Second, can speculation
 in the Bitcoin market lend explanation for the cryptocurrency's noteworthy price fluctuations
 in 2017? Finally, is there any evidence of bubble-like behavior in the Bitcoin market
 in recent years? My results show that while variables conventionally used to study
 financial asset pricing do not provide much explanation behind Bitcoin's price evolution,
 speculation and bubble-like behavior were key contributors to Bitcoin's unusual price
 development in recent years.

Title:
Beta Asymmetry in Bull & Bear Markets in the Eurozone and its Applications in Spread
                                 Trading
Abstract:
In this paper I use the dual beta model (DBM) to estimate bull and bear betas for
 individual stocks and then compare the performance of bear betas versus standard betas
 in creating hedges in a spread trading strategy. I also explore multiple scenarios
 by using different return calculation approaches (weekly, 1 month and 3 month returns)
 and having different definitions of bull and bear markets (using 3, 6 or 12 month
 rolling averages). (i) I find that there is no relationship in using different methods
 in estimating bull and bear markets and stock returns and their impact on the performance
 of the portfolios. (ii) In terms of returns, in 12 out of the 20 industries the bear
 beta portfolios outperformed the standard beta portfolios. (iii) In respect to volatility
 the results where the opposite, only in 4 out of the 20 industries did the standard
 deviation of the bear beta portfolio outperform the standard beta portfolio. (iv)
 For Sharpe Ratios the results indicate that in 15 out of the 20 industries the bear
 beta portfolios outperformed standard beta portfolios, thus ultimately confirming
 my hypothesis.

Title:
The Link between Household Heads' Education and Children's Schooling in Pakistani
                                 Households
Abstract:
This paper addresses the intergeneration transmission of education in Pakistan, by
 investigating the extent to which the highest level of education attained by a household
 head has an impact on the likelihood of their children being enrolled in school. A
 logistic regression model with Odds Ratios is used to determine the impact of different
 levels of heads' education on the binary outcome of their children either being currently
 enrolled in school or not, while controlling for factors such as the sex of the child,
 the province the household is located in and whether the household is situated in
 a rural or urban area. The results are consistent with the primary hypothesis that
 higher levels of heads' education have a greater impact on the likelihood of their
 children being enrolled in school.

Title: Globalisation and Income Inequality
Abstract:
Globalisation is often linked to and promoted in an attempt to induce economic growth.
 It picked up pace starting the early 2000s. In an age where virtually all countries
 are experiencing unprecedented globalisation simultaneously with sharp increases in
 income inequality, the question of a link between the two arises naturally. This paper
 attempts to investigate the effect of globalisation on income inequality across countries
