 with varying income levels. It focuses on the differences between the economic development
 and the income levels of these countries and how these influence the impact of globalisation.
 The empirical evidence presented provides support to the claim that globalisation
 adversely affects income inequality in Upper-middle income and Lower-middle income
 countries. Thus economic policy-making for these countries should incorporate considerations
 regarding income distribution when pursuing globalisation. The paper finds no evidence
 of globalisation being correlated with income inequality in High-income and Low-income
 countries.

Title: Gender differences in returns to migration: Does motivation matter?
Abstract:
This paper employs the sixth round of Ghana Living Standards Survey (GLSS) data to
 quantitatively verify (1) whether men and women select into migration for different
 reasons and (2) whether this heterogeneity affects their returns to migration. I find
 that women are less likely than men to migrate for work related reasons, and that
 women who migrate for other reasons have lower returns to migration than men. Women
 who migrate for work, on the other hand, have weakly higher returns to migration than
 men. Overall, reason for migration has a bigger impact on women's returns to migration.

Title:
Analysis of Monetary Financial Integration through Equity Returns for the New Eurozone
                                 Members
Abstract:
This paper focuses on the impact of the Great Recession and the European Sovereign
 Debt Crisis on the financial integration of the new Eurozone members. Previous research
 on financial integration of the initial members of the Eurozone identifies a strong
 link between joining the monetary union and improved financial integration through
 bond, equity, and credit markets. This paper applies similar models related to the
 equity markets to a new set of Eurozone countries. Moreover, it explores possible
 negative effects that recessions might have had on the financial integration and accounts
 for other country specific factors that might affect investor behavior and hinder
 the rate of financial integration. By comparing various measures of equity market
 convergence this paper finds that the financial integration was indeed slower when
 the new EMU members joined the Eurozone compared to the countries that joined the
 EMU in 1999.

Title: Islam and Prosocial Consumer Behavior
Abstract:
Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) models have been widely adopted by many companies
 and have become core to their businesses. However, companies who are involved in CSR
 in the religious environment may be more effective than in the non-religious environment
 because religious people are more prone to prosocial behavior than non-religious people.
 This paper proposes an experimental design to study the direct effect of religion,
 in particular Islam, on consumer behavior and tradeoffs made in purchasing decisions.
 The experiment aims to study the consumer behavior of subjects who are religiously
 primed to trigger the Muslim identity and assess if they are more likely to pay more
 for products from companies known for their CSR efforts. The proposed experimental
 design consists of 6 sections: (i) Priming; (ii) CSR Questionnaire; (iii) Pricing
 Game; (iv) Dictator Game; (v) Identity Test; (vi) Post Experimental Questionnaire.

Title: Impact of remittances on welfare of children
Abstract:
As foreign remittances continue to starkly increase, much literature has evidenced
 the various impacts of remittances on household behaviour as well as outcomes. However,
 one stakeholder that has seen little attention is that of children. Using a panel
 dataset from 2002- 2015, this project explores the impacts of remittances on health
 and educational outcomes of Children in the Philippines. I find that there are general
 positive effects towards health and educational outcomes though with weak statistical
 significance on certain dependent variables.

Title:
'Conscious Capitalism': The Impact of Financial Performance on Corporate Social Responsibility
                                 (CSR)
Abstract:
The purpose of this paper is to examine the relationship between the financial performance
 of firms and their Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) before/during/after the financial
 crisis of 2008-2009. We conduct an empirical analysis, using S&P 500 companies and
 their financial information, as well as equal-weighted CSR score constructed by ASSET4
 ESG Database. Results indicate that there is a statistically significant relationship
 between the financial performance and CSR scores only before the crisis (2006, 2007),
 but not during (2008, 2009, 2010) or after the crisis (2011, 2012, 2013).

Title: Is there a gender gap in self-competition? Evidence from an online experiment
Abstract:
Gender differences in willingness to compete have been shown to explain disparities
 in labor market outcomes and thoroughly documented in economic experiments. More recently,
 "self-competition" has been suggested as a strategy to increase gender parity. This
 study attempts to replicate the finding that self-competition eliminates the gender
 gap present in traditional competitive scenarios, recruiting the same sample and using
 nearly identical procedures as a previous study. The self-competition effect does
 not replicate: a weakly significant gender gap persists in self- competition and no
 evidence of a meaningful difference between other- and self-competition is observed.
 Risk attitudes predict competitive choices in all conditions, and the self-competition
 effect observed in the original study appears to be due to low score variance and
 learning effects reducing the riskiness of self-competing. The evidence suggests that
 policies for inequality reduction should aim to directly address gender differences
 in confidence and risk aversion rather than emphasize self-improvement.

Title: Gender, Competitiveness, and University Study Choices
Abstract:
The emerging literature examines whether gender differences in willingness to compete
 can explain the gender differences in education choices. Using a laboratory experiment,
 I investigate whether competitiveness has an effect on study track choice among students
 at New York University Abu Dhabi, as suggested by previous studies. I observe significant
 gender differences in study track choices, where males pick more difficult study tracks
 than females despite no differences in their personal math ability. My study also
 shows some gender differences in competitiveness. However, unlike in previous studies,
 I find that competitiveness is not correlated with study track choice. More importantly,
 competitiveness cannot explain the gender gap in study track choices in my sample.
 I discuss possible reasons for the different findings.

Title:
The effect of aid on the growth of a country's exportable manufacturing sector through
                                 the channel of an appreciated exchange rate
Abstract:
This paper replicates a study by Rajan and Subramanian (2009) which argues that countries
 receiving aid suffer from an aid-induced Dutch Disease. We examine the effect of aid
 on export-sensitive manufacturing sectors particularly through the channel of an appreciated
 exchange rate. This study successfully replicates their cross-industry methodology
 to find relative growth rates of different countries throughout the 1980s and 1990s.
 Furthermore, we extend the paper to the 2000s and construct a new measure of exportability.
 We find that the way we define export-sensitive industries determines whether aid
 affects the exportable manufacturing sector. Furthermore, we did not find evidence
 that an appreciated real exchange rate is the channel through which an aid-induced
 Dutch Disease occurs.

Title:
Trade Deliberalisation and the Spatial Distribution of Firms: The Bifurcation of Bihar,
                                 India as a Natural Experiment
Abstract:
An inter-state tax on trade was in effect in India until 2017. How did this tax affect
 firms and workers? In November 2000 the state of Jharkhand was carved out of Bihar
 to facilitate the development of its tribal population. This new border was an exogenous
 shock to trade between Bihar and Jharkhand. We use the bifurcation of Bihar as a natural
 experiment to examine the extent to which trade deliberalisation through the creation
 of additional state borders affects the spatial distribution of firms. This empirical
 study uses a difference-in-difference estimation strategy and geocoded village-level
 data to find two key results. First, a discontinuity in the number of firms and workers
 emerged along the border by 2013, with lower numbers along the Jharkhand side. Second,
 it seems like Jharkhand was able to invest in itself to allow for the better provision
 of public goods along its side of the border.

Title:
Short-Run Events and Stock Market Reactions: Early Evidence from the Economic Blockade
                                 on Qatar
Abstract:
An unprecedented economic blockade imposed by the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Egypt
 and Saudi Arabia on June 5th, 2017 resulted in the suspension of trade with Qatar.
 Using a regression based event study, this paper aims to observe daily variations
 in the returns of the Qatar All Share Equity Index (QEAS) to determine the effect
 of four event announcements on and around the official days of the announcement of
 the economic blockade. First, the returns of five Middle Eastern country indices are
 regressed upon three event windows to find that only the QEAS reacts significantly
 to the focus event. Second, the returns of seven different industry sectors in Qatar
 are regressed upon the same three event windows to find that the transportation and
 consumer goods and services sectors were most affected by the blockade. Third, the
 returns of all forty-three companies that are publicly-listed in the QEAS index are
 regressed on the same three event windows to analyze firm-specific return reactions
 over each event of interest. Although there is predictive power in assuming negative
 abnormal returns as a result of negative news announcements, this paper analyzes the
 short-run market shock of the blockade on the performance of the Qatari economy.

Title:
The Effect of Mobile Phone Diffusion on The Law of One Price for Commodity Markets
                                 in Ghana
Abstract:
Limited or costly information can prevent economic agents from engaging in optimal
 arbitrage and cause price dispersion across markets. Consequently, goods may not be
 allocated efficiently. As a result, information technologies may improve market performance
 since they reduce communication costs and allow individuals to send and obtain information
 quickly and cheaply on a variety of economic, social, and political issues. This paper
 evaluates the effect of mobile phone diffusion on the price dispersion of commodity
 markets in Ghana. Using geographical data on mobile phone usage as well as market-level
 price data, it shows that the adoption of mobile phones is not associated with a reduction
 in price dispersion and does not hold to the Law of One Price. Furthermore, this report
 dismantles the effect of mobile phone adoption for different regions and different
 commodity types. It finds no difference in effect between southern and northern markets
 and it concludes that the effect is greater for retail markets than for wholesale
 markets, as well as greater for non-perishable commodities than for perishable ones.

Title: Mechanism Design with Limited Attention Agents
Abstract:
We relax a common assumption in mechanism design that agents never fail to consider
 all available options. Unlike their fully attentive counterparts, limited attention
 agents may examine only a subset of their choice sets and may thus overlook their
 true preferences. We introduce a notion of implementation that allows for a wide range
 of heterogeneity in individual attention, from those with one-strategy consideration
 to fully attentive agents. We propose a weaker version of strategy proofness and extend
 the rectangular property. We show that these new conditions are necessary and sufficient
 for our implementation concept. Our results corroborate the importance of attention
 on the performance of strategy-proof rules in experimental settings.

Title: Why are Millennials Job-Hopping? An Analysis of Job Mobility and Income Satisfaction
Abstract:
This paper studies the relation between measures of satisfaction and job mobility.
 I employ the first five waves of the UK Household Longitudinal Study (UKHLS) dataset
 to study the effect of income satisfaction on job mobility. I find that an apathetic
 individual has job mobility 4 times higher than that of someone who is mostly dissatisfied.
 I also find that this result is driven by Millennials in the sample who report neutral
 levels of income satisfaction but have the highest job mobility in the sample. These
 findings hint at measures firms can take to retain Millennials and decrease their
 job mobility.

Title: The Effect of Heavy Rail Infrastructure on Labor Supply: Evidence from Lima, Peru
Abstract:
This paper uses the Peruvian National Household Survey (ENAHO) to study the impact
 of the newly opened metro on the extensive and intensive margin of labor supply in
 Lima, Peru. The key finding is that the metro increased employment both on the extensive
 as well as the intensive margin. By breaking down the effects per year, I find that
 the largest impact occurs during the first years of metro operations. I also observe
 that the effects on both the extensive and intensive margin appear to be driven by
 women.

Title: Rationality of Investment in Cryptographic Assets
Abstract:
We study the rationality of investing in the cryptocurrency market. We examine investor
 rationality by studying the risk-return trade-off between investments in portfolios
 of cryptocurrencies and investments in portfolios of traditional securities. Our findings
 suggest that investments in cryptocurrencies are consistent with rationality because
 including them in a portfolio entails superior risk-adjusted returns as well as diversification
 benefits. In addition, we show that portfolios including cryptocurrencies would benefit
 from active investment strategies given that the costs of re-balancing in the crypto-markets
 are often negligible.

Title: Is Less More? Course Selection and the Burden of Choice
Abstract:
Standard theories in psychology and economics both affirm the motivational consequences
 of offering consumers a large variety of options. Recent studies have found that despite
 the long-held view of 'the more the merrier', larger assortments have a number of
 important drawbacks related to an increase in cognitive costs. How is this context
 refined when we apply it to student motivation and the process of choosing undergraduate
 classes? Based on data collected from 326 students at New York University, this study
 proposes that individuals choosing from extensive choice sets experience lower post-choice
 satisfaction and increased feelings of regret. Building on the general proposition,
 the paper identifies additional internal factors —importance of choice, preference
 certainty, experience, and decision-making type— and examines whether they moderate
 the relationship between assortment size and choice overload. The results reveal that
 some internal factors do have this effect, and what's more, the impact differs between
 individual decision-makers. These findings suggest that assortment size alone cannot
 predict when choice overload is likely to occur, and raise the question of what factors
 influence individuals' post-choice sentiments.

Title: The Effect of Landmarks on Neighborhood Development
Abstract:
New York City is often held up as a successful example of a city that underwent gentrification
 alongside Paris, London, and other metropolises. Past researches and case studies
 have examined the development of neighborhoods in the Manhattan borough but have lacked
 focus in other boroughs of New York City although the metropolis consists of five
 boroughs; Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, and Staten Island. Some researchers
 have used the argument that the artistic brand created by artists and galleries can
 spur gentrification. In this paper, I examine whether the effect of iconic branding
 brought by the concentration of landmark buildings in Brooklyn generate physical (1)
 and financial (2) development in neighborhoods. Results indicated landmark buildings
 caused an increase in share of residential and office units, creating an inbound of
 more business and people to move in, as well as a rise in value of properties in close
 proximity.

Title: Sovereign Wealth Fund Investments: Short and Long-Term Stock Price Impacts
Abstract:
In this paper, I studied the impact of Sovereign Wealth Fund investments on public
 firms in which those funds invest. First, I estimated abnormal returns of firms that
 received SWF investment the next day and half-year after the event, and then determined
 the significance of those abnormal returns. I analyzed which factors explain those
 abnormal returns. I found that in short-term the market reaction to SWF investment
 is driven by how much stake of the firm SWF purchased and the transparency ranking
 of SWF. In the long-run, abnormal returns are explained by how much stake SWF purchased
 and the political affiliation of SWF.

Title:
Does Competition From Agricultural Imports Affect Production Efficiency Of Their Domestic
                                 Equivalents? A Study Of Rice Sector In Ghana
Abstract:
The link between agricultural policy distortions and the well-documented productivity
 gap between rich and poor countries remains largely unexplored. This study is the
 first to examine the effect of exposure to competition from agricultural imports on
 the performance of the domestic agricultural sector in a context allowing for insights
 into efficiency oriented trade policies of developing economies. Examined in this
 paper is Ghana's rice market, where for over a decade around 70 percent of demand
 has been met by imports, despite the right agronomic conditions to produce rice in
 Ghana throughout the year. I approach this question by analyzing the relationship
 between rice farm's productivity and exposure to rice imports, proxied as proximity
 to the coastline, where foreign rice accesses Ghana's market. Data obtained from GLSS
 6 demonstrates a robust negative relationship between the distance from the coastline
 and farm's productivity, which on its face defies the infant economy logic and predicts
 higher productivity where competition is high. Yet, there are two possibilities: either
 farms learn to become more competitive or inefficient farms quit rice production where
 competition is too high. Further analysis provides some evidence for the latter theory,
 but more research is essential to address the puzzle.

Title: Preferences in the Workplace and the Clash of Generations
Abstract:
We study cohort differences in job preferences using data from the International Social
 Survey Program. Using variations of the Age-Period-Cohort model, based on a multiphase
 non-parametric median polish analysis, we determine whether there are differences
 in job preferences between Millennials and prior generations. We contribute to the
 existing sparse literature on generational differences in the workplace by presenting
 a method to disentangle cohort effects from age and period effects based on epidemiology
 empirical research. This study shows that Millennials, especially younger members
 of the generation, are more likely to have higher preferences for meaningful jobs
 compared to Generation Xers and Baby Boomers. However, older members of the Silent
 generation exhibit similarly signi cant cohort effects, refuting Millennials' "exclusive"
 differentiation in job preferences relative to meaning. We show that while country
 setting and educational attainment have a signi cant effect on generational cohort
 variations relative to job preferences, their impact on preferences is very heterogeneous
 with often polarized bearings.

Title: Currency Devaluation and The Stock Market An Event Study on the Case of Egypt
Abstract:
This paper studies the effect of the floating and/or devaluation of currency on the
 stock market in Egypt using an event study methodology. The study uses data for daily
 stock index returns of the two main indices in Egypt: EGX30 and EGX100 for the period
 from August till November 2016, while carefully analyzing news and reports surrounding
 the dates of interest. Results suggest that there was pre-information or anticipation
 of the devaluation of the Egyptian pound prior to the official announcement. Results
 also show that the market reacted positively with increased average daily returns
 during the devaluation and the effect continued for a week after the devaluation announcement.

Title:
Cricket and crime rate: The effects of Cricket game outcomes on the levels of crime
                                 rate in the state of Karnataka, India
Abstract:
The relationship between sports and violence has been well documented through multiple
 different studies, however, crime effects are rarely observed in developing countries
 as well as in less popular sports. Using vast daily data on more than 40 different
 crimes from 600 police stations in Karnataka, India between 2011-2016, and more than
 500 cricket games of different formats from the same time span, we observe the relationship
 between cricket game outcomes and effects on crimes. Through our analysis, we have
 found that violent crime in the state goes up by a significant amount when Indian
 national team and/or Karnataka state team losses a game. Indian Premier League (IPL)
 games have bigger effects on property crimes and have not shown significant effects
 on other grouped crimes. The study also contributes to the general discussion of sports
 and crimes against women as well as ethnic and religious minorities. In the majority
 of the observations, except of IPL, no serious effects regarding crimes against women
 and ethnic minorities were found. The results provide evidence for the non-economic
 theory of crime, but also in some instances show effects on economic drivers of crime.

Title: Undoing Racial Discrimination: An Unintended Consequence
Abstract:
This paper explores serial independence of foul calls in the National Basketball Association
 (NBA). In 2007, Price and Wolfers found evidence for positive own-race bias in NBA
 referee decisions; they received great attention from the media and prompted wide
 criticism of referee behavior. Six years later, Pope, Price, and Wolfers (2013) found
 that raised awareness reduced the racial bias. Building upon this research, our paper
 suggests that in a conscious effort to seem unbiased and fair, following Price and
 Wolfers (2007), referees began to alter their foul calls based on the race of the
 players. They avoided long sequence of fouls on players of the same race. In our research,
 we find evidence for higher degrees of negative serial correlation or lower degrees
 of positive serial correlation in referee foul calls post-2007. Hence, in an attempt
 to undo racial discrimination, referees have failed to achieve color-blind decisions.

Title: Entrepreneurship Education and Startup Development: The Case of the UAE
Abstract:
There has been done an extensive amount of research on the role of entrepreneurship
 education and startup development around the world. However, only during the last
 decade Middle Eastern startup ecosystem started its rapid growth. UAE specifically
 has been reported as one of the most attractive countries in the world for entrepreneurs
 and investors. This paper discusses the relationship between entrepreneurship education
 and startup development in the context of the UAE. The research uses 61 observations
 collected manually through an online survey and 12 in-depth interviews with UAE founders.

Title:
The Effect of Foreign Direct Investment Inflow on Entrepreneurial Activity: A Difference-in-differences
                                 Analysis of the Case of Egypt
Abstract:
This paper investigates the effect of foreign direct investment on the performance
 of entrepreneurial firms in Egypt. The study explores the geographical variation in
 FDI inflows across Egypt, and uses a difference-in-differences estimation to measure
 the treatment effect from 2013 to 2016. Using firm-level panel data from the World
 Bank Enterprise Survey, the study uses intensive measures of entrepreneurial activity:
 firm sales and no of employees. The paper bases its choice of variables on the notion
 that, like new firms, many incumbent firms display entrepreneurial activity through
 growth in sales and size (Ahmed & Hoffman, 2008). With approximately 4,000 entries,
 the paper controls for different sets of regressors, to minimize omitted variable
 bias. Overall, the results either display negative or insignificant effects of FDI
 on entrepreneurship. These results are consistent with findings in earlier firm-level
 papers like Konings (2001), De Backer & Sleuwaegen (2003), and Barbosa & Eiriz (2009),
 and are in line with the crowding out theory.

Title: Carbon Trade and Labor Markets in the European Union
Abstract:
Attempts to mitigate the adverse effects of climate change through various carbon
 pricing mechanisms consistently raise concerns over increased production costs and
 job displacement. This paper aims to estimate the impact of the largest of such arrangements
 – the European Union Emissions Trading Scheme (EU ETS) – on labor market dynamics
 in the region in the third trading period of the ETS. Differently from the previous
 literature, we test the effect of both primary and secondary ETS market on employment
 rates across the EU member states. We find a small positive relationship between employment
 and carbon pricing. Results suggest that there is much room for interpretation of
 the impact of carbon markets on the economic activity of its respective region.

Title:
Immigration: Opportunity or Threat? Analyzing the Wage Effects of Eastern European
                                 Immigration in the Polish Labor Market
Abstract:
After joining the European Union in 2004, Poland experienced a considerable economic
 growth which was accompanied by a mass emigration of its citizens. By 2017 around
 2.5 million Polish citizens emigrated, creating a supply shortage in the labour market.In
 2013 this situation started to change with a sudden increase of the number of immigrants
 from the former USSR, mainly Ukrainians, entering the Polish labour market. Their
 number reached 1.6 million in 2018.The immigration phenomenon coincided with a period
 of rapid growth of the Polish economy, leading to a lot of speculation about the role
 of the immigrants in the economic development of Poland. This Capstone Project explores
 the economic effect of immigration in Poland by approaching the most controversial
 part of it, namely the wage effect in the labour market. The methodology used in the
 project leads to a rejection of the hypothesis stating that the presence of immigrants
 has a negative effect on the level of Polish wages.

Title:
Professionalization of UAE-Based Art Galleries and Their Evolving Role as Cultural
                                 Entrepreneurs
Abstract:
This qualitative investigation studies the emergence of the UAE art market by focusing
 on the developments of the primary art galleries. Based on a series of interviews
 with gallerists and other art professionals, this paper analyzes the role of gallerists
 as cultural entrepreneurs in terms of their professionalization and their ability
 to legitimize the value of contemporary art. Three stages in the developments of UAE-based
 galleries have been distinguished from 1979 until today, based on their level of professionality
 and their market scope. Additionally, this research finds three driving forces behind
 the professionalization of the art galleries: the pioneering role of The Third Line
 gallery, the opening of Christie's in Dubai, and the presence of international galleries
 during the local art fairs.

Title:
Can developing countries pay for Climate Adaptation? Experimental Evidence Through
                                 a Contingent Valuation Method (CV) in Nepal
Abstract:
Despite the widespread consensus on the need of climate adaptation finance to support
 developing countries, funding for climate adaptation projects is limited. There is
 extensive debate and literature that suggests that adaptation funding will come ultimately
 from the residents of developed countries via taxation. This paper, however, studies
 the willingness to pay (WTP) for adaptation from glacial flooding among university
 students in Nepal as a way to explore if residents of developing countries can fill
 the funding gap for climate adaptation. By eliciting WTP using a contingent valuation
 method, I see that university students in Nepal exhibit a positive value for funding
 climate adaptation. Consistent with other studies, I see that gender and level of
 income have a significant influence on the WTP value while information treatment does
 not. While the positive WTP value among students of developing countries can be used
 to fulfill the funding gap, it also highlights the urgency to which adaptation funding
 is required in vulnerable communities.

Title:
The Real Cost to Wed in the United Arab Emirates: A Study on the Economic, Educational
                                 and Cultural Determinants of Mahr in the UAE
Abstract:
Although it is widely discussed that dowry amounts in the United Arab Emirates have
 been on the rise, what influences such a change is yet to be understood. To examine
 the determinants of dowry, I administer an original retrospective survey to create
 a data set for marriage and dowry statistics. Over 1,500 observations were gathered
 to test for (1) assortative matching, (2) effects of a bride's characteristics on
 the size of dowry and (3) effects of a groom's characteristics on the size of dowry.
 Results reveal that there is a high degree of positive marital sorting by education,
 social hierarchy and wealth. Moreover, in a marriage market, women can bargain for
 a higher dowry or a spouse through their mannerisms (i.e. social hierarchy levels
 and educational attainment). Contrarily, the characteristics of men that are observed
 to have a significant and positive effect on the size of a dowry are considered to
 be materialistic (wealth and income levels). The results highlight important influencers
 of dowry size that will hopefully lend a helping hand to policymakers in impeding
 further dowry inflation in the UAE.

Title: Wage inequality in Football Association: the case of English Premier League
Abstract:
This paper tests for the existence of nationality, race and skin tone wage discriminations
 amongst players in the English Premier League. An OLS regression analysis has been
 performed on each variable to test for the existence of wage discrimination. The results
 show that non-white and non-European players earn an economically significant salary
 premium compared to white and European players of similar productivity. There is no
 significant evidence of salary discrimination against non-white and non-European players.
 The OLS models explain more than 65 percent of the observable variance in player salaries.
 In addition, no significant evidence of wage discrimination based on skin color tone
 was identified.

Title: Predicting the Success of Cryptocurrencies: An Economic Model
Abstract:
The rise of blockchain cryptocurrencies has noted both great successes and spectacular
 failures that sparked interest of the general public. In order to respond to the uncertainty
 millions of casual investors' experiences, I outline a predictive model that can provide
 a consistent way of estimating the prospective outcome reached by a given cryptocurrency
 (Azgad-Tromer 2018). The paper is chiefly concerned with the determinants affecting
 the token success defined as an aggregate of measures, including per-currency market
 capitalization. I propose that the most indicative analysis should be primarily based
 on a scrutinous examination of the network structure of the cryptocurrency-issuing
 companies. I believe the presence of the bonds among the employees of the coins, established
 through various incidents of shared employment noted in their job history, has an
 impact on the success of the firm. With the data from LinkedIn, a professional career-oriented
 website, used in the cryptocurrency field as a primary medium of promotion, I show
 that economic success of firms positively correlates with their centrality measures
 in the network. The analysis concludes the network structure of a company is a significant
 factor of success and can be used to predict the outcome of a particular coin.

Title: Smart and Attractive: Exploring the Relationship Between Smart Cities and Migration
Abstract:
This paper explores the relationship between a city's level of smartness and its net
 wave of migration. Based on a regional census provided by Eurostat, we use technology-related
 characteristics to define a an index of city smartness. We then propose a model of
 migration to the city which includes three different methodologies to compute smartness:
 independent smart variables, Z-Score Standardization, and Principle Component Analysis.
 For each methodology, we run four OLS regressions with different level of control
 variables in order to explore changes of behavior in our smart index. The most important
 result is the positive but weak correlation between migration and smartness using
 the Principal Component approach.

Title:
Surfing the High Seas: Factors that Influence the Decisions of Internet Users to Download
                                 Movies
Abstract:
While global cinema and TV revenues have fallen over the past two decades, downloading
 online movies for free has become increasingly common among the youth in the past
 two decades. Using survey data from current NYUAD students, this paper investigates
 how nine factors influence the likelihood and the extent of downloading. Budget constraint
 has a positive correlation with the number of movies downloaded in the past 6 months.
 Budget constraint, social norms, and attitudes regarding fairness are statistically
 significant influence on the frequency of downloading. Budget constraint and swiftness
 of legal punishment are statistically significant predictors on the last time users
 downloaded. The only variable that was a consistent statistically significant predictor
 of the likelihood and the propensity of downloading was budget constraint.

Title: Bitcoin and Beyond: Effect of Regulations on Development of Cryptocurrencies
Abstract:
The increasing popularity of Bitcoin attracted the attention of the governments worldwide,
 which decided to impose various regulations on digital assets. This paper focuses
 on the previously not investigated topic of the impact of national regulations on
 the development of Bitcoin all over the world. The research concentrates on finding
 the answer to the question what is the impact of national regulations on cryptocurrencies
 on their acceptance as a payment method. In order to answer this question, the paper
 uses panel data regression with fixed effects with fixed country effect. The regulations
 categories investigated in the paper are self-designed. According to the results,
 most of the regulations categories included in the paper are significantly correlated
 with Bitcoin acceptance as a payment method, modeled through the number of vendors
 accepting Bitcoin as means of payment for transactions per country.

Title: What do farmers get?
Abstract:
When buying agricultural commodities from farmers traders pay a price based on stock
 exchange commodity futures, but the price paid to the farmer often differs from that
 international price. This paper investigates the economic passthrough to farmers in
 Brazil. We analyze this by using purchase data from the world's largest coffee merchant.
 We use a flexible econometric model that allows us to examine the role of different
 contract specifications such as coffee quality, contract size, certifications to analyze
 how economic passthrough are determined. Based on our estimates, we examine how farmers
 can structure their sales in order to maximize the economic passthrough they get.

Title: Income and The Gender Gap in Education: The Case of Gambia
Abstract:
The right to education is one of the most fundamental human rights. By investigating
 the educational attainment of individuals using the 2015 Gambian Integrated Household
 Survey (IHS), I evaluate the gender discrepancy in educational attainment of individuals,
 while also exploring the impact of income, through the lens of rainfall as a proxy,
 on the gender inequality in education in Gambia. I find that before the Girls' Education
 Initiative was introduced, girls have more years of education than boys and boys'
 years of education is positively impacted by rainfall. Moreover, I find that rainfall
 is negatively associated with years of education for boys during post-reform period
 and unrelated to females' years of education, which suggests that the gender gap is
 closing.

Title: Airports and City Attractiveness for FDI
Abstract:
The aim of this paper is to empirically investigate whether an airport influences
 a city's attractiveness, as measured by the number of new greenfield foreign direct
 investment (FDI) projects received during the period 2003-2014. To do so, we built
 a unique database in which we gather information, for more than 3300 cities in the
 world, on the number of FDI projects, on the presence and extent of airports, on other
 public transport infrastructure, and on many socio-economic characteristics of cities
 likely to affect multinational location decisions. We find that a hub airport has
 a significant impact on the attractiveness of a city for foreign investors. These
 results are robust to the implementation of a long-term difference which enables to
 control for potential remaining unobserved factors of the attractiveness of a city.
 According to our estimates, building an airport leads to 11% more inward FDI in the
 city.

Title: Heat and the Ability to Play a Game: Evidence from Professional Tennis Players
Abstract:
There has been no study to show a correlation between heat and human cognitive ability
 to play a game. We use tennis as a target of study and test if temperature affects
 serial independence and winning probabilities differently across genders. We find
 serial independence decreases at higher temperature for men, but no effects are observed
 for women. We also discover winning probabilities are more frequently equalized when
 it is hot for women, while winning probabilities are equalized regardless of temperature
 for men. Our result implies heat impairs human cognitive ability to play a game for
 men, but not for women. Besides, heat may even facilitate cognitive ability to play
 a game for women.

Title: Logistics Performance on Sectoral Specialization
Abstract:
This is a novel and preliminary attempt at studying the impact logistics performance
 has on patterns of sectoral specialization across countries. The hypothesis is that
 improvements on logistics performance offers competitive advantage for sectors that
 employ logistics heavily and therefore causing sectoral specialization trends as logistics
 intensive sectors grow relative to non-logistics intensive sectors. Generalized-Least-Square
 analysis is used for the panel data consisted of 63 countries across 2007, 2010, 2012,
 and 2014. Some statistically significant result supports the hypothesis and shows
 improvements in logistics performance has expansionary and contractionary effects
 on the relative size of sectors that use logistics intensively and those that do not
 use logistics intensively respectively. The results suffer from endogeneity, but instrument
 variable methods cannot be applied appropriately because of the limited data available.

Title: Emerging Markets as an Asset Class and Investors Behaviour
Abstract:
We assess the factors that investors take into account when reacting to financial
 shocks across Emerging Markets (EM), covering four (4) key episodes of EM-wide financial
 stress since the mid-1990s to 2018: i) the Mexican "Tequila" Crisis of 1994, ii) the
 South American Economic Crisis of 2002, iii) the Argentine Economic Crisis of 2018,
 and iv) the Turkish Currency and Debt Crisis of 2018. Using a VAR approach and a series
 of post-regression tests, we conclude that: 1) Investors did not discriminate across
 EMEs before the Global Financial Crisis (GFC) which led to strong intracontinental
 contagion; 2) Differentiation among EMEs based on macroeconomic fundamentals after
 the GFC is much more evident; 3) Specific factors such as trade patterns and currency
 exposure between the source country and other EMEs influence investors decisions,
 leading to heterogeneous responses to shocks and country-specific contagion; 4)the
 role of capital controls in explaining financial contagion is unclear given the limited
 availability of capital flows and foreign ownership data.

Title: Do Industrial Parks Spur Innovation: Evidence From China
Abstract:
With development of industrial parks increasingly favored by developing countries
 as a strategy to simulate domestic innovation, the relationship between industrial
 clustering and technological innovation has been a subject of intense interest and
 debate. This study presents a big-picture, cross-sectoral view of the effect of industrial
 clustering on innovation in China. With fixed-effects regression analyses on an original
 panel dataset covering over 2000 industrial parks in China and spanning 19 years,
 I found no significant relationship between industrial park development and levels
 of innovation activities. The study controls for indicators of regional GDP levels
 and educational attainment and found increases in GDP per capita and proportion of
 residents with at least college education to be much more strongly associated with
 innovation capacity regardless of the level of government-initiated industrial clustering.

Title: Distributive Politics and a Simple Voter Game
Abstract:
People vote for different policies depending on the information that they receive.
 They construct strategies based on how they believe other voters will behave. This
 paper adds to the literature that investigates policies that are ex-ante preferrable
 but that fail to pass because these policies do not receive the majority vote. By
 using a simple two-person voting game, we find two equilibria one of which is trivial
 and one of which is responsive to the specific information provided for a voter. We
 implement the Fehr-Schmidt utility function which allows voters utilities to be inequity
 averse by incorporating the "shame" and the "envy" components. Ultimately, we find
 that this equilibrium is robust to this inequity aversion.

Title: Capital Structure Choices in the Middle East: The Case of the UAE Firms
Abstract:
Financial markets of the Middle Eastern Arab countries have long evolved under the
 influence of the local culture and religion. Among all, the particularities of the
 tax system in the United Arab Emirates suggest its importance as a ground for examining
 the capital structure choices of the local firms, especially in the context of the
 economic development in the region since early 2000's. This research focuses on 54
 publicly traded non-financial firms in the UAE in the period of 2011- 2017 to re-evaluate
 the positive relationships between the leverage ratio and firms' growth opportunities
 derived by Barakat in the period 1997-2003 and to explore other factors attributing
 to the leverage, such as tax rate, collateral, dividends, firm size, profitability
 and volatility.

Title: Experience in Professional Baseball and Salary Premia in South Korea
Abstract:
This project explores the relationship between years of experience and salaries of
 professional baseball players in Korean Baseball Organization (KBO) and Major League
 Baseball (MLB). Through a comparative analysis of Korean and American baseball salary
 data, this study attempts to test whether or not the Korean cultural tendency to respect
 seniority is reflected in the Korean baseball world. Results suggest that baseball
 salary is positively correlated with years of experience after controlling for age
 and statistical performance indicators. Furthermore, an interaction term comprised
 of the main independent variable and the dummy variable indicates that the Korean
 Baseball Organization (KBO) League offers higher salary premia for more experienced
 players.

Title:
An analysis of the level and predictors of Financial Literacy among youth in the United
                                 Arab Emirates
Abstract:
Financial literacy is a measure of how adequate a person is to make sound financial
 decisions. Historically, financial literacy is reported to be on a low level worldwide.
 The disadvantaged groups, measured to have lower levels of financial literacy are
 older people and teenagers, women, less educated and lower-income bracket people.
 This paper estimates the level of financial literacy of Emirati university students
 and evaluates what indicators drive students' levels of financial literacy by conducting
 a three-section survey. Results show that there is a statistically significant relationship
 between financial literacy level and gender, employment status, family income and
 saving behavior.

Title:
Estimating Labor Market Participation and Employment Transitions for Disadvantaged
                                 Single Men in the United States: Evidence from the SIPP
Abstract:
Low-educated, young, single men in the United States are an understudied demographic
 group with a high poverty incidence and a low labor force participation rate. Moreover,
 their situation has deteriorated since the onset of the Great Recession. In this paper,
 I describe the transitions of single men, aged between 25 to 54 years, with a high
 school degree or less, in and out of the labor force, and in and out employment. I
 tie their labor market participation and employment behavior to economic conditions.
 Using the Survey of Income and Program Participation dataset from 1995 to 2015 and
 employing a dynamic probit model, I show that labor market participation and employment
 status in the previous period overwhelmingly influence their status in the current
 period. I also find that their transitions are substantially affected by changes in
 the state-level unemployment rate, but not from changes in the minimum wage. I estimate
 these effects for my whole sample and by race. I also conduct a sensitivity analysis.

Title:
Are living standards consistent predictors of communal budgets across time? Case study
                                 on Ile-de-France and its banlieues (1999 – 2017)
Abstract:
This project looks to establish the existence of a link between different measures
 of socio-economic well-being and the size of the budget allocated to a commune in
 the Parisian region, across time. Communes are the smallest French territorial divisions
 and since 1982, raise a substantial part of their budget on their own following a
 national policy on fiscal and administrative decentralization. The Ile-de-France region
 counts 1276 communes as of 2018 (INSEE) and offers the ideal set-up for a case study
 with the capital city Paris being at its center and it
 offering data on many observable economic variables. The central question driving
 this thesis is the extent to which the public budget collected by every municipality
 is affected by the standard of living of individuals in that very circumscription.
 I hypothesize that living standards should consistently predict, across
 time, budget size. If that hypothesis holds, the implication is that richer communes
 would get a higher budget per capita, therefore feeding into a cycle of positive cash
 recycling (i.e. more infrastructures and productive public goods). The poorer communes,
 where are located most of the banlieues and a large immigrant and second-
 generation immigrant population, would then see a widening inequality gap in terms
 of available funds and therefore opportunities for social mobility. The findings point
 towards the existence of a time lag between living standards and budgets as well as
 a two-way causal relation; I find that income levels and quality of education
 corroborate my main hypothesis. However, the data shows that the government is intervening
 to level up the budget inequalities through equalization schemes.

Title: Gender Differences in Loss Aversion
Abstract:
Gender differences play a defining role in today's global labor environment. There
 is a growing body of literature linking gender differences in the labor market to
 varying attitudes towards risk and loss. This study examines loss preferences as measured
 in an online experiment conducted on Amazon Mechanical Turk. In my experiment, participants
 with diverse socioeconomic backgrounds take part in an incentivized loss preference
 elicitation task involving ten lotteries that entail possible gains and losses. I
 report significant gender differences in loss aversion, with females exhibiting higher
 levels of loss aversion than males. I find that tolerance toward losses is inversely
 related with age while no significant relationship exists between loss aversion and
 income or education.

Title: Diffusion of Information Goods in Networks With Restriction on Resale
Abstract:
We study how network structures affect the diffusion of an information good, when
 there are limited resale opportunities. Buyers not only are consumers, but also act
 as intermediaries as they reproduce the good at zero cost and resell it to other buyers
 they have access to. Sellers indirectly appropriate profits from buyers along intermediation
 chains, but also enter into competition with buyers who replicate and resell. A network
 partition captures the effects of monopoly power versus competition. We extend the
 analysis to investigate the effects of limited resale opportunities on a seller's
 captive market and profits. By generating a directed network, we find that restricting
 resale expands sellers' captive markets when a network is sufficiently well-connected.
 Meanwhile, restricting resale limits diffusion and generates competition between buyers.
 As a result, a seller may be unable to extract profits from every buyer within his
 captive market, but he may obtain more than his bilateral monopoly share when the
 threat of dealing with the next highest-value buyer is credible. We find a formula
 to compute sellers' profits when there is no uncertainty in diffusion paths and competition
 between buyers does not interact with competition between sellers.

Title: The Impact of Infrastructure Development on Economic Growth: Evidence from China
Abstract:
China has demonstrated incredible overall economic growth in the past four decades,
 yet, regional development of the country has not been balanced: economically developed
 East drastically contrasts the rural West. By studying China, a country that transformed
 from an agricultural giant into a global innovation hub in less than 30 years, yet
 still demonstrates presence of significant regional disparities, this project aims
 at assessing the relationship between infrastructure development and economic growth
 in various provinces of China. In this research, the focus is on hard infrastructure
 and how presence of paved roads, city bridges, and street lights contributes to economic
 development. A comprehensive and up-to-date dataset from 1998 to 2017 is used to assess
 the relationship between fluctuations in infrastructure development and economic growth
 while accounting for endogeneity.

Title: To What Extent Are Chinese Takeovers in Europe Value-Driven?
Abstract:
A growing number of acquisitions of European companies by Chinese entities in the
 last few years has fuelled a vigorous debate in Europe over the economics of such
 acquisitions and over the long-term geopolitical implications of this phenomenon.
 The European Parliament has recently passed a regulation to implement a European mechanism
 to screen inbound cross-border takeovers and various European leaders expressly address
 the phenomenon as a threat for Europe's independence and stability. This research
 contributes to this debate by showing that European companies acquired by Chinese
 ones in the past decade have performed in line with comparable companies in Europe.
 It therefore advocates a cautious treatment of the geopolitical concerns without nonetheless
 forgetting the benefits provided to society by a lively market for corporate control
 and by successful company acquisitions.

Title: Long Run Economic Outcomes of Ancient Nomadic Travel Routes in the Highlands of Asia
Abstract:
Works on the impact of transportation infrastructure are primarily comparison studies
 across periods or location setting (rural vs. urban). These works fail to include
 how a location's geographic (terrain) characteristics might influence the emergence
 of economic activities. Similarly, the conventional narrative among these existing
 works depends on the construction of actual transportation infrastructure which leads
 to a lack of exogeneity variation in the studies. This paper confines the study to
 a fixed geographic setting (Asian highland) as it faces its own sets of challenges
 and barriers to infrastructure development. To overcome the lack of exogeneity in
 the study, we use simulated travel routes taken by nomadic pastoralist for hundreds
 of years in the region as a proxy for the transportation network. We make use of nightlight
 intensity, population density, locations of road networks, and cities' locations to
 study how closely contemporary economic activities are established around the ancient
 travel routes. We find that there are positive economic outcomes in the region where
 simulated travel routes existed suggesting a long-lasting positive effect of infrastructure
 development on the economy.

Title:
A Hedonic Price Analysis on the Impact of Macroeconomic Policies on Residential Rental
                                 Listing Prices in the Emirate of Abu Dhabi
Abstract:
This capstone explores the economic impact that macroeconomic housing policy decisions
 have had on residential rental listing prices in the Emirate of Abu Dhabi. It is motivated
 by a desire to address the following questions: What internal and external factors
 influence the rental listing prices of residential Apartments and Villas in the Emirate
 of Abu Dhabi? What effects do housing-related government policies have on these prices?
 By employing hedonic price analysis, this paper confirms the following Hypothesis:
 Macroeconomic policy changes relating to housing have had substantive impact on residential
 rental listing prices in the Emirate of Abu Dhabi. This paper presents evidence that,
 for the Emirate of Abu Dhabi, the implementation of housing fees for non-citizen residents
 and the introduction of a relocation policy have had statistically significant impacts
 on rental listing prices for both Apartments and Villas.

Title:
Influence of Macroeconomic Indicators on the Spread Between Emerging Market and US
                                 Bonds Between January 2008 and December 2017
Abstract:
This paper analyzes the impact of macroeconomic indicators on spreads between yields
 on Emerging Markets and US bonds. The data examined spans from January 2008 to December
 2017 and covers a set of seven countries: Brazil, China, Hungary, Poland, Russia,
 South Africa and Turkey. Probed independent variables include: CPI, Total Reserves,
 price of Brent Oil, Debt to-GDP ratio, imports and short-term interest rates. Panel
 data regressions such as Fixed Effects Model and Random Effects Model are used to
 determine the impact of independent variables. The Hausman Test is used in order
 to account for the most accurate model. The Random Effects Model was shown to be the
 most accurate. Analysis presented CPI, Price of Brent Oil, and Short term interest
 rates as statistically significant variables on a 1% significance level in the explanation
 of the spread.

Title: A Comparative Study on Healthcare Systems around the world
Abstract:
This capstone project aims to find the impact of out-of-pocket percentage of health
 financing on several key health indicators. With more coverage and decreased out-of-pocket
 percentage, there is both an increase in appropriate and necessary health services
 rendered as well as an increase in inappropriate and unnecessary services. Higher
 out-of-pocket payments also mean people either use medical services fewer times or
 that people are more incentivized to take better care of their bodies in order to
 pay less for health services. The methodology of this study is multiple statistical
 regressions on key health indicators and out-of-pocket percentage with varying control
 variables. Fixed effects regressions were also used to better eliminate the different
 intra-country effects on results. The results of this study find that increased out-of-pocket
 percentage of health financing increases health according to the key health indicators,
 with 4 of the 6 health indicators being statistically significant. Other findings
 include more statistical significance in wealthier countries that spend more on health
 expenditure than less wealthy countries, as well as no statistical significance between
 geographical locations.

Title: Energy Investment in Developing Countries: Trends and Determinants
Abstract:
Developing countries are set to drive the world's additional energy consumption between
 now until 2040. With climate change a major threat during this time period and linked
 to the use of non-renewable energy, the burden to invest in renewable energy lies
 upon developing countries. Yet, they face the dual challenge of expensive renewable
 energy sources combined with enticing Chinese investment opportunities in non-renewable
 energy sources. In this report, I analyse the energy investment trends of developing
 countries between 2014-2018. I then use regression analysis to understand the determinants
 of investment in renewable energy in these countries, of which energy consumption,
 energy shortages, and Belt Road Initiative participation are found to be significant
 variables. Data is primarily sourced from Inframation News, with supporting data from
 the World Bank and Damodaran.

Title:
Do we expect women to volunteer more than men? Framing and gender differences in the
                                 game of chicken
Abstract:
Recently, Babcock et al. (2017) claims that one cause for gender differences in labor
 market outcomes may be that women are more likely than men to receive and accept tasks
 with low promotability. Using a lab coordination game similar to the game of chicken,
 they argue that women have higher probability of volunteering than men and that such
 behavior is influenced by subjects' belief that women are more likely to volunteer.
 The experimental design labelling the volunteering task as "invest in a group account"
 raises questions on whether framing affects gender differences in the game and whether
 the conclusion is robust in a more diverse population. We applied three frames to
 the chicken game and conducted an online experiment. Our results show that framing
 increases volunteer rates for both genders but does not affect gender gaps. We also
 find that women indeed volunteer more than men across treatments and that women are
 more likely than men to expect their female colleagues to volunteer.

Title: Would You Risk it All? An Experiment on Bargaining under Adverse Selection
Abstract:
When a buyer and seller bargain over the trade of a good, both parties have a tendency
 to cause costly and inefficient delay. Providing the opportunity to reject an offer
 more than once reduces total payoff because of time frictions, yet only allowing one
 rejection results in a significant reduction in trade frequency. In a laboratory experiment,
 buyers and sellers are asked to play different bargaining institutions of varying
 high type probabilities and time horizons. Findings suggest that participants are
 sensitive to increases in high type probabilities, as shown by an increase of both
 trade frequency and payoff. Although individual payoff rises, delay and inefficiency
 remain present even in games of non-severe adverse selection. When given the option
 of bargain type, buyers eventually tend towards the one-shot bargain, yet are not
 capable of consistently providing an offer that would ensure trade with the seller.
 As a result, buyers do not extract levels of individual profit equal to that of the
 ex-ante expected payoff. Behavioural preferences for loss aversion and fairness also
 play a significant role in determining how efficiency is distributed between buyer
 and seller.

Title: Sexual Assault on U
Abstract:
Despite the extensive qualitative research on sexual assault on college campuses,
 there is limited quantitative analysis of the topic that influences the safety and
 security of millions of students around the world. In my research, I conduct a quantitative
 analysis of the institutional factors that influence reported sexual assault on college
 campuses in the U.S. ranging from student body size to whether the institution is
 religious or secular and located in a college town or city, among other characteristics.
 My analysis indicates that there is a significant relationship between alcohol and
 reported sexual assault, with institutions that allow alcohol on campuses demonstrating
 higher rates of reported sexual assault.

Title: Gender Differential in the UAE Labor Market: A Pilot Study
Abstract:
This study investigates the effect of higher education on the male-female wage differential
 in the labor force of the United Arab Emirates through a pilot study investigation
 of graduate employment. Descriptive statistics and the Oaxaca-Blinder decomposition
 model are used to gain preliminary insights. Findings reveal a negative wage gap suggesting
 that females earn more than males. The paper concludes with recommendations of improving
 the research design by increasing the sample size, making the sample more representative
 of the population, and distributing the web survey more efficiently across higher
 education institutions.

Title:
Step Into or Stand Aside: Career Choices and Motivations of Emiratis to join the Family
                                 Business
Abstract:
Most people, in their lifetime, go through the process of choosing their career path.
 When people look at the options, they consider both pecuniary and nonpecuniary components
 of the job. In addition, to considering these components, people from families with
 family businesses need to consider individualistic and family perspectives when choosing
 their careers, and therefore more complexities arise. Upon looking at what makes a
 family business and its history in the context of the UAE, my study explores the factors
 influencing the career choices of Emiratis with family businesses and affecting the
 willingness of these Emirati individuals to involve in or abstain from their family
 business. My goal is to better understand the main factors that drive family members
 to make the type of career choices they do. Sixteen semi-structured interviews were
 conducted to find that family and personal factors influence the career decisions
 of the participant. Also, there are no major differences found in the factors that
 influenced male and female participants.

Title: Can it be Automated? An Abilities Approach to Detecting an Occupation's Rate of Automation
Abstract:
The aim of this paper is to uncover which occupations are the most susceptible to
 automation. I devise a unique methodology to construct a model which does just that.
 The first part of the method includes conducting a meta-study of over 40 engineering
 and computer science papers that cover recent developments in the fields of AI and
 Robotics. The second part involves using figures I derive during the meta-study along
 with O*NET Abilities data to determine the rate of automation for 968 different occupations.
 Following the calculation of the occupational rates of automation, I expound the meaning
 of the results, discuss limitations, and provide brief remarks on opportunities for
 future research.

Title: Creative Industries Comparative Study: Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates
Abstract:
Though the State of Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) are relatively young
 nations, they both have a rich history in the arts and culture. With Kuwait being
 the pioneer of the modern arts movement in the region and the UAE gaining global recognition
 for its tourism, the two countries make informative cases for a comparative study
 on the evolution of the creative and cultural industries (CCI) throughout the years.
 This comparative analysis will be divided across three levels: (1) Macro overview
 of cultural attraction using cultural and economic indicators; (2) aggregate percentage
 breakdown of artistic workers; and (3) yearly activity of established creative workers
 relative to other fields over time. My research contributions extend to analyzing
 macro-level relationships between economic and cultural indicators, outlining the
 most prominent professions within the arts and culture core sector, and producing
 the short-term differences in differences visual on notable culture-core workers relative
 to other professions for Kuwait and the UAE. This research is instrumental in paving
 the way for future research to analyze how policies and government incentives explain
 trends in the evolution of the arts and culture.

Title: How Do Regional Income Inequalities in the European Union Affect the Levels of Euroscepticism?
Abstract:
This paper explores the relationship between regional income inequalities and their
 impact on the electoral manifestation of Euroscepticism in the 2019 elections to the
 European Parliament. For all EU-28 countries, the model developed in this paper merges
 regional- and national-level data by capturing regional income inequality values within
 a country. Regional income disparity is measured by the standard deviation of Gross
 Regional Product per capita across each country. This metric is then introduced into
 the multivariate regression model featuring additional economic and political variables.
 The model supports the hypothesis that the magnitude of regional income disparities
 have a positive impact on the electoral manifestation of Eurosceptic attitudes, although
 with a statistically insignificant result. The positive effect of regional income
 inequalities on Eurosceptic votes is especially pronounced in non-Eurozone countries.

Title:
Sponsoring Refuge: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Pay to Support Venezuelan Refugees
                                 in Colombia
Abstract:
Colombia has hosted about 35% of 4.6 million Venezuelan Refugees since 2015. However,
 little is known about consumer support for efforts aiding refugees, and even less
 within the context of the Venezuelan refugee crisis. This paper uses an online survey
 to gather data and measure consumer willingness to pay for efforts supporting Venezuelan
 refugees in Colombia. I also implement a priming mechanism through a sentence-descrambling
 exercise in order to increase saliency and sensitization to the crisis in Colombia,
 and measure its effect on respondents' generosity, empathy and willingness to pay.
 I find that priming robustly and consistently increases respondents' levels of generosity
 and empathy. However, such effects do not extend to significant increases in consumer
 willingness to pay. Taken together, these findings suggest a clear disconnect between
 self-identification with generous and empathic attitudes and real willingness to monetarily
 support programs aiding Venezuelan refugees. As a pioneer in the field, this paper
 opens the discussion of consumer attitudes toward supporting this crisis and highlights
 the urgency to motivate an integrated approach to refugee aid by understanding consumer
 support for such aid efforts.

Title: Healthcare ICT Usage and Healthcare Outcomes
Abstract:
Healthcare information communication technologies (ICT) have been credited as tools
 to significantly improve public health outcomes, yet there is a lack of compelling
 evidence on the impact of Healthcare ICT on patient-centric healthcare outcomes. This
 paper estimates the effects of physicians' and patients' active healthcare ICT usage
 on the change in the number of patients treated. Using physician-level survey data,
 this paper finds that the effects of active healthcare ICT usage are modest but significant.
 The data shows that the positive impact of Healthcare ICT usage on healthcare outcomes,
 on average, is the highest in large city hospitals and in hospitals where computers
 are used during consultations. This paper fails to reject the hypothesis that the
 usage of Healthcare ICT has no effect on the change in the number of patients seen
 and patients treated.

Title: Does Trade Openness Have an Impact on Deforestation?
Abstract:
Globalization observed over the last 30 years has greatly shaped the land-use practices
 around the world and increased the opportunity cost of keeping natural forests intact.
 A strong economic incentive to convert forest land for other uses presented governments
 with a trade-off between the economic and environmental value of the natural forests.
 This paper examines the impact of trade openness on deforestation per a given level
 of income in 1990- 2015. I create an instrument based on the gravity model of bilateral
 trade flows to account for the possible endogeneity of trade. I also estimate the
 model separately for countries with high and low levels of agricultural exports. I
 find no significant relationship between trade openness and deforestation but report
 consistent evidence that the Environmental Kuznets Curve Hypothesis holds true in
 the case of the deforestation.

Title: Fatality and Age in USA Vehicle Accidents: Using the Fatality Analysis Reporting System
Abstract:
This paper observes the age of persons involved in fatal car crashes and the additional
 variables that impact the fatalities. Data from the 2010 Fatality Analysis Reporting
 System (FARS) are used. Additional variables of sex, vehicle age, and crash location
 are used to show the relationship between age and fatalities in crashes. The youngest
 drivers, from 18 to 24 years, have the highest number of fatalities with a peak at
 19 years old. However, when adjusted for the US population it is determined that 80
 to 84 years have the most fatalities with 15 to 19 years having the second most.

Title:
Effect of Social Media Marketing Activities on Customer Equity: An Empirical Study
                                 of a Startup Cosmetic Brand
Abstract:
This paper examines the effectiveness of social media marketing activities by analyzing
 data of a Korean startup cosmetic brand, Phykology. Due to the rapid increase in the
 usage of social media, businesses tend to invest more resources in social media marketing.
 However, it is very challenging to evaluate and assess the effect quantitatively.
 The four activities, influencer marketing, social media advertisements, giveaway events,
 and sales promotion, are identified as the main social media marketing activities
 that the company has allocated its resources the most. Their impact on drivers of
 customer equity, which are brand equity, relationship equity, and value equity, are
 examined. The result identified specific features of the social media marketing activities
 that have significantly positive effect on customer equity, providing suggestions
 for the marketing strategy of the firm.

Title: Gender and Racial Discrimination in Mortgage Rates
Abstract:
The 1992 Boston Fed Study revealed that minorities in the US are significantly more
 likely to be rejected for a mortgage even while controlling for objective characteristics
 of the financial Situation of the borrower. Following these findings, substantial
 debate and academic research explored discrimination in the mortgage market by looking
 at the probability of rejection for a mortgage as well as the mortgage rates different
 groups pay. Furthermore, research revealed that in periods of recession, minority
 groups are adversely affected with regards to labor market conditions. This study
 investigates the effect of changes in the business cycle (as demonstrated by state
 unemployment rates) on the differences in mortgage rates paid by: White men; White
 women; African American men; African American women; Hispanic men; and Hispanic women.
 Using data from the Federal Housing and Finance Agency and the Bureau of Labor Statistics,
 the results suggested that Hispanic Females and Males pay the highest mortgage rates
 on average when controlling for several characteristics including borrower credit
 scores. The results also revealed that if anything, Black males get the most favorable
 rates on their mortgages. Finally, the paper revealed that white males and females
 were the most sensitive to changes in unemployment rates.

Title: The Drivers of Demand for Ride-Hailing Services in New York City
Abstract:
Since their debut in 2009, Ride-Hailing services have been widely described as both
 disruptive and transformative. This research project aims to investigate the key factors
 that drive demand for the services in New York City, by using data from the 2017 US
 National Household Travel Survey. Using a Zero-Inflated Negative Binomial Count Model,
 the analysis in this paper sheds light on the impact of Ride-hailing in terms of improved
 accessibility, sustainability and inclusivity. It also explores its relationship with
 Public transit, and whether it is a viable solution to the First Mile/ Last Mile problem
 in Public transportation. Results from this study provide more clarity on the impact
 of Ride-Hailing on the local transportation ecosystem if New York City.

Title: Artificial Intelligence vs Professional Poker Players: Analyzing Mixed-Strategy Equilibrium
Abstract:
In 2016, Deepstack became the first Artificial Intelligence player to defeat professionals
 at two-player poker. Using empirical payoffs from the game, I study the behavior of
 Deepstack and professionals with respect to von Neumann's theory of mixed-strategy
 equilibrium. I use two-sided t-tests and the Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests to compare the
 observed data with the hypothesis. I find that both DeepStack and professionals play
 at the predicted level of optimality, at the 95% confidence interval. The results
 contribute to existing literature that show the role of experience and professionality
 in situations where people try to outguess their opponents.

Title: The Effect of Leadership Transitions in Latin America on Investor Beliefs
Abstract:
This paper explores the effect transitions in leadership ideologies have on foreign
 investor beliefs in Latin American countries. Investor beliefs will be represented
 by FDI as a percentage of GDP, macroeconomic factors related to attractiveness of
 a country as an investment will be used as controls, as well as regime types and executive
 constraints. The study finds that transitions from right leaning ideologies to left
 ones tend to have a positive impact on FDI while transitions from left leaning ideologies
 to right leanings ones' result in a negative impact. The study also highlights the
 importance of the type of regime as those that are more democratic tend to attract
 more FDI.

Title: The Effect of OBC College Reservations in India on OBC College Enrollment
Abstract:
A new reservation policy was introduced in India in 2008 that reserved 27.5% of all
 seats in higher education institutions run by the central government for other backward
 class (OBC) students. This paper first looks at the social and educational position
 of the OBC population in India right before the policy was implemented. It then analyzes
 if these reservations benefitted the OBC population by looking at the change in enrollment
 rates for the OBC population and comparing it to the forward class population. It
 also studies whether the creamy layer effect was in play or not by comparing the change
 in college enrollment for students coming from less educated households to college
 enrollment rates for students from more educated households.

Title:
The Relationship between Improvement in Business Regulatory Environment and Income
                                 Inequality
Abstract:
The paper examines the relationship between Ease of Doing Business ranking, published
 annually by the World Bank, and income inequality in 168 countries over the span of
 12 years. The paper specifically focuses on the 10 components of Ease of Doing Business
 ranking, such as ease of getting electricity and ease of getting credit. I find that
 while some components are significantly associated with reduced inequality, others
 are actually associated with increased income inequality. These results also depend
 on whether a country is in the high-income group. I also find that in countries with
 high trade openness, EDB is associated with decreased inequality while in countries
 with low trade openness - with increased. Lastly, I find that countries rich in natural
 resources offset the reduction of inequality, associated with EDB.

Title:
Who 'Ya Ghana Trust: Demand Volatility and Interpersonal Trust as Barriers to Firm
                                 Growth
Abstract:
This paper uses a eld study to investigate the effect of demand volatility and interpersonal
 trust as potential constraints to rm growth. I exploit network data on garment makers
 in Ghana and their willingness to hire and work for other garment makers they know,
 as well as their levels of trust. I randomize the language describing the demand that
 the respondent will face and find that mentioning `reliably many demand' increases
 the number of matches for those with below median expected sales. These matches are
 driven by matches with people they have not identified in the network, hinting at
 an information barrier to growth. Respondents responded more strongly to volume than
 the consistency of the added information of demand. Finally, average levels of trust
 is high in this sample, which suggests that trust cannot be a barrier to rm consolidation.

Title:
Do commissioners favour firms from their home countries? An empirical investigation
                                 of national bias within the European Commission using stock market data
Abstract:
The European Commission (EC) has the exclusive power of initiating laws within the
 European Union (EU). There are 28 Commissioners within the EC, each of whom has been
