 nominated by their national government and confirmed by the President of the EC. Every
 Commissioner holds a specific portfolio, and some of these portfolios, such as Energy
 and Internal Market, have scopes directly tied to specific industries. Therefore,
 EU laws initiated by Commissioners with such portfolios directly affect firms within
 those market sectors. While Commissioners are obliged to be free of national bias,
 prior qualitative studies have suggested the existence of national interests in the
 work and decision-making processes of the EC. Thus, this research seeks to empirically
 answer whether commissioners are biased towards firms from their national countries.
 To study this, this research employs the event-study methodology and stock market
 data to test for the presence of abnormal returns in national stock markets in response
 to two market shocks. The test found no significant market reactions to both market
 shocks, therefore concluding that there is no significant empirical evidence for national
 bias among Commissioners with key economic portfolios.

Title: How does the level of conservatism affect individual earnings? A study on Poland
Abstract:
My Capstone project examines the link between social values and individual income.
 In case of Poland, the manifestation of liberal vs. conservative ideology follows
 the West-East divide, inherited from the partitions of Poland in the 19th and 20th
 centuries. I hypothesized that societal conservatism has a negative impact on individuals'
 earnings, based on the theoretical framework that conservative beliefs imply that
 people pay less attention to money and more to family and community. In this Capstone,
 the econometric model tests the relationship between variables obtained for all 380
 counties in Poland. First, I develop a standard OLS model, with average salary as
 dependent variable, and selected measures of conservatism and liberalism (respectively:
 relative number of marriages and family size, and relative number of singles and divorces).
 Then I extend it to include instrumental variable of city status for each county.
 The results for both Eastern and Western parts of Poland support the hypothesis that
 conservative ideology is negatively correlated with individual earnings.

Title:
Difference-in-Difference Approach to Estimating the Relationship between Landmark
                                 Construction and Villa Sales Price in Abu Dhabi
Abstract:
Countries and cities across the world aspire to differentiate themselves through large
 capital expenditures with the hope they become easily recognizable landmarks. The
 UAE in particular has strived to assert itself on the world stage through these projects
 that draw upon large sums of public funds with the additional expressed purpose of
 attracting tourism, increasing prestige and increasing real estate values. This study
 contributes to existing literature examining how externalities affect real estate
 prices. This study employed a quantitative approach using a difference-in-difference
 (DID) method combined with a controlled regression analysis to reveal how landmarks
 impact housing prices from a spatial and temporal perspective. This provides insight
 into the cost- benefit relationship with the hopes of better guiding the use of scarce
 resources in the future.

Title: Colonial Legacy and Contemporary Armed conflict in Africa
Abstract:
This paper explores how variations in the colonial experience of African countries
 correlate with the contemporary levels of conflict on the continent, hence entering
 a broader body of research about the historical roots of comparative development.
 We closely follow previous research on the impact of ethnic partitioning on conflict,
 also using a geo-referenced conflict events dataset from the Armed Conflict Location
 and Event Data (ACLED) as well as other geographical, ecological and demographic georeferenced
 data on the African continent. A negative binomial model with multi-way clustered
 standard errors is estimated, and the main findings point at the existence of a significant
 correlation between variations in the colonial experience and conflict levels across
 the African continent.

Title:
Impact of Chinese Investments on Trade of Receiving Countries, The Case of Developing
                                 Countries
Abstract:
With Belt and Road Initiative unfolding and with a large number of countries accusing
 China of being involved in "new colonialism", this paper explores the impact of Chinese
 Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) and construction projects on trade of receiving developing
 countries. The data in use is trade and investment data for 17 developing countries
 over 12 years from 2005 to 2017. The research finds that Chinese investments have
 a small negative but statistically insignificant impact on trade of the receiving
 countries. We also find that the investments have a strong positive impact on redirection
 of trade of these developing countries from other places to China. Even though China
 does not seem to specifically target indebted or resource-rich countries to create
 a deeper "debt trap" or get involved in "new colonialism", in terms of trade, they
 are still the only party who benefits from these investments. This trend, however,
 does not appear in all sectors of an economy. The energy sector, for instance, is
 one of the industries which benefit from Chinese investments.

Title: Hydrogen Economy in the UAE: Feasibility, Opportunities and Risks
Abstract:
To advance clean energy initiatives in the United Arab Emirates, this paper proposes
 the integration of hydrogen gas as an additional energy input to the 2050 energy mix.
 By using the Levelized Cost of Electricity (LCOE) measure, a cost-comparison of three
 energy inputs (natural gas, solar energy and hydrogen), with unequal lifespans and
 power capacities, was conducted. In a hypothetical hydrogen production scenario, the
 paper finds that the UAE Levelized Cost of Hydrogen (LCOH) would approximately range
 between 4.8 – 2.8 $/kg H2. The findings show that hydrogen gas and solar power act
 as complimentary inputs to energy generation and that hydrogen deployment is economically
 feasible due to existing and planned large-scale solar power plants in the UAE. Furthermore,
 an energy policy of removing subsidies from the UAE natural gas sector is assessed.
 The paper attempts to discuss the policy by introducing a technological shock, such
 as hydrogen, to the solar energy sector using a partial Dynamic Stochastic General
 Equilibrium (DSGE) model. The reasoning shows that such an energy policy can smooth
 out energy price fluctuations caused by the disruptive impact of substituting natural
 gas with hydrogen gas for the long-term.

Title: Stock market response to CEO scandals: A study of US Stock Market from 1993-2018
Abstract:
This article examines the short-run impact on the company stock prices caused by CEO's
 scandals and misconducts of both business and non-business nature, between 1993 and
 2018 in the US. Our findings suggest that in the short run, investors react adversely
 to such events, especially with the CEO's business misconducts that directly involve
 the company operations, but the adverse effect is less significant for non-business
 scandals. However, when we do post-estimation test, there is no significant difference
 in investors' response between the two scandal types . While the non-business scandals
 of "me too" nature (which include both extra-marital affairs and sexual harassment
 of female employees) has no significant effect on stock returns, we find there is
 a negative and significant effect on stock markets returns of sexual harassment misconducts.
 This paper contributes to the existing literature by considering CEO's scandal events
 that are not necessarily business-related but also concerning non-business, immoral
 behaviors.

Title:
Market response to hurricanes' formation: A study of 20 industry portfolios in the
                                 US stock market from 1964 to 2019
Abstract:
This paper conducts an event study to examine the impact of North Atlantic Hurricanes
 on the US stock market at the industry portfolio level from 1964 to 2019. Our findings
 suggest that investors in most industries react adversely to the occurrence of hurricanes.
 Based on the number of industry portfolios that are significantly affected, we find
 that the economic implications of a hurricane have become more severe in the past
 three decades and that investors react more aggressively in the states across the
 East Coast & Florida than they do in states that border the Gulf of Mexico. Our last
 finding shows that the scale of financial damages incurs ex-post has no proven effect
 towards the market reaction.

Title:
Prosociality across Socio-Economic Disparities: Altruism, Trust and Trustworthiness
                                 in Argentina
Abstract:
The current observational literature disagrees on the impact of socio-economic status
 on the prosocial behavior of individuals. This paper experimentally varies economic
 status, inequality and knowledge of inequality through the initial endowment of games
 played in an experiment in Argentine classrooms. It is found that individuals randomized
 to the extreme ends of the spectrum of privilege behave more prosocially than those
 in the middle, forming an inverse u-shape in generosity. However, knowledge of inequality
 appears to attenuate prosociality. Finally, the inverse u-shape is not observed using
 observational data accounting for the socio-economic status of students. This paper
 experimentally validates both directions of socio-economic status effects on prosociality,
 but only in the case that inequality is unknown.

Title:
More Land, More Power? An Analysis on How Gender-Equalizing Inheritance Reform Impacts
                                 Domestic Abuse Rates in India
Abstract:
This paper analyzes how the Hindu Succession Act Amendment (HSAA) of 2005, a nationally
 implemented legislation giving women equal inheritance rights to men, impacted domestic
 abuse rates in Indian households in the year following its passage. Using data from
 the Demographic Health Survey from 2005-06 and inputting it into an econometric regression
 model that holds for relevant exogenous variables, I aim to find a relationship between
 the passing of the HSAA and domestic abuse rates. I expect, amongst the 29 states
 in India, the states that are exposed longer to the reform will have lower reportings
 of domestic abuse.

Title: Twitter and Investor Expectations: A Study on the US-China Trade War
Abstract:
This paper presents evidence that President Trump's Twitter statements regarding the
 US-China economic conflict impact the expectations of investors on the long-term performance
 of the US economy. This is implied by the effect of Trump's tweets related to the
 US-China trade war on the daily treasury yield curve rates from the start of the trade
 war till September 2019. The collected tweets were classified into 2 categories: whether
 they bring good or bad news about the US-China economic conflict overall. The average
 effect of an additional standard deviation of "bad" tweets is around negative 4.83
 bps (for the 2- to 5-year maturity bonds) on the same day and around negative 5.07
 bps a day after (for the 2- to 10-year maturity bonds). A multitude of tweets that
 bring bad news would decrease the yield on the 10-, 20- and 30-year maturity bonds
 by negative 22.4 bps, on average, on the same day. These results convey that market
 participants could believe that President Trump's trade policy is recessionary and
 will be difficult to revert in the future.

Title: Ethnicity and Social Mobility in Trinidad and Tobago: Does colonial history matter?
Abstract:
Trinidad and Tobago's labor market today is largely composed of Indo-Trinidadian (IT)
 and Afro-Trinidadian (AT) groups of an approximately equal size. This is as a result
 of the country's colonial history, which first brought African slaves and then Indian
 indentured laborers to replace labor- deficient plantations after the abolition of
 slavery. Since this period, latent ethnic rivalry has been documented between the
 two groups. The complexities of the ethnic relations in Trinidad and Tobago cause
 some questions to arise regarding the implications of its colonial history on ethnic
 relations between the two groups and on the economic outcomes of the groups today.
 The goal of this paper is to determine whether perceptions that ITs enjoy a higher
 standard of living today when compared to ATs is actually true by devising a unique
 measure of standard of living (SOL) which amalgamates various household characteristics
 for the time period 1970-2011. The findings show that between 1970 to 1990 ATs are
 relatively better off compared to ITs. However, after 1990, ITs seem to be relatively
 better off than ATs.

Title:
Testing the Efficient Market Hypothesis in an Online Counter-Strike: Global Offensive
                                 Betting Market
Abstract:
This paper analyzes whether the Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH) holds in a relatively
 low-volume, immature market, with the betting market of Counter-Strike: Global Offensive
 (CS:GO) being in question. This paper also discerns whether the change of betting
 currency from real money to virtual currency had an impact on the accuracy of the
 predicted outcome based on bets placed before the matches. This paper finds that even
 though the Counter-Strike betting market is newer and not as mature as other traditional
 prediction markets, the betting market was weak-form efficient, in both real money
 and virtual currency periods.

Title: A study of religiosity and donations: Does religion make its believers more prosocial?
Abstract:
This research measures the effects of three different primes, neutral (control group),
 religion-salient (Treatment I), religion and in-group-salient (Treatment II) on the
 donation behavior of Muslim subjects. Data for this experiment was collected online
 using Qualtrics as a survey platform and includes 372 Muslim participants in India
 for which data was collected online using Qualtrics. Participants who were primed
 with religion were biased against the non-Muslim charity and donated a significantly
 lower percentage of their earnings to this charity. Otherwise, there were no other
 significant treatment effects, which could be explained by the violence between Hindus
 and Muslims in India at the time of the experiment creating strong religious and ingroup
 sentiments among the Muslim population in India. Nonetheless, there was a correlation
 between survey measures of religiosity and donations. In particular, participants
 who scored higher in the religious activities and stance on Islamic issues dimension
 donated larger shares of their earnings to charity. There was also a significant gender
 and age effect as women and older participants donated more on average.

Title: The Effects of Recent Refugee Influxes on Different Regions in Germany
Abstract:
Germany has witnessed several large-scale refugee influxes from parts of the Middle
 East and Africa over the past decade. This paper studies the ways in which these recent
 refugee influxes have affected social and labor market indicators in the different
 regions of Germany. Using the fixed effects model as the core methodological framework,
 the paper finds that refugees lower unemployment and have no significant impact on
 safety standards in Germany's different regions. The paper also deduces that refugees
 do not significantly affect the agricultural labor market, but have a positive, significant,
 and almost equal effect on employment in the manufacturing sector and employment in
 the industrial sector.

Title:
Death and Demand: a look at Mexican criminal activity and its relationship with firearm
                                 pricing in the United States
Abstract:
Many aspects of the firearm market in the United States are poorly understood by both
 economists and policy makers. This paper attempts to take a closer look at the market
 utilizing a novel data set and create a model to explain the variety of prices found
 from 2007 to 2017. The paper focuses on AR-15's,notable for the amount of media attention
 it receives in and out of the US. This is done due to time and data constraints, as
 well as the relative newness of the AR-15 market. The model this paper constructs
 also integrates the level of criminal demand in Mexico, as measured by the number
 of homicides. This paper is the starting point for expanding understanding of the
 firearm market for both those participating in the market, and those attempting to
 regulate it.

Title: Event Study: Undemocratic Events and Turkish Stock Market
Abstract:
This paper examines the effects of 74 undemocratic events on the Turkish Stock Market.
 The events are collected from LexisNexis and local Turkish newspapers. Stock market
 data are acquired from Borsa Istanbul, which is the Turkish Stock Market. Undemocratic
 events are divided into five categories; Imprisonment of Journalists, Dismissal of
 Public Sector Employees, Imprisonment of Politicians, Acquisition of Mayorships, and
 Closure of Media Outlets, Universities and Hospitals. 36 undemocratic events were
 found to have significant effect on the stock market. This study is the first extensive
 event study on the Turkish Stock Market with the creation of a new dataset of undemocratic
 events.

Title: Impact of Parental Leave Policies on Female Labor Participation in Japan
Abstract:
This paper considers overtime work hours and gender pay gap as contributors to low
 female labor participation in economies afflicted by issues of aging crisis and low
 fertility rates. Even though generous parental leaves are provided, existing literature
 finds mixed evidence of its impact on female labor participation after childbirth
 in Japan. Using empirical evidence, our findings suggest that taking parental leave
 negatively affects mother's employment status. Furthermore, full-time workers are
 less likely to be employed after taking parental leave.

Title: The Effect of the US-China Trade Conflict on Equity Markets
Abstract:
When in 2018 President Trump accused China of lucrative trading practices, he began
 imposing protectionist policies in the globalized US economy, causing many worries
 for businesses with international supply chains. Later in 2019, the series of bilateral
 import tariffs enacted by the leaders of both nations became termed as the US-China
 "trade war". This paper uses the event study methodology to evaluate how announcements
 of tariffs and negotiations affected equity markets in either country during the "war".
 Results indicate that equity indices have mixed reactions to the news, as the American
 market performs as expected while the Chinese market does the opposite. Possible reasons
 include uncertainty, differing index composition, and asymmetric information. Further
 investigation also discovers a lack of transparency in both equity markets.

Title: Entrepreneurship in India: Determinants and Motivations
Abstract:
This paper attempts to explore the determinants of and motivations for entrepreneurship
 in India, with a focus on the impact of individual perceptions and behavioral factors
 on future and established entrepreneurial activity. Using the Global Entrepreneurship
 Monitor's individual level data for India, the paper finds that behavioral factors
 seem to be likely determinants of entrepreneurial participation, especially in the
 established business owners category. Specifically, business opportunity perception,
 the presence of business networks and positive perception of personal entrepreneurial
 skills are likely determinants for established entrepreneurship and predictors for
 future entrepreneurship. These results offer recommendations for future policy work
 to increase entrepreneurship.

Title: Unions in Bankruptcy: A Help or a Hindrance?
Abstract:
Chapter 11 Bankruptcy in the United States allows firms to reorganize their capital
 structure rather than liquidate. This form of bankruptcy allows firms to emerge from
 bankruptcy and continue operating, retaining much of their staff. Labor unions take
 part in the bankruptcy negotiation process by obtaining seats on creditors' committees;
 employees in firms without labor union presence are not otherwise represented in bankruptcy
 negotiations. This paper studies the effect of labor union presence on firms' likelihood
 to emerge from bankruptcy and subsequently survive for five years. I find that labor
 union presence is positively correlated with emergence from bankruptcy for large,
 public companies. No significant correlation is found between labor union presence
 and survival for five years after bankruptcy.

Title: A Dynamic Study of the Impact of Oil Price Changes on the US Stock Market
Abstract:
This paper investigates how changes in oil prices have influenced the performance
 of the US stock market as a whole (SP 500) and selected energy-dependent industry
 groups, such as oil and gas exploration and production companies, energy equipment
 companies, manufacturing and construction companies over a time period of 30 years,
 from 1990 to 2020. The key findings of this paper indicate that the performance of
 the US economy as a whole was positively influenced by an increase in oil prices starting
 in 2010 and was negatively influenced before 2010. For oil and gas exploration and
 production companies, energy equipment companies, the relationship between oil price
 changes and the industry performance was also positive. For construction and manufacturing
 industry group, the relationship was generally positive. This paper has important
 implications in such areas of economics as investment portfolio optimization, hedging
 risks, government regulation, and public and private spending.

Title:
The Impact of Mobile Digitalization on Financial Development: The Introduction of
                                 Spotify and Netflix in Latin America and the Caribbean
Abstract:
This research focuses on the impact that the introduction of Netflix and Spotify had
 on financial access in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) from 1980 to 2017. Through
 prediction modelling and regression analysis using interaction variables and fixed
 effects, I anticipated that the exogenous introduction of Netflix and Spotify in LAC
 would increase financial access due to subsequent increases in digitalization, operationalized
 as cell phone subscriptions and internet users. This study finds, counter to my hypotheses,
 that for a majority of LAC countries, the digitalization intervention that occurred
 with the introduction of the biggest players in the consumer subscription service
 industry had a non-positive effect on financial access. I find that LAC could be missing
 an opportunity to improve financial access through mobile digitalization, as lower
 classes are not equipped with the financial or technological literacy necessary to
 best utilize it. The threshold effects at play in LAC mitigate the potential economically
 egalitarian effects of increased financial access. This investigation provides a cautionary
 tale for governments looking to advance financial development by increasing digitalization
 without creating inclusive financial policy to support it.

Title:
The Effect of Rumors about Government Bailout of Banks on the Financial Market in
                                 Ireland
Abstract:
The European Financial Crisis had a major impact on the EU's peripheral countries,
 as they continued falling into a multi-year debt crisis starting from 2009 and reaching
 Ireland by the end of 2010. This paper examines the impact of the rumors about the
 bailout on the Irish financial markets during the banking crisis of 2010, testing
 the hypothesis that only the financial sector will be significantly and positively
 affected by the news. Contrary to our expectations, the findings of an Abnormal Return
 analysis reflect that the financial sector suffered from the start of the rumors,
 while the Industrial and the Oil and Gas companies benefited.

Title: Farming and Working Well: Irrigation & Female Labor Force Participation in India
Abstract:
Access to irrigation water is an important agricultural input that has significant
 effects on the socioeconomic outcomes of farmers in developing contexts. While there
 are many studies investigating the impacts of specific forms of irrigation, little
 is known about how irrigation, broadly considered, affects the outcome of female labor
 force participation. In this paper, we perform a descriptive study of female labor
 force participation in India, followed by a causal analysis on how it is impacted
 by irrigation. We find that irrigation shares a statistically significant and positive
 relationship with female and male labor force participation. Our analysis suggests
 that the effect of irrigation on labor force is smaller for women than for men. This
 research is an important first step in understanding the priorities faced by female
 farmers with regards to labor force participation.

Title:
Does working part-time during schooling affect dropout rates after the mandatory schooling
                                 years?
Abstract:
In this paper, I look at the effects of working part-time during primary or junior
 high school on dropout behavior after mandatory schooling years in Indonesia. I obtain
 my data from the Indonesian Family Life Survey (IFLS) and use a binary choice probit
 model to see if working during schooling provides a strong signal that a child will
 drop out of school immediately after mandatory schooling years. Moreover, I suggest
 a Linear Probability Model (LPM) with Instrumental Variable (IV) approach to elicit
 causal effects and find that working during primary or junior high school leads to
 a lower dropout rate among children in Indonesia.

Title: Innovating an Innovation Index
Abstract:
In both academic and policy circles, there is a growing interest in understanding
 the role of innovation and productivity at the firm level. However, innovation measurement
 remains to be challenging as innovation is characterized by various dimensions, which
 have been mostly studied separately in the literature. In this paper, we study innovation
 activities in US public firms by constructing a novel index to measure innovation
 and using this index to examine the role of innovation on subsequent operating performance
 of the firms. Our results indicate that the constructed innovation index has a much
 more robust and positive relationship with subsequent firm performance than earlier
 methods proposed in the literature.

Title: Wealth, Wages, and Working Hours: Evidence from the Panel Study of Income Dynamics
Abstract:
Both theoretical frameworks and empirical findings regarding the effects of wealth
 and wealth shocks on wages and labor earnings are mixed. Understanding these effects
 has profound implications on economic theory, particularly in the field of labor economics,
 and policymaking. This project hopes to contribute to the literature on this topic.
 I use the Panel Study of Income Dynamics dataset from 1997 to 2007 to study the effects
 of wealth and wealth shocks on the wage rate, annual labor income, and working hours.
 With a set of six specifications, I find that these effects are all statistically
 insignificant at the 0.01 level. When they are occasionally significant at the 0.05
 level, the effects are small. The results suggest that the wage rate, labor income,
 and hours of work are, for the most part, not influenced by wealth and wealth shocks.

Title:
Impact of North Korean Provocation on Financial Performances of Different Industries
                                 in South Korea and the U
Abstract:
With this research, I attempted to look into the impact of North Korean provocation,
 specifically of ICBM and nuclear testing, on the financial performance of overall
 South Korean and the U.S. stock markets as well as different industries such as defense,
 construction, and tourism among others. All in all, the South Korean overall market
 moved according to our hypothesis while the U.S. one did not. Specifically, the South
 Korean market showed a decreasing cumulative abnormal return following the events
 while the U.S. market did not respond. Defense industries from both countries have
 responded positively to the North Korean provocations. Among ten inter-Korea cooperative
 industries, six have responded negatively towards the events following our prediction,
 two have not been impacted, and two have moved in a positive direction. There was
 an overriding issue of deriving significance out of the results except in two industries:
 U.S. defense and South Korean road construction. Investors should not expect that
 all the inter-Korea cooperative industries would behave in the same ways and must
 be aware of the differences in respective industries.

Title: The Evolution of Women's Labor Force Participation in Egypt: Post-Revolution
Abstract:
This paper focuses on the changes to women's labor force participation after the revolution
 in Egypt, in both the short and medium run. This analysis uses panel data from the
 Egypt Labor Market Panel Survey (ELMPS), focusing on the years 2006, 2012 and 2018.
 Using difference-in-difference specifications, the paper investigates the changes
 to the labor force participation of women in different age groups. The paper finds
 that overtime, including both periods after the revolution, women's participation
 in labor has decreased, where younger women are the least likely to participate in
 labor. Nevertheless, the paper also found that younger women experienced the most
 positive change after the revolution, relative to older women. The results suggest
 a possible convergence in the labor force participation rates of women across all
 ages.

Title: Invisible Oil Spills: Tracing Art to Oil
Abstract:
In recent years, the arts and cultural sector has enjoyed increasing attention in
 economic and political arenas for its rife diversification and growth potential. This
 is particularly true of oil-based economies, as best exemplified by the member states
 of the G.C.C. Yet, the relationship between energy, particularly oil, and art has
 largely been overlooked by scholars, complicating policy setting and compromising
 the long-term growth of this sector. This paper documents the long-term relationship
 between oil production and the arts and cultural sector. It models its analysis at
 both the state-level, using U.S. data, and at the country-level, using G.C.C. data.
 Despite the different data sources and variables employed in the two studies, they
 both find a positive association between oil production and the size of the arts and
 cultural sector in oil-based economies. Untangling the causal mechanism behind this
 association is the grounds for future research.

Title: Sectoral Diversification in the UAE
Abstract:
With the rise of alternative fuels and growing concerns over the environmental sustainability
 of the global economies' consumption behaviors since the turn of the century, more
 attention has been devoted to the diversification of the United Arab Emirates' economy
 to achieve a sustainable future. However, despite the growing interest in export and
 labor diversification, there is a lack of research in economic sectoral diversification.
 This paper will define economic sectoral diversification and introduce a measurement
 for it that is inspired by other diversification indices. Using that measurement,
 a ranking of the countries' diversification levels will be produced, and a series
 of regression analyses is performed to study the relationship between economic sectoral
 diversification and some macroeconomic variables. This research finds that the UAE
 is well-diversified relative to the reference group.

Title:
Understanding the Changing Nascent Entrepreneurial Attitudes & Activity in the United
                                 Arab Emirates: An Update on the Entrepreneurship Landscape
Abstract:
The aim of this paper is to understand the changing entrepreneurial behavior in the
 United Arab Emirates (UAE). This paper examines cross-sectional data, where a bivariate
 probit regression model is applied to two waves of the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor
 (GEM) data. The anticipated finding is there are improving attitudes towards pursuing
 entrepreneurial ventures. This is critical for understanding how the UAE should effectively
 develop legislative policies pertaining to entrepreneurship. The paper concludes by
 discussing the need for the UAE to realize the essential components needed to diversify
 and dynamize the economy by implementing regulations that positively impact the changing
 entrepreneurship landscape and allocate investments that will allow UAE-based entrepreneurship
 to reach its optimal level.

Title:
Does Oil Rent Dependence Affect Entrepreneurship? A Comparative Analysis of The MENA
                                 Region versus The Rest of The World
Abstract:
Extensive empirical evidence shows that rents produced from natural resources like
 oil reduce engagement in productive entrepreneurship as they shift incentives towards
 rent-seeking. This study has a geographical focus on the Middle East and North Africa,
 which, despite their recent efforts to increase entrepreneurial activity, still lag
 behind the rest of the world. The study compares the nexus between oil rent dependence
 and entrepreneurship in the MENA region with that of the rest of the world. Using
 the number of newly registered limited liability firms every year as a proxy for entrepreneurship,
 we find empirical evidence that higher oil rent dependence in an economy diminishes
 entrepreneurship levels globally but find no statistically significant relationship
 between oil rent dependence and entrepreneurship for the MENA region specifically.
 The findings have important policy implications, especially for oil-rich countries.

Title: Asset Correlation Shocks at times of Crisis: In Application to the CVC
Abstract:
Following the GFC of 2009, there has been emerging focus on the risk-on/risk-off regimes
 following high market volatility times. This shed light on the assumption that cross-asset
 correlations within markets seem to notably increase and persist at times of high
 market uncertainty. This phenomenon is more relevant to the Covid-19 crisis, as the
 pandemic enforced aggressive economic structural changes that are significantly influencing
 asset classes' behaviors and pricing. The onset of the crisis itself has distorted
 traditional market betas within the equity space and also created relative winners
 and losers geographically too. This capstone proposal aims to set the groundwork for
 the main thesis: Is there a CVC Asset Correlation Shock affecting the efficiency of
 portfolio diversification? Theoretical work will first illustrate the evidence of
 increased cross-asset correlations in the CVC. This will then be reflected by the
 portfolios constructed in the study. Based on the attained conclusions, the research
 will make a strong case for the optimal portfolio strategy and try to quantify the
 correlation shock.

Title:
Rethinking Winners and Losers of Trade: A Firm-Level Analysis of Trade Reform in Sri
                                 Lanka
Abstract:
Post-independence Sri Lanka has gone through capricious shifts in trade policy, with
 the economic policies of successive governments moving back and forth between trade
 liberalization and protectionism. Yet little is known about the impact that these
 reforms have had on domestic firms and consumers. In this study, I exploit large shifts
 in Sri Lanka's trade policy in recent decades to study what lower and higher input
 tariffs mean for the survivability, size, and the markups of domestic firms, as well
 as consumer prices. Using novel firm-level panel data and a difference-in-difference
 identification strategy, I show that domestic firms that remain in the market following
 trade liberalization and expand both their production levels and markups are the real
 winners of lower input tariffs, while firms that are forced out of the market are
 outright losers. Firms that enter the market anew under higher input tariffs are winners
 of trade protectionism, while firms that were already in the market but now have to
 downsize their production levels and also earn less profits are losers. Consumers
 are neither complete winners nor complete losers.

Title: The Impact of Oil Prices on Russian and Saudi Arabian Stock Markets
Abstract:
Spring 2020 had a major impact on oil prices and stock markets of two of the world's
 largest oil-exporting countries, Russia and Saudi Arabia, due to the effects of COVID-19
 and the Russian-Saudi oil-price war. This paper analyses the relationship between
 oil prices and Russian and Saudi stock markets in 2019 - 2020 using structural vector
 autoregression and compares the results to the Chinese stock market, since China is
 an oil-importer that was also affected by COVID-19, but not the oil-price war. Our
 findings reflect that both Russian and Saudi stock markets follow a pattern of declined
 dependence after the start of the oil-price war and the COVID-19 pandemic. In contrast,
 there was no significant impact of oil price shocks on the Chinese stock market both
 in 2019 and 2020 due to the oil-importing nature of the country, as well as its non-involvement
 in the oil-price war.

Title: What is the relationship between remittances and savings in Pakistan?
Abstract:
Foreign remittances are an important economic sector for Pakistan. Literature focuses
 on the direct relationship between remittances and economic growth in Pakistan, but
 has conflicting results. This paper attempts to use an indirect approach to studying
 this relationship, by looking at a driver of economic growth: savings. I use Pakistan
 Standards of Living Measurement (PSLM) survey data to empirically analyse the relationship
 between remittances and savings. I do this directly and also by looking at the relationships
 remittances have with household income and expenditures – since their difference is
 savings. In theory, if in response to remittance inflow savings increase, there should
 be a positive shift in the steady state stock of capital. As this paper shows, despite
 several limitations and concerns to be cautious of, there are statistically significant
 relationships between remittances and the aforementioned key variables in Pakistan.

Title:
Do Rainfall Shocks Impact Agricultural Technology Adoption Differently by Gender?
                                 The Case of Ethiopia
Abstract:
Technology adoption and productivity growth in the agricultural sector are essential
 for poverty reduction. A vast literature has explored incentives and barriers to adopting
 fertilizer, the benefits of which depend on adequate rainfall. Female headed households
 (FHH) have, in previous literature, been shown to adopt less fertilizer, yet factors
 beyond lack of market access remain largely unconsidered. This capstone explores if,
 how, and why FHH's fertilizer use responds differently to rainfall shocks than that
 of male headed households (MHH). I use four rounds of panel data from the Ethiopian
 Rural Household Survey containing household-level information on agriculture, livestock,
 and consumption, combined with rainfall data at the village level. I find that FHH
 use significantly less fertilizer than MHH when rainfall is below the expected level
 of rainfall. For each additional child and consumption expenditure a FHH has, the
 household uses less fertilizer than MHH, and livestock does not modify FHH's fertilizer
 use as it does for MHH. The findings of this capstone suggest that certain mechanisms
 discussed in previous literature may not be as effective at modifying the response
 to rainfall shocks for FHH as for MHH.

Title:
Non-Linear Hedge Fund Prediction Models using Public Sentiment Data about Firms' ESG
                                 performance
Abstract:
I exploit proprietary unstructured Natural Language Processing data measuring public
 sentiment of 492 US public companies' ESG performance and different financial metrics
 over a twelve-year time period, to study the non-linearity between public sentiment
 metrics regarding ESG performance and financial metrics. I prove through my algorithmic
 non-parametric portfolio that there is a divergence between public sentiment about
 a firm's ESG performance and its financial metrics. This fact allows me to prove,
 by designing a parametric non-linear portfolio without data accumulation and a parametric
 non-linear portfolio with data accumulation, that a long strategy focusing on a positive
 screening on high-ranked ESG companies outperforms a negative screening on low-ranked
 ESG sentiment companies. I test for robustness using a Fama-French five factor model,
 focusing on the alpha-generating capabilities of the best performing portfolio, namely,
 the parametric non-linear portfolio with data accumulation. I further expand on the
 arbitrage opportunity that this positive screening mechanism using divergence on ESG
 and financial data represents, concluding that eventually, this noise will disappear
 as market agents act upon this information.

Title: Does Knowledge Follow Gravity Model: Evidence from AI Citation Network
Abstract:
This study applies the gravity model on the Artificial Intelligence (AI) citations
 network to study the impact, productivity and over-impact of AI research across world
 cities. Over-impact is the extent to which a source city's academic impact to the
 destination city exceeds the expected impact given the cities' sizes, the distance
 and other cultural factors such as language and colonial relationship. The study finds
 that the gravity model explains the data very well in which AI impact is found to
 be positively and significantly correlated with the sizes of two cities and inversely
 related to distances. Distance between cities explains part of global AI citations
 patterns, with most of the correlation due to citations to papers produced within
 cities or a small radius. The global network of cities reveals asymmetric impact above
 benchmark. The West is over-impacting the East significantly while the East under-impacts
 the West. This study also plots the global centers of gravity (CGs) of AI impact,
 productivity, and over-impact from 1990 to 2017 and finds that the CGs have been consistently
 shifting to the East in all three measures.

Title: Can we profit from corporate M&A?
Abstract:
This thesis studies the factors influencing takeover prediction and the potential
 to generate returns based on a probability-driven takeover strategy. A conditional
 logistic regression model is used to predict the effect of fifteen variables divided
 into four categories including firm size, inefficient management, undervaluation,
 and leverage and liquidity, as well as an industry dummy that takes the value of 1
 if there has been an acquisition in the same industry in the year studied. The used
 data includes a sample of 444 observations of target companies listed on the London
 Stock exchange for the period between 1989 and 2019, as well as a non-target sample
 of 7,942 observations of companies listed on the London Stock Exchange that have not
 experienced a takeover bid over the same period. The empirical evidence finds that
 a conditional logistic regression model is a good tool to reliably identify takeover
 targets, with the highest three decile portfolios containing nearly 70% of all targets.
 Additionally, it is possible to generate positive market-adjusted returns but the
 evidence doesn't support the hypothesis that probability-driven trading strategies
 can generate abnormal returns.

Title:
What Does Islamization Do? The impact of religious education on schooling of women
                                 in Pakistan
Abstract:
Religion plays an important role in the lives of people, especially when the state
 adopts policies with underlying religious foundations. This capstone estimates the
 impact of Islamization of the education system in Pakistan in the 1980s. We exploit
 arguably larger exposure to Islamization in rural Pakistan where students have fewer
 private education options to estimate impacts using a difference-in-difference approach.
 The difference in the difference between rural and urban women increased after Islamization
 with the education of rural women stagnating in comparison to urban women. We also
 find a statistically significant differential effect of exposure on women by their
 area of residence for the ability to read, write and do mathematical calculations.
 Similarly, the difference in difference between urban and rural women increased for
 number of days and months worked. Lastly, we find that the probability of head of
 household identifying as female increases in rural areas after Islamization. This
 capstone takes a step towards better identification, but further research is required
 to rigorously test a causal impact.

Title: Is There Social Inequality in the Sharing Economy? - A case study of Airbnb
Abstract:
Airbnb is one of the key pioneers of the sharing economy which has grown rapidly over
 the last decade. Airbnb income has become a vital component of people's lives allowing
 them to make ends meet. This paper examines whether there is evidence of social inequality
 on Airbnb, specifically investigating a host's earnings. We further the existing literature
 by constructing a unique dataset for this paper using hosts' profile pictures from
 Airbnb and collecting data from five major cities in the US on hosts' age, race and
 gender. We then study the effect of age, race and gender on the host's earnings which
 are determined by the price and demand of a listing. We also control for a rich set
 of variables in our analysis and find statistically significant evidence of race-based
 differences in earnings on Airbnb.

Title: Market Design : Carpooling in a city
Abstract:
We apply the algorithm developed by Hatfield and Milgrom to a carpooling problem.
 In particular, we use their generalized version of the Deferred Acceptance Algorithm,
 hereafter denoted as the HM algorithm, to organize carpooling. We put preferences
 on road segments and identify road segments with one or multiple cars. We show that
 the HM algorithm gives rise to stable and efficient allocation of cars and riders.

Title: An Analysis of Determinants of financial inclusion in Ethiopia
Abstract:
The study analyzed various determinants of financial inclusion (FI) in Ethiopia. The
 study analyzed and addressed some of the most common FI determinants in Ethiopia.
 Descriptive and econometric analysis methods were used to determine and evaluate the
 determinants of FI. Mainly the study focused on understanding the determinants of
 FI on socio-economic and demographic factors such as gender, education, financial
 literacy, financial capability, and FI barriers. The analysis found that better education,
 financial literacy, gender, living in urban or rural areas, living in the capital
 city, religion, and preference for formal financial services are associated with a
 significant level of FI. The majority of the citizens in Ethiopia cannot access financial
 services for both voluntary and involuntary reasons. Notably, distance from financial
 service institutions is a significant barrier to FI. The study suggests non-traditional
 financial services and products such as agent banking and mobile banking should be
 promoted and expanded in rural Ethiopia. Notably, most Ethiopians live in rural areas,
 and distance from financial service institutions is a significant barrier to FI. Therefore,
 the government should increase traditional banking and microfinance branches and promote
 government-to-people transfer to digitalize such as utility bills and school fees,
 both in urban and rural areas.

Title:
Sustainable Investing & Islamic investing: Does Practicing Shariah Compliance Have
                                 An Impact On A Firm's Environmental, Social, Governance ("ESG") Score?
Abstract:
For every dollar invested in the US, one third of that takes into consideration some
 form of ESG criteria (US SIF, 2020). Our study takes into account the growing trend
 of sustainable investing and attempts to propose shariah compliant equities as a comparable
 investment alternative. In spite of previous literatures' efforts to show the financial
 outperformance of a shariah-sustainable investment, none have attempted to quantify
 the "sustainability premium" inherent in shariah compliant equities. Using a dataset
 of 2,711 ESG rated firms from 6 economic regions across 10 sectors, results indicate
 that shariah compliance results in a 4% to 10% increase in ESG score compared to non-shariah
 compliant equities. The variation in the "sustainability premium" is sector dependent,
 with technology driven and asset light equities taking the lead.

Title: The Effects of Health Insurance Schemes Consolidation in China
Abstract:
The Chinese government established the new Urban Rural Resident Basic Medical Insurance
 (URRMI), unifying Urban Resident Basic Medical Insurance (URMI) and New Rural Cooperative
 Medical Insurance (NRCMI). This study examines the impact of the health insurance
 scheme consolidation's effects on the elderly population's health. The analysis drew
 panel data from the China Health and Retirement Longitudinal Study (CHARLS) and employed
 a fixed-effect model to control within-unit differences. Our findings show that there
 is no statistically significant result to support that the new unified URRMI insurance
 scheme improved the participants' health status and primary health- care access. Regarding
 health expenditure, results show that for the 45 years old and above subjects, the
 unified new health insurance scheme lead to statistically significant decrease in
 percentage of out-of-pocket expenditure for outpatient care. However, we do not observe
 similar pattern with inpatient care.

Title:
The Effect of Transportation, Green, and Municipal Hard Infrastructure Investment
                                 on Commodity Housing Prices in China
Abstract:
China's commodity housing prices have been increasing at an enormous speed over the
 past decades. It is important to understand the determinants of the variation in housing
 prices. Infrastructure might play a role behind it: infrastructure might have a positive
 effect on housing prices by adding more attractiveness to a region, yet it might also
 have a negative effect by decreasing the congestion in tier-1 cities by linking them
 to tier-2 and 3 cities. This capstone project aims to explore the following questions:
 What is the impact of infrastructure investment on housing prices in China? How does
 this impact vary over time? By doing a panel regression with prefecture city level
 data, I have found that highway construction has a significant and negative correlation
 with the housing prices in tier-1 cities in China, while it has a significant yet
 positive correlation with tier-2 cities' housing prices. This finding corresponds
 to the hypothesis that infrastructure could help decrease the congestion in developed
 cities, thus driving down the housing prices.

Title: Oil Price Pass-through to Sectoral Inflation: Evidence from Morocco
Abstract:
Morocco is a country heavily dependent on oil. Hence, fluctuations in oil prices do
 not only impact GDP growth and household demand but also its prices. This study explores
 the pass-through effect of oil prices to domestic and sectoral inflation in Morocco
 between January 2007 and March 2020. The study examines the effect using non-linear
 autoregressive distributive lag model (NARDL) to assess the difference between the
 impact of positive and negative oil price shocks. Results show that (1) oil prices
 affect domestic and food CPI in the long run and the short run, (2) non-food CPIs
 are only affected in the short run (3) there is evidence of asymmetric, incomplete
 and/or lagged price transmissions in more oil-intensive industries, which suggest
 potential market power dynamics.

Title: U-Shape Hypothesis Test in Panama Using Micro-Determinants of Female Labor Force Participation
Abstract:
For my capstone project, my main goal was to test the U- shape relationship between
 economic development and female labor force participation in Panama using census microdata.
 I employed a linear probability model to estimate the effects of educational attainment,
 fertility, and household income on female labor force which may explain changes in
 female labor force participation according to the U-Shape theory. I extended the model
 by adding variables for occupation of the household head to understand the role of
 the structure of the economy in women's choices to participate in the labor force.
 Regression results from the primary model indicate that educational attainment, household
 income and fertility contribute towards the upward portion of the U-Shape in explaining
 changes in female labor force participation. The extended model results show that
 the structure of the economy also plays a small role at explaining changes in female
 labor force participation, both across space and time. The primary and extended model
 regression results only show evidence of the upward portion of the U-Shape relationship
 between economic development and female labor force participation in Panama.

Title:
Quantitative Easing in the Eurozone: Stock Market Performance and Dependence on External
                                 Finance
Abstract:
In this paper, I analyze the impact of quantitative easing announcements and the industries'
 dependence on external finance on stock market returns in the 19 Eurozone countries.
 As a result of the 2007 Great Recession, and most recently, the COVID-19 pandemic,
 the European Central Bank made multiple announcements to pursue an unconventional
 monetary policy, quantitative easing, which subsequently affects companies' stock
 due to changing expectations about their future performance. However, the extent to
 which companies can benefit from the consequences of quantitative easing differs on
 how reliant they are for external finance. Therefore, the idea of the dependence on
 external finance across industries is used by Rajan and Zingales (1998). Daily stock
 return data from 2010 to 2021 are retrieved from Compustat and the quantitative easing
 announcements are obtained from the European Central Bank's Press Releases. I find
 that with quantitative easing announcements, as a company becomes more dependent on
 external finance, the company's daily stock returns are positively affected.

Title:
The effects of Information and Communication Technology On Climate Change Knowledge
                                 in Sub-Saharan Africa
Abstract:
This paper measures how the adoption of Information and Communication Technology (ICT)
 in 34 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa affects the awareness of and attitudes towards
 climate change. Four multiple logistic regressions were run to find how different
 types of ICT adoption shape climate change knowledge. We find that access to mobile
 phones with Internet and social media increase the likelihood of an individual being
 aware of climate change. However, the adoption of these ICTs does not significantly
 impact the perception of the negative impacts of climate change, the perception of
 the need to address it, and confidence among people that individual efforts can effect
 change. In contrast, traditional ICTs like television, radios, and newspapers have
 a significant effect on shaping such attitudes.

Title:
Trending to Trading: Using Twitter sentiments to study the stock market movement during
                                 the Covid pandemic
Abstract:
This paper looks at the relationship between the sentiment expressed on Twitter regarding
 the stock market and the change in the stock price of S/P 500 during the COVID pandemic
 (January- August 2020). Using Granger Causality and Vector Auto Regression (VAR),
 we study the correlation between the daily sentiment with daily change in the stock
 price of the S/P 500. We find that out of six different sentiments (Compound, Happy,
 Sad, Angry, Surprise, Fear) as measured by text analysis tools (VADER and text2emotion),
 only two sentiments, angry and Surprise, are significant in granger causing the changes
 in stock price movement of S/P 500 during the pandemic. By comparing our results with
 similar research on the financial crisis, we also analyze how the COVID pandemic was
 unique from other economic crises and how people's sentiment about the stock market
 during the pandemic was different and short-lived.

Title:
How does vocational education impact professional outcomes? Evidence from an abrupt
                                 policy change in Argentina
Abstract:
Despite general unemployment levels remaining relatively stable, youth unemployment
 has been increasing at an alarming rate worldwide. A tool to potentially reduce youth
 unemployment is vocational education, which is offered in many countries as an optional
 complement to secondary education, allowing students to specialize in a specific field
 or craft. This capstone studies an unusual policy change approved in Argentina in
 1993, which made vocational education a mandatory component of the national high-school
 curriculum instead of an optional complement. I utilize representative quarterly data
 from household surveys to track the educational and professional outcomes of Argentinian
 students who were part of this program relative to those who were not. The results
 show that the policy change had positive effects on completion of high school and
 pursuit of higher education. However, results also indicate higher unemployment and
 lower real wages for those students who underwent this educational change. When the
 effects of the policy were evaluated by gender, it is observed that most of the benefits
 are experienced by women, helping to close existing gaps in employment and wages.

Title:
"Welfare Magnet" or "Welfare Deterrent"? - Examining New Evidence from the Post-Enlargement
                                 European Union
Abstract:
There has been ongoing debate about the "welfare magnet" hypothesis (Borjas 1999)
 in the EU context, especially for East-West migration, ever since the Eastern EU enlargements.
 Existing research has mostly relied on census and household survey data with coverage
 only until the mid-2000s and often lacking data on migrants' exact countries of origin.
 Conducting panel data regressions on annual, bilateral migration flow data between
 2001-2018 from the OECD International Migration Database (IMD), this paper contributes
 to the literature in two important ways: Firstly, a specially designed EU Movement
 Restriction Index controls more rigorously for 'transitional arrangements' – temporary
 movement restrictions affecting Eastern EU citizens in the early years after accession.
 Secondly, the bilateral nature of the data enables me to investigate heterogeneity
 of the "welfare magnet" effect along different migration corridors, specifically along
 the East-West corridor and within Western Europe respectively. My analysis suggests
 that the "welfare magnet" effect is essentially zero for East-West migration whereas
 a puzzle of seeming "welfare deterrence" poses itself for migration within Western
 Europe.

Title:
Technological Persistence in a Globalized World: Was the 3rd Industrial Revolution
                                 different?
Abstract:
Recent research has pointed to the existence of technological persistence over multiple
 centuries. The studies claim that an increasingly globalized world should have eased
 knowledge sharing, allowing developing countries to catch up to innovators, but that
 seems not to be the case. However, most studies use indirect measures for technology
 like Total Factor productivity (TFP) and RandD Expenditure whose relationship with
 output and technological adoption remains unclear. There exists an additional concern
 that the appropriate control variables have not been used to account for factors like
 spatial autocorrelation. This paper uses the CHAT dataset with information on 104
 technologies from 159 countries to construct a direct measure of technology to estimate
 whether technological persistence exists. I found that the technology variable for
 1500 was able to predict the technological measure for 1960, 1980 and 1990 but broke
 at 2000 following which there was no statistical long-term (500 years) relationship.
 In the short run (60 years), the technology measures predicted 2018's but the accuracy
 decreased as we increased the time lag. We evaluate whether these findings suggest
 that long-term technological persistence has ceased to exist and discuss the conditions
 which could have led to the break.

Title: Securitization and Systematic Risk in Chinese Banking: Empirical Evidence
Abstract:
Asset-backed securities and their associated risks were one of the main factors of
 the financial crisis in 2008. Theoretical arguments support the view that securitization
 can either increase or decrease the issuer's systematic risk, and previous empirical
 results obtained using data from the US and Europe indeed give a varied picture. This
 paper studies whether asset-backed securities issuances affect the systematic risk
 (equity beta) of the issuing bank. Using a data set of 114 mortgage-backed securities
 during 2014 and 2020 from banks listed in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Shenzhen Stock
 Exchanges, results show that securitization decreases systematic risk for banks listed
 in Hong Kong, but does not have a clear effect for banks listed only in mainland China.
 Seemingly unrelated regressions (SUR) under an event-study analysis is used to obtain
 the results in this paper.

Title:
Thinking about value: assessing knowledge creation and spillovers by the world's largest
                                 tech companies
Abstract:
The large-tech firms (Google, Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Microsoft) have become some
 of the biggest companies in existence, with extraordinary market shares in product
 markets and extraordinary market valuations in stock markets; they have also been
 the subject of much criticism for monopolistic practices that stifle competition and
 bottle up innovation (see, for example, Philippon 2019 and Lamoreaux 2019), thereby
 potentially limiting the sorts of positive spillovers that Romer (1986) identified
 as being crucial to growth. This paper assesses the extent to which the large-tech
 firms (defined as the largest companies by market value globally) produce and disseminate
 technological advances that lift the broader economy. This paper uses an original
 dataset on patents and patent citations to provide an assessment of innovation and
 spillover of innovation by the biggest tech firms. Specifically, it compares the innovation
 and diffusion rates of GAFAMs against their historical counterparts (five biggest
 companies in last five decades by market value) and their acquisitions (e.g., WhatsApp
 for Facebook). Our goal is for the results of this study to inform debates about the
 impact of these firms on the broader economy.

Title:
The Effect of Pro-Exploitation Parties on Deforestation: An Analysis of Close Municipal
                                 Races in the Brazilian Amazon
Abstract:
This paper explores the relationship between the election of pro-exploitation political
 parties and deforestation in municipalities in the Legal Amazon. Using panel deforestation
 data and electoral data from close municipal races, the study applies a Regression
 Discontinuity Design to aim to understand the effect of a narrow win by a political
 party on deforestation, considering the municipalities are very similar otherwise.
 Political parties are categorized in this study as either pro-exploitation or non
 pro-exploitation through a process that takes into consideration a variety of different
 factors. Main findings show that pro-exploitation parties are associated with higher
 levels of deforestation, particularly in the period after the 2016 local elections,
 but that the impact does not seem to be significant.

Title: The Gender Gap in Financial Inclusion: A Global Analysis of Predictors and Trends
Abstract:
Despite many documented benefits of financial inclusion, there exists a significant
 and persistent gender gap. Using the World Bank's Findex database, a rich and representative
 individual-level dataset focused on financial inclusion in 144 countries between 2011
 and 2017, this capstone documents that although the overall level of financial access
 has increased globally, the gender gap has also widened. In addition to this increase,
 the effectiveness of individual-level characteristics in explaining this gender gap
 has fallen from what was found in previous literature. There are significant differences
 in the gender gap across regions, suggesting that external country-level factors also
 drive gender differentials in financial inclusion. I also find that country-level
 gender equity policy indicators that explained the gap in financial access, financial
 usage, and mobile financial usage in 2011 explain it less in 2017, while the explanatory
 power of cultural factors has increased. Ultimately, this capstone suggests that gathering
 comprehensive individual-level data on cultural factors may be an important addition
 to the next round of the World Bank's Findex database. Regardless, further research
 to better understand this increasing and increasingly unexplained gender gap in financial
 inclusion is key to its mitigation.

Title:
Catalyst or Stabilizer-The Effect of Government Policy on Stock Market during COVID-19
                                 Pandemic in G20 Countries
Abstract:
COVID-19 is a black swan event that has caused tremendous public health concerns and
 severe economic downturn. To tackle the crisis and rebuild the resilience, governments
 are accountable for making reaction and recovery plans at the national level. As governments
 launched a wide range of measures, the effect of policies on financial markets remains
 an unsettled debate. This paper addresses whether policy responses to COVID-19 generate
 negative repercussions or create positive returns on stock markets, and how quickly
 does policy effects materialize. Based on panel data evidence of G20 countries, we
 demonstrate that income support, international travel ban and moving restriction have
 a positive impact on daily stock market return, while testing policy has a negative
 impact. Announcement of all four policies instantaneously affects the stock market
 return on the next trading day.

Title: Perceptions and Lying -- An Experimental Study on Motivations to Cheat
Abstract:
This Capstone Project is an experimental study to measure how our perceived social
 class, level of education, and money, affect our tendency to lie in the presence of
 a monetary incentive. Participants carried out a small exercise to manipulate their
 self- perception regarding any of the three categories and then rolled two virtual
 dice. We told participants that their payoffs depended on the sum they reported, therefore,
 providing them with an incentive to lie. We found that comparing yourself in terms
 of social class, education, or money does not seem to play a significant role in affecting
 people's tendency to lie in the presence of a monetary incentive. However, our results
 suggest that the higher the level of education, the smaller the chance to exhibit
 this type of unethical behavior.

Title: The effect of infrastructure spending on housing prices in major Indian cities
Abstract:
India is set to have one of the largest urbanization events over the next 30 years.
 City populations have been increasing and so have property prices. In April 2020,
 the government set a target of constructing roads worth Rs. 15 lakh crores ($212 billion)
 in the next two years. Existing literature has documented the effect of constructing
 highways on housing prices in cities with a population of over 5 million people. This
 project studies the effect of infrastructure investment on 50 cities in India. The
 results show that increasing the length of national highways has a positive effect
 on housing prices.

Title:
Testing the Fama-French Three-Factor Model vs the Fama-French Five-Factor Model in
                                 the GCC
Abstract:
This paper tests the Fama French Three-Factor Model against the Fama French Five-Factor
 Model to find the best asset pricing model for the GCC region. As averages of the
 intercepts from both models are significantly different from zero, there are other
 risks outside the model that explained the expected returns. The intercept averages'
 difference between the two models is also not significant, so we cannot determine
 whether the Three-factor or the Five-factor model is better for the GCC region. When
 reviewing the factor coefficients, Market, Value, Profitability, and Investment risks
 play a role in explaining the expected returns of stocks, while it is unclear whether
 Size is significant in explaining the returns.

Title: Use of Machine Learning Algorithms on Fund Performance Prediction
Abstract:
Although many econometrics papers found a strong correlation between fund and fund
 managers' characteristics with performance, machine learning prediction models refrain
 from these characteristic data, and use only variance or returns as independent variables.
 This capstone paper tries to fill this gap between machine learning and fund performance
 prediction. Using fund characteristics and fund managers data in addition to variance
 and returns, we test different machine learning algorithms to identify outperforming
 funds in U.S CRSP dataset. Our best performing gradient boosting model reached a high
 77.23 percent prediction success rate in identifying a positive alpha performance
 for the next year, a much higher success rate than a smaller machine learning model
 using only past performance. This result indicates that fund characteristics increase
 machine learning's prediction success rate, providing a better decision-aid for investors
 and money managers.

Title:
An Evaluation of Differences in Educational Attainment between Immigrant Students
                                 and Native Students in OECD Countries Using PISA Data
Abstract:
This capstone paper aims to understand the gap between the educational attainment
 of immigrant students and that of native students using 2018 PISA data, and observe
 how it has changed compared with the results from the 2009 PISA data. In addition,
 the paper aims to update how students' immigrant background moderates the impact of
 socioeconomic status (SES) on students' educational attainment. The research is conducted
 on a selection of OECD countries based on the country's percentage of immigrant students
 as well as the completeness of data as recorded by the PISA test. The paper finds
 that immigrant background affects students' educational attainment as reflected by
 the PISA test score, although the effect is mixed, which could be explained by the
 different origins of immigrants for different countries. It also finds that higher
 socioeconomic status will lead to higher educational attainment, and in most of the
 selected countries, immigrant background will have negative moderating impact on socioeconomic
 status' impact on students' educational attainment.

Title: The Impact of the Arab Spring on Gross Domestic Product
Abstract:
This paper uses the synthetic control methodology to estimate the impact of the Arab
 Spring on per capita GDP in four countries; Egypt, Tunisia, Jordan, and Morocco between
 2011 and 2017. The results suggest that the output gap for Egypt and Tunisia continued
 to get worse year on year reaching 13% and 21% respectively in 2017 where the main
 channels of the impact were losses in tourism receipts, gross capital formation, and
 FDI inflows. Findings also suggest that spillover effects have substantial impacts
 on per capita GDP. Jordan was impacted more directly by the Syrian refugee crisis
 and trade shocks which led to output losses reaching 37% in 2017 with no evidence
 of recovery. Morocco was impacted less directly and the relatively smaller shock was
 easily managed by government policy.

Title:
Impact of the Local Provision of Primary and Secondary Education on Years of Schooling
                                 and Employment Status of the Youth in Ethiopia
Abstract:
This paper examines the connection between years of schooling and employment status
 of the youth caused by the 1990's local provision of primary and secondary education
 policy reform in Ethiopia. Using temporal variation generated by the implementation
 of the reform, the impact of the policy reform is identified by using average year
 of schooling and average year of none or pre-school across region, age groups, and
 gender. The policy affected slightly different ages differently, if an individual
 was old enough the time the policy was rolled out relative to young enough for it
 to matter. The paper finds that after the implementation of the reform there is an
 increase in years of schooling for younger people, who were fully exposed to the policy.
 However, on average youth between the age range 20 to 29 are estimated to have paid
 employment status that is 0.08 points lower than those above the age 30. On the other
 hand, females compared to males face excessive disadvantage in the labor market and
 are often confined to an unpaid and informal sector. Ordinary Least Squares regression
 (OLS) model is used to estimate the return to years of schooling and its impact on
 employment status.

Title:
Understanding the Legislative Spectrum of Sex Work: A Brief Case Study of the Netherlands,
                                 South Africa, and Sweden
Abstract:
This study explores legislative frameworks surrounding sex work, and how the legal
 environments of various contexts shape the social conditions around them. The study
 begins with an overview of understanding contemporary sex work, namely through discussing
 the key schools of thought in sex work debates, as well as the often-neglected but
 massively important topic of indoor sex work. Indoor sex work is discussed at length
 to discuss its potential as the most viable form of sex work for an environment where
 the practice is legal. After this discussion, three case studies are addressed, discussing
 the relationships between their respective legal systems and how sex work operates
 in each society. The case studies (the Netherlands, South Africa, and Sweden) are
 chosen to illustrate points on a broader legislative spectrum with regards to sex
 work. The study concludes by noting the immense differences in the needs of each case
 study with respect to improving their legal systems so as not to increase sex worker
 victimization. Additionally, it is concluded that none of the legal frameworks discussed
 represents an ideal scenario for sex workers, but each offer insights on how to improve
 sex work legislation in general.

Title: Introduction to Continuous Voting
Abstract:
Major: Political Science Abstract: Continuous Elections are the election methods of governing systems that
 do not have set term lengths or election cycles, but rather employ a fluid voting
 system where individuals may cast, retract, or change their vote at will and, consequently,
 potentially cause a new outcome at any time. We offer the first, rudimentary computer
 models of this method, which predict a generally stable outcome for most organizations.
 We engage in what is thus far the most comprehensive discussion concerning the theoretical
 underpinnings of this method, as well as, its potential merits and shortcomings. Finally,
 we offer an open-source program and framework for this election method that can be
 freely downloaded and employed in the interest of providing future scholars with data
 so that we might further our understanding of this unique election method.

Title: Intertwining powers: The Case Study of Hungary's Declining Separation of Powers
Abstract:
Major: Political Science Abstract: In 1989 a peaceful revolution swept away the Soviet-style socialism in Hungary
 the foundations of the modern, democratic Hungarian nation state were established.
 Although in the '90's the Hungarian Republic was built upon the ancient concept of
 the Separation of Powers, now, merely two decades later, this model seems to be deteriorating.
 Many blame the 2010 Parliamentary elections that concluded in the landslide victory
 of the conservative right-wing party, Fidesz, and their consecutive Constitutional
 reforms for this deterioration. Furthermore, there is a number of other, often less
 obvious changes in the state structure that redistributed power from the executive
 and judiciary branches to the Parliament and thus allowed uncontested governance for
 Fidesz. In this paper I intend to investigate the state of the Hungarian Separation
 of Powers model to determine the extent to which the legislature has usurped powers
 formerly reserved to the other branches. This analysis may also have implications
 for other young and transitional democracies (anocracies) around the world.

Title: Roma Race: The Racialization of Roma Identity in Hungary
Abstract:
Major: Political Science, Middle Eastern Studies Abstract: This paper examines how racial identity is constructed by analyzing the
 legal framework that the Hungarian State devised for Roma affairs in the last decades.
 The examination of how the Hungarian legal system shapes and constructs Roma identity
 reveals how national and ethnic identities are part of "classificatory struggles"
 and what consequences those struggles can incur. Even though State laws and the legal
 framework do not explicitly mention racial categories, they do set the Roma apart
 from the majority and only a minority of them can perform the identity that the state
 assigns. The need to identify them can thus perpetuate other markers, e.g. racial
 features, for which there is historical precedence and empiric evidence.

Title: The Impact of Civil War Violence on The Education System in Nepal
Abstract:
Major: Political Science Abstract: Nepal suffered civil war violence over the course of ten years, from 1996
 to 2006. In the aftermath of the civil conflict it appears that education was one
 of the most affected areas. This paper examines the effects of the civil war violence
 on the education system in Nepal. The research presents two approaches: empirical
 analysis and qualitative research findings. I conclude that the violence caused by
 the Maoist insurgency had a significant impact on public and private school enrolment
 and educational processes, which potentially facilitated the increase of the number
 of private schools in post-conflict Nepal. This research aims to inform the public
 and private sectors, governmental organizations and NGOs about the relationship between
