 incentives for states to develop treaties to mandate its fair use. Therefore, what
 are the determinants of the mechanisms that ensure compliance among signatories in
 treaties? In this paper, I study the determinants influencing water treaty design
 and focus on regime type, a major determinant of trust within treaties. The levels
 of trust between signatories can either create strict or lenient demands in order
 to ensure compliance among one another. Through expectations, reputations, and past
 actions, states attempt to anticipate future outcomes in order to mitigate noncompliance.
 I find that different regime type dyads utilize different enforcement mechanisms.
 Autocratic dyads respond better to coercive enforcement mechanisms, while democratic
 dyads incorporate mechanisms that prioritize inclusion and transparency. Democratic
 dyads design more flexible treaties relative to mixed and autocratic dyads, given
 that the levels of trust are relatively higher. These results illustrate how regime
 type dyads affect the levels of trust among signatories, thus, influencing water treaty
 design.

Title: Motivated Reasoning in the Perception of Brazil's COVID-19 Response
Abstract:
Brazil has been one of the hardest-hit countries in the world by the coronavirus pandemic.
 Since the crisis began, President Jair Bolsonaro has been dismissive of the threat
 and prioritized the economy over health concerns. Understanding how Brazilians view
 the response can offer insight into how political alignment influences perceptions
 of the impact. I use a survey to assess who Brazilians blame for the virus, their
 estimation of its seriousness, and who they credit for the government's response.
 I also carry out a survey experiment to understand how political alignment influences
 willingness to take the coronavirus vaccine. I find that specifying that a vaccine
 will be free makes a person 9.86% more likely to take it compared to offering no information,
 and specifying that President Bolsonaro endorses it makes someone 15.49% more likely
 to take it. I also find that the president's supporters blame China compared to his
 detractors, who blame Bolsonaro and other internal factors rather than external ones.
 These results suggest that motivated reasoning, not misinformation, can explain who
 Brazilians blame for the negative impact of the virus, but does not explain who they
 credit for a positively-viewed policy.

Title: Examining the Effects of Ethnic Conflict on Power Sharing: The Case of Guyana
Abstract:
How does ethnic violence affect ethnic power sharing at the executive level in post-colonial
 democracies? In this paper, I hypothesize that ethnic conflict results in a lower
 extent of executive-level power sharing across ethnic lines. This analysis focuses
 on the effects of historical ethnic violence specifically in postcolonial democracies
 on the potential for power sharing. I examine the case study of Guyana to build a
 hypothesis and theory surrounding this question. I argue that ethnic violence in post
 colonial democracies reduces inter-ethnic coalition building, increases ethnic party
 polarization and voting, and decreases trust in national institutions. All of these
 phenomena, in turn, result in a lower level of power sharing. I then test this hypothesis
 empirically using key variables derived from the Ethnic Power Relations Armed Conflict
 Dataset. Overall, this paper finds no effect of ethnic conflict on power sharing.
 However, the analytical basis, rooted in the case study of Guyana, provides implications
 for further research. Specifically, these include a deeper understanding of the role
 of colonialism in democratization in ethnically plural post colonial democracies,
 the effects of external powers of institution building, and how different forms of
 violence may affect institutions differently.

Title:
Judicial Bias After Crises in US Civil Courts: Evidence from Prisoner Petitions in
                                 the Time of 9/11
Abstract:
This paper focuses on the effects of judicial bias on federal civil courts. Civil
 courts are often ignored as part of judicial bias research, yet they are prisoners'
 only recourse to address human rights concerns. This article fills this gap in judicial
 bias scholarship by leveraging prisoner cases in the fallout of the terrorist attacks
 on September 11, 2001. Civil courts served as Muslim prisoners' only place to address
 evidence of mistreatment following 9/11. This paper utilizes various outcomes along
 the prisoner petition timeline along with difference in difference estimations to
 consider the presence and magnitude of judicial bias in civil courts. Ultimately,
 this paper contends that Muslim prisoners were more likely to have attorney representation,
 and more likely to reach settlements or trial than other prisoners in the years following
 9/11.

Title:
The Effects of Community and/ or Government Participation on Women Representation
                                 in Decision-making Processes
Abstract:
Does government and/or community participation in public goods provisions affect women's
 participation in the process? In this study, I analyze the effects of stakeholder
 involvement on women's representation in public goods decision-making processes. I
 speculate that governments may use the presence of women as a signaling device to
 the international community, resulting in more women representation. In comparison,
 communities themselves may have customary traditions that are obstructive to women's
 participation in leadership. Thus, I hypothesize that government participation in
 public goods allocation will result in more women representation compared to no stakeholder
 participation and/ or community involvement. The study draws from a large development
 program that took place in 2015. Three hundred thirty-nine villages in Eastern Congo
 received a large development program that distributed funds to hospitals and schools.
 The program included two experiments: government and/ or community stakeholder involvement
 in the decision-making processes related to the said funds. The data suggest no evidence
 that the intervention affected gender representation in local public goods provisions.
 I discuss potential reasons for the statistically insignificant results, including
 context-specific obstacles that may have obstructed the expected relationship.

Title: Voting after Violence: Incumbent Support after Civil Wars
Abstract:
Does exposure to violence have an effect on the support for wartime incumbents? Prior
 research investigated how violence shapes general political attitudes and engagements,
 but has not managed to explain why some parties continue their rule after the war,
 while others get voted out. This paper seeks to explain how voters' exposure to local
 violence alters the postwar electoral success of wartime incumbent parties. I draw
 on municipal-level electoral data from Bosnia and Herzegovina to test whether communities
 that experience more wartime violence tend to vote incumbent parties out of office.
 Using a difference-in-difference identification strategy, I show that the effect of
 violence is heterogeneous across different parties. Parties representing those who
 experienced disproportionately high levels of violence were punished in the postwar
 elections more, but this effect is likely mediated by selective emigration of the
 voter base. Conversely, parties which achieved their wartime goals see an increase
 in local government seat share.

Title: Ideological Leaning of News outlets and Trends in Terrorism Coverage
Abstract:
The media plays a crucial role in keeping the public updated on the events happening
 around the world, including security threats such as terrorism. However, the framing
 of such incidents is not homogenous. Some outlets may frame a violent incident as
 "attack" or "explosion"; others may refer to the same event as an instance "terrorism".
 The differences in framing have implications for the public sense of security and,
 maybe more importantly, for the perception of publicity success of perpetrators. This
 study applies Structural Topic Modeling and sentiment analysis to the coverage of
 incidents of terror published in major newspapers from five countries (Australia,
 United Kingdom, Spain, Chile, Mexico) to contribute to answering the overarching question:
 what shapes the variation in the framing of terrorist attacks? More specifically,
 this paper looks at differences between conservative and liberal media outlets in
 their framing of said events with respect to their use of the "terror" frame as well
 as their sentiment when reporting such incidents. Contrary to previous research, this
 study finds no significant differences in these aspects between liberal and conservative
 outlets.

Title:
Reframing Turkish Laiklik: 'Regulatory Secularism' from the Kemalist Republic to the
                                 AKP, 1923-2020
Abstract:
How has Turkey come to be near-universally theorized as a secular state despite having
 routinely violated the substantive components of secularism as defined by Western
 political theory? Using the methodology of historical institutionalism,
 this paper undertakes a systematic investigation of that puzzle. Based on that investigation,
 this paper argues that– far from embodying "secularism" as that term has traditionally
 been conceptualized in comparative political theory– Turkey has,
 from its so-called golden age of secularism under Atatürk to the present, more Islamist-tinged
 regime of Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, never fit the core components of secularism (including
 functional separation of church and state, and equal treatment of citizens without
 discrimination based on religious beliefs). To more accurately understand religion-state
 relations in Turkey, this paper contends that political theorists must recognize that
 Turkey embodies a distinctly alternative approach to standard theorizations of Western
 secularism. I term this "regulatory secularism"– an approach characterized not by
 the traditional metrics of functional separation or non-discrimination, but by (1)
 the state's monopolization and control of religious institutions and (2) the state's
 ideology of Muslim majoritarianism.

Title: Can Monitoring Induce Positive Remittance Behaviors for Community-wide Initiatives
Abstract:
This paper studies remittances and behavioral intervention. It peers into a dimension
 of remittances often overlooked in the literature and by other stakeholders in the
 remittance field: non-proximate remittances, that is, remittances sent to persons
 or for purposes not directly connected to senders' families or friends. Specifically,
 I look into the potential of orienting remittances towards community-wide projects
 in communities of remittance senders' countries of origin. I investigate the effect
 of monitoring – one behavioral intervention – on migrant populations' remittance behaviors
 via a survey experiment and randomization. Though the treatment has an insignificant
 negative effect on the general sample, it has a significant negative effect on a subset
 of respondents I designate as being highly attentive during the survey. Ultimately,
 the survey's insights indicate a generally positive and pragmatic outlook on the concept
 of non-proximate remittances.

Title: Political Self-Censorship: A Climate Study of Chilling Effects at NYU Abu Dhabi
Abstract:
Through original survey research carried out on 157 students at New York University
 Abu Dhabi, this study investigates the effect of clarifying local media laws and Diversity,
 Equity and Inclusion policy on both chilling effects and levels of self-reported self-censorship
 on and off campus. Firstly, I find that NYUAD students are least likely to express
 their political opinion in off campus environments. Secondly, in response to the DEI
 statement students report lower levels of self-reported self-censorship strictly on
 campus. However, in an online setting both the DEI and Law prime saw participants
 indicate higher levels of constraint. Lastly, self-identified conservatives are more
 likely to report greater instances of self-censorship in all on campus environments.
 There remains much research to be done on the application of chilling effects in academic
 spaces.

Title:
Shaping Perceptions and Accountability of Traditional Leaders through Community Driven
                                 Development: Evidence from the Democratic Republic of Congo
Abstract:
This study researches whether community driven development programs lead to changes
 in perceptions and accountability of traditional leaders by citizens in the Eastern
 region of the DRC. For perceptions, this study looks at preferences in leadership
 and public goods allocation. In terms of accountability, this study focuses on non-electoral
 accountability which is comprised of inclusive decision making and need to verify
 leader's actions. The study is based on data collected in 2010 and 2011. Random assignment
 is used to measure the effects of community driven development programs on outcome
 variables. I also test to see if sub-groups such as males in study have any interaction
 effects with the treatment on perceptions and non-electoral accountability. The results
 show that CDD programs have a significant negative effect on perceptions of preference
 in traditional leadership whereby citizens prefer local democratic processes over
 traditional leadership in managing resources. However, this study finds no evidence
 that CDD programs have any impact on citizens perceptions of public goods allocation
 or non-electoral accountability of traditional leaders. Additionally, there is no
 interaction effect between treatment and gender on outcome variables indicating no
 significant impact on men in CDD programs.

Title:
The Structure and Distribution of Ideologies and Political Positions of Parties in
                                 Ethiopia
Abstract:
This project is the first comprehensive empirical study into Ethiopian political parties
 and party systems. Using a sample of 76 national and regional parties, it conducts
 different computer assisted analysis to produce an ideological space for Ethiopian
 parties on a one-dimensional left-right spectrum. It also attempts to determine the
 association of the parties to certain salient topics in the current domestic political
 climate. In addition, using clustering algorithms, this project groups parties together
 based on their similarities and conducts a comparison analysis among parties in the
 sample and other parties from established democracies.

Title: Scared Straight: Stigma, stress and sexual diversity in U
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy Abstract: Adopting minority stress theory and stigma management theory for sexual
 minority youth, this study aims to understand how supportive and unsupportive environments
 engender different sexuality outcomes. Using a cross-classification variable comprised
 of sexual attraction, relationships and identity, this study examines the effects
 of individual-level and environmental-level indicators of school integration, religious
 fundamentalism, experience of prejudice, exposure to violence, and school sanctions.
 Using multinomial regression analysis of data from the National Longitudinal Survey
 of Adolescent Health, this study finds that unsupportive environments limit sexual
 fluidity and sexuality outcomes, particularly in female respondents, while there is
 also some indication that more supportive environments engender greater sexual diversity.
 Given the considerable psychological consequences of repressing one's sexuality, the
 findings of this study encourage policy interventions at the high-school level to
 foster greater education and inclusivity to overcome the additive stresses that sexual
 minority youth face, while encouraging further research into the dynamics of contemporary
 high schools.

Title: Volunteerism and Divergent Forms of Giving in the Abu Dhabi Community
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy Abstract: In the last 25 years (Ali, 1986), the Emirate of Abu Dhabi, as a subsidiary
 of the greater United Arab Emirates, has experienced a massive influx of immigration
 that has dramatically impacted the demographics and nature of the resident community
 in the capital. This growth has precipitated a diversification of the Abu Dhabi community,
 which has in turn affected the composition of the potential volunteer pool in the
 Emirate. Drawing upon existing literature on the motivation to volunteer and perceptions
 of volunteerism across varying sociocultural backgrounds, this study investigates
 the nature and function of volunteerism in the Emirate through analysis of interviews
 with local volunteer coordinators, complemented by exploratory statistical analysis
 of a non-probability sample of 209 digital surveys completed by local residents. Findings
 show that differences in volunteers' sociocultural and demographic backgrounds correlate
 with respondents' reported motivations, conceptions, and integration into the local
 volunteer landscape, and that diverse orientations towards volunteerism are represented
 within the Emirate.

Title: Volunteerism and Divergent Forms of Giving in the Abu Dhabi Community
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy Abstract: In the last 25 years (Ali, 1986), the Emirate of Abu Dhabi, as a subsidiary
 of the greater United Arab Emirates, has experienced a massive influx of immigration
 that has dramatically impacted the demographics and nature of the resident community
 in the capital. This growth has precipitated a diversification of the Abu Dhabi community,
 which has in turn affected the composition of the potential volunteer pool in the
 Emirate. Drawing upon existing literature on the motivation to volunteer and perceptions
 of volunteerism across varying sociocultural backgrounds, this study investigates
 the nature and function of volunteerism in the Emirate through analysis of interviews
 with local volunteer coordinators, complemented by exploratory statistical analysis
 of a non-probability sample of 209 digital surveys completed by local residents. Findings
 show that differences in volunteers' sociocultural and demographic backgrounds correlate
 with respondents' reported motivations, conceptions, and integration into the local
 volunteer landscape, and that diverse orientations towards volunteerism are represented
 within the Emirate.

Title: Dominance and Antidominance as Motives of Groups in Conflict
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy Abstract: Groups that are more powerful in a conflict will often characterize less
 powerful groups as trying to gain power for the purposes of domination. But it is
 not clear that these are the motives of the less powerful. Our study considers the
 conflict of gay marriage in the United States. Through a content analysis of texts
 of representatives of higher-power, anti-gay marriage authors and lower-power, pro-gay
 marriage authors, we show that while higher power groups in a conflict consistently
 characterize the lower power group as trying to dominate, no such evidence can be
 found in the writings and speeches of low-power groups. Instead, lower-power groups
 use language of resisting domination by demanding equal treatment, respect and dignity.
 The paper concludes with a discussion of the theoretical and political implications
 of these findings as well as possibilities for future research.

Title:
Programmatic and Voting Cohesion of European Political Groups in the 7th European
                                 Parliament
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy Abstract: This study diagnoses whether European parties fulfill their function as
 the primary mechanism for European representation and delegation. The EU party system
 functions at two levels: national and supranational. At the European elections, EU
 citizens vote for a national party of their choice. After the elections, the national
 parties that have received enough votes enter the EP and join one of the transnational
 European political groups ("EP factions"). These groups are conglomerates of different
 national parties and form coalitions based on – what they claim to be – a shared ideology.
 This study examines 1) whether the EP factions are programmatically cohesive, and
 2) whether programmatic cohesion, rather than intra-faction pressure, is what explains
 the high voting cohesion rates of EP factions. Discriminant analysis based on the
 programmatic profiles of national parties suggests that EP factions are programmatically
 cohesive units. Variation in the voting agreement rates, however, is mostly due to
 intra-faction pressure, more prominent in the mainstream pro-EU factions. The programmatic
 cohesion and voting efficacy of EP factions prove that EP elections and the legislative
 process are becoming increasingly European and decreasingly national.

Title:
The Role of Race in Mental Health: A Study on the Children of Cuban Immigrants in
                                 Florida
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy Abstract: The racial disparities in mental health are well documented, and there are
 many studies examining the link between race and mental health. In this paper, I model
 this relationship by comparing the differences in the depression index scores of Cuban
 children with differing races and then examining two pathways (discrimination and
 acculturation) that may contribute to the difference in scores of White and Black/Multiracial
 Cuban immigrant children to the US. Results indicate that this model provides support
 for the hypothesis that there is a statistically significant difference in the average
 depression index scores of White and Black/Multiracial Cuban children. However, this
 model does not provide support for the two pathways that may contribute to those differences.
 This study provides a unique lens with which to explore the relationship between race
 and mental health. Unlike other studies of its kind, it focuses on self-reported discrimination,
 combines racial discrimination with acculturation, and uses quantitative analysis
 to better understand this relationship within a highly specific immigrant group, Cuban
 immigrants.

Title: On Fertility, the Preference for Sons and Child Mortality in India
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy Abstract: The social development theory of demographic transition holds that demographic
 trends, especially the level of fertility, reflect the degree to which political and
 economic institutions reflect social justice (Ratcliffe, 1978). The falling fertility
 rates in India in the last few decades are thought to reflect the success of the processes
 and policies with the potential to empower women. Au contraire, similar amount of
 literature exists that argues otherwise - that falls in fertility are believed to
 be occurring independent of social development. The purpose of this paper is to analyze
 the changing gender differential in child mortality (which is a reflection of either
 an intensification or a reduction in the effect of son preference), when there is
 a fall in fertility. This question is analyzed using two waves of NFHS data to build
 on the work of Basu (1999) and Gupta and Bhat (1997). I find that in states that were
 already characterized by a preference for sons, a fall in fertility at a relatively
 faster pace saw the gender differential in child mortality increase significantly,
 indicating an intensification of existing son preference at lower parities. This paper
 ends with policy suggestions.

Title: The social mobility processes of second-generation
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy Abstract: Based on data from semi-structured interviews, this study investigates the
 social mobility strategies employed by upwardly mobile German-Turkish women living
 in Berlin. Using educational attainment and labour market achievement as objective
 indicators of upward mobility, the subjects fit into three categories of social mobility
 trajectories. Important processes for upward mobility are identified within these
 categories, using the framework of Bourdieu's theory of capital. In some cases, the
 domestic transmission of cultural capital is essential for upward mobility, while
 in others it is a context-specific resource for effective decision-making. Moreover,
 an expansion of social capital to extend beyond isolated ethnic communities is decisive
 for all subjects; either for its conversion into necessary cultural capital or through
 the avoidance of some of the negative effects of social capital on women in certain
 tightly-bound ethnic communities. While the mobilisation of ethnicity is useful for
 the upward mobility of a subgroup of German-Turkish women, it is a limitation for
 others. Finally, regardless of social mobility trajectory categorization, subjects
 are unified by their lack of symbolic capital in mainstream German society. The strategies
 they employ to counter this are found to be more assertive and focused on Germany
 than those employed by the previous generation.

Title: "This is a Bangla Place": Identity Claims to Public Space in Downtown Abu Dhabi
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy Abstract: There is a square in downtown Abu Dhabi that is known to Bangladeshis of
 the city as khajur tola. This place has, for almost forty years, been a site of gathering
 for Bangladeshis. This paper will examine the ways in which this public space in Abu
 Dhabi is informed with a Bangladeshi identity and how a community that is marginalised
 comes to make claims to space. The paper will argue that in this community's claims
 to public space, they assert a right to belong in the city. That right is contested
 by both active municipality control but also broader social processes that are eroding
 the sense of place made here.

Title: Not Yet Saved: Storytelling and the Social Process of Conversion
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public Policy Abstract: This thesis explores the processes of becoming and being a Christian in
 a Chinese Evangelical Christian congregation in Abu Dhabi, combining life history
 interviews with participant observation to study the ways in which stories and social
 practice are constitutive of individual identity and group cohesion. Specifically,
 I focus on the stories and rituals that enable the learned process of self-transformation.
 I argue that immediate acts of social coordination combine with the practice of telling
 and listening to conversion narratives to incorporate new and potential converts into
 the congregation. Individuals begin to think of themselves as Christian converts through
 physical practices that situate them in the religious community and narrative practices
 that reconstitute their past and coordinate their futures.

Title:
A Window Into Private Opinions: Facebook and Changes to the Migration Discourse in
                                 Germany in 2014
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public PolicyAbstract: PEGIDA, Patriotic Europeans against the Islamization of the Occident, emerged
 in December 2014 urging for changes to policies allowing Muslim migration to Germany.
 By analyzing Facebook comments published throughout the year 2014, I ask how PEGIDA
 influenced a change in the migration discourse on Facebook in Germany. I find, that
 the rise of PEGIDA in December 2014 encouraged a shift in the migration discourse
 on Facebook. It reoriented the debate from discussing immigration to rejecting right
 wing nationalist ideology. As PEGIDA supporters amplified their presence on Facebook,
 commenters concerned with the extremist discourse overshadowed those in support of
 immigration. Immigrants themselves were not the primary topic of discussion in the
 migration discourse in December.This is an example of discursive deflection, as the silence regarding immigrants resulted
 from individuals becoming focused on nationalist stances on migration. The discursive
 deflection in this research is not unique to Facebook users in Germany. It emerged
 across social circles and mediums, as individuals turned to defend political correctness
 amidst a rising nationalist discourse. Facebook comments nonetheless provide an insightful
 window into discursive deflection, because they make visible a multitude of private
 opinions, which would not otherwise become public knowledge.

Title: A Worthy Cause?: How Social Meanings of Illness Impact the Success of Medical Crowdfunding
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public PolicyAbstract: In the past decade, crowdfunding has emerged as an alternative point of
 access to economic resources. The crowdfunding of medical bills is of particular interest
 given rising healthcare costs, but has received little attention in research on the
 dynamics of crowdfunding. As the general public evaluates which cases are worthy of
 their donations, it becomes increasingly important to understand the factors accounting
 for differences in donation behavior. One factor specific to this type of crowdfunding
 is represented by the categories of illness that individuals cite in their requests
 for donations. Diagnostic categories are both shaped by and shape social meanings
 and valuations of illness and the ill. Using a dataset of over 40,000 medical fundraising
 campaigns from the crowdfunding platform, GoFundMe, this research finds that existing
 theories of social meanings and value rankings of illnesses predict differences in
 financial support in the context of medical crowdfunding. The implications of these
 findings are discussed and directions for future research are proposed.

Title: Post-Soviet Identity in the "Russian" Restaurants of Abu Dhabi
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public PolicyAbstract: This thesis explores the complexness of identity of the post-Soviet nations
 in the restarurants of Abu Dhabi, combining interviews of the employees with participant
 observations to study the presence and strength of the Soviet legacy in the environments
 of the restaurants. Specifically, I focus on the stories and contents of the restaurants,
 which have a unifying effect on the people of the post-Soviet nations, such as common
 language and cuisine, and evaluate the significance of these effects on the perception
 of identity.I argue that despite the fact that it has been approximately 25 years since the fall
 of the Soviet Union, as well as despite various nationalistic movements in the post-Soviet
 states, the Soviet legacy remains strong. I further argue that the identities of the
 post-Soviet nations are neither nationalistic, nor Soviet, but rather a mix of both,
 having numerous unique features, yet simultaneously sharing numerous cultural aspects
 with the people of the ex-Soviet Union.

Title: Embeddedness of Entrepreneurial Activity: The Case of the United Arab Emirates
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public PolicyAbstract: The research question this study explores is: what motivations do Emirati
 entrepreneurs ascribe to their entrepreneurial activity, and how does the context
 of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) influence these motivations? Using data collected
 from interviews with Emirati entrepreneurs, as well as representatives of organizations
 that promote entrepreneurship in the UAE, I investigate the different rationales behind
 entrepreneurial activity of Emirati entrepreneurs in tandem with the social, cultural,
 and institutional dimensions of the entrepreneurial context of the UAE. The findings
 reveal that most Emirati entrepreneurs pursue entrepreneurship with intrinsic motivations
 of following their passions, proving themselves through a personal challenge, and
 most commonly, making a social or cultural contribution to the UAE and to the larger
 Arab world. I conclude that specific aspects of the entrepreneurial context of the
 UAE give rise to a purposeful and value-focused nature of entrepreneurship, where
 economic motives are absent or secondary. The study contributes to the literature
 in economic sociology that finds entrepreneurial activity to be socially embedded,
 and guided by factors other than economic self-interest.

Title: "A Match Made in Heaven": Spousal Selection Among Iranians
Abstract:
Major: Social Research and Public PolicyAbstract: Romantic love, especially in the context of marriage, has been the topic
 of much attention and debate in recent academic and non-academic discussions. The
 debate however is often centered on the necessary societal and cultural conditions
 for producing romantic love in marriage. This paper aims to take a different perspective
 on the interaction of culture and romantic love. Instead of looking at culture as
 a direct cause of the role, structure and view of love in marriage among Iranians,
 this paper follows more contemporary views of culture as heterogeneous and context-specific
 rather than a singular and uniform driving force of all action. Using Latent Class
 Analysis, I uncover classes of people who have different constellations of preferences
 for selecting their spouse. This analysis reveals that love can be simultaneously
 associated with other values, which prima facie appear contradictory. This paper finds
 that love can have different meanings to different people depending on the constellation
 of other mate selection criteria with which it is chosen and associated; and therefore,
 that coherence is contextually established.

Title: Is Getting Pregnant the Worst? Attitudinal Responses to Peer's Pregnancies
Abstract:
Cultural explanations of adolescent pregnancy suggest that normative attitudes in
 an individual's social context can play an important role in mediating pregnancy incidence.
 This study investigates the inverse relationship by examining changes in individuals'
 attitudes towards pregnancy in response to an instance of pregnancy in their peer
 group. I find that individuals who are exposed to pregnancy in their peer groups have
 higher rates of change in pregnancy attitudes than individuals who are not exposed
 to pregnancy in their peer groups. On average, however, individuals are not more likely
 to change their attitudes in a positive or negative direction. These results suggest
 that exposure to pregnancy at the peer group level changes individual's attitudes
 towards pregnancy, but not in a predetermined way. Further results suggest that while
 characteristics of the individual's social context may not be important in shaping
 individual's attitudinal responses to their peer's pregnancies, the normative climates
 in which individuals are embedded do shape how individuals respond to their peers'
 pregnancies.

Title:
Political Timing of Non-political News: A Study on Political Scandals and Celebrity
                                 Gossip
Abstract:
Scandals are costly to the social and political life of politicians. To minimize the
 political cost of scandals, politicians may attempt to reduce the public attention
 given to the news. In this article I examine whether celebrity gossip is released
 in tandem with political scandals, testing a widespread media conspiracy theory in
 South Korea. I hypothesize that the more political scandals are in the news, the more
 celebrity gossip we observe. Using unique data on popular news stories in South Korea,
 I test this hypothesis. Both the linear correlation and the time series analysis of
 gossip and scandals show that there is more celebrity news on days when there are
 political scandals. This finding supports the popular belief in Korea that the timing
 of celebrity gossip is manipulated to crowd out political scandals.

Title:
Towards Novel Approaches to Memory Work: Guided Tours at the Memorial to the Murdered
                                 Jews of Europe, Berlin
Abstract:
Based on ethnographic research of guided tours for German high school students at
 the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe in Berlin, this paper examines guiding
 strategies at a remembrance site within the emerging "counter-monument" phenomenon.
 Attempting to resist redemption from the task of remembrance, the architect provided
 no interpretation about his artwork, encouraging visitors to develop their own meaning.
 Maintaining multiple interpretations during a tour is the central strategy practiced
 by guides. I argue that such presence of multiple ideas not only demonstrates to participants
 that there is no single correct interpretation, but it also resists closure with the
 memorial. I further argue that, in the context of this memorial, guiding techniques
 empower students with a sense of authority as meaning-makers and direct them towards
 a novel approach to memory work that invites individuals to confront the difficulties
 of remembering, engendering it as a continuous process.

Title:
It's Not About the Money: Negotiating Emirati Masculinity amid State Promotion of
                                 Women's Employment
Abstract:
This study explores Emirati men's gendered identity negotiations in relation to state-promoted
 women's employment in the United Arab Emirates. Drawing from a series of qualitative,
 in-depth interviews, I adopt a social identity and gender constructivist analytical
 approach to understand intersectional Emirati masculinity in flux. I argue that state-promoted
 women's work challenges a codified ideal masculinity, encouraging men's aspiration
 to and practice of shared breadwinning, while impacting the gendering of childcare
 less. I also examine Emirati men's experiences of women-centered state policy, finding
 that their concern over status decline and support for women's work are not mutually
 exclusive. Especially evident in their relational comparisons to other men, awareness
 of international notions of modernity and stereotyped Arab masculinity pervade Emirati
 men's social identity construction. This study deepens understandings of intersectional
 Emirati masculinity and highlights conditions that challenge strict gender norms.

Title: Tomorrow's Neighbors: Strategies for Temporary Refugee Integration in Athens, Greece
Abstract:
Between 2015 and 2016, over one million migrants and refugees entered Greece via the
 Mediterranean Sea. After Greece's northern borders closed and the EU signed a migration
 agreement with Turkey in 2016, 60,000 asylum seekers found themselves confined in
 Greece, where the asylum application process can last over a year. This paper discusses
 the need for temporary refugee integration and seeks to answer the questions: what
 are the main barriers to refugee integration in Athens, and how can policymakers facilitate
 the temporary integration of refugees into the city? Data for this study was collected
 during two rounds of field interviews in Athens in 2016. Respondents were sampled
 from three categories: refugees (n=46), direct service providers working for nongovernmental
 organizations (n=27), and independent volunteers (n=13). These conversations revealed
 many barriers to refugee integration in Athens, including poor employment prospects,
 secluded accommodation, and refugees' reluctance to stay in Greece. However, several
 factors that could improve integration prospects were identified, including English
 and Greek language learning, mentorship from other migrants, and stable accommodation.
 This paper concludes with a series of policy recommendations for service providers
 to encourage the temporary integration of refugees in Athens.

Title: The "Many Hats" Worn:  Discourses on Women and Work in Oman
Abstract:
This research project explores the experiences of Omani female lawyers and engineers
 and compares their narratives to dominant policy discourses about women's employment
 in Oman. I investigate sex segregation in the workforce through semi-structured interviews
 and discourse analysis. The women interviewed reproduce some policy discourses, but
 always as pertaining to "other" women who are deemed more traditional. However, some
 of the women's narratives diverge from policy discourses, presenting a more complex
 reality, for example, in the case of familial relations. Furthermore, women discussed
 structural challenges faced in the workplace, a notion that the policy discourse misses.
 Challenges women face are over attributed to culture, tradition, individual efforts
 and mindsets of women through the influence of modernization and development narratives.
 This over-attribution overshadows structural barriers preventing necessary policy
 level change to occur. This study also aims to counter exceptionalist narratives on
 the region and reveals far more complex lived realities of Omani women.

Title:
The Evolution and Modernization of Families, Marriage and Weddings Across Three Generations
                                 in the United Arab Emirates
Abstract:
With increased modernization in the UAE, many traditional and cultural aspects of
 Emirati life have been impacted attracting notable changes to the way the traditional
 customs of marriage are conducted. Due to the fast rate of development and modernization
 of the country, these changes are noticeable among current generations in the country.
 With primary research conducted across three generations, the customs of Emirati weddings
 have indicated changes in as little as a few years. Identifying the major changes,
 as well as nuances, in the customary wedding traditions in the UAE across three generations
 have demonstrated the direct impact of modernization and urbanization on the Emirati
 culture.

Title: Mental Health Perceptions Among Emirati Youth
Abstract:
This study compares mental health perceptions of Emirati youth, those who have experienced
 mental illnesses and those who have not, with what they believe are their parents
 perceptions and beliefs on mental health. The aim of this study is to understand the
 stigma associated with mental illness in the UAE using 12 semi-structured interviews,
 with youth ranging from the age of 18-26. The data proves that stigma stems from the
 generational difference between the mentalities of the youth and their parents. The
 first difference is illustrated through their different understanding of the relationship
 between faith and mental illness, and the second difference is demonstrated through
 the legitimacy and illegitimacy of mental illness. The youth exhibited complex relationships
 between faith and mental illness whereas older generations were portrayed to have
 a straightforward understanding, believing that there is a causal relationship between
 faith and mental health. Moreover the youth advocated for the legitimacy of mental
 illness through the use of medical intervention. On the other hand, they believed
 their parents would prefer religious intervention instead of medical intervention
 because they did not believe in the legitimacy of mental illnesses. The youths understanding
 of their parents perceptions on mental illnesses influence their own.

Title: The Case of Emirati Parents: Making Sense of Child Abuse and Children's Rights
Abstract:
This paper is an attempt to unravel how Emirati parents come to understand children's
 rights, specifically child abuse, and how that relates to their practices of parenting
 and discipline. Through semi-structured interviews, this paper taps into the lives
 of Emirati parents, in light of the introduction of Wadeema's Law and its supporting
 policies. To examine the case of Emirati parents, the frameworks of sense making and
 the critiques of human rights are used to analyze parents' responses. Parents take
 part in dynamic negotiations to reconcile ideas of discipline and parenting. They
 attempt to raise confident, well-mannered and socially integrated children, under
 conditions that are more challenging from the ones in which they were raised. Parents
 understand children's rights as merely providing the children with a "good life".
 In an ever-changing society, the parents try to uphold the ways in which parenting
 is done, by solving problems within the family and attempting to maintain the power
 dynamic.

Title: Emirati Youths' Academic Decision-Making
Abstract:
This study explores how Emirati youth make decisions about higher education, what
 are the factors that influence them and what is their decision-making process. This
 study draws from a series of in-depth, semi-structured interviews related to academic
 decisions with Emirati youth from different universities within and outside of the
 UAE. Qualitative analysis sheds light on the complex process of transitioning from
 high-school to university from the perspective of the youth. Given the fact that there
 is no in-depth study of how Emirati youth make decisions regarding higher education
 and the flawed media portrayal of youths' academic trends, my research is crucial
 to filling that gap. This study extends on the findings of developmental studies,
 which critically look at how developmental discourse sometimes overstates the role
 of families in traditional societies and overlooks the agency of the youth. The study
 found that through the narratives of the Emirati youth an accurate portrayal would
 highlight the variation and the various factors; prospective employment, individualistic
 approach, institutional support, patriotic motives, and location of the university,
 that influence the youths' decision-making process in the UAE.

Title: Caregiver Turned Breadwinner: Undermining the Ideal Type of Marriage
Abstract:
There are expectations of the ideal type of relationship in a marriage, where, for
 instance, the husband is the primary breadwinner of the household and the wife is
 the chief caregiver of the family. What happens when the wife's employment upsets
 the "normal" or "traditional" household arrangement? While the UAE can be characterized
 by a traditional gender ideology, it is also a modernizing country and the composition
 of the workforce is changing. Through in-depth interviews of employees at the Abu
 Dhabi Judicial Department, the Abu Dhabi Judicial Academy and the Family Guidance
 Division, I will explore how four factors, collectively, undermine the ideal type
 of marriage within Emirati couples. The aim of this research is not necessarily a
 depiction of how many Emirati divorces fell victim to these factors, but how this
 process works. Knowing this reveals the implications of the traditional and the modernizing
 self living together, displaying the potential issues that could arise when women's
 work becomes an issue in a marriage, how the "traditional" household arrangement still
 stands strong with some Emirati families, and how conclusions of Western literature
 can be generalizable to the Arab-Muslim world, particularly the UAE, filling a potential
 gap in current literature.

Title: Dokha Diffusion Outside the UAE
Abstract:
This capstone focuses on how an alternative tobacco product, 'dokha', spreads beyond
 its regional use in the UAE and into new environments. Through in-depth interviews
 with dokha users in London, I explore the mechanisms by which and the reasons for
 which dokha use in London has recently proliferated. Users are typically exposed to
 dokha through social settings in which a person who has brought dokha from the UAE
 provides the opportunity for a first trial. Afterwards, users continue to smoke dokha
 for a number of reasons, the most compelling of which is the physiological effect,
 or namesake 'buzz', that it provides. I find that while dokha's spread is somewhat
 reminiscent of that of other alternative tobacco products, namely waterpipe or 'shisha',
 several of dokha's characteristics set it apart from other products, and I argue that
 understanding these differences is vital to the development of effective policies
 regarding dokha cessation and prevention.

Title:
It Takes Two (To Make a Thing Go Right): A Study of Factors Influencing Stress and
                                 Self-Efficacy of Teachers Working with Refugees at German Vocational Schools
Abstract:
This capstone provides an in-depth study of stress and self-efficacy of teachers working
 with refugee students at vocational schools in the state of Schleswig-Holstein. As
 the result of large-scale international migration, over 300,000 minor refugees currently
 attend public schools across Germany's 16 federal states. Research has demonstrated
 the benefits of refugees' medium- to long-term integration into the workforce, which
 reduces welfare costs, increases government revenue, and fosters social integration.
 As many refugee students currently lack linguistic and employability skills, vocational
 schools, and teachers face increasing challenges of addressing the unique needs of
 refugee students adequately. Combining field work, interviews, and survey data, I
 analyse the situation of refugees at vocational schools from the perspective of teachers.
 Assessing teacher quality through the concept of teacher self-efficacy, my research
 is guided by the empirical research question "What factors influence teachers' stress,
 motivation, and self-efficacy working with refugees at German vocational school?"
 Findings highlight the impact of motivation on teacher quality, and underscore the
 need for refugee-specific teacher training.

Title:
The Effect of Bilingualism on Socioeconomic Outcomes for Second-Generation Immigrants
                                 in the United States
Abstract:
The United States is home to the greatest diversity of immigrants from both social
 and national origins. The population of interest, second-generation immigrants, consist
 of the most and least educated citizens with the highest and lowest rates of poverty.
 The disparity in wealth reflects the socioeconomic implications of immigration in
 the U.S., especially on the American economy. The second generation is also a linguistically
 rich population, of which most speak a mother-tongue language in addition to having
 native fluency in English. The purpose of the study was to examine whether bilingualism
 of second-generation immigrants has a positive effect on their socioeconomic outcomes.
 The study uses online cross-sectional survey responses from self-identified second-generation
 immigrants in the U.S. (n=3215). The linear regression analysis shows that bilingual
 second-generation immigrants have higher earnings relative to their English monolingual
 counterparts; children of Chinese immigrants outperform their second-generation peers;
 there is no effect of signaling bilingualism in the resume, and all levels of bilingualism
 improve occupational status. Thus, I conclude that investment in bilingualism for
 second-generation immigrants will be beneficial for American economy and society.

Title:
Gender Based Violence in Jordan: Legal and Social Protection for Women Against Sexual
                                 Assault
Abstract:
Jordan successfully revoked Article 308 of its Penal Code, which had previously allowed
 impunity to rapists if they married their victims. The marry-your-rapist-laws are
 manifestations of institutionalized Gender Based Discrimination (GBD), and have contributed
 to systematic marginalization and Gender Based Violence (GBV) and Sexual Violence
 (SV) against women. These laws have historically been controversial, and the revocation
 is seemingly positive. However the social controversy around revocation shows that
 revocation failed to address the social and cultural nuances. Thus, to provide legal
 and social protection for women against Gender Based and Sexual Violence, this capstone
 argues that a sociological understating of these laws and women's experience must
 precede legal change. Thus, this capstone constructs and deploys a sociological framework
 of analysis on qualitative sociological data from a series of interviews conducted
 with stakeholders in Jordan. The paper found that the policy an social environment
 around women's issues are constructed and affected by four factors: Society and Culture,
 Economic History, Political History, and Distinct Contextual Factor, Current Political
 Climate for Jordan. The Capstone concludes with policy recommendations that primarily
 address the enhancement of women's legal and social protection against SV, and on
 a larger extent, end GBD and GBV in Jordan.

Title:
One Thousand Kilometers of Difference: A Set of Recommendations for the Ministry of
                                 Education of Ukraine on Integration of IDP Youth into Lviv, Ukraine
Abstract:
This work explores solidarity, integration, access to education, and language barrier
 for internally displaced (IDP) youth in Lviv, Ukraine. The data collected from a sample
 of 19 local and IDP secondary school and university students through focus groups
 and questionnaires suggests that, while secondary schools and higher academic institutions
 are generally accessible to IDP youth, the availability of financial aid in universities
 remains paramount in allowing them to pursue their academic interests. The process
 of receiving financial aid should be streamlined regardless of whether the university
 reports primarily to the Ministry of Education or the Ministry of Culture. Given that
 IDPs are mainly clustered in schools with Russian language of instruction, further
 social studies should be conducted to assess and conceptualize the presence of segregated
 education in the city. There also is an urgent and continuously growing need for professional
 academic advising and career development services in secondary schools and universities
 in Ukraine that are not provided in reality despite the already existing decrees.
 Furthermore, the urgent need for an intercultural education and cultural engagement
 program in the city's secondary schools and universities is apparent.

Title:
Workers or Citizens: An Analysis of US and Canadian High-Skilled Temporary Migration
                                 Laws and Debates
Abstract:
My capstone project focuses on high-skilled temporary foreign worker programs in the
 U.S. and Canada. I look at reasons behind why these programs were enacted, and what
 they reveal about how each nation thinks about immigration. My overall goal is to
 figure out how each nations' laws are designed to promote their larger migration scheme:
 while the US focuses on family reunification, Canada focuses on high-skilled immigration
 and assimilation. I use textual analysis on the immigration laws, as well as on an
 aggregate level on immigration debates surrounding these laws, to see if the rhetoric
 and reasoning around the laws match how they are eventually set up, and what the debates
 reveal about how and why each nation's laws are set up the way they are.

Title:
A Rubbish Capstone: Improving Residential Recycling at NYU Abu Dhabi through Infrastructure
                                 and Feedback Treatments
Abstract:
This paper examines the effect on quality and quantity of recycled waste after infrastructure
 and feedback treatments. Three first-year student residence buildings were allocated
 to a Control Group (N=155), Group A (N=103), and Group B (N=58). Each building's general
 waste, paper/cardboard recycling, and plastic/can recycling was weighed and rated
 (on quality of separation) each day by the cleaning staff for a 5-week baseline period
 and 5-week post-treatment period. Each apartment within Group A and B received labeled
 paper/cardboard and plastic/can recycling bins [infrastructure alteration] during
 a one-week treatment period. Additionally, Group B received weekly feedback pamphlets
 on their recycling rates, quality, and tips for improvement [feedback treatment] throughout
 the post-treatment measurements. After both treatments, a survey was conducted on
 all groups to measure recycling knowledge, as well as treatment saturation, spillover,
 and student opinions on interventions. Data shows promising evidence that infrastructure
 alteration leads to improved recycling behavior and knowledge, while the feedback
 treatment had marginal to no observed effect on recycling improvement. This paper
 ends with policy recommendations for NYUAD.

Title: I will work where I want: Sex Desegregation in the Tour Guide Industry in Zanzibar
Abstract:
This paper explores the gendered experiences of tour guides in Zanzibar. I specifically
 focus on how gender norms affect both entrance into the profession and how the tour
 guides conduct themselves within the field. The analysis draws on 20 interviews with
 tour guides around Stone Town, Zanzibar. Based on this data, I argue that due to the
 function of tour guiding as a performance of cultural authenticity, female tour guides
 occupy a position of contradiction as both the challenger and performer of authentic
 culture. The paper examines this contradiction by discussing the ways in which tour
 guiding is socially constructed as a male profession. Additionally, it explores the
 barriers that maintain these gender norms and the tools women use to break these barriers
 while maintaining authenticity. I conclude that the women who become tour guides show
 an understanding of both gender norms and market dynamics which they manipulate in
 order to gain entrance into the profession.

Title: The Massachusetts Opioid Epidemic: Course and Coverage
Abstract:
The United States is currently in the grips of the worst drug epidemic the country
 has ever seen, the opioid epidemic, and Massachusetts is one of the states that is
 hardest hit. As of 2016, approximately 5 people died a day from opioid overdose in
 Massachusetts (Bebinger, 2016). Much of the existing literature on the opioid epidemic
 focuses on the link between overprescription of opioid painkillers and addiction which
 eventually leads to overdose and death. Information about what populations are hit
 worse in terms of race, socioeconomic status and lifestyle factors is also increasingly
 documented. This research aims to add to the existing body of literature surrounding
 the opiate epidemic by examining town-level correlates of the opioid epidemic in Massachusetts.
 As town-level correlates are predictive of both the intensity of the epidemic and
 representative of community resources in fighting the epidemic, understanding them
 merits increased attention. Key findings include the correlation between town characteristics
 of low income, low educational attainment, low proportion of white people, and high
 political conservatism with high overdose death rates. The second paper employs text
 analysis to illuminate how the epidemic enters public consciousness, and what community-level
 characteristics shape newspaper coverage.

Title: The Outsiders' Grief: Behind the Radicalization of British Muslims
Abstract:
This project explores narratives of second- to third-generation British Muslims who
 are often discriminated for their identity and the reason why the discrimination is
 experienced by many yet only enhances extremist ideology among a minority. The narratives
 of de- radicalized and non-radicalized interviewees are compared in order to examine
 the role of multiple outlets utilized by non-radicalized interviewees to evade extremist
 ideology. The interviews reveal that the availability of outlets to nurture multiple
 components of one's identity is effective in preventing discriminated individuals
 from joining extremist groups - a notion that policy discourses often misses. On the
 other hand, those who identify strongly with only a single component of their identity
 tend to act violently when it is 'under attack'. With the findings from 52 hours of
 interview, this study aims to augment existing studies on identity and counterterrorism,
 as well as to suggest new directions for related research.

Title: The Case of Internet Research Agency Twitter Propaganda in the 2016 U
Abstract:
The purpose of this study is to shed light on the features of tweets that drove Americans
 to engage with propaganda disseminated by the Russian Internet Research Agency (IRA)
 on Twitter around the time of the 2016 U.S. Presidential election and to understand
 the differences between the content of originally authored versus retweeted IRA propaganda
 tweets. This study defines engagement in terms of the number of retweets and likes
 that tweets receive. Using comparisons of specific tweet features such as URLs, hashtags,
 tweet length, sentiment, and language, this study finds that while there are subtle
 but not substantively significant differences in engagement for some features, overall
 engagement with the tweets in the dataset is low and more evidence is needed to understand
 tweet features as drivers of engagement. Following that, this study categorizes the
 corpus of tweets into frequently occurring topics using structural topic modeling
 and conducts a regression analysis to predict the probability of particular topics
 being retweeted or originally authored.

Title:
Deconstructing the Social Construct of Reputation (A Case Study of Emirati Women in
                                 Abu Dhabi)
Abstract:
The research focuses on the shift in the mentality of Emiratis regarding 'reputation'
 through the conduction of twenty-four in-depth interviews with Emirati women in Abu
 Dhabi. The women who participated in the research varied in age, ranging from elderlies
 (over the age of sixty) to youth (twenty-year-olds), demonstrating the change in perceptions
 over the span of generations. The topics that will be discussed are kinship as related
 to lineage and family name, social interactions involving gatherings and social media,
 systems of beliefs such as religion and tradition, and generational differences in
 mentalities. The rapid transformation that the country underwent including the contact
 with people from diverse backgrounds since the 1960s led to a shift in the mentalities
 of the Emirati people. All of which affected the criteria on which women in society
 based their conceptualization of one another's reputation as well as their own. Ultimately,
 this paper aims to address the shortcomings in the existing field of research by deconstructing
 the concept of 'reputation' in Emirati society.

Title:
The Effect of Stressors on the Mental Health of Displaced and Non-Displaced Children
                                 and Adolescents in Niger
Abstract:
Reflected in the student demographic, the West-African landlocked nation hosts a growing
 forcibly displaced community composed of refugees, returnees, and IDPs residing alongside
 civilians. Identifying the effect of stress-inducing factors or "stressors" on displaced
 children and adolescents in relation to their non-displaced peers can shed light on
 how Niger can strategically address mental health symptoms in a geopolitically sensitive
 region. This study analyses the baseline results of a Global TIES for Children dataset
 collected in the 2016-2017 academic year on 1,876 students dispersed across thirty
 "Education in Emergency: Evidence for Action"schools located in the Maine-Soroa and
 Diffa regions. Specifically, the study examines the effects of five stressors –hunger,
 community safety, age appropriateness, future mobility, and French literacy– on student
 mental health operationalized through the following instruments: the Strengths and
 Difficulties Questionnaire, the Response to Stress Questionnaire-Stress Levels, the
 Response to Stress Questionnaire-Involuntary Engagement, and the Preschool Self-Regulation
 Assessment. The main findings of this study suggest that community safety and French
 literacy significantly affect the mental health of displaced and non-displaced children
 and adolescents, implying that displaced students do not differ from their non-displaced
 counterparts. These results contribute to expanding the frontiers of literature on
 mental health stressors and displaced youth in the Global South.

Title: Perspectives on Marriage and Gender Roles Through the Lens of Youth from Abu Dhabi
Abstract:
This research project examines youths' perceptions on marriage and marriage roles.
 Moreover, it addresses how young men and women in Abu Dhabi negotiate their views
 on marriage in relation to the state's rhetoric. Drawing from in-depth interviews
 as well as field work, I address the following questions: How do youth who are at
 the conjunction of this social, cultural and economic turmoil understand social conceptions
 of marriage and gender roles? How does the government, through cultivation programs
 and institutions, depict the modern Emirati Family? To what extent does this image
 of a Modern Emirati Family overlap with youths' perceptions and expectations of marriage?
 How do youth describe marriage and what aspects of marriage are they preoccupied with?

Title: Promoting Healthy Living: A Case Study of International Schools in Abu Dhabi
Abstract:
This paper explores how schools in Abu Dhabi implement health policies in order to
 create a health-promoting school environment for students. While the current literature
 consists of studies highlighting the different approaches schools take to address
 unhealthy behaviors and the role of parents in said behaviors, I investigate the barriers
 that limit health policy implementation in international schools. Through semi-structured
 interviews with school administrators and managers of catering companies, I discover
 that conflict between parents and school administration is prevalent and largely based
 on the socioeconomic status of parents and the school.

Title: Don't Burnout: The role of the Arab Family in Teacher's Mental Health in Lebanon
Abstract:
This paper seeks to investigate the role of the Arab family in moderating the relationship
 between the mental health and burnout rates of teachers in Lebanon. This study aimed
 to understand what factors in the Middle Eastern context, an understudied region in
 teacher burnout literature, are having an impact on this relationship. The research
 found that teachers with family sizes larger than five persons, and specifically females
 with these larger family sizes, had a stronger relationship between their mental health
 and burnout levels. Single teachers were also found to have a stronger relationship
 between their mental health and burnout rates. These results suggest that more resources
 and programming should be targeted at supporting teachers with larger families, and
 in particular single teachers and women, in order to help them manage their mental
 health and burnout levels.

Title: Religious Affiliation as a Predictor of Student Academic Outcomes in Sierra Leone
Abstract:
The study seeks to evaluate how religion and gender, in combination, can be significantly
 indicative to academic achievement. Using data from Global TIES for Children's 3EA
 project, "Education in Emergencies: Evidence for Action (3EA)", the study investigates
 the relationship between religion and academic outcomes of primary school students
 in Sierra Leone. Secondary data analysis shows a very low significant correlation
 between being Muslim and one's academic achievement and finds no correlation between
 child annual percent attendance and being Muslim. However, the joint role of religion
 and gender with regard to student outcomes proves to be significant when looking at
 the comparative beta values among the religion-gender groups in the regression analysis.
 I find that being both female and Muslim yields higher academic achievement than any
 other group in the study. The study also finds a significant positive association
 between student attendance and academic outcomes but does not succeed in manifesting
 a mediating effect of attendance. Overall, this study aims to highlight the importance
 of understanding and evaluating the factors that influence schooling outcomes in conflict-affected
 and low-income countries like Sierra Leone.

Title: The Young Expat: The Development of Expatriate Adolescence in the UAE
Abstract:
The stories of young expatriates, those who emigrate with their families to the U.A.E.
 is a complex one. However, these narratives are often assumed or set-aside. This qualitative
 research project hopes to provide integral insight by understanding the nuances in
 the individual stories of young foreign nationals living in the U.A.E. The paper investigates
 and explores whether, how, and to what extent the intersection of an expatriate way
 of living – contained within expectations about what it means to a 'good' expat –
 conflicts with a restrictive nature of adolescent development. The social phenomenon
 is called Expatriate Adolescence. The process involves foreign teenagers toiling with
 the central question of how they come to navigate their new home in Abu Dhabi - be
 it social, familial or cultural, what unique challenges does this populace encounter?
 Given the changing ethnoscape of this country, there is much variance in the degree
 to which the young expatriates experience a 'curated' adolescent life in the U.A.E.
 Hence, the studying of this population is vital in filling a lacuna in the scholarship
 on Gulf migration, as well as in adolescent development theory.

Title: Female Migration, Adaptation, and Child Health in Urban India: Evidence from NFHS-3
Abstract:
The purpose of this paper is to analyze the effect of female rural-urban migration
 on child health outcomes in urban India, within the framework of the disruption and
 adaptation theory of migration. Drawing on data from the third wave of the National
 Family and Health Survey, I compare socioeconomic factors and child health outcomes
 among rural-urban migrants, urban non-migrants, and rural non-migrants. I find no
 direct support for the hypothesis that children of rural-urban migrants are worse
 off in terms of health. Instead, my findings suggest that small differences in child
 health are explained by observed differences in wealth and education among urban residents.
 Additionally, contrary to the belief that migrants eventually adapt to their new environment,
 I find that outcomes and socioeconomic factors do not improve over time among rural-urban
 migrants. This paper deepens the understanding of urban child health and suggests
 that future research and policies should address the urban poor and uneducated.

Title:
Islamic Education in the UAE: Promoting National Security, Refuting Islamists, and
                                 Nation Branding
Abstract:
In recent years the content and character of state-sponsored religious education in
 the Middle East have been the subject of an intense debate. Upon analyzing the Islamic
 Education textbooks taught to all Muslim students in every school across the UAE,
 I make three arguments pertaining to the role of Islamic education in the UAE. First,
 the UAE's Islamic Education curriculum works to legitimize the state and promote national
 security by inculcating in students a sense of loyalty to the nation and obedience
 to its ruler. Second, that the curriculum works to present an image, directed at local
 and international audiences, of religious moderation and tolerance. Third, that the
 curriculum works to support government objectives of economic growth by presenting
 the ideal Muslim as one who is hard-working and productive. I situate the UAE's Islamic
 Education curriculum and textbooks within broader, long-standing state efforts to
 cultivate a loyal citizenry devoted to state agendas related to political stability,
 modernization, and economic growth, refuting Islamists narratives, and being recognized
 by the West as a natural partner in the fight to eradicate religious extremism and
 promote tolerance in the region.

Title:
"It is like my life has become an answer [to these questions]…": Understanding the
                                 Accounts of Acid Violence Victims in Pakistan
Abstract:
Stigma is a global problem, but in Pakistan, the problem of a double-stigma is salient.
 The victims of acid violence, in addition to the stigma associated with irrevocable
 physical disfigurement, also suffer the allegation of an immoral character, causing
 inflated psychological and social difficulties. Accounts allow stigmatized individuals
 to participate in strategies that enable their empowerment and inclusion in society.
 Drawing on a series of interviews with female victims of acid violence in Pakistan,
 this paper explores the discursive strategies employed by the victims across different
 situations.The findings suggest several patterns: providing unfiltered accounts, denying
 identity of a victim of violence, using socially acceptable language, embracing an
 identity of a professional, negotiating an increased social status, and shifting identities
 from that of a victim, to a survivor and a savior of other victims.

Title: Women and Pakistani Sharia: A Case Study of Khula Laws
Abstract:
How is Sharia contextualized when granting rights to women in the post-colonial context?
 How is it used by courts in South Asia in terms of divorce? This paper looks at khula
 case law from the Lahore High Court in Pakistan and the Punjab and Haryana High Court
 in India to examine the role that Sharia plays in the decision-making process of the
 courts. My analysis examines eighteen cases from the Lahore High Court and five from
 the Punjab and Haryana Court in detail. I argue that in both India and Pakistan, Sharia
 and Islam are being utilized to create rights for women in the realm of divorce, where
 they don't exist through non-Islamic means. I also argue that in the Lahore High Court,
 the court uses language that is filled with Islamic symbolism to grant legitimacy
 to its decisions that are favorable to women. However, this symbolism is not found
 at the Punjab and Haryana High Court. To make sense of this variation, I argue, Shariah
 is used as a reliable device in both Islamic and non-Islamic contexts to achieve similar
 results, albeit with varying motivations.

Title: The Use of Pseudonym, Team Composition and Identity in Cryptocurrency
Abstract:
Satoshi Nakamoto is known as the founder of Bitcoin and the pioneer of cryptocurrency.
 Yet, until this day, no one knows who Satoshi Nakamoto is or whom the name represents.
 Because of him, the usage of pseudonyms among members of cryptocurrency companies
 has gained popularity. This paper will explore how team composition and identity affects
 the usage of pseudonyms among the cryptocurrency company members. Team composition
 and identity will be broken down to three components of publicity, technical roles,
 and gender of the cryptocurrency company members. By investigating the relationship
 between team composition and identity and the usage of pseudonyms, the study will
 demonstrate how pseudonyms can be used not only to hide one's identity, but also to
 augment one's identity.

Title: Pre-exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP): a Miracle Drug or a Moral Hazard?
Abstract:
Little is known about the way in which taking pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) affects
 sexual behavior and sexual health outcomes of men-who-have-sex-with-men (MSM). I examine
 these outcomes by using Facebook, Grindr and the Gay Ad Network as recruitment sites,
 linking ads to a questionnaire which 1823 US-based MSM completed. Using a series of
 one-sided t-tests, I find that MSM who are on PrEP have significantly more sexual
 partners, are more likely to be involved in concurrent relationships, use condoms
 less frequently and report higher incidences of bacterial STDs than MSM who are not
 on PrEP. I then use propensity score matching to control for a set of demographic
 and behavioral characteristics associated with PrEP use to estimate the effect of
 taking PrEP on the above-mentioned outcomes. I again find statistically significant
 results for all outcomes. Lastly, I employ a conjoint experiment to compare how MSM
 who are on PrEP compare to those who are not on PrEP make partner-selection decisions.
 I find that MSM on PrEP do not take the number of their partner's previous sexual
 relationships nor their condom use into account to make this decision, while those
 who are not on PrEP do.

Title: Networks of Influence: Think Tank Behavior, Relationships and Bias in Washington DC
Abstract:
The current debates around the use of money in politics and the amount of foreign
 influence in Washington DC have brought the unique role of think tanks under increased
 scrutiny due to their potential to channel both effects. While think tanks, in theory,
 are supposed to produce unbiased policy analysis and help promote informed debate--criticism
 of think tanks often alleges that they are far from unbiased. While such literature
 has attempted to delineate this problem, most of the research has focused on external
 analysis of think tanks as part of the larger policymaking system. Leveraging ethnographic
 research conducted within the think tank community itself rather than externally,
 my analysis questions the consensus view that think tank behavior is largely driven
 by seeking policy impact; instead finding that think tank behavior is conducted according
 to internal and external relationships. With a greater understanding of think tank
 behavior, I seek to better understand the origin of bias and how it materializes in
 think tanks' most visible output - external research.

Title: Change in Peacebuilding Diplomacy: A Case Study of Finland
Abstract:
In 2008, Finland created a National Action Plan for the implementation of the United
 Nations Security Council resolution on Women, Peace and Security that was unanimously
 adopted in October 2000. The resolution was significant as it was the first of its
 kind to specifically address women's role in conflict and peacebuilding. Though Finland
 has been on the forefront of the peacebuilding scene for years, the country shaped
 its action plan for the resolution a few years later than many other states. This
 research project looks deeper into this foreign policy change and endeavours to answer
 the following question: why did Finland adopt its National Action Plan for the United
 Nations Security Council Resolution on Women, Peace and Security in 2008? By looking
 into policy documents and speeches, as well as drawing from public debate and previous
 literature on foreign policy change and policy diffusion, I find that the Finnish
 case warrants a multi-layered explanation: using the policy diffusion mechanisms of
 learning, competition, coercion and emulation, the drive for Finnish foreign policy
 change has taken place on three distinct levels (international, regional, and civil
 society), where the three levels mutually created the condition for change.

Title: Religion, State, and Nation: Claims to Citizenship Among Pakistan's Ahmadiyya Community
Abstract:
This research focuses on Pakistan's Ahmadiyya community, who self-identity as Muslims
 but the state recognises them as a non-Muslim minority, to demonstrate how the state
 narratives about inclusion in Pakistan have been used to exclude and reduce this community
 to the status of second-class citizens. Most of the existing literature has focused
 on how the Pakistani nation- state has constructed its imagined community based on
 exclusionary citizenship, but little is said about the grievances that the marginalised
 have from the state and what it can teach us about national citizenship. Given the
 exclusion of Ahmadis from Pakistan's national discourse, I have conducted twelve semi-structured
