 interviews with community members and conducted an analysis of op-ed articles in an
 alternative media publication to understand counter-narratives of Ahmadis in relation
 to the dominant narratives of state. This research focuses on counter-narratives of
 Ahmadis about Pakistani identity in order to broaden our understanding of identity
 through a focus on the excluded citizen rather than the State. The research sheds
 light on what national identity looks like when viewed through the lens of exclusion.

Title:
Neither Here nor There: Non-political transnationalism amongst Bosnian refugee families
                                 and the blurring of migrant taxonomies
Abstract:
Third-country resettlement is one of the UN's three "durable solutions" made available
 to refugees worldwide. While millions have benefitted from such programmes, there
 remains a gap in knowledge concerning the long-term effects of resettlement on the
 experiences of refugees. At the same time, migration studies literature has established
 a dichotomy between voluntary and involuntary migrants. Here, a tendency is shown
 which views connections to people in places in the country of origin as distinctly
 political in form and motivation. This essay takes a transnationalist approach to
 studying the experiences of Bosnian refugee families resettled to Boise, Idaho, USA
 during and immediately after the Bosnian War (1992-1995). Focusing on transnational
 practices developed by refugees over two decades in the United States, my analysis
 questions the prevailing image of refugees as inherently political transnational actors.
 This study investigates non-political forms of refugee transnationalism by examining
 patterns of ownership and flows of goods, funds, and people between Boise and Bosnia.
 In doing so, I seek to blur the lines between traditional migrant taxonomies and contribute
 to a more holistic understanding of the refugee as an informed and empowered international
 actor.

Title: Navigating Entrepreneurship: The Role of Law in Organizational Emergence in the UAE
Abstract:
This project observes the law and policy that govern entrepreneurship in the UAE,
 comparing it, empirically, to the lived experiences of entrepreneurs on the ground.
 I observe entrepreneurship as a novel work environment that offers starkly different
 experiences for UAE nationals and residents alike. The distinction, primarily, manifests
 in the levels of ease of organizational emergence for both groups. I suggest that
 the UAE offers a quasi-experimental insight into the two different pools of entrepreneurs
 that result by having a 'high' or 'low' bar—the former for residents and the latter
 for nationals. In comparing the experiences of entrepreneurs emerging across these
 two pools, this capstone asks whether a more 'helpful' legal and institutional environment
 increases the success the rates of entrepreneurial ventures. Based on its finding
 that the increased ease of starting up is not necessarily an advantage, this study
 complicates the theoretical assumption that low barriers to starting up are necessarily
 always preferred because they lead to a higher aggregate entrepreneurial activity.

Title:
The Power of Ethnic Politics in Foreign Policy Making Decisions: A Comparison of Malaysia's
                                 Mahathir and the Philippines' Duterte in the Belt Road Initiative
Abstract:
Malaysia's rejection of China's Belt Road Initiative came as a shock to the international
 community. In order to understand the driving forces behind this rejection, this research
 created a structured approach to examine plausible factors that could lead to this
 policy decision, including the economic, geopolitics and domestic factors. Upon examining
 these factors in comparison to the Philippines, which accepted the Belt Road investments,
 I conclude that domestic ethnic politics act as a catalyst to Prime Minister Mahathir's
 decision.

Title:
Post Generation: Social Media Use of WeChat and Facebook by Chinese and American College
                                 Students
Abstract:
This project is a comparative study of contemporary social media usage of both Chinese
 and American social media sites by Chinese and American NYUSH freshmen conducted through
 mixed methods of social media content analysis and interviews. Ultimately, this paper
 seeks to better understand the extent to which technological features, cultural backgrounds,
 and pre-existing and new networks influence social interactions online.

Title: Fostering refugee-inclusion: the role of self-affirmation and perspective-taking
Abstract:
This research has tested the role of self-affirmation and perspective-taking tasks
 in fostering inclusive intergroup behavior and motivating the respondents to provide
 help and assistance to Syrian refugees. The experiment was conducted with a sample
 of working age and retired Canadians, outside the laboratory. During the experiment
 the participants have completed either self-affirmation task, perspective-taking task,
 combination of both tasks, or participated in a control condition before answering
 the measures of attitudes and perceived threat towards Syrian refugees and participating
 in the behavioral task measuring the respondents' readiness to support this outgroup.
 Results show that self-affirmation and combined intervention were effective in fostering
 inclusive behavior towards the outgroup. This study has also found that the middle
 aged respondents had less malleable views, and were less likely to be motivated to
 change their behavior by a one-time intervention. The participants between 35-54 years
 of age were more likely to hold strong unfavorable views of Syrian refugees due to
 the perceived competition over finite resources and welfare benefits in Canada. This
 paper also draws further implications for the researchers and policymakers.

Title:
Bodies in Difference: 'Determination' in the Lived Experience of Disabilities in the
                                 UAE
Abstract:
In the past decade, disabilities have gained unprecedented visibility in public discourse,
 popular media, and government action in the UAE. Following international events like
 Special Olympics World Games and the UAE's very own Year of Tolerance in 2019, an
 inquiry is necessitated into the implications of this new-found visibility and translation
 of federal and societal efforts into the day-to-day experiences of people of determination.
 Through qualitative data collection involving in-depth interviews, focus groups, participant
 observation, and document analysis, this ethnographic field research explores the
 lived experiences of disabilities in the UAE through analysing disability discourse
 among the groups of able-bodied and differently-abled individuals dubbed 'disability
 representatives', given their intimate understanding of the disability experience.
 The research explores perceptions in favor of and against the label 'people of determination'
 in understanding the role played by language in creating and maintaining stigmatised
 disability identities and overall lived experience of disabilities in the country.
 'Determination' moves beyond existing as a mere characteristic and becomes associated
 with empowerment, heroism, harm, and modernism - all the while as a label, it becomes
 an active linguistic and social force shaping disability perceptions and experiences.

Title:
Bringing the Valley to the Desert: Comparing the Experiences of Emirati Tech and Non-tech
                                 entrepreneurs
Abstract:
The UAE has heavily advocated for the pursuit of entrepreneurship amongst its young
 population over the past decade, creating institutions such as the Khalifa Fund for
 Enterprise Development, as a way to drive this mission forward. Even more recently,
 the UAE has begun to shift all modes of life, from business payments to government
 services, into a digitized sphere. The push of both entrepreneurship and further digitization
 within the UAE has in effect created bustling tech and entrepreneurial ecosystems,
 which often overlap. In this study, I analyze the interactions between the non-tech,
 or SME entrepreneurship ecosystem and the newer and more popular tech entrepreneurship
 ecosystem, using the experiences of tech and non-tech entrepreneurs as a mechanism
 through which the interactions between these two ecosystems; one that is becoming
 ideologically outdated and one that is possibly overrated, in an effort to understand
 the overall entrepreneurial ecosystem of the UAE and its actors and situate this progress
 within the fields of critical development theory and critical entrepreneurship studies.

Title: The Impact of National Service on the Higher Educational Attainment of Emirati Males
Abstract:
In 2014, H.H Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed issued UAE Federal Law No.6, mandating all Emirati
 males of ages 18-30 to enlist in the military. This study explores the effect of UAE
 National Service on the higher educational attainment of Emirati males. Using an online
 survey taken by 440 participants to conduct quantitative analysis, a series of informal
 interviews are drawn to explain the findings. Educational outcomes of high school
 cohorts prior to the implementation of the UAE National Service law, 2013 and earlier,
 and after the implementation of the law, 2014 and later, are compared using logistic
 regression models and other methods of statistical analyses. Drawing from a series
 of qualitative responses, the national service can either encourage higher education
 or act as a displaced time gap between high school education and higher education.
 By examining the highest degrees obtained and their intentions of pursuing a higher
 educational degree in the next five years, cohorts of 2014 and later are less likely
 to pursue a higher educational degree. Policy recommendations are suggested to bridge
 the gaps between high school education, national service, and higher education.

Title:
Is there a Substitution Effect? The Relationship between Formal and Informal Childcare
                                 on Children in Jordan
Abstract:
This paper seeks to investigate the role of cultural capital on moderating whether
 mothers consider formal childcare (kindergarten enrollment) a substitute to informal
 (mothers' involvement) with children in Jordan. This study also aims to investigate
 the effect of the two forms of childcare on the academic attainment of children. The
 research found that although kindergarten enrollment is not considered a substitute
 for mothers' involvement, children enrolled in kindergarten have higher chances of
 being exposed to informal childcare, compared to children who are not enrolled. Results
 also show that both forms of childcare have positive effects on the academic attainment
 of children. Lastly, the more the cultural capital of parents, the stronger the relationship
 is between formal childcare and attainment. These findings suggest that the goal of
 universalization should be carefully applied by the government to take into account
 the inequalities that could arise between the different groups of children.

Title:
The social forces that help or hinder an individual's professionalisation process
                                 in amateur sports: An Ethnography on Brazilian Jiu Jitsu in the UAE
Abstract:
In this paper, the author examines the benefit of sponsorships and endorsements for
 amateur athletes, within the context of the UAE. Through participant observation methodology
 and informal interviews with members of an Emirati Jiu-Jitsu team in downtown Abu
 Dhabi, this paper analyses the social forces which help or hinder the professionalization
 process in amateur sports. The current literature on amateur sports in MENA and the
 Gulf region tends to focus on women's rights and sports participation rather than
 the professionalization process. This paper aims to offer a more nuanced understanding
 of how sponsorships and endorsements are an intrinsic part of the professionalization
 process. This research study also includes the social factors which limit an individual's
 ability to fully capitalize on these sponsorships and endorsements.

Title: The Congregation Family: Youth Integration into the Croatian Catholic Church
Abstract:
This research is an empirical exploration through in-depth semi-structured interviews
 of how the Catholic Church integrates Croatian youth, between ages 18 through 30,
 into the religious community and what the political implications of such integration
 are for the Croatian society and politics. I analyze the way the youth are introduced
 to the congregation community and the oratory, followed by a three-part integration
 process that consists of active, spiritual, and moral commitment. The commitment is
 established through different activities and education that are easily relatable to
 the youth as they mirror the mainstream youth culture. By evoking commitment to the
 community and the sacred, the congregation connects private and public morality, thus
 incentivizing the youth to defend the Catholic faith in political actions, showing
 that there are possible political implications of youth integration into seemingly
 nonpolitical institutions.

Title:
From All Angles: The Multilayered Effects of Gender and Inequality of Earnings on
                                 Fairness of Earnings and Attitudes toward Negotiation
Abstract:
This study investigates gender effects on perceptions of fairness of earnings and
 attitudes toward negotiation. It entailed 707 U.S. adults evaluating 10 vignettes
 containing information about an employee (i.e., ego) and their coworker (i.e., alter).
 Respondents were asked to assess the fairness of ego's earnings and judge whether
 ego should negotiate for a higher salary. When information about the inequality of
 earnings (i.e., alter earning 30 percent more than ego) was provided, respondents
 rated ego's earnings as unfairly low and indicated support for ego's negotiation for
 a higher salary. Interestingly, under those same conditions, when alter's earnings
 were 30 percent higher than the earnings of a female ego, female respondents rated
 the earnings of a female ego as unfairly low (i.e., female egos should get paid more)
 and deemed that the female ego should negotiate for a higher salary (this effect was
 reversed for male respondents). Overall, I find that the effects of gender on perceptions
 of fairness of earnings and attitudes toward negotiation are highly situational and
 circumstantial.

Title:
Foreign Education, Foreign Jobs, Foreign Passports: Strategies to Mitigate Intergenerational
                                 Consequences of Migration for Adult Children of Syrian Migrants to the UAE
Abstract:
Over the past decades, the Arab Gulf has seen among the largest inflows of economic
 migrants globally, while Syria has produced one of the largest global outflows. Countries
 in the MENA region are unique in their approach to migration. Unlike those traditionally
 studied in the literature, they do not provide permanent residency or citizenship
 options to legal immigrants or their descendants. As such, the adult children of immigrants
 experience a process of 'aging out' of their legal status. This paper attempts to
 understand how the second-generation of Syrian immigrants to the UAE navigates this
 loss of status and subsequent legal precarity. Through interviews conducted with second-generation
 Syrian immigrants who underwent this process in the aftermath of the 2011 conflict,
 I broadly explore the question of how second-generation migrants negotiate legal precarity
 in their receiving countries. I find that in addition to utilizing strategies such
 as educational and professional attainment commonly discussed in the literature, these
 individuals strategize around obtaining legal documents in third countries. Their
 approach thus brings into question the significance of passports, residency, and citizenship
 - no longer merely markers of location or lineage, but as tools for upward mobility.

Title:
Contributing Factors to and Perceptions and Attitudes on Female Labor Force Participation
                                 in Jordan
Abstract:
Jordan is considered among the countries with the lowest female labor market participation
 rate in the world, amounting to around 14%. This statement raises questions regarding
 the current situation; essentially, the questions all fall under what contributes
 to the extremely low rate. This ties to how the problem is perceived - is it recognized,
 and if yes, how grave people feel the problem may be? The proposed study examines
 these questions through an online survey in which 748 Jordanians participated. Throughout
 this study, I will be taking a "micro lens", i.e., investigate the drivers that affect
 labor force participation as well as people's perceptions regarding gender equality
 in the workforce and the Jordanian society.

Title:
Perspectives on Minority Language Issues and Education Policy: A Comparative Analysis
                                 of Ireland and Israel
Abstract:
Language has been described as the "cultural glue that binds communities together"
 (Riehl, 2019). Language keeps social practices and cultures alive; therefore, loss
 of language would cause loss of community heritage and identity. Its preservation
 matters on multiple levels- not only for those who speak it, but for all of us. Language
 also helps us gain deeper insight into social cohesion, cultural reproduction, and
 human relations and negotiations in times of conflict and peace. A deeper understanding
 of linguistic diversity and the richness of associated cultures and traditions is
 of benefit to the global community.This capstone project focuses on the historical
 role and current status of two languages in two contexts: Irish in Ireland and Arabic
 in Israel. I chose to position these two languages at the heart of a comparative study
 because both Irish and Arabic are considered minority languages as well as 'heritage
 languages' within their respective national contexts, and both languages are often
 subordinate to the use of other dominant languages within those contexts.

Title:
Sustaining a Community in a Transient Setting: An Ethnographic Study on Abu Dhabi
                                 Singers
Abstract:
Abu Dhabi has been described by several scholars as a place of temporariness with
 highly transient expatriate residents. Despite the city's transient nature, however,
 Abu Dhabi Singers (ADS), a community choir and musical theater group, has survived
 for 43 years. This group has succeeded in cultivating a deep sense of community for
 its members despite a member retention rate of less than 30%. Given this unique situation,
 what is the mechanism that enables groups such as ADS to survive transience and maintain
 a community when its members do not envision a long-term stay in the UAE? Through
 a year-long ethnography and interviews, this study shows that ADS developed a porous
 community-an inclusive community that endures constant membership changes-by deliberately
 blurring the precise boundary of membership and facilitating the integration of new
 members through socialization activities. This ethnographic case robustly illustrates
 how member retention strategy and commitment mechanisms play out in the transient
 environment, expanding the organizational sociology literature. This case also contributes
 to Gulf studies, adding complexity to its existing expatriate experience narrative
 by examining how expatriates cultivate a sense of belonging in Abu Dhabi.

Title:
Strong today, Stronger tomorrow, Strongest together: Local NGOs as key facilitators
                                 in the integration of displaced Syrians in Lebanon
Abstract:
In 2011, Lebanon opened its borders to those fleeing the Syrian civil war. However,
 once the number of Syrians surpassed the one million mark, the Lebanese government
 resorted to implementing the December 2014 policy to reduce the number of Syrians
 by increasing requirements to acquire legal status. Consequently, as of 2019, an estimated
 74% of them lost their legal status. This paper examines the effects of this policy
 and seeks to answer the following questions - How is the integration of displaced
 Syrians in Lebanon affected when they are stripped of their legal status? What kind
 of NGO assistance is provided to displaced Syrians in Lebanon to facilitate their
 integration in a context without legal protection? Data for this study was collected
 through 25 in-depth interviews with NGO workers and Syrian refugees currently residing
 in Lebanon. This study reveals that while the legal system functions in a way that
 does not favor the integration of displaced Syrians, the improvisation of actors from
 the host community have made it temporarily possible for Syrians to integrate in Lebanon.
 This paper is timely as it concludes with recommendations for the new government formed
 in January 2020.

Title:
Visitors' Experience and Perception in the Louvre Abu Dhabi: A Multi-layered and Unique
                                 Experience in a Modern Museum
Abstract:
The United Arab Emirates, striving to develop a modern and progressive image and to
 redefine the Arab identity, introduced a number of cultural projects in order to establish
 the brand. The Louvre Abu Dhabi, commenced in 2007 and opened in 2018, is one of the
 projects as a result of the collaborative partnership between France and the UAE.
 Even though there is abundant theoretical research on its global diplomatic ambitions,
 economic benefits, and national aspiration for a new identity, very few studies have
 focused on visitors' study. To fill the gap, this article investigated the visitors'
 experience in the Louvre Abu Dhabi and their perception of the distinct museological
 approach that reflects the museum's specific missions and visions. Ethnographic field
 research has been conducted in the permanent gallery, which is composed of observations
 of visitors' behaviors and 40 interviews. The article identifies the overall architecture,
 internal organization and ambiance, and museum narrative as the three most significant
 dimensions that influence visitors' experience. The article concludes that a fulfilling
 visit in the Louvre Abu Dhabi is created by the multi-layered experience and attributes
 to positive perception about the museum distinguished by its modernity and uniqueness.

Title:
A Garden of Readers: How a Mobile Library in Rural Mexico is Cultivating Future Learners
                                 and Lovers of Knowledge
Abstract:
This ethnography tells the story of NDÖNÍ, a mobile library that fosters love for
 reading while traversing urban and rural areas in Mexico. It is a project that tackles
 two of the most pressing issues in the Mexican education system which are accessibility
 and quality. Rooting its pedagogy in literacy experiences, such as storytelling, craft
 making and book exploration, NDÖNÍ is promoting love for learning, a fundamental characteristic
 for long lasting human development. This study highlights how NDÖNÍ is helping children
 to flourish through two specific approaches: first, by creating spaces for the users
 to exercise their agency and the second, by providing opportunities for children to
 develop expressivity. By grounding learning experiences in the immediate social surroundings
 and cultural context, this library is adapting its educational activities to the needs
 of the communities it visits. Its aim is to see children and culture flourish in Tequisquiapan.
 This ethnography presents an account of children whose love for learning has already
 germinated. It also poses questions for the future, specifically, how NDÖNÍ is going
 to foster love for learning in broader communities through collaborations with schools
 and families.

Title:
Love from a Distance: Reconfiguring Motherhood in the case of Filipina Migrants in
                                 the United Arab Emirates (UAE)
Abstract:
With the rise of female migration, academic research has concentrated on migrant mothers
 and their motherhood experiences in the transnational context. However, little attention
 has been paid to how migrant mothers carry out different strategies to meet their
 maternal responsibilities while being abroad. In particular, the influence of gender
 roles and local network support on their mothering strategies has been given scant
 attention in transnational motherhood literature. By applying the concept of "kin
 work" and "gender ideologies" by Di Leonardo and Arlie Hochschild respectively, this
 paper seeks to understand how migrant mothers reconstruct the concept of motherhood
 post-migration. Drawing on 15 semi-structured interviews with Filipina migrant workers
 in the United Arab Emirates, my research has shown that migrant mothers interweave
 breadwinning with motherhood by practicing a transitional marriage model. They also
 perform kin work as a way to maintain kinship ties with different individuals such
 as family members, friends and neighbors and lean on them for practical support to
 ensure their children receive caregiving. This research has contributed to a better
 understanding of how transnational mothers form new meanings of motherhood to accommodate
 temporal and spatial separation from their children and family.

Title:
Integration Amidst Crisis: Exploring the Social Integration of Students in a Greek
                                 Neighborhood
Abstract:
In the last decade, Athens, Greece has experienced a near collapse of their economy
 and an unexpectedly high volume of refugees entering the country. This study explores
 the conditions which promote or hinder students' social integration, a key factor
 in students' well-being. Many adolescents in Athens are in a critical stage for long
 term development and must cope with multiple levels of vulnerability including financial
 instability, migrant backgrounds and previous trauma. The focus neighborhood, Kypseli,
 is a diverse community of students who are Greek, second generation migrants and refugees.
 This study takes a mixed-methods approach using both qualitative interviews with parents,
 teachers and NGO employees and quantitative surveys with students. The findings reveal
 that students' language barrier, intent to stay in Greece and friendship with an ingroup
 member are conditions that promote social integration; however, refugees have significantly
 lower measures on all of these variables. It is recommended that policies take into
 account the refugee students' perception of Greece as a temporary space; their challenge
 due to the language barrier; and conditions which would enable refugee students to
 develop intergroup friendships in an effort to integrate with the community.

Title:
Is Education Her Salvation? Motivations Amongst Swahili Girls in Kenya in Attaining
                                 Secondary Education
Abstract:
Given the high dropout rates amongst Swahili women in Kenya, I examine the motivations
 of those who persist in completing their secondary education. Through semi-structured
 interviews, I analyse the divergence in narratives between students that choose to
 attain education and those that drop out. I investigate the challenges behind the
 attainment of education, specifically, cultural barriers such as early marriage. Findings
 indicate that while girls who complete education are goal-oriented, the community,
 particularly female figureheads, play a decisive role in modelling behaviour reflective
 of the consequences of attaining education. Therefore, Swahili girls draw cues from
 female figureheads to fuel their motivation for education. Findings are consistent
 with previous research, although this paper highlights modes of intrinsic and extrinsic
 motivation in response to the risk factor of early marriage in the attainment of education.
 More importantly, this paper shows how poverty complicates the proliferation of traditions
 that demotivate the education of Swahili girls. To increase education attainment rates
 amongst the Swahili, this paper suggests an integrated approach to the issue of economic
 and cultural barriers to education, by increasing education access and empowering
 not just the girls, but the community, on the importance of education.

Title: The Role of Gendered Scanning System Policies in Educational Institutions in The UAE
Abstract:
In view of young Emirati students and adults voicing their opinions on Twitter regarding
 the scanning system policy at Zayed University in late 2019, this capstone studies
 the different views towards scanning system policies that track female students' movements.
 Using interview methodology with female and male students/graduates from four universities
 in the United Arab Emirates, this capstone argues that the scanning system policy
 is an example that shows how women are often the midpoint in a paradoxical relationship
 of state development and the safeguarding of societal traditions. Looking beyond the
 state's gender balance and women empowerment initiatives as well as statistics stating
 women are surpassing men in higher education, we find that women face gendered aspects
 in educational institutions, that affect them in various ways including, but not limited
 to their freedom of movement.

Title: Minorities Within a Minority: The Masking and Projecting of Half Emirati's Ethnicities
Abstract:
My project analyzes the notion of purity and its consequences on how the native Emirati
 population and the expat population perceives half Emiratis and how they perceive
 themselves. The experiences of half Emiratis in the UAE interacts in ambivalent ways;
 on the one hand, they are stigmatized and discriminated against by the national population
 because of their perceived impure race and low-status class but also because of a
 restrictive collective notion of national identity that is mandated by the state.
 Though some half Emiratis signal their Emiratiness to avoid this stigma, it is impossible
 for some half Emiratis to disguise their foreign identity because of racial and cultural
 differences such as phenotypical differences, dialect, sexual orientation and other
 lifestyle practices. This stigma resulted in half Emirati's negative prospects on
 marriage and their choice in masking either their Emirati or non-Emirati identity.
 On the other hand, half Emiratis' identities are privileged in the context of the
 workplace because of their perceived linguistic capital but also their positive reputation
 among the expat community which enables them to project their non-Emirati identity
 more to disassociate themselves from the 'lazy' Emirati stereotype.

Title:
Drug Use Among Emiratis in the United Arab Emirates: Stigma, Family, and the Treatment
                                 of Addiction
Abstract:
Drug abuse is a prevalent and ongoing social problem in the United Arab Emirates (UAE).
 Due to the UAE being a patriarchal society with strict cultural values for females,
 there is a tendency to overlook female drug abusers. Despite the gender context, Emirati
 females constitute a large proportion of addiction patients. However, the results
 of this study go beyond this demographic to analyze broader issues within people's
 perceptions of drug use and treatment. While most research on drug abuse in the UAE
 has adopted a medical perspective, my capstone examines the role of family and gender
 norms in producing stigma. This study explores the different perceptions of drug use
 in the UAE by analyzing 14 interviews with medical professionals, 385 online surveys
 collected from the general public, and 7 online surveys collected from former female
 patients. The findings illustrate that both medical professionals and Emiratis agree
 that drug use is taboo in the UAE. The family was found to be the prominent factor
 in my study, as all three populations perceived the family as causing or preventing
 drug use among Emiratis. This study also looks at challenges of awareness and treatment;
 understanding repression, stigma, and confidentiality.

Title:
'It's a Chemical Imbalance!' How Youth Engage in Pervasive Attempts to Destigmatise
                                 Mental Health in Families in the UAE
Abstract:
The mental health impact of COVID-19 has been severe. By engaging with the narratives
 of 28 youth and parents this paper provides insight into how UAE families see mental
 health. It explores how youth and parents engage with their weak and close ties when
 seeking out mental health support. It finds that youth are more likely to seek out
 expert support from weak ties, and mental health awareness often remains unequal at
 the family dimension. To equalise understanding, youth "diffuse'' mental health knowledge
 to their parents, a process which takes place as part of "emotional negotiation".
 Youth motivation to partake in this process include the desire for familial acceptance,
 extrinsic pressures from an imbalanced care economy, and intrinsic aspirations to
 normalise mental health and their experiences. This study fills a lacuna on scholarship
 pertaining to the mental health experiences of families and help-seeking behaviour.
 It reveals that young people who choose to seek help are tasked with relaying these
 learnings back to their parents and normalising their experience. Subsequently, these
 findings show a blind spot in mental health advocacy, with a need to address this
 gaping knowledge gap between youth and parents to ensure a balanced care economy.

Title: Love as Resistance: Women's Identity Negotiations in Hindu-Muslim Marriages
Abstract:
This research project investigates the complex lived realities of Indian women in
 Hindu-Muslim relationships, who live in societies where the marital system is primarily
 based on the stratification of caste and religion. Centering the voices of participants
 from fourteen in-depth, semi-structured interviews, this study explores the processes
 of identity negotiation after marriage. While women generally faced greater expectations
 to negotiate their identity than their male partners due to conceptualizations of
 womanhood and gender inequalities within the institution of marriage, they also strategically
 exercised their agency through identity negotiations to love beyond religious boundaries.
 In a social system that deeply stigmatizes intermarriages, these women's identity
 negotiations are idealized as acts of political subversion and resistance. This study
 also challenges reductive, oppressive narratives of women in Hindu-Muslim relationships
 by focusing on their embodied agencies and the intricacies of their lived experiences.

Title:
Compliance and Policing of COVID-19 Public Health Guidelines by Abu Dhabi and Dubai
                                 Residents
Abstract:
Regulations to individual behavior intended to sustain public health have become the
 norm for cities around the world in the time of COVID-19. However, little is yet known
 about what drives people to adhere to these mandates and to police others who do not,
 especially in UAE cities. We conduct a survey to 1) collect evidence about the predictors
 of compliance and policing behaviors 2) carry out a factorial-vignette experiment
 to test for national-origin biases in reporting decisions. We find that believing
 that one is likely to be fined for breaking the rules increases compliance levels,
 while threat salience of COVID-19 and objective or subjective risk of catching the
 virus exhibit no significant effects. Moreover, perceptions of neighborhood diversity,
 compliance by neighbors, and likelihood of contracting COVID-19 all predict an increase
 in policing tendencies. Finally, our data suggests that UAE residents are more likely
 to call the police on a neighbor with whom they do not share a region of origin. We
 discuss policy ideas to manage the sustainment of public health during the COVID-19
 pandemic and potential future crises, as well as to address discriminatory reporting
 at the neighborhood level.

Title: Goodbye Flood City: Loss and Community Driven Resettlement in Louisiana
Abstract:
This study focuses on a community deeply affected by decades of repeated flooding
 and analyzes how resettlement can be used as an adaptation tool for planned and orderly
 migration to higher ground when environmental displacement is imminent. Through interviews
 with participants in the Pecan Acres resettlement program in Louisiana, this research
 project asks how a community navigates repeated disaster, and how disaster response
 institutions respond to these repeated floods. How do communities become trapped on
 environmentally vulnerable land, and what can be done to break them out? I argue that
 residents understand flooding and resettlement in terms of a cycle of loss. The long-term
 environmental degradation faced by Pecan Acres is not a singular event as studied
 by most of the sociology of loss and disasters thus far. It is instead a long-term
 cycle of loss supported by poverty and political abandonment. Understanding flooding
 in Pecan Acres as a cycle helps to explain the failings of existing disaster response
 mechanisms, and realizing what factors contribute to trapping communities in this
 cycle is crucial to the development of environmental adaptation policy in the future.

Title:
Transcending Through Open Space: High-Skilled Pakistani Women Shaping Transnational
                                 Feminist Discourse in the United Arab Emirates
Abstract:
Over the last couple of decades, the United Arab Emirates has seen a massive influx
 of migratory movements, particularly from the South Asian countries. There continues
 to be growing research done on the phenomenon, and the lived experience of the migrants.
 The existing research focuses strongly on labour migration, particularly that of low
 skilled men. My study aims to broaden the scope of research by accessing a hidden
 population of high-skilled Pakistani working women in the United Arab Emirates (UAE)
 to highlight the ways in which their migration and the following lived experience
 contributes to transnational feminist discourse. Drawing on 21 semi-structured interviews,
 it achieves this by a sociological analysis of the space they feel themselves transcending
 into after migration and directing focus to what it indicates about their agency.
 This paper also contributes to the way such an analysis situates the migration lens
 to better understand Pakistan as a sending country and UAE as a host country for South
 Asian women. It does so by finding that the UAE allows them to practice a journey
 that is transformative yet heavily nuanced within their professional, social and personal
 spheres.

Title: Educator Language Ideologies: Concerning the Romani Language in Slovakia
Abstract:
This paper explores language ideologies that educators in Slovakia hold, with a particular
 focus on the Romani language. Through analysis of quantitative and qualitative data
 collected via a survey, which was distributed to pedagogical staff in six municipalities
 in Slovakia, the paper seeks to answer the following research questions: (1) What
 language beliefs and ideologies do educators hold, particularly in relation to the
 Romani language?; (2) What background factors and characteristics predict educators'
 language beliefs and ideologies?; and (3) How do educators perceive implementation
 of Romani language classes into their school's curriculum (potential or actual)? Through
 exploratory factor analysis, the paper identified six language ideologies, however,
 regression analysis determined only a few statistically significant predictors overall.
 Finally, qualitative analysis of answers to an open-ended question discovered a divide
 in opinions on implementation of Romani language classes: educators who worked at
 schools which offered Romani classes expressed overwhelming support and highlighted
 benefits of the measure, while educators who worked at schools which did not offer
 Romani classes expressed a wide spectrum of opinions and concerns.

Title:
COVID-19 and Climate Change: A Snapshot of Policy Priorities in the United States
                                 and Canada during the COVID-19 Pandemic
Abstract:
COVID-19 has been the largest emerging threat of 2020s. The global pandemic and its
 response have thus far relied upon expert opinion, state intervention, and tackling
 an 'invisible enemy'. Little research has investigated actual global policy preferences
 from a comparative perspective. Using a conjoint survey, the present study saw respondents
 rate policy priorities in terms of urgency and long-term importance, comparing two
 samples (total N = 2229) from a country with high rates of COVID-19 (United States)
 and a country with low rates of COVID-19 (Canada), as well as two snowball samples
 from primarily Oceanian countries. COVID is strongly preferred in terms of urgency
 and importance, regardless of country. The strongest and consistent correlate of this
 preference is political ideology, with greater conservatism decreasing the likelihood
 of prioritizing either COVID-19 or climate change. The author finds that the effect
 of political ideology varies across countries, with stronger negative effects of political
 ideology in the United States.

Title: The Effects Partisan Value Framing and Symbolic Racism on Pro-Environmental Behavior
Abstract:
Environmental degradation continues to pose one of the greatest threats to human well-being,
 posing a disproportionate burden on communities of color. Environmental action, however,
 fails to reflect this urgency, leaving social-behavioral research at the frontier
 of environmental conservation, as well as environmental justice. Broad societal consensus
 for environmental action is particularly sparse among conservatives. The lack of even
 small personal sacrifices in favor of the environment could be attributed to the relatively
 low salience of environmental threats to white Americans and the partisan nature of
 environmentalism in America. We evaluate if (1) environmental action is causally related
 to the partisan value framing of an environmental issue; and (2) if the perceived
 race of impacted communities influences environmental action as a function of racial
 resentment. Using a large-scale, original survey experiment examining the case of
 air-pollution, we found that higher symbolic racism corresponded to lower donations
 to an environmental organization, and aligned value framing increased donations among
 liberals but not among conservatives.

Title:
Are all migrants similarly mobile? The role of pre-migration context for mobility
                                 in the UAE labor market
Abstract:
This project examines the labor market mobility of non-nationals in the UAE using
 a mixed-methods approach. The project comprises of both qualitative data collected
 through interviews with 10 HR professionals in the UAE and quantitative data collected
 through an online survey. Using an experimental approach, in the survey, I test whether
 there are group based differences in job application behavior.

Title:
A Critical Reflection on Ethnography, Documentary and Ethnographic Film: Power, Positionality
                                 and Reflexivity
Abstract:
In this paper, I reflect on the process of developing an ethnographic documentary,
 the ethical dilemmas that came with it, and the larger questions of power, positionality
 and agency that it gave rise to. This paper also centers emotions as a means of tracing
 my internal journey as a student filmmaker and ethnographer, and in doing so, hopes
 to contribute to an expanding dialogue about the importance of ethical reckoning and
 reflexivity in ethnographic and documentary practices. This paper is part of a joint-capstone
 project in Film and New Media (Practice) and Social Research and Public Policy.

Title:
Gender Inequality in University Attainment, Employment, and Earnings in Japan: A Comparison
                                 with the United States
Abstract:
Despite its high levels of development, Japan is yet to achieve gender equality, and
 often scores much lower in measures of gender equality than countries with similar
 levels of development. This paper tackles the question: is Japan exceptional in its
 gender inequality, especially in its university attainment, employment, and wage?
 We conduct a comparative analysis on the US and Japan through regression analyses
 on the data from Luxembourg Income Study. Our analyses reveal that the gender gap
 in university attainment is reversed in both countries, with higher female university
 attainment than their male counterparts, and the US widened the female superiority
 slightly more quickly than Japan. Analyses on employment shows that, contrary to past
 literature, Japan has a smaller gender gap than the US, with US widening the gender
 gap in recent cohort while Japan diminishes the gap. The gender wage gap is larger
 in Japan than the US and its exceptionalism has decreased in the recent cohort.

Title:
The Psychosocial Impacts of Infertility and Mechanisms Used by Ethiopian Women to
                                 Cope with them: A Qualitative Study
Abstract:
Despite the huge prevalence of infertility in the African continent, the experiences
 of African women with infertility remains understudied. Thus, research exploring the
 consequences of infertility and the coping mechanisms used by women to navigate through
 this consequence is crucial in the fields of reproductive and mental public health.
 To this end, this qualitative study investigated the mechanisms used by 10 infertile
 Ethiopian women to cope with mental consequences of infertility- stress and anxiety.
 Using data from a single round of in-depth semistructured interviews with women getting
 treated at AlHikmah Fertility Center, a combination of emotion and problem-focused
 coping strategies are identified. Emotion-based coping mechanisms such as praying
 for strength, meditation and suppressing were used to manage emotions and assert control
 over the situation. Problem-focused coping mechanisms were employed to look for solutions
 through learning about infertility and seeking instrumental social support. The findings
 of this study may assist public health professionals and policymakers to design and
 implement interventions that emphasize holistic health care provision in fertility
 centers. Through holistic healthcare, access to better mental health services and
 enhanced awareness about infertility can be possible. This not only reduces the mental
 impact of infertility but also improves the patients' understanding of it.

Title:
The Role of Trust as a Determinant of Fundraising Success in Nascent Venture Capital
                                 Ecosystems: The Case of the G
Abstract:
This paper seeks to investigate the role of trust as a determinant of fundraising
 success in nascent venture capital ecosystems. Utilising interviews with both VC managers
 as well as investors (LPs), the paper seeks to understand different factors and strategies
 deployed by stakeholders that lead to establishment trust and fundraising success.
 Venture ecosystems such as the G.C.C. are fairly nascent compared to mature VC ecosystems
 such as the United States. Given the dearth of financial returns data on VC funds,
 this paper seeks to investigate the factors that potential investors (LPs) prioritise
 in the absence of returns data in order to assess the trustworthiness of VCs and how
 these factors potentially affect their investment decisions. The paper also examines
 factors that VC managers prioritise while pitching to potential LPs. Utilising interviews
 from both investors as well as managers gives the paper a holistic perspective in
 understanding the trust relations between the two stakeholders. This paper offers
 insights for not just venture practitioners but also entrepreneurs and other observers
 of venture ecosystems in emerging markets.

Title:
Expanding Opportunity in Low-Income Neighborhoods: Effect of the Low-Income Housing
                                 Tax Credit on Neighborhood Gentrification, 1990 to 2010
Abstract:
There is growing concern that subsidized housing only concentrates poverty in low-income
 neighborhoods. This paper analyzes the underexplored causal effect of the Low-Income
 Housing Tax Credit (LIHTC), the largest subsidized housing provider in the U.S., on
 gentrification in low-income urban neighborhoods from 1990 to 2010. Using propensity
 score matching, the paper finds that the average LIHTC-funded neighborhood is substantially
 more likely to gentrify than non-LIHTC-funded neighborhoods and that LIHTC-funded
 development likely contributes directly to this effect. These findings suggest that
 LIHTC-funded development, through the creation of mixed-income housing, attracts higher-income,
 college-educated residents, whose heightened presence could be conducive to a proliferation
 of neighborhood amenities and an increased likelihood of low-income residents attending
 and completing college. In other words, subsidized housing development could be transforming
 low-income neighborhoods from within into spaces of opportunity. Nevertheless, the
 paper considers the classed and racialized nature of gentrification that governs low-income
 residents' access to opportunity in their revitalized neighborhoods. Framing LIHTC-funded
 development as state-supported gentrification, the paper discusses what these findings
 mean for the future of subsidized housing policy and recommends policies to guide
 federal policymakers in ensuring subsidized housing development upholds equity and
 inclusion.

Title:
Hiding among the "Hidden Population" : The Teachers and School Leaders of the Pakistani
                                 Schools in the UAE
Abstract:
The school staff (teachers and school leaders) are considered critical actors in the
 quality of our educational systems. Pakistani schools in the UAE are an example of
 schools with a primarily dominant immigrant student body and relatively low resources
 which rely heavily on the 'hard work' of its educators. However, at the same time,
 very little efforts are made to understand the complex realities of the circumstances
 in which they work. Therefore, through in-depth semi-structured interviews, this study
 uses the narratives and experiences of teachers and school leaders to explore the
 landscape for the school staff in the Pakistani schools of the UAE. In this paper,
 I specifically discuss how the scope conditions of the school imposes 'extra responsibilities'
 to be exhibited by teachers and school administrators. I present these extra responsibilities
 as an overlap between responsibilities that are formally designated to them and those
 that emerge informally. Through this paper, I also seek to disseminate the findings
 of the research to relevant organisations and authorities as an attempt to initiate
 meaningful discourse and support structural improvements

Title: Vote by Mail Policy Adoption in the U
Abstract:
This paper presents an analytical narrative of vote by mail policy changes in Iowa
 and Indiana and utilizes a dataset to contextualize those changes across all 50 states.
 Most fundamentally, this paper aims to answer why Iowa expanded vote by mail in the
 general election in response to the pandemic while Indiana did not. In both states,
 there was a possibility for change: Covid-19 widened the policy window for greater
 access and both states took steps to do so. However, in a key time period between
 the primary and general elections, the influence of national narratives driven by
 elites changed the rules of the game. No longer could vote by mail follow its historically
 nonpartisan logic; instead, it fell into the same calculus of partisan electoral advantage
 that dictates the adoption of most other voting rules. There is a strikingly similar
 process of politicization in both states; differences in outcomes arise from the policy
 feedback of a longstanding policy in Iowa and the barriers and openings created by
 political institutions in both states. This paper adds to the increasingly relevant
 literature on voting rights in the United States and fills a gap with its focus on
 vote by mail.

Title:
How the East and West Report: A Qualitative Study Examining the Relationship Between
                                 Peer Monitoring Tendencies and Culture
Abstract:
Large international companies play a major role in the globalization, specifically,
 by facilitating the migration of skilled labor. As a result of operating in and hiring
 from different markets, these international companies have a diverse workforce that
 is formed by people with various cultural and ethnic backgrounds who come together
 to work towards shared company goals. From an organizational and employee perspective,
 it is important to understand how people monitor each other's performance. Can peer
 monitoring tendencies of individuals be driven by their cultural origins and values?
 This qualitative study explores this question in the context of Western offices of
 large international technology companies. Twenty interviews with a situational vignette
 reveal differences in peer monitoring tendencies between people from Western and Eastern
 cultures: when Eastern employees notice a slacker on their team, it takes them longer
 to report the problem to the manager compared to their Western counterparts. The study
 also reveals that men tend to choose their peer monitoring mechanisms based on different
 contextual conditions while women tend to have an unconditional approach. These findings
 suggest that cultural and gender differences can have implications on individual careers,
 team dynamics and performance monitoring in organizations.

Title:
The "Other Way" of Doing Leadership: Lessons from Women Leaders in Paraguayan Precarious
                                 Settlements
Abstract:
Contemporary Paraguayan female academics and activists have made significant efforts
 to vindicate the myriad contributions of Paraguayan women throughout the country's
 history. They emphasize the role of las disconformes, women who worked for and dreamed
 of an "other way" of doing politics in a country that has been continuously led by
 men. In a machista culture with an ongoing lack of female presence in high leadership
 positions, it is interesting to see that hundreds of women living in precarious settlements
 are occupying the higher leadership positions available in their communities. In addition,
 these women are effectively achieving community organization and improvement. This
 research is a qualitative study about women leaders in precarious settlements from
 the Metropolitan Area of Asuncion, Paraguay. The main goal of this study is to understand
 how the particular characteristics of women leaders in precarious Paraguayan settlements
 are enhancing community organization and improvement. Being a woman, especially a
 woman living in a precarious settlement, has equipped them with "what it takes" to
 organize their communities to achieve essential gains. The stories of these women
 leaders can help us better understand how far we can go as a society if we start giving
 place to women and their "other way" of doing leadership.

Title: Anti-Chinese Sentiment in the United States amid the COVID-19 Pandemic
Abstract:
Anti-Asian sentiment and hate crimes in the United States spiked during the COVID-19
 pandemic, raising awareness and concerns of discrimination and racism towards this
 group of "perpetual foreigners" and foregrounding policy-relevant discussions. Individuals
 with connections to China, the first country that reported clusters of COVID-19 cases,
 are likely to be especially affected. In this paper, we investigate unequal treatment
 towards Chinese-born individuals living in the United States as compared to their
 U.S.-born counterparts using an experimental approach, more specifically with the
 give-or-take dictator game. Relying on a nationally representative sample and two
 survey waves fielded in May and October 2020, the paper contributes to the existing
 literature by examining behavioral evidence of unequal treatment and the associations
 between various COVID-19 related threats and mistreatment. We find evidence of Chinese
 alters receiving worse treatment in the first but not the second wave of data collection.
 Moreover, the investigations on self-reported and community-level exposure to health-related,
 economic, and symbolic threats revealed the impact of political identification on
 the exacerbated unequal treatment of Chinese-born U.S. residents.

Title: Vaccine Diplomacy and Sentiment Improvement: Evidence from Kenya and South Africa
Abstract:
Does vaccine diplomacy work? Do people in Sub-Saharan Africa demonstrate a more positive
 sentiment towards vaccine donor countries when news of their vaccine distribution
 projects is made salient? In this paper, I leveraged Facebook Ads to deploy experimental
 surveys in Kenya and South Africa to examine whether groups exposed to news about
 Chinese and U.S. vaccine availability in their country presented an improvement in
 popular opinion toward the vaccine donors. I show that while information salience
 of Chinese vaccines had a moderate effect on improving political support, no significant
 change was observed among the group treated with information on American vaccines
 in their country. I also discuss the implications of my findings on an effective strategy
 for superpower nations to increase their soft-power presence in the African continent.

Title: Mixed-Gender Interaction and Street Harassment Amongst Emirati Youth
Abstract:
This study highlights the lived experiences and perceptions of Emirati women facing
 street harassment in the UAE, as well as the perception of Emirati men on this issue.
 The reason I focus on Emirati nationals specifically is because they are usually raised
 and spend more time in gender-segregated spaces, and I have also examined the role
 these spaces have on mixed-gender interactions (i.e. friendships, romantic relationships,
 etc.). To do this, I have conducted interviews with young 10 Emirati women and 1 Emirati
 man. This article also investigated the most prominent locations of street harassment
 through carrying out ethnographic field research by visiting locations where street
 harassment is prevalent in the emirate of Abu Dhabi: Marsa Al- Bateen, Qasr Al-Hosn,
 and Al-Hudayriyat Island.

Title:
From Dream to Reality: A Case Study on the Perceptions of Small-Scale Weddings Among
                                 Emirati Youth
Abstract:
This study investigates the transformation of the wedding culture in the United Arab
 Emirates as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic. The aim of this study is to analyze
 the perceptions and attitudes that Emirati youth have towards the changes in the wedding
 culture in the UAE through thirteen semi-structured interviews with Emirati youth
 (ages 18-29), and one semi-structured with a wedding planner based in the UAE. Weddings
 prior to the pandemic were viewed as problematic by Emirati youth because grooms were
 faced with high wedding costs, and brides experienced pressure to plan extravagant
 weddings because of weddings being public social events. The publicness of these wedding
 ceremonies placed more pressure on the bride and groom. The data of this study suggests
 that the emergence of small-scale weddings during the pandemic temporarily met the
 expectations of Emirati youth, and solved the issues associated with weddings prior
 to the pandemic.

Title:
Marital Challenges In the UAE From the Female Perspective: Examining the Effectiveness
                                 of State Initiatives
Abstract:
With the recent alarming rate of early divorce cases between Emirati couples in the
 capital of the UAE, Abu Dhabi, as 62 per cent were predicted to get a divorce during
 the first four years of marriage, the UAE government has provided free marriage counseling
 through its initiatives aimed directly at combating divorce rates. This study examines
 the efficiency of such governmental initiative in addressing and resolving marital
 conflict by first investigating the marital challenges faced by newly married Emirati
 females (married for less than four years), as women were found to make up the majority
 of callers seeking marriage counseling during the pilot study. This study found that
 the challenges amongst the married respondents included conflicting expectations that
 are seemingly informed by the parents' marital model, family interference and combating
 the traditional view of women as housewives. The challenges that caused two respondents
 to seek early divorce further included emotional negligence and miscommunication.
 The government initiative was found to be efficient in regards to maintaining privacy
 and confidentiality but requires improvement in two respects, as it must ensure counselors
 are specialized in the area and it must address the reluctance to seek marriage counseling.

Title: Examining the UAE's Soft Power Strategy: A Case Study of Expo 2020
Abstract:
This paper explores how Expo 2020 will contribute to the United Arab Emirates' soft
 power strategy. The UAE is the first Middle Eastern country to host the World Expo
 in 2020. Soft power plays a vital role in its ability for countries to obtain the
 outcomes they desire through attraction. We hope to discover how this mega-event can
 influence the soft power strategy of the UAE, which includes 6 main diplomacy pillars:
 humanitarian, scientific and academic, national representatives, people, culture and
 media, and economic. Our study is based on surveys conducted on-site at Expo 2020
 for 135 country pavilion representatives. The survey measured the respondents' current
 and future perception of Expo 2020 and its effectiveness at implementing the goals
 put forward by the UAE's Soft Power Council. An ethnography was also administered
 to supplement the insights on the given environment at Expo 2020.
